them.

I a^ counted with them that go down into the pit: I am as a man that has no
strength.
4 By the troubles of my mind, my body is quite wasted, I am a very skelliton,
nothing but skin and bones, as weak as water, no strength left in me, so that
by all symptoms, I am by all that see me, given for a dead man, irrecoverable.

Free among the dead, like the slain that lie in the grave whom thou
rememberest no more: and they are cut off from thy hand.
5 Though I live, yet my soul is as if it were departed, for it administers no
comfortable communion to my body, which is as a corpse laid out for burying, and
I no more to be reckoned amongst the living, but a free-denizon of another
society, of that moietie of mankind which are dead; nor do I die as others, by
a natural death in the ordinary way, and by ordinary means of sickness or
old age, but I languish under a wounded spirit; God as an enraged enemy
thrusts mine heart through as it were with a sharp sword, and sends me by a
violent death down into the grave, where is ended all that care and providence
thou have over us, whilst we are living; there I shall be as it were laid out
of thy sight and forgotten, thy hand of providence which was wont to provide
and care for me, then shall be quite quite of me, and I both untimely and
violently ravished from it, as they that lose their lives by some ireful
judgment, portending thy everlasting displeasure, and disregard as well of
their souls as bodies.

6 Thou, Thou have said me in the lowest pit, in darkness, in the deeps.
Lord, have brought me into such an estate, as I can scare tell how to express
it, or find fit terms to parallel the condition, and dimensions of my misery;
I am as it were shut up under ground, excluded the society of mankind, in an
Abiss void of the suns comfortable light, a very dungeon of darkness; in the
bottom of the bottomless sea, with all the waters a top of me: so extreme
uncomfortable is this my condition, so full of horror and perturbation of
spirit, and so overwhelmed with grief, and withal so remediless.

7 For thou have afflicted me with such a weight of wrath, Thy wrath lies hard
upon me: and thou have afflicted me with all thy waves. Selah.
and so laden me with judgments, that I am even pressed to death; all
comforts are gone and life it self is going after, thou as it were have let in
the sea upon my soul, thy terrors and affrightments come so thick, one in the
neck of another, that they bear down all before them, no hope nor comfort can
stand in their way. My grief is very great.

8 Thou have made me so uncomfortable a companion, Thou have put away mine
a^quaintance far from me: thou have made me an abomination unto them. I am shut
up and I cannot come forth.
that my old friends and acquaintance separate from me, they have abandoned all
society, and converse with me, for indeed, I am like no man, nor fit company
for any, being miserably inclaved in this forlorn comfortless condition, whence
I cannot extricate my self, nor none for me, but am as without comfort, so
without hope and help.

9 I have almost wept my self blind, Mine eye mourns by reason of af^^ition,
Lord, I have called d^lly upon thee, I have stretched our mine hands unto thee.
by reason of the long duration and heavy oppression of this mine affliction:
Lord, thou know with what uncessant prayers and hands lifted up to heaven, I
have importuned thy favor, and mitigation of this my terror.

Will thou show wonders to the dead, shall the dead arise and praise thee?
Selah.
10 Lord, how long shall it be before thy mercy and truth relieve me, if it be
whilst I live, it must not be much longer deferred, if thou have a purpose to
do me good, thou must either do it suddenly before the breath go out of my
body, which truly is expiring, or else miraculously, when I am quite departed,
but that is not likely, it is not thy manner to show mercy to men dead but
living, as yet I am, I expect not to be raised out of my grave, to live again,
after I am dead, to praise thee on earth, no, therefore I hope to do it ere I
die for all this.

Shall thy loving kindness be declared in the grave, or thy faithfulness in
destruction?
11 Thy love and faithfulness will certainly be better manifested and fulfilled
in preservation and deliverance, than in death and destruction, and thy people
can better magnify thee for them living, than dead.

Shall thy wonders be known in the dark? and thy righteousness in the land of
forgetfulness.
12 Is it underground that thou will manifest thy power where none shall see
it, and fulfill thy promise in the gravem when we are in an incapacitie for it?
where nothing is taken notice of, but thy power, grace, and faithfulness will
die, and be buried with us.

But unto thee have I cried, O Lord; and in the morning shall my prayer prevent
thee.
13 But, Lord, as I have not deferred my prayers to the grave, so I hope nor
will thou thine answers, and whilst I live, that the evening of death do not
close up mine eyes, and shut my mouth, I will not cease to importune thee, and
hope to prevent so sad a farewell, by obtaining mercy before I die.

Lord, why castest thou off my soul, why hidest thou thy face from me?
14 Lord, what is the cause of this grievous desertion, and seeming rejection of
my soul? why am I thus benighted, thy face over-clouded, no beam of divine
favor shining into me, nor no spark of renewing grace glowing in me.

15 Lord, I am afflicted and ready to die from my youth up: while I su^fer thy
terrors I am distracted.
thou know, I am sure, I for my part remember well, that ever since I could
remember, I have scarce had a good day, my trials and troubles have been so
grievous, they have brought me I know not how often to deaths door, so tedious
and comfortless a life have I led, being almost always exercised, either under
the present sense or future expectation and fear of their return to my no small
torment and distraction.

16 Lord, Thy fierce wrath goes over me: thy terrors have cut me off.
it is no small matter that I complain of, thou know I have cause, for my
burden is greater than I can bear, or any man alive, that had the feeling of it
as I have: Thy fierce wrath who can stand under it, and yet I am made to bear
it, and to undergo the surges and waves thereof, which are raised like storms
and tempests in my soul ready to overwhelm it, my terrors and perplexities of
mind are such, that they have cut me off of all comfort in my self, and almost
of all hope in thee.

17 They brake in upon me like a fierce torrent, They came round about me daily
like water: they compassed me about together.
daily they do so, I have seldom any ease or quiet, they fill every crannie of
my soul, and so begirt me round, that I can come at no comfort, by no means I
can use, with complicate evils on all sides am I besiedged, so that comfort can
enter in at no door.

18 Mine intimates avoid me, Lover and friend have thou put far from me: and
mine acquaintance into darkness.
and mine old acquaintance will not now know me, I am as a man dead and buried
out of their sight, having no companion but grief and sorrow, not any to make
my moan to besides thy self, or that can or will comfort me.

The lxxxix. PSALM.
Expositours differ upon the occasion of this Psalm, some make it to be in
reference to the salling of the ten tribes from Rehoboam, others to Absalons
rebellion, others to the Babylonish captivity, to which I incline, conceiving
it prophetically to be composed by Ethan for them to use in that estate. It
contains matter of praise to God for his covenant, for his power to make it
good, which he both has done and will do. But expostulates how that captivity
and the matter of that covenant can be reconciled; and puts God in mind of
dangerous inconvenience, that must needs ensue upon breach of covenant, and
abolition of David's Kingdom, as also of the enemies reprochful blasphemies. And
concludes with faithful praises notwithstanding all seeming discouragements.

Psalm lxxxix. Maschil of Ethan, the Ezrahite.
An instruction for the people of God, how to demean themselves in public
calamities and concussions of Church or Commonwealth, by sad complaining,
humble expostulating, and earnest prayer to God; penned by Ethan, one of the
sons of Zerah of the posterity of Judah, famous for his wisdom. 1 Kings 4.31.

I Will sing of the mercies of the Lord for ever: with my mouth will I make
known thy faithfulness to all generations.
1 WHat ever befall, I will be confident of the mercies God has promised, that
they shall be fulfilled, I will set them forth and sing their praises whilst I
live, and leave them upon record to thy Church for ever to do the like: Thy
faithfulness to thy people according to thy promises, I will publish and assert
it to this age, and all that are to come.

For I have said mercy shall be built up for ever: thy faithfulness shall thou
establish in the very heavens.
2 For upon a deliberate well-grounded faith I believe, and therefore do and
dare affirm, and have ever done so in the midst of the greatest concussions
that ever befell us, that mercy shall be built up from one age of the Church to
another, like so many stories, until it come in the end like a building
perfected to its full accomplishment, the Churches perfection in her glorified
condition to all eternity. Thy faithfulness whereupon the promise of mercy
and grace is builded, and whereby it shall be fulfilled, it is engaged and
ratified to thy son, the Churches head in heaven on thy Churches behalf on
earth, therefore sure enough to be accomplished from first to last, both here
and hereafter, as well in heaven as on earth, nothing shall hinder.

3 Even this mercy which thou have declared and stipulated Covenant-wise, I
have made a covenant with my chosen; I have sworn unto David my servant.
and sworn it too (the faster to bind thee and strengthen our faith) to thy
chosen servant, even to David that Kingly type of Christ, and head of thy
people.

4 That thou will establish the Kingdom and Church in David the type, Thy seed
will I establish for ever: and build up thy throne to all generations. Selah.
and his posterity in successive generations, and in Christ the antitype for
ever, and will make his throne glorious, and his dominion to increase and
enlarge it self to all nations and all generations. Even so Amen.

5 According to which Covenant for the fulfilling thereof in the preservation
and deliverance of thy Church, And the heavens shall praise thy wonders, O
Lord: thy faithfulness also in the congregation of the saints.
thou shall manifest such power, and do such wonders as shall affect the very
Angels in heaven, who shall in the sympathy and love they bear to thy people
praise thee, as if themselves shared in the benefit, and in heaven magnify thy
faithfulness as well as we on earth, for keeping promise and remembering thy
Covenant to fulfill it.

6 For as there is none that on earth ought to be adored and magnified but God,
For who in the heaven can be compared unto the Lord? who among the sons of the
mighty can be likened unto the Lord.
so nor in heaven where he alone rules as well as here below, the Angels are
our fellow creatures and subjects, as much inferior to him as we are to them;
Yea, though they are not of humane race, propagated as we are, but by the
immediate hand of God created, as was Adam, yet there is no more comparison
betwixt them and him, than betwixt us and him, he alone is absolute and
Almighty.

God is greatly to be feared in the assembly of the saints: and to be had in
reverence of all them that are about him.
7 As God is great, yea, the sole Monarch of heaven as well as earth, so is he
there greatly had in reverence, and so ought to be of those his holy Angels and
glorified saints, as well as here of his people; they therefore have the honor
to be his servants in ordinary, domestics in heaven with him, that they may
glorify him sutably to their excellent natures and happy condition, it is
their duty, and his due.

O Lord, God of hosts, who is a strong Lord like unto thee? or to thy
faithfulness round about thee.
8 O God, that have the sole Empire in heaven and earth, and the sovereign chief
command of all creatures in both; who therefore is of strength like unto thee?
nay, of any strength at all but thee? from whom all things are, and thou only
eternally of thy self: who then can match thee in power, or in faithfulness
which is equal to thy power, and appears in all things wherein thy power
appears, be they acts of providence or created Beeings, and where is it that
thy power appears not on every side, in heaven or earth, before or behind, on
the right hand or on thy left? and of like extent is thy truth, thy promise
being as large as thy power, and thy goodness as large as both in thy Churches
behalf, for her preservation and accomplishment.

Thou rulest the raging of the sea: when the waves thereof arise, thou stillest
them.
9, 10 What was it but thy power and faithfulness, that when time was, did
dispose and rule the unruly waters of the red sea, for the preservation of thy
Church then ready to be killed or drowned, Thou have broken Rahab in pieces, as
one that is slain, thou have scattered thine enemies with thy strong arm.
by it before, and the Egyptians behind, whom thou as it were at one blow cutst
off and destroyest as one man at once, and did defeat those thine enemies,
because thy Churches, and their great preparations and bloody designs upon thy
people by a mighty manifestation of power, which thou shall ever put forth in
thy Churches behalf, stilling the storms that every where in the world she
shall meet with like a ship at sea, and preserve her, spite of all her enemies,
though never so proud and potent.

11 How can it be otherwise, The heavens are thine, the earth also is thine: as
for the world and the fullness thereof, thou have founded them.
for all is thine and at thy dispose, heaven, earth, and all things in them
both, it is thou that have given existence, and Being to the whole world and
all things in it, both sea and land, as many as they are.

12 Thou have created all things from one end of the heavens to the other, The
North and the South thou have created them: Tabor and Hermon shall rejoice in
thy name.
from pole to pole, thy Church every where from East to West, for so it shall
spread, as Judea from mount Tabor in the West to mount Hermon in the East shall
have cause of rejoicing in thy power, and faithfulness, manifested in her
behalf, and to praise thee for it.

13 Thy strength and power, Thou have a mighty arm, strong is thine hand, and
high is thy right hand.
when as thou please to make use of it, and put it forth either by means or
miracles, in an ordinary or extraordinary way, it is unresistable and
prevalent.

14 As thou have power worthy thy greatness to execute thy will withal,
Justice and judgment are the habitation of thy throne: mercy and truth shall
go before thy face.
so also justice and judgment, mercy and truth, the beauty and establishment
of thrones and dominions, these are principally and originally in thee who
governest and orders thy jurisdiction over the world, respectively to good and
bad, by them dispensing to the unrighteous enemies of thy Church, and thee,
justice and judgment, and unto her, even all thy holy ones, thou will exhibit
merciful providence, and for her fulfill faithfully thy promises, with the
gracious manifestation of thy love and favor to her in all those thy
dispensations.

Blessed is the people that know the joyful sound: they shall walk, O Lord, in
the light of thy countenance.
15 Blessed are thy people above all the world; for they only of all the world
are acquainted with the inward sense, and savorie taste of thy peculiar love and
saving grace, whispered into their consciences by the still voice and secret
workings of the spirit, to the ravishing their hearts with joy unspeakable and
glorious, as thine Israelites are inured to, and cheared with the sound of the
sacred trumpets of God in their solemn feasts and sacrifies. Such shall
comfortably run their race in the whole progress of their lives, they shall
walk in a steady course by a faithful dependancie upon thy faithful providence,
and in sweet interviews of thee, and frequent feelings of thy favor.

In thy name shall they rejoice all the day: and in thy righteousness shall
they be exalted.
16 Such as these shall all their life long have cause of rejoicing in thy
powerful dispensation of providence from time to time in their behalf, and in
thy keeping promise with them, the experience and faith whereof shall lift up
their heads above dangers and difficulties.

For thou art the glory of their strength: and in thy favor our horn shall be
exalted.
17 For their glorying is in thee, who though weak in themselves, yet are as it
were omnipotent by their interest in thee and relation to thee that art so, by
whose power and gracious favor, we that are thy people Israel, resemblancers
of thy Church, doubt not of a prosperous state both civil and sacred, and to
have the better of our enemies.

For the Lord is our defense: and the holy one of Israel is our King.
18 For the great and faithful God is our defense and protection, his power and
goodness shall preserve us as a shield, the holy Lord that has chosen Israel
to be a holy people, and that shall ever have on earth a holy Church, is the
Sovereign Lord and protector of us and it, and so shall Christ his vicegerent
be, and David his.

Then thou spa^est in vision unto thy holy one, and said, I have laid help
upon one that is mighty: I have exalted one chosen out of the people.
19 Thou, Lord, in thine own appointed time did make known thy mind by special
revelation to thy holy prophet Samuel, that thou had ordained one to be a
singular type of Christ, to give deliverance and yield protection to thy people
against their enemies, over whom thou would make him victorious, who should
be chosen from amongst his brethren by thee, above and before all others, to be
exalted from a mean condition to be King and ruler over them, as Christ in our
nature shall be exalted from the Cross to the Crown, and Empire of his Church.

20 I the Lord, I have found David my servant: with my holy oil have I anointed
him.
have by especial appointment set apart David, he is the man, and caused Samuel
to go seek and find him out in the obscure condition and place where he lived,
and from amongst all his brethren, more likely men than He, in Samuels own
eyes, to take and anoint him with oil I bid him take with him for that purpose,
to that Kingly office and typical dignity over my people.

21 I will set the Crown upon his head, With whom my hand shall be established:
mine arm also shall strengthen him.
my power shall protect him, and carry him through all oppositions, and maugre
all his enemies he shall be King, and the Kingdom established upon him, by my
might shall he overcome all his adversaries, both before and after his
inthronization.

22 Enemies he shall have good store, The enemy shall not exact upon him: nor
the son of wickedness afflict him.
but they shall never have their will of him, he shall make them tributarie,
but so shall not they him, nor shall any wicked malicious opposer of his be
able to suppress him, but he shall prevail to be King, and to flourish in his
Kingdom, spite of all gainsayers.

23 I will make it appear, And I will beat down his foes before his face: and
plague them that hate him.
how much I love him by the great things I will do for him, no enemy shall be
able to stand before him, all his foes secret, and open, that oppose or stand
in the way of his advancement, I will lay them low enough, yea, they that do
but in their hearts malign him, though they do not openly oppose him, shall
smart for it.

But my faithfulness and my mercy shall be with him: and in my name shall his
horn be exalted.
24 But as for him I will make good all I have promised, his sins and
infirmities shall not hinder me, for though I may punish them, yet will I have
a merciful respect and consideration of him, from first to last shall my grace
and truth be steadfast with him, as it shall be with my Church to the end, and
by my might and power shall he and his Kingdom flourish with great glory.

I will set his hand also in the sea, and his right hand in the rivers.
25 And be extended far and near, from the red sea to the river Euphrates, his
dominion shall be enlarged without the limits of the land of Canaan very far
several ways.

He shall cry unto me, Thou art my Father: my God, and the rock of my
salvation.
26 As a dear child and only son, as is the Messiah, so shall he be unto me,
and as a tender Father so will I be to him, and such shall he acknowledge me by
the experience he shall have of my love and care, and by the great deliverances
and victories that I will give him, and as to his only God and Savior shall
he make his applications to me.

Also I will make him my first born: higher than the Kings o^ the earth.
27 As my son the Messiah is the first born of every creature, and in all things
has the pre-eminence, so shall my servant David that figures him be advanced
to the honor of being the highest Prince on earth, blessed and accepted by me
far beyond them all.

My mercy will I keep for him for evermore: and my covenant shall stand fast
with him.
28 My mercy and truth shall be sure to keep touch with him, I will never forget
to be gracious, though I may seem severe; I will not fail of what I have
promised him, but as in grace I made my covenant, so in mercy and
faithfulness, I will make it good, nothing shall hinder.

His s^ed also will I make to endure for ever: and his throne as the days of
heaven.
29 His posterity shall continue and possess the throne till they transmit it
to the Messiah, in whom it shall be eternized, and in those that shall be
begotten to God by the sanctification of the spirit, the blessed offspring of
Christ the son of David, every of which shall reign as Kings, both on earth and
in heaven, for evermore in grace and glory.

30, 31 If his children and childrens children that succeed him in the throne
rule not righteously, If his children forsake my Law, and walk not in my
judgments.
nor order their conversation aright, If they break my statutes, and keep not
in my judgments.
but sin against me, and keep not my commandments.

32 Then will I, Then will I visit their transgression with the rod, and their
iniquity with stripes.
as well as I loved their Father David, and them for his sake, be sure to let
them know I am sensible of their sins, by making them sensible of my
corrections, neither their impiety nor injustice shall go unpunished.

33, 34 Nevertheless, Nevertheless, my loving kindness will I not utterly take
from him: nor suffer my faithfulness to fail.
I will not quite cast off the sinner for his sin, because of David my servant,
but will remember my love to him and covenant with him, so that I will pardon
as well as punish, My covenant will I not break: nor alter the thing that is
gone out of my lips.
and be faithful as well as just, they shall not frustrate my covenant, no not
by their sins, because it was of grace, no more than shall mine elect
regenerate people for my sons sake; with whom I have covenanted, and for whose
sake I will perform it to his seed and mine adopted ones, throughout all
generations.

35 I have once for all irrevocably bound my self by as deep an oath as I know
how to take; Once have I sworn by mine Holiness, that I will not lie unto David.
even by the most sacred attribute and property that is in all my divine
nature, that gives a verdure to all the rest, mine Holiness, which is indeed my
whole self, the greatest pledge I can lay to stake, the resemblance whereof my
sanctuary you have amongst you, that I will for no cause whatsoever falsify
with David, nor fail of what I promised.

His seed shall endure for ever; and his throne as the sun before me
36 That his seed Christ, the son of David, and the faithful that are begotten
by the incorruptible seed of the word, shall last as long as time lasts. He
shall reign in and over his Church by special commission and favor, as my
vicegerent and fellow in Government, as long as the sun abides in the
firmament, till all things be no more, and he give up the Kingdom into the
Fathers hands.

It shall be established for ever as the Moon, and as a faithful witness in
heaven. Selah.
37 Till then it shall be established, even so long as Sun and Moon endures,
those never-failing witnesses of my grace and providence as a faithful creator
to the children of men, for all their iniquities, notwithstanding which, these
have afforded their light and influence from the very beginning, both to the
just and unjust, shall do to the end. As the sins of the wicked, because my
grace super-abounded, has not annihilated these mercies of mankind, so, nor
shall the sins of the Godly, the sons of Christ, the son of David, make void my
Covenant of grace peculiar to my son and his seed, figured by David and his
posterity, no not for ever.

But thou have cast off and abhorred: thou have been wroth with thine anointed.
38 But, Lord, what consonancie is there betwixt this thy Covenant with David,
and the state of the Kingdom as now it stands, instead of loving kindness,
establishment, and mercy, here is nothing but utter dereliction and rejection
of his posterity and people with abhorrencie; How could thou well be angrier
with the seed of thine anointed servant than thou art, to whom for his sake thy
covenant reaches, and is to be fulfilled.

Thou have made void the covenant of thy servant: thou have profaned his crown,
by casting it to the ground.
39 Truly, Lord, to the eye of sense and natural reason, thou have broken all
the ties that were upon thee, oath, promise, faithfulness, holiness, covenant,
which seems to be quite made void, even that thou made with thy servant David
concerning the establishment of his throne and dignity upon him and his
posterity for ever. For thou have suffered as much despite to be done to that
royal diadem, as the profane ignorant Idolatrous heathen can devise to do, by
captivating King and Kingdom, contemptibly subjugated and transplanted into
another nation far remote, where they are made bon dmen, even the people and
posterity of David, his throne is thus abased of whom thou said. The enemy
shall not exact, nor the son of wickedness afflict him.

40 Instead of protection thou have brought upon it utter devastation, Thou
have broken down all his hedges: thou have brought his strong holds to ruin.
thou have quite ruinated all the strength of the Kingdom defensive and
offensive, and made the enemy absolute there.

41 He is brought to so forlorn a condition, All that pass by the way spoil
him, he is a reproach to his neighbors.
that the whole Kingdom, country, cities, people, goods, every thing are preid
upon and spoiled at pleasure by all that will, houses, gardens, vine-yards, all
the whole land is a very through-fare for all comers and goers, that take and
leave as they list themselves, there is no body nor nothing to resist them.
Those Idolatrous profane people the Ammonites, Moabites, etc. that border
about us, whom thou saidest should be under him, are got above him, and most
insultingly reproach him upon this occasion, and deridingly ask if this be the
King whose throne shall endure so long as the Sun and Moon, which extremely
reflects upon the Messiah himself, and calls in question thy covenant as to him.

42 Thou have given strength, Thou have set up the right hand of his
adversary: thou have made all his enemies to rejoice.
courage, and success to his enemies, and made them triumphant over him.

Thou have also turned the edge of his sword: and have not made him to stand in
the battle.
43 On the contrary, thou have weakened his power, made ineffectual all his
endeavors, and turned the courage wherewith he was wont to be endowed into
cowardice, and made him to fly before the enemy, who was wont to fly before
him.

Thou have made his glory to cease; and cast his throne down to the ground.
44 Thou have put an end to that honor and dignity, which thou said, nay
swearest should continue for ever, his throne which thou covenantest to
establish is utterly demolished, he is laid level with the common people, nay a
very bondsman in captivity.

The days of his youth have thou shortened: thou have covered him with sham^.
Selah.
45 Instead of estating him and his Kingdom in everlasting happiness, thou have
brought sudden and speedy desolation, it is true some few days of glory and
felicity he has seen, but they soon have an end, nay a shameful end. Lord
this is true.

How long, Lord, will thou hide thy self for ever? shall thy wrath burn like
fire?
46 Lord, instead of being everlastingly gracious, will thou be everlastingly
displeased, shall we never partake of favor and grace again, art thou utterly
estranged, and we utterly rejected? shall we be quite consumed in thine anger,
without any mixture of mercy, or mitigation of thy wrath?

Remember how short my time is: wherefore have thou made all men in vain?
47, 48 Lord, consider the shortness and vanity of my life, and by me judge of
all other men, that by course of nature are as I am short-lived, and sure to
die. What man is he that lives and shall not see death? shall he deliver his
soul from the hand of the grave. Selah.
Now then if thou thus breakest covenant, casts off thy people, nullifies thy
Church, and hereby overthrows all possibility of the Messiah and his Kingdom,
what a vain thing must it needs be for thee to have made man, if all the
happiness he shall have, is but to live a few days on earth and so die, or if
that be all the honor and service thou art like to have of him, and truly,
Lord, if thy Church and covenant be null, that is all can come on it, for none
shall be saved but thy people, and no people are so but by Covenant, if then
the one be not, and so the other be frustrate, we are all reduced into the
sinful mass of mankind, at best to live miserably and die wretchedly. This will
be the issue.

49 Lord, Lord, where are thy former loving kindnesses, which thou swarest unto
David in thy truth?
thou do infinitely amaze us, to consider what loving kindness thou have
heretofore covenanted to show to David and his seed for ever, and ratified it
with a deep and solemn Oath, obliging thee in thine infinite truth and
faithfulness to fulfill it: we are at a stand to think on this, and withal how
this thy word, and these thy works are consistent and reconcilable.

50 Lord, Remember (Lord) the reproach of thy servant: how I do bear in my bosom
the reproach of all the mighty people.
for all this, make it appear thou can keep Covenant, and preserve thy Church
and people as low as they be brought, and that thou may be moved hereunto;
Remember and take notice of the reprochful contumelious usage, thy servants
have at their enemies hands for thy sake, more than their own, and to thy
dishonor more than theirs. Weigh well to what an ebb of fortune we are fallen,
when subjugated and captivated under the insolentest and mightiest nation upon
earth, whose reprochful insufferable abuse of thy people they are forced to put
up, and with infinite patience to dissemble their grief, which goes to my heart
to think of, and am as sensible of it as if I bare the whole burden on my own
back.

51 Even those blasphemous reprochful taunts which those victorious heathen,
Wherewith thine enemies have reproched, O Lord: wherewith they have reproched
the footsteps of thine anointed.
enemies to thee, and for thy sake to thy people, do cast upon their hope in
thy promises, and their faithful expectation of the coming and near approach of
the Messiah their King thine anointed, now in this their so low, miserable, and
irrecoverable estate.

Blessed be the Lord for evermore. Amen and Amen.
52 But how ever it be, neither our misery, the enemies insolency, thy
severitie and seeming perfidie, nor our amazements upon all these shall
eradicate the faith, and hope mine heart has in thee and thy covenant, nor
stop my mouth from praising thee for it, but that I do affirm thee holy,
faithful, and gracious for all these, even to David, to whom thou will make
good all that ever thou have promised, yea, to the end of the World shall his
Kingdom last. The Messiah for all this shall come, whose shall be the Kingdom,
power, and glory for evermore. And in the faith hereof I do bless thee now, as
if it were, and pronounce thee worthy of blessing, praise, and thanksgiving
throughout all ages of the World, so long as Sun and Moon endures, so be it,
yea, Lord, dispose the hearts of thy people to believe that so it shall be,
that in the hope thereof we may praise thee, and in the happy enjoyment
thereof all ages hereafter may do so too.

The xc. PSALM.
This prayer of Moses in likelihood was made by him, some time before his
death, betwixt the Israelites, being inhabited Canaan, because of their
murmuring and misbelief, when the spies brought an evil report upon the land,
in that long peregrination of theirs in the wilderness, and the time they
entered it: wherein he first mentions the continual care that he the
everlasting God has had over them, in all their travels and sojournings, and
next the often afflictions and destructions, to which their sins and his
displeasure brought them, and the great deliverances he has afforded them, as
it were a resurrection from the dead. Then declares how its worse with them his
people than the rest of mankind, for though all must, and do perish by frailty
and casualty, yet his wrath is upon none so sore as them, they perish by that
more than th^se. All life is short and all old age wearisome, but their
shortest and wearisomest of any, he prays that a good use may be made both of
the natural and supernatural brevity of their lives, and that God would after
so long estrangement be gracious to them, and make good his promise touching
the promised land, and their happy condition therein.

A Psalm being a Prayer made by Moses, Psalm xc. A Prayer of Moses the man of
God.
that extraordinary servant and Prophet of the Lord.

1 LOrd, LOrd, thou have been our dwelling place in all generations.
ever since we were thy people, even from Abraham and so downward, successively
we have wandered and sojourned as strangers in one place after another by thy
appointment and providence, who have still gone along with us, provided for us,
and been a harbor, shelter, and protection to us in all places, and throughout
all ages to this day, as thou will be to thy Church to the end of the world.

2 There is no God besides thee who art eternal, Before the mountains were
brought forth, or ever thou had formed the earth and the world: even from
everlasting to everlasting thou art God.
the Creator of all things, for before the huge mountains, which seem to have
had no beginning, but to have been from everlasting, yet before them thou had
thy being when they had none, nor no appearance of any, both which thou
causedst, providing the Abyss and huge concave of the sea to receive the
waters, which till then overflowed their highest tops, yea, before the earth
both sea and land, and heavens too had any existence, thou, Lord, had thine,
and formedst them as now they are. Before the world was, thou wast, for else it
had not been; yea, before time was, even from everlasting thou wast God, and so
shall be to everlasting, even when time and all this world shall have an end,
and thy peoples God from their everlasting predestination, to their everlasting
glorification.

3 Living and dead, Thou turnest man to destruction: and say, return ye
children of men.
man's sin and frailty, thy power and mercy appears; For thou often bring him
to the point of ruin, and yet pronounces a reprieve and lengthenest his life
as we well know, that else would soon expire under thy hand, when thou laiest
it upon him, and when death it self has swallowed him, thou by thine Almighty
power shall command the grave to give up her dead, after she has long detained
them, and make all mankind at last to live again at the resurrection, whereof
we have been a figure.

For a thousand years in thy sight are but as yesterday when it is past, and as
a watch in the night.
4 For, however we judge and measure things by time being subject to futurity,
and so think a little a great deal, and that which is short to be long, but to
thee who comprehends Eternity, and before whose eyes all things past and to
come are present, a thousand years are nothing, they are as it were at an end
so soon as begun, what time past is to us, such time to come is with thee, an
hour, day, year, age, are all alike, even all the time we lie in the grave,
though a thousand years, which to our thoughts seems a kind of Eternity, it is
to thee but as a piece of a night, a few hours, the watch of one Centry.

Thou carriest them away as with a flood, they are as a sleep: in the morning
they are like grass which grows up.
5, 6 Lord, how in thy displeasure do thou sweep away the sinful sons of
men, what examples of it have we seen both amongst our enemies and our selves,
In the morning it flourishes, and grows up, in the evening it is cut down
and withers.
like an overflowing torrent that bears down all before it, so vain a thing is
man, and so frail a thing his life, as transient or momentary as a sleep or
dream, as short-lived as grass. In the youthful part of their time, which is
as it were the morning of their age, they are strong and busy for a while,
like unto grass which in the morning of the day is green and flourishing, and
before night is mowed down and withered, so short and uncertain is the life of
man.

7 We of all men have experience of it, For we are consumed by thine anger, and
by thy wrath are we troubled.
that have so often and so many of us perished in thy displeasure, and by
terrible judgments been strangely and suddenly slain to the amazement and
terror of the rest.

8 For our sins and provocations, Thou have set our iniquities before thee, our
secret sins in the light of thy countenance.
as such times as thou have been pleased to take notice of them, and to reckon
with us for them, which thou have done very severely, even those sins which
we had thought thou had scarce taken notice of, the murmurings and secret
misbelief of our hearts, these thou have clearly seen, and we have felt as
much, thy grace and favor being be-clouded toward us by their interposition.

9 Insomuch as we that had a flourishing time of it, For all our days are
passed away in thy wrath: we spend our years as a tale that is told.
when first we came out of Egypt, having the light of thy countenance shining
sweetly upon us for some season, are now in a quite other condition, and for a
many years have wandered and wasted away in thy displeasure, our carcases
falling in the wilderness, vainly and unprofitably exhausting our time, living
uselesly, and dying regardlesly.

10 The ordinary rate of man's life is seventy years, The days of our years are
threescore years and ten; and if by reason of strength, they be fourscore
years, yet is their strength labor and sorrow: for it is soon cut off, and we
fly away.
and if by special blessing or bitterness of constitution, any surmount that
number, and attain to fourscore, yet by reason of the infirmities incident to
old age, that surplusage of time is of little or no content saving that they
live, so accompanied is that remainder of their life with pains and irksomness
(such as we have had our shares of in this time of thy disfavour) for their
strength then is not vigorous, merely yields subsistence and being, but no
well-being, and that very being so frail and feeble, that almost any thing
serves to annihilate it, so uncertain and transient is our life always,
especially then at that decrepit age, that we are gone in a moment.

Who knows the power of thine anger? even according to thy fear, so is thy
wrath.
11 We have had experience of thine anger and thy power to execute it, though in
a remiss degree, what infinite numbers of us momentany short-lived creatures
have untimely perished by it? and not reached that proportion of years, which
our infirm natures might else have attained unto, and yet have thou been
merciful to us too, considering how able thou wast to have cut us all off at a
blow, for it can neither be expressed nor conceived, how Almighty thou art to
vindicate thy dishonor upon such sinners as we have been, if thou would have
stirred up all thy wrath, and put forth thy power to the uttermost, but this
terror of thine is hid from most men's eyes, the world has not the faith of
it, because they have not the fear of thee, only thine own people, nor they
neither, saving such of them as thou have by an inward call begotten to thee,
and made to fear thee, have any right understanding of the greatness of it,
they that filially fear thee, which is the true knowledge of thee, do only
tremblingly reverence thine irefulness.

So teach us to number our days, that we may apply our hearts unto wisdom.
12 Naturally we know nothing, neither the power of thine anger, nor our own
brevity of life and imbecility of nature, thou must teach us not only what
concerns thee, but what concerns our selves also, doctrine will not do it, it
is thou that must be our teacher, else we shall never learn practically and
profitably to know we are mortal. Lord, therefore pity our stupidity,
teaches us even what we know already; for common truths that are of greatest
use, though they be most known, yet they are oft-times least understood; for we
live as if we should never die, though we know nothing is more sure, nor more
uncertain than death, such fools are we and void of true wisdom till thou
inspire us with it: make us then so to know the momentanies of our loves, as
thereby to be instigated to make it our first and chiefest care to seek and
secure to our selves a blessed eternity after them, especially we that are
under thy heavy displeasure, and consumed by it day by day; let the loss of
this earthly, incite us to look after a heavenly Canaan.

13 O Lord, Return (O Lord) how long? and let it repent thee concerning thy
servants.
call to mind that ancient love, wherewith thou lovedst our forefathers, and
those many acts of grace, which we their children have participated from thee
formerly, to persuade with thee, to reassume that temper toward us, and to be
again gracious to us. We, Lord, think it long till we be received into favor
again, do thou think so too we humbly pray thee, and put an end to this thy
displeasure, that has so long lain heavy upon us. Yea, let what thou have
already done seem too much, at least, Lord, do no more so, but cease to destroy
us, and take us into grace again, whom thou have honored above all the world,
with the title of thy people and servants.

14 O satisfy our longing desires after mercy, O satisfy us early with thy
mercy; that we may rejoice, and be glad all our days.
and do it betime, whilst some of us are yet left alive, before the sun be set
upon us all; Lord, spare that remnant that are not yet consumed, and let us see
some token for good, that may again revive us, and persuade us of thy
reconciled favor toward us, which would make us quite forget all our sorrow
passed, for the joy we should conceive thereat, and be happy men for time to
come.

Make us glad according to the days wherein thou have afflicted us, and the
years wherein we have seen evil.
15 Lord, let thy mercies hold some proportion with thy judgments, especially
toward us thy people, against whom, though thou have denounced some threats,
yet have thou made us many more promises, therefore call to mind the number,
nature, and long continuance of our afflictions both in Egypt, and since we
came thence, especially this long peregrination of ours, ever since thou
swarest we should not enter into thy rest, now at last to have some
commiseration, and another while to let us taste of mercy, as we have done of
misery, and to have a surviving joy to succeed our long-lived sorrow.

Let thy work appear unto thy servants, and thy glory unto their children.
16 Lord, thou have engaged thy self in a great undertaking, even to give this
thy people the land of Canaan in full possession and dominion, some progress
its true thou have made toward it, by our deliverance out of Egypt, and
conduct through the wilderness to the skirts thereof, but the complement of it
we would fain see, which we had seen ere this but for our own default, which we
pray thee at last obliterate, and make good thy promise of possession in our
sight and time, and of that glorious state and condition, which shall be to thy
Church and Kingdom in succeeding ages, let after-generations see it in its full
splendor.

And let the beauty of the Lord our God be upon us: and establish thou the
works of our hands upon us, yea, the wo^k of our hands establish thou it.
17 And let the blessing and favor of the Almighty and our good God, be with
his people for ever, to make them beautiful and glorious in the eyes of all
nations, who in the absence thereof, are the abject despondent people living.
And make succesfull all their great undertakings in enterprising Canaan,
driving out and destroying those many Kings and great people, the enlarging
their borders and dominion into remote countries, and building of the Temple;
whatsoever, Lord, thou have promised to do for them, give them hearts
faithfully to believe it, and in the faith thereof courageously to undertake
it, and indefatigably to persist in it, and succesfully to prosper in all
things unto an establishment in a full fruition, absolute dominion, and
glorious condition of Church and Kingdom.

The xci. PSALM.
The Psalmist prophetically declares Gods great care for the welfare of the
faithful, commends it by his own testimony and example, and therefore exhorts
them to walk with a holy carelessness in midst of dangers upon assurance of his
de^ence. Brings in God himself, promising to the faithful deliverance
temporal, and salvation eternal. Psalm xci.


1 HE that by faith is firmly fixed upon God, HE that dwells in the secret
place of the most high, shall abide under the shadow of the Almighty.
making him his never-failing refuge, and wholly confiding in his sure though
invisible protection, at all essays shall be as secure and safely preserved,
as the Almighty power of God can tell how to protect him, which he need neither
fear nor doubt of.

2 I believe, I will say of the Lord, he is my re^uge, and my fortress: my God
in him will I trust.
and therefore I will and dare with boldness affirm as much of the Lord by mine
own experience of him, as I recommend unto others to make trial of, how that
he is the only refuge and fortress, even this my God that I have ever in all
straits and concussions fled unto, and never found him falsify his word or
fail my trust, therefore I both have and will trust in him, and rely upon him
and him only, fall back fall edge.

Surely he shall deliver thee from the sn^re of the fowler: an^ from the noysom
pestilence.
3 Let me and mine example persuade with thee to do so too, surely thou shall
not repent thee, but find the happy fruits of it, in his gracious and powerful
preservation of thee, neither men nor devils, by power or policy, shall be able
to do thee any hurt, they may endanger thee, but thine extremity shall be his
opportunity; no nothing, though in its own nature never so destructive and
inavoidable, the plague it self, that uncomfortable all-devouring disease,
shall not annoy thee.

He shall cover thee with his feathers, and under his wings shall thou trust:
his trust shall be thy shield and buckler.
4 He shall take care of thee, and by his Almighty power secure thee from
danger, as a Hen does her Chickins, wherein the more thou trusts the more thou
may, such experience shall thou have of him and of his faithfulness; cast but
thy care on him and trust firmly in him, and thou shall find him true of his
word, and true to thy trust, and thy self better safeguarded by thy faith in
his faithfulness, than by any humane helps, or warlike accommodations
whatsoever.

Thou shall not be afraid for the terror by night; nor for the arrow that
flies by day.
5 Thou shall therein apprehend such safety, and thy mind find such recumbency
as that nothing shall disquiet thy peace, no time, place, person, nor thing
shall be cause of fear to thee, for day and night shall thou have sweet repose
in his protection, both against natural evils, and supernatural extraordinary
judgments, which as they come immediately from him, so are they ordered by
him, how mortal and sudden soever they seem to be.

6 Thou shall be antidoted, Nor for the pestilence that walks ie darkness:
nor for the destruction that wastes at noonday.
and fearless of the plague of pestilence that infecteth secretly, and
spreads here and there uncertainly and insensibly, and where it rages leaves
sad spectacles of natures frailty, sinners mortality, and Gods heavy
displeasure, to be seen and lamented by all in all places, in streets and
houses frequently and openly, dying night and day.

7 And though by Gods just judgment and secret dispensation, A thousand shall
fall at thy side, and ten thousand at thy right hand: but it shall not come
nigh thee.
men die and fall as thick as hail round about thee by the pestilence, which of
it self knows no difference, nor makes none, betwixt one man and another, whose
natures are alike mortal, and their constitutions alike apt to infection, yet
shall God whose judgment it is, and whose will it performs, so order and
dispose the dispensation of it, that thou shall be as it were shot-free, when
thousands, and ten thousands drop dead at thy feet.

8 Thou in thine own person shall feel no harm, Only with thine eyes shall
thou behold: and see the reward of the wicked.
thou shall only be a spectatour of other men's destruction, and Gods judgment
executed upon sinners, by sudden and untimely death, overtaking many thousands
that misimploied their lifetime, living in sin and impenitency, and would have
continued so.

9 Because thou have done as I do, Because thou have made the Lord which is my
refuge, even the most high, thy habitation.
thou shall speed as I have sped; for God his promise and performance shall be
one and the same to all believers, and therefore as I made him my refuge, and
so he was, so thou doing the like, he shall be the like, even the Almighty God
from heaven, shall safeguard thee as well as me, if thou take sanctuary in him.

There shall no evil befall thee, neither shall any plague come nigh thy
dwelling.
10 So doing, thou shall be like Israel in Egypt, when the first born were
smitten, how ever it happen to others, thy faith shall secure thee, yea, both
thee and thine, even from commonest judgments.

For he shall give his Angel^ charge over thee: to keep thee in all thy ways.
11 For all the powers of heaven shall be imploid to preserve thee if there be
need; besides both the ordinary and extraordinary providence of God, he shall
double his guard upon thee, yea, not one but many, nor many, but all the Angels
of heaven shall stand charged with thee, if there be cause to protect thee,
from miscarriage by any power or accidents on earth, whilst thou walk in
ways pleasing to God, and believe steadfastly in him.

They shall bear thee up in their hands: least thou dash thy foot against a
stone.
12 For as the faithful have many and great enemies, so have they many more and
greater friends; If Satan and his Angels lay stumbling blocks in thy way, God
and his Angels shall either remove them, that is, enable thee to keep on thy
course without making a stand or turning back, thou shall either not stumble,
or so as not to fall, thou shall catch no hurt though thou may be endangered.

Thou shall tread upon the lion, and adder: the young lion and the dragon shall
thou trample under feet.
13 Manifold dangers and fierce enemies, men and devils the faithful shall meet
with, secret plotters and open assailers, but neither the one nor the other
shall do them any hurt, but instead thereof both they and their attempts shall
miscarry; Gods faithful people shall take no hurt by the most hurtful
creatures, be they never so poisonous or ravenous, nor by men of like
dispositions, to whom the godly are great eyesores, living amongst them they
are a trouble and vexation to them, against whom they act their rage and malice
but to their own destruction.

Because he has set his love upon me, therefore will I deliver him: I will set
him on high, because he has known my name.
14 Besides my doctrine and example, hear God himself bespeaking thee with
promises as from his own mouth, whom I his Prophet personate. Because (says
he) he that is faithful, has out of love to me and my faithfulness put his
affiance in me, he shall have no cause to repent him, I will not deceive him,
he shall not miscarry, I will deliver him out of trouble and danger, set him
quite out of gunshot, they shall as soon hurt heaven as him, because out of a
right understanding and belief of my power and faithfulness, he has honored
me by believing in me, with suitable recumbency.

15 Such an one shall but ask and have, He shall call upon me and I will answer
him: I will be with him in trouble, I will deliver him, and honor him.
if he be in trouble I will have an eye to him, and an ear for him, if he call
for deliverance it shall come at his call, I will deliver him, and in such a
manner, as that because he honors me, I also will honor him with special
marks of my favor, such as his very enemies men or devils shall honor or envy
him for, here on earth, and reward him with glory in heaven.

16 Thus will I preserve and lengthen his life to his own desire, With long
life will I satisfy him, and show him my salvation.
maugre all that would shorten it, he shall know I can and will save him if he
trust in me, yea, my everlasting salvation more worth than my temporal will I
open his eyes to see, and desire above it, and if he believe me for it, he
shall be sure of it, and he that has the comfort and assurance of that by my
spirits ascertaining it unto him, will have no cause to think I break faith
with him, or deceive his faith in me, whatever happen.

The xcii. PSALM.
The Psalmist for the better sanctifying of the Sabbath, having penned this
Psalm, shows the proper and adequate service of that day, is to praise the Lord
for his manifestations of himself, and thank him for his gracious and
beneficial administrations to his people, richly declared in his works of
creation, redemption, providence, and just judgments; all which are nothing in
the eyes of worldlings, that mind the creature and not the Creator, but how
ever they neglect God, yet be neglects not to punish them and bless his people,
who by him and in him shall be happy here and hereafter.

Psalm cxii. A Psalm or song for the Sabbath Day.
A Psalm to be both sung and played by voices and instruments, principally of
use upon the Sabbath Day, for its better celebrating and the peoples edifying,
when then they are solemnly assembled to serve the Lord.

IT is a good thing to give thanks unto the Lord: and to sing praises unto thy
name, O most high.
1 IT is an acceptable service to God, and a commendable imploiment for his
people to be much conversant, specially on the Sabbath Day, in the meditation
and recollection of all the benefits of what nature soever, which God has and
does bestow upon us, whether of creation, providence, or redemption; and to
have our hearts affected and enflamed with them, so as to be exceeding
thankful for them: And to view and consider his power, goodness, and mercy
manifested and exhibited in them, so as to be moved thereby with reverence,
love, and admiration, devoutly and solemnly to worship before him, and to
celebrate his glory and praise, as the great and only God worthy of honor.

To show forth thy lovingkindness in the morning: and thy faithfulness every
night.
2 Our duty is to take continual notice of thy continued and renewed benefits,
and always to have our hearts upheld thereby in a sweet gratuitous frame and
temper, with the eye of faith piercing into the love and faithfulness,
answerable to his grace and promises, which shine forth in them, that should
take us more than the things themselves, and cause our thanksgivings far beyond
them.

3 Which cannot be too solemnly celebrated, Upon an instrument of ten strings,
and upon the Psaltery; upon the harp with a solemn ^ound.
all the music of the Temple is too little to do it, therefore lay out your
utmost strength and skill you that are especially appointed to that honor and
service, and gifted for it, resembling the heavenly Quire, raise up your
hearts, and in that holy place, at the appointed times tune up all your
instruments, those chiefly that are most affecting and heart-ravishing, to this
work, chiefly on this day.

4 For though, For thou, Lord, have made me glad through thy work: I will
triumph in the works of thy hands.
O Lord, thou art exceeding beneficial to all mankind, yet of all the world
thou have done most for us, which I and the rest of thy peculiar people have
cause to remember and acknowledge, and with joyful hearts to praise thee for,
especially for that transcendent work of mercy, in chosing us from out all the
world to be thine, which together with those concomitant powerful
dispensations and manifestations of thy self in our behalfes from time to time,
gives cause to me and them to triumph, and glory in faith and hope.

5 O Lord, O Lord, how great art thy works! and thy thoughts are very deep.
how unconceivable is thy power and wisdom in all thy decrees, counsels, and
dispensations toward both thy Church and the enemies thereof, in thy strange
providence and mavelous judgments?

6 Which yet are little taken notice of by most men, A brutish man knows
not: neither does a fool understand this.
so worldly minded and sensually disposed are people ordinarily, that God is
not in all their thoughts, spending their time more like beasts than men of
reason, minding the creature more than the Creator, who is never so much as
owned, much less honored by the earthly minded, and wicked Athiesticall
persons of the world in any thing he does, though never so remarkable.

When the wicked spring as the grass, and when all the workers of iniquity do
flourish: it is that they shall be destroyed for ever.
7 Neither the hazardous condition that they themselves are in, in this their
earthly felicity, which they take to be a special note of Gods peculiar favor
to them, that they can sin and yet prosper, when others that are holy and
strict in their ways are at an ebb-water, in poverty and misery: not
considering that God gives wicked men their hearts desire here, lets them swim
in plenty and pleasure for a while during a short life, that they may complete
their sins to the sum total, and he his judgments even unto everlasting
destruction in endless pains, never to enter into his rest.

But thou, Lord, art most high for evermore.
8 They neither understand themselves nor thee, O Lord God, never imagining that
thou rulest in the highest heavens, and thence judge of all men and their
actions here below: But whatever their vain thoughts are, thou art the
everlasting King of thy Church and people, and the righteous judge of thine and
their enemies, and so they shall find thee to be to the worlds end.

For lo, thine enemies O Lord, for lo thine enemies shall perish: all the
workers of iniquity shall be scattered.
9 For as sure as Gods in heaven, so sure shall the wicked of the earth however
they prosper, and whatever they may think of themselves compared with other
men, come to ruin and utter destruction; for though they think God their
friend, yet does he know, and reckon them for his enemies, and as such, shall
his proceedings be toward them, for all evil doers though they be many, and
the godly few in all ages and places, they shall be weeded out and consume away
by the hand of God upon them, they and their felicity shall part and be
everlastingly separated.

10 But as despicable as the godly are in the eyes of worldlings, But my horn
shall thou exalt like the horn of an unicorn: I shall be anointed with fresh
oil.
they shall have their turn, I and other thy faithful servants shall see
better days, when they shall see worse, principally in heaven that everlasting
sabbatism; when our turn comes to rise, then they shall fall, and there is no
doubt but that day will come, when we shall be made able by thee, whose
faithfulness is engaged for it, to lift up our heads, and enjoy those
everlasting consolations hoped for, and those divine honors of being Kings and
Priests unto thee.

11 The faithful shall not fail of the grace promised them, Mine eye also
shall see my desire on mine enemies, and mine ears shall hear my desire of the
wicked that rise up against me.
and the justice to be executed upon their enemies, but they shall undoubtedly
be both eye, and ear-witnesses of the righteous judgments of God upon the
wicked of the world, that hate and persecute them.

12 The righteous however they be decried and depressed by wicked worldlings,
The righteous shall flourish like the Palm Tree he shall grow like a Cedar in
Lebanon.
yet shall God so bless them, that they shall out-grow their miseries, and
overtop their enemies: Gods Church and his people of whom it consists, shall
grow in grace until they arrive in glory.

13 Those that are Israelites indeed, Those that be planted in the house of the
Lord, shall flourish in the courts of our God.
which by the spirit and faith are made members, and have taken rooting in the
family and Church of God, shall thrive and come on prosperously in spiritual
graces, by use of holy means in frequenting his sanctuary, and sanctifying his
Sabbath to Gods glory, their own assurance, and unspeakable rejoicing. They
that are rooted here in grace, shall grow up from grace to grace, and be
crowned at last with eternal life in the heavens.

They shall still bring forth fruit in old age: they shall be fat and
flourishing.
14 These trees and plants of Gods own planting, by a divine supernatural
supply of spiritual sap and nourishment, contrary to the course of nature, the
elder they grow the better, they shall flourish and fructify both on earth and
to all eternity in heaven.

To show that the Lord is upright: he is my rock, and there is no
unrighteousness in him.
15 Thus shall both the wicked perish, and the godly flourish, to show that
however by outward appearance of providence and weakness of faith, the Lord
seems oft-times to us to go against himself and break his word, yet its nothing
so, the Lord for all that, is faithful, true of his promise, a never failing
refuge to every true believer, and there is no such thing as our sinful
imagination and unbelief-fancy of him, not the least u^righteousness in word or
deed.

The xciii. PSALM.
The Psalmist goes about to settle the faith of the Church in the Empire, and
omnipotency of the Lord her God, together with his faithful engagements, the
holy performances whereof she is bound to believe and rely upon for ever.
Psalm cxiii.


THe Lord reigns he is clothed with majesty, the Lord is clothed with
strength, wherewith he has girded himself, the world also is established that
it cannot be moved.
1 THe Church and people of God ought to know and believe this for an infallible
maxim in practical, as well as dogmaticall divinity, that The Lord reigns.
He that is their God is God and King of all and over all: the empire and
regalitie of the whole world is his, the resplendent majesty whereof appears
in all created Beings in heaven and earth, and in that power which he so
effectually and dexterously manifests for his Churches preservation, and their
enemies confusion, whereby the world also is centred so firm as upon a basis,
so that though it hang like a ball in the air, yet it is as firm and immovable
as the fixed mountains.

2 This dominion of thine, Thy throne is established of old: thou art from
everlasting.
O Lord, glorious in its administrations of protection and government, has
ever been, never was there any vacation of it, and as it has been, so it shall
be from everlasting to everlasting, as thou thy self art.

3 As in nature thou, The floods have lifted up, O Lord, the floods have lifted
up their voice: the floods lift up their waves.
Lord, have ordained in the waterie element thereof, v^^y formidable and
dreadful agitations, as in the tempestuous ragings of the sea, and the
overflowing of great waters making a hideous noise; such storms and
concussions are raised on land too, even all the earth over against thy Church,
tossed as a ship at sea, and boistrously handled by wicked and unreasonable men
that rage against her, ready to be swallowed up and devoured by them.

4 But as high as these waves and tempests of danger and destruction to thy
Church do mount, The Lord on high is mightier than the noise of many waters:
yea than the mighty waves of the sea.
yet is the Lord in heaven both higher and mightier than they, be they never so
terrible for noise and number, he can allay and quiet them at his pleasure, yea
though the Church be as a boat in a storm at sea in the midst of gusts and
surges, God can preserve it, and will; for as he raises sea-tempests, and
therefore can lay them, so he by his providence and appointment sends
landstorms, and therefore can order and quit them in like sort.

Thy testimonies are very sure: holiness becomes thine house, O Lord, for ever.
5 And as thou art powerful, so art thou faithful, we need no more doubt of
the one than of the other what thou have promised; as thou have power, so
likewise have thou will to perform it. Thy grace of protection is as certain
and infallible, as thy power is omnipotent. The obediential faith of thy holy
performance of all that thou have promised, becomes thy Church, the house of
the living God, which, O Lord, ought to be fixed and established by it, and in
it for ever, what ever befall her.

The xciv. PSALM.
In some very heavy pressure that lay upon the people of God in general, by
by the heathens, or else upon the faithful under the wicked Kings and Judges
of Israel, this Psalm seems to be made, wherein God is earnestly called upon to
take off the yoke which lay so heavily upon them by the tyranny and
persecution of bloody and (...) hemous wretches, whom be counsels to do
better; and from their abuse of Gods own clemency to their own perdition,
shows the blessed estate of Gods own people, because of Gods fatherly
chastisements. He acknowledges God for his sole support, which is his comfort
when he is at a loss, and is confident God will not always suffer tyrants to
sit in his seat, and rule over his Church, but that he will find a time to
judge them, Psalm xciv.
and deliver her out of their hands.

O Lord God, to to whom vengeance belongs: O God to whom vengeance belongs
show thy self.
1, 2 O Almighty and righteous Lord God, who have power, and to whom of right
it belongs to revenge the injuries and oppressions of thy Church, appear in her
behalf, Lift up thy self thou Judge of the earth, ^ender a reward to the proud.
so that both she and her oppressors may see thou do so. Let her proud
insulting enemies feellingly find that thou that art judge of all the earth,
favourest her cause and do her right upon them.

Lord, how long shall the wicked, how long shall the wicked triumph?
3, 4 Lord, it is not without cause that we cry to thee, for as our pressures
have been very great, so they have been very long. How shall they utter and
speak hard things? and all the workers of iniquity boast themselves.
The wicked have had a long reign, and lorded it with a witness over the good,
and by reason of thy delay they glory in their doings, as if either thou
could not or would not punish them. And what they think they stick not to
speak, even blasphemies against thee, and cruelties against us, and the more
wickedness they commit, the more they give themselves content, boasting one to
another, and vying one with another who can do most mischief, thy impunitie
being their immunitie.

5, 6 They make pot-sheards of thy people, They break in pieces thy people, O
Lord: and afflict thine heritage.
O Lord, loading them with such merciless oppressions and afflictions, even
thine own chosen and peculiar heritage, They slay the widow and the stranger:
and murder the fatherless.
and that because they are so, as they break their very hearts, and leave them
not the name or face of a people scarce upon earth, destroying all before them,
mercilesly breaking all laws humane and divine, respecting neither age nor sex,
pitying none in any kind or condition, though never such objects of compassion.

7 And so hardened are they in their wicked courses, Yet they say, The Lord
shall not see: neither shall the God of Jacob regard it.
and so presumptious by thy forbearance, that they are confident thou regardest
not what they do to thy people, nor never will call them to account for it,
making a very aw-word of the God of Jacob.

8 Be men of more understanding, Understand, ye brutish among the people: and
ye fools, when will ye be wise?
than to harbor such vain thoughts of so great a God, ye, that though ye be
heads and chief among the vulgar, yet are as void of understanding and true
judgment, as the common people themselves; be not still so foolish to persist
in wickedness, provoking the Lord, but consider that the end must needs be bad,
and that you will repent when it is too late.

9 For weigh with your selves whether it be reasonable to think, He that
planted the ear, shall he not hear? he that formed the eye, shall he not see?
that you can either act such things or speak such words, and God not see nor
hear them that gives ears and eyes to all men living, shall the author of
those senses be senseless?

He that chastises the heathen, shall not he correct? he that teaches man
knowledge, shall not he know?
10 He that is Judge of all the earth and punishes the very heathens for their
exorbitancies and unjust oppressions among themselves, shall not he much more
be righteous to revenge the wrongs done to his own people? and have you such
mean thoughts of God, as to judge him any thing less than omniscient? think you
to escape or deceive him that gives you your selves the knowledge you have, and
all men else?

The Lord knows the thoughts of man, that they are vanity.
11 The Lord very well knows what vain and wicked thoughts men naturally have of
him, how they abuse his clemency, as if he neither saw, heard, regarded, nor
will judge them for their wickedness, because he delays to do it.

Blessed is the man whom thou chastenest, O Lord: and teach him out of thy
law.
12 Therefore what ever the world think of the godly under afflictions, yet
blessed is the man that is so much favored of God, as to be chastised for his
faults, and admonished of his duty to Gods commandments, whilst he suffers
others to run riot without check or control.

That thou may give him rest from the days of adversity, until the pit be
dug for the wicked.
13 That he may make him meet for the inheritance of the saints, prepare him for
heaven, which shall be the end of his course, which is accompanied with
sorrows, as hell shall be of the wicked when they are prepared for it by a
consummation of the number and measure of their sins, by their liberty of
sinning.

For the Lord will not cast off his people, neither will he forsake his
inheritance.
14 For whatever we through shortness of spirit, and impatience under
afflictions may think of God, as if he had disregarded his people, yet its
nothing so, God may cast them into afflictions, but not because he rejects
them, but because he loves them, he will find a time to make it appear so, that
for all that, nay, that therefore he is their God, and they his dearly beloved,
because he does afflict them, when as he saves them by it, suffering others to
go to hell for want of it.

15 But how ever things seem to be topsi-turvie, But judgment shall return
unto righteousness, and the upright in heart shall follow it.
the wicked a top of the wheel, and the good under it, yet there is a time when
the world shall be set right again, each man shall be paid his wages, God shall
take the government into his hands, whereas now the reins seem to be let loose,
and in righteousness judge the good and the bad, which is the time that all
upright-hearted sincere Godly-ones long for, and in hope of it shall
notwithstanding, all obstructions, follow it in the way of piety.

16 Who is there beside thee, Who will rise up for me against the evil doers?
or who will stand with me against the workers of iniquity.
O Lord willing or able to deliver me from under this tyrannical oppression of
wicked workers, surely none in all the world. If thou do not save me, I
perish.

17 Yea, Unless the Lord had been my help my soul had dwelt in silence.
had not thou when time was been a present help, so near was I to
destruction, I had certainly died, and been silent in the grave instead of
being now speaking to thee, and praising of thee.

18 When I concluded with my self, When I said my foot slippeth: Thy mercy, O
Lord, held me up.
there was no way but death, then of a sudden beyond expectation in so eminent
a danger, did thy mercy appear to my wonderful preservation and deliverance.

19 When I was at the fullest of anxious cares, In the multitude of the
thoughts within me, thy comforts delight my soul.
and troublous thoughts were revolved in my breast, by reason of my desperate
condition what would become of me, then when I but cast the eyes of my mind upon
thine all-sufficiencie and faithfulness, I was presently quieted, and never am
so deep plunged in sorrow but these bladders bear me up again, and make my joy
and hope surmount them.

Shall the throne of iniquity have fellowship with thee: which frames
mischief by a law?
20 Lord, will thou that art the Judge of all the World not judge righteously?
shall the wicked escape thee, as they do the corrupt Judges here on earth? No
thou will not suffer tyrants and persecutors of thy people always to rule over
them in thy stead, whose King thou properly art, such as make laws flat against
thine, enact sin, and legitimate their unjust and mischievous practices against
thy people.

They gather themselves together against the soul of the righteous; and condemn
the innocent blood.
21 They conspire and plot the destruction of the righteous, yea, sit in
judgment upon the godly as upon malefactors, and right or wrong condemn them
to death, though they can find no just accusation against them.

But the Lord is my defense: and my God is the rock of my refuge.
22 But maugre the malice and injustice of mine enemies, I doubt not of defense
from them, I have found God an all-sufficient refuge and safe hiding place, and
my faith is in him as it was, therefore I fear not but to find him the same God
now, as ever heretofore in my defense and preservation.

And he shall bring upon them their own iniquity, and shall cut them off in
their own wickedness: yea, the Lord our God shall cut them off
23 Yea, he shall compass my deliverance, and the deliverance of his Church by
her enemies confusion, their fall shall be her rise, what they purpose against
Gods people shall redound upon themselves to their own mortal wounding, this
our good and Almighty Lord God is able to do, and to the glory of his
faithfulness and praise of his power, he shall effect it to all men's admiration.

The xcv. PSALM.
David, as appears by Heb. 4.7. was author of this Psalm, wherein he incites
the people solemnly, unanimously, and affectionately to sing praise and thanks
to God, for his grace to them, and his greatness in himself, and over the
world, and not to be like their forefathers, rebellious, and unbelieving, but
to hear and obey, lest imitating their sins, they share in their plagues.

1, 2 O How meet a thing it is for all us Israelites, Psalm xcv.
the adopted people of the Lord, O Come let us ^ing unto the Lord, let us make
a joyful noise to the rock of our salvation.
frequently to meet together, and with willing minds and thankful hearts to
set forth the praises of the Lord in solemn assemblies, Let us come before his
presence with thanksgiving, and make a joyful noise unto him with Psalms
let us unanimously and cheerfully do so, even sing aloud the praiseworthy
preservations that he the Rock of our salvation has in all ages vouchsafed
unto us. Let us joyfully repair to his sanctuary in the faith of his presence
according to his promise, with our hearts full-fraught with the memory of his
mercies, and our lips gratuitously pouring out the praises of them before him
there, singing joyfully with all the melodious harmony of voices and
instruments, the Psalms made for that purpose.

3 For who is there like him, For the Lord is a great God: and a great King
above all Gods.
or who is besides him worthy of worship? He only is God, great in might and
majesty, doing whatsoever pleases him, the only Potentate, whose is the
kingdom, power and glory. The maker of all things, besides whom there is no
God, though, falsely and abusively, there are gods many and lords many, as
heathenish idols, civil majestrates, glorified Angels, yea, devils also bear
that name, but he is above every thing so called, and commanded them as well as
us.

4, 5 What is there that he has not fashioned and framed in all the world, In
his hand are the deep places of the earth: the strength of the hills is his also.
and consequently which are not at his command and dispose: The sea is his and
he made it: and his hands formed the dry land.
from the bottom of the bottomless sea to the top of the mightiest mountains in
the whole earth; for both land and sea were made by him, and possessed of those
places they enjoy, at first he commanded the al-over-flowing waters now the
sea, to the abyss prepared for them, that the face of the earth might appear
above them for the use of man and beast, and so it did.

O come let us worship and bow down: let us kneel before the Lord our maker.
6 O let me exhort you again and again, cheerfully and jointly with unanimitie
and gratuitie, to frequent the tabernacle of this immense majesty, there to
worship him in all the ways and ordinances he has appointed, and adore his
great and glorious name, by humbling and prostrating our selves before him with
lowly hearts and bended knees, in token of giving our whole selves a living and
reasonable sacrifice unto him, as a homage due to so Almighty a God and our
Creator, of whom, we as well as all other things had our beeings and have
still.

For he is our God and we are the people of his pasture, and the sheep of his
hand: to day if you will hear his voice,
7, 8, 9 Nor is that all, but besides the common interest of Creation, he is our
God by special Election, who governs us not only by common providence as all
mankind, Harden not your heart, as in the provocation; and as in the day of
temptation in the wilderness:
but by special gubernation as his Church and chosen people, to whom, and on
whom he has bestowed his saving truths and ordinances for us to feed upon,
When your fathers tempted me, proved me, and saw my works.
and grow by unto everlasting life and happiness, we are not of his flock which
he turns out to the wide world, as sheep-masters do some sheep to commons and
fallows, but we are his pasture-sheep, yea, his cades brought up at hand, his
very domestics, these privileges we have if we know how to use them, and walk
worthy of them, obedientially hearkening to the voice, and submitting to the
guidance of this shepherd of Israel, and not after so much and so long
