experience as we have of him, his goodness, faithfulness, and power, at this
time, above what our forefathers had formerly, and the light that now shines
amongst us, toward the perfect day more than it did then, harden our hearts as
they at Meribah and Massah, the place where they chid with Moses, and with
ungrateful unbelief questioned the power and presence of the Almighty,
whether he were with them, and would or could supply their want of water, after
the great things he had done for them all along from Egypt thither, when as he
expected far other from them, considering what things he had even then done for
them, but much more for us since then, and therefore expects much more from us,
for this was in the wilderness long ago, during their peregrination there,
short of our times and what we have seen, when yet God expected even then and
there their faith and obedience, to have been answerable to his care and
providence, and therefore there proved them purposely; but instead of
hearkening to the voice of Moses, and of his miracles, to trust in him
faithfully, and walk before him humbly, in a meek and patient depending on him,
and seeking to him in their necessities, they speak rebelliously, mutined and
murmured at God and his servant ungratefully, and instead of submitting
themselves to the will and dispensations of God, to be proved by him, that they
might have opportunity to show forth their faith and obedience in and to him
that had done such great things for them, they turned it to a contrary use,
obstinately tempting and proving him, by misbelieving and questioning his power
and goodness, instead of meekly yielding to be proved by him, and answering his
expectations by suitable returns. These were our progenitors, of whom we come,
and of whose sins we therefore ought to beware.

10, 11 And this they did, Forty years long was I grieved with this
generation: and said, It is a people that do err in their heart, and they have
not known my ways.
not only once but often, nor out of frailty, but obstinacy, Nothing I could
do or say (says God) could reclaim them, but they persisted the self same men
from first to last, from the Red Sea to the skirts of Canaan forty years
together, Unto whom I swear in my wrath, that they should not enter into my
rest.
perpetually vexing me with their unbelief and rebellion, even all the
generation of them, scarce a man that did other, insomuch that at last, after
so long trial and experience of them, I concluded that there was no good to be
done, they are a people whose hearts are not upright with me, that err not of
infirmity, but obstinacy; and for all that, by my word and works, I have
taught and assured them thus long of my love, care, power, and faithfulness,
yet have not they learned in all this time, nor never will* being wilfully
blind and perversely inconsiderate, how to walk and demean themselves toward
me, by honoring of me with their faithful dependence, humble submission, and
hopeful expectation of my goodness and power to appear for them and be
extended to them, and to return me praise and thanks, love and obedience, that
so a perpetual intercourse of friendship and sweet correspondencie might have
been traded betwixt us for ever as I intended. But so hateful and vexatious
was their carriage, and so infinite and endless their provocation, that at last
when I had tried them to the uttermost, had brought them to the very borders of
the promised land, and saw they were still the same, as unbelieving and
murmuring as ever before, it made me past patience, so that in my rage I swear
(never to revoke it) that so unworthy a people that I saw neither was nor never
would be good, do all that I could, I say, I swear they should upon no terms
nor entreaty enter into and be possessed of the end of their travels, the type
of heaven, that resting place the land of Canaan, but should wast their days,
and end their lives in the wilderness, where they had so sinned against me,
even the whole generation of them, which I made good to the last man of that
rebellious crew. Let us fear and tremble, hearken and obey, praise and give
thanks, lest we the offspring of such progenitors be guilty of their sins, and
partake of their plagues, be cast out as they were kept out, of this good land.

The xcvi. PSALM.
This Psalm was ^ndited at the remove of the Ark to its settled abode upon the
hill of Sion in Jerusalem, being in substance all one with that 1. Chron.
16.23. to 33. wherewith David, ravished in spirit, and prophetically disposed,
stirs up all the world, Jews and Gentiles, to praise the Lord for the Kingdom
of Christ, which was approaching, which that typified, yea, and all creatures,
the most irrational and unsensible ^or the general Iubilee that shall then be,
the happy restoration begun, and not long to perfecting. Psalm xcvi.


1, 2 O What a joyful day is this, O Sing unto the Lord a new song: sing unto
the Lord all the earth.
to see the Ark brought after all its travels to its place of abode, the holy
mount in Jerusalem. This new mercy deserves a new song, Sing unto the Lord,
bless his name: show forth his salvation from day to day.
yea, extraordinary praise and thanks, not only from us, but from all the
world, the Gentiles as well as Israelites, which from Sion shall have the glad
tidings of salvation published to them, news worthy of new songs and ineffable
praises to be given to God, whom we nor they can praise enough, nor bless that
infinite goodnese of his, in vouchsafing the grace and knowledge of his
salvation to us so eminently in this type of Christ's peaceable and glorious
Kingdom, which they shall have really and indeed everlastingly amongst them,
worthy everlasting praises for them.

3 Spread the glorious tidings of Christ and his approaching Kingdoms far and
near, Declare his glory among the heathen: his wonders among all people.
let it be told the Gentiles, for they shall share in it, and glorify for it
let all that he has done for his Church, and promised to do, those wonderful
things of sending his Son, calling the Gentiles, and spreading his Church over
the face of the earth, be made known all the world over, to prepare them for it
with joy and thanks to receive it.

For the Lord is great, and greatly to be praised: he is to be feared above all
gods.
4 For the Lord shall be better known, though now they are ignorant of him, and
set light by him, valuing stocks and stones before him, yet the time will come
when they shall know, that this our God, is the only great and praiseworthy
God, and as well worthy to be worshipped and honored of them, instead of those
false and fond gods, they now serve, as of us. That there is none like him, nor
none but him.

For all the gods of the na^ions are idols: but the Lord made the heavens.
5 For all other gods which they ignorantly worship every where; (for all the
world lies in darkness) are but dumb and deaf Idols, made of wood and stone,
or at the best but creatures; the Lord only is the Creator, that made the
whole world, the glorious and beautiful heavens, and reigns therein alone.

Honor and majesty are before him: strength and beauty are in his sanctuary.
6 In the midst of unaccessible Honor and Majesty, which no man can see and
live, communicating thence some beams and rays of his heavenly and Divine
properties of grace and power, in that spiritual splendor that powerfully
shines out of his holy sanctuary, into the souls and spirits of those that in
faith and sincerity worshipping him there, have their hearts thereby
strengthened in believing, and their graces enlivened by the fresh
communicating of his ordinances, and effectual answers to their prayers against
their enemies.

Give unto the Lord (O ye kindreds of the people) give unto the Lord glory and
strength.
7 All ye people, whether sons of Adam, or of Abraham understand the Lord
aright, so as to honor him worthy of himself, by glorifying him as the only
God of power, yea, the Lord Almighty.

Give unto the Lord the glory due unto his name: bring an offering, and come
into his courts.
8 Worship not other gods instead of him, nor yet together with him, let him
rule alone in your hearts, that rules alone in the world, pay your tribute and
do your homage to him at his sanctuary, neither worship any God but him, nor
him in any other manner than as he has appointed, sacrifice to him upon his
own altar in his own courts.

9 Let all, O worship the Lord in the beauty of holiness: fear before him all
the earth.
far and near, come and welcome too, do as we do, worship the Lord in his holy
sanctuary; O that the whole earth would turn to the Lord, Gentiles as well as
Jews, as when Christ comes they shall have as free access to worship God as we,
and their worship as well accepted then, as ours is now.

10 Publish to the heathen what God has made known to you his people, Say
among the heathen that the Lord reigns: the world also shall be established
that it shall not be moved: he shall judge the people righteously.
How that the Lord only is God, and that the kingdom of the world, as well as
of Israel, belongs to him, and that his Church shall flourish every where as
well as here, which is not long to; all things shall be brought into a better
order, one God in Christ shall be worshipped, and steadfastly believed in,
instead of those mutiplicitie of gods, and extravagancies of worship that the
world is distracted with: He shall take upon him the kingdom of the Gentiles as
well as of the Jews, they shall take laws from him as well as we, and be
subjected to his righteous judgments as we are, who now are a lawless people,
void both of the knowledge and fear of God.

11 When that day comes, that we shall be no more under the Law, Let the
heavens rejoice, and let the earth be glad: let the sea roar and the fullness
thereof.
but under Grace, it shall be like the restoring of all things, a very first
fruits of it: Christ when he comes to enter upon his Gospel-kingdom, shall give
cause of joy to all things above and below, heaven, earth, land, water, and to
all creatures that live in and replenish all elements, shall be glad to be from
under his spreading confusion and chaos of ignorance and disorder, now
abounding under the time of nature and the curse, and to be reduced under the
headship and government of the reconciling and peacemaking Mediator, author
of light and life, as the forerunner of their final and absolute deliverance
at his second coming.

Let the field be joyful and all that is therein: then shall all the trees of
the wood rejoice
12, 13 All the earth, and all the creatures in it, shall have cause of
rejoicing, even the irrational and the unsensible (like as also all the wide
world of Gentilism) for its deliverance from the bondage of corruption, Before
the Lord, for he comes, for he comes to judge the earth: he shall judge the
world with righteousness, and the people with his truth.
then certainly begun, which is not far off, being till then made subject to
vanity, and its restorement into the glorious liberty of the children of God
then assuredly hastening. The whole creation in the mean time groaning and
traveling in pain together; waiting for the adoption and day of redemption, to
come from the presence of the Lord, which is not far behind the coming of the
Messiah, nay he himself is that King and Judge that comes to that very end and
purpose, to put an end to confusion and unrighteousness, and to create himself
a righteous Church out of the unrighteous world, that now is nothing else: and
a people that shall know Holiness and Truth from lies and vanity, whom he
shall bless, and the creature for their sakes, and ease them of the curse that
lies upon them, by taking it upon himself; dispensing grace and mercy to the
good, judgment and wrath to the wicked: by whose righteous government, the
whole creation shall be rendered much more acceptable in the eyes of the
creator, and so the creature partake of the first fruits of its redemption and
restoration, and the assured hopes of the speedy compleatment and finishing
thereof so much desired by it.

The xcvii. PSALM.
This Psalm is a prophecy of the kingdom of Christ in the time of the Gospel,
when he is come in the flesh, amplifying it in its certainty and universality,
together with its dreadful concomitants, as to unbelievers and contemners of
it. The joy that it shall be of to all the Israel of God. And concludes with an
animadversion to sincerity in contradistinction to formalitie, and the
happiness of such, maugre all enemies and evils that shall befall them. Psalm
xcvii.


1 THe glorious kingdom of Gods sole regencie by Jesus Christ is near at hand,
THe Lord reigns, let the earth rejoice: let the multitude of Isles be glad
thereof.
whereby error and vanity that has hitherto prevailed over the face of the
whole earth shall be extinguished, and the light of the gospel of salvation
shall shine like the sun into all the regions, to the unexpressable joy of the
whole earth, yea, it shall spread in its saving efficacy and virtue, from out
Judea where it has long been confined, to the remotest and unfrequentedst
corners and countries of the world, by land and sea.

2 You know how terribly the Lord appeared when he came down from heaven to
earth, Clouds and darkness are round about him: righteousness and judgment are
the habitations of his throne
to give the Law on Sinai, his terror and Majesty shall be every whit as
great at his second coming, to bring and publish the Gospel, as dreadful shall
he be to the contemners and disobeyers thereof as of the Law, for righteousness
and judgment shall be administered in, and are essential to his
Gospel-kingdom, and not to the Law only, as Gospel-sinners shall be sure to
find.

3 Whithersoever his Gospel Grace and mercy goes, A fire goes before him, and
burns up his enemies round about.
and wheresoever it is published, there goes along with it wrath and judgment,
which shall certainly and heavily fall upon the enemies and refusers thereof,
for the defense of it and his Church every where.

His lightenings enlightened the world: the earth saw and trembled.
4, 5. Recollect and enumerate all the terrible things that accompanied the
mighty and dreadful majesty of Almighty God, The hills melted like wax at
the presence of the Lord: at the presence of the Lord of the whole earth.
when he gave the law on mount Sinai, thunderings, lightenings, earthquakes,
etc. and the same dreadfulness accompanies the Gospel for its vindication and
protection, upon contemners and against opposers.

The heavens declare his righteousness: and all the people ^ee his glory.
6 The heavens declare him to be a faithful Creator, one that in mighty
long-suffering and patience toward the sons of men, keeps his promise made to
Noah after the flood, causing the lights and influences of heaven to keep their
natural courses, and afford their benefits even to the heathenish idolotrous
nations, notwithstanding their sins, who are eyewitnesses of his manifold
glorious dispensations every where, in all the parts and places of the world.

Confounded be all they that serve graven images, that boast themselves of
idols: worship him all ye gods.
7 Who see not their sin and folly in taking the benefit of Gods creatures, such
glorious ones as shine from heaven, and yet fall down to the stock of a tree,
and worship it for God; a strange stupiditie. O that therefore the time were
come, which certainly shall come, and is not long to, of that gospel light
which shall shine like the sun upon the face of all the earth, to the
conversion or confusion of all idolatrous nations, who now in this time of
ignorance God bears with, but when light is come into the world, if then men
love darkness more than light, they shall be, and so let them be, destroyed,
all that are so wilfully blind and brutish, as still to worship and confide in
idols, and set them in opposition to the only true God made manifest in
Christ. All ye supposed gods, cease to deceive men, now let truth take place;
ye living oracles, feigned deities, disclaim the superstition and adoration
wherewith the foolish people worship you, tell them you are no Gods, that God
in Christ is only to be worshipped, do you exalt him and abase your selves,
that his Kingdom may come amongst the deluded heathen.

8 What joy will it be to the faithful Israel of God, Sion heard, and was
glad, and the daughters of Judah rejoiced; because of thy judgments, O Lord.
at that day when Christ shall come, and shall shine out of Sion as the Sun out
of the East, his Kingdom taking rise from thence to the fall of Idols and
Idolatry every where, the happy predictions of the near approaches, and the
early dawnings of it being heard and seen shall be unspeakable joy to them,
because the truth of all those ancient long looked for promises and prophesies,
are then immediately to be fulfilled in the universal Sovereignty and Empire
of Jesus Christ, who comes to judge the world and rule his Church.

9 For however the world is grossly mistaken by fancying other divinities
besides thee, For thou, Lord, art high above all the earth: thou art exalted
far above all Gods.
as if the Government were not thine, and thou were not God alone; yet thou will now set their judgments right, and let them know, that none can pretend
to Godhead but thy self, as heaven is thy throne, so the earth is thy
footstool, and shall be subdued unto Jesus Christ, for that in him thou shall
be magnified beyond all that are called Gods, who shall then appear to be what
indeed they are, Lying vanities, and so shall be accounted of.

10 Great shall be the numbers of Professors, Ye that love the Lord hate evil,
he preserves the souls of his Saints, he delivers them out of the hand of
the wicked.
and pretenders to Christianity, infinite will give their names to Christ, and
be ambitious to have his name named upon them in those days, but there is more
belongs to it than so. He that is indeed the Lord Christ's, a loyal subject of
his Kingdom, and member of his Church, must sincerely love him, and that must
appear by an upright walking with him, and believing on him, he must fear to
offend him, and therefore hate sin because it does so; and so doing be fearless
as touching his salvation and preservation, faithfully relying upon the truth
and providence of God for both, maugre both his ghostly and temporal enemies;
which God may suffer to hazard his Church and people for the trial of their
faith and exercise of their graces, but never to ruin them.

Light is sown for the righteous, and gladness for the upright in heart.
11 For when ever God seems to plow and harrow his Church by persecutions and
troubles, that is, his and her seeds-time, then is he but husbanding his field,
weeding and clodding it, all that time of darkness and infelicity is but the
seed-season and preparatory, to the breaking out of greater favor and grace
upon her, which he preserves in store; she shall not lose but gain by it, when
the spring and harvest comes, her joy shall be redoubled when the eclipse is
over. Thus shall it be not with all professors, but with the incorrupt and
pure in heart, who are the Lords as well within as without, in affections as
actions, whose ends and motives are principled from God and for God, by faith
in him and love to him.

Rejoice in the Lord, ye righteous: and give thanks at the remembrance of his
holines^.
12 Let such righteous ones, though they meet with never so many rubs in the
way, be so far from being dismayed at them, as to go on with full sails of
assurance and joy in God, making no stop, but overtopping all fear by faith,
still casting their eye upon Gods never-failing faithfulness, and being as
thankful for a happy issue and deliverance out of their afflictions, as if
they had it, because of the engagement of Gods holiness which cannot deceive
them.

The xcviii. PSALM.
This Psalm is as if it had been made by John Baptist himself, pointing out
Christ and his Kingdom already come through the propinquity and certainty of
it, showing sorth the prais-worthy deliverance and universal benefit that to
Jew and Gentile shall accrue thereby, yea, to the very irrational and
unsensible creatures, whereupon be excites all, rational and irrational, to
praise the Lord proportionably.

A Psalm to be sung. Psalm xcviii. A Psalm.


1 O what wonderful occasions from time to time has God given his people
Israel, O sing unto the Lord a new song, for he has done mavelous things;
his right hand and his holy arm has gotten himself the victory.
of frequent and fresh praises by deliverance upon deliverance, and all of them
so strange and miraculous, that we could not have the face to ascribe them to
any but to him, to whom we have endited and sung many a new Psalm for new
mercies, all which temporal salvations, and our thanksgivings for them were
but prefigurations of that one only salvation of his Church by Christ God
incarnate, whose powerful triumphant death and holy life, active and passive
obedience, has gotten so glorious a victory to his everlasting praise, over
all the spiritual enemies of his elect and faithful people; which as it is
the deliverance whereof all others were but adumbrations, so ought it to have
the praise above them all jointly or severally. A Quire of Angels are but fit
to celebrate this great and Gospel salvation, the good news whereof ought much
more to set the spiritual Priests and people of God on work to praise him for
it, that are saved by it.

The Lord has made known his salvation: his righteousness has he openly
showed in the sight of the heathen.
2 The heathen people have admired our salvations, and wondrous deliverances
many a time, which the Lord has wrought for us in their sight and hearing; But
they shall have much more cause to admire their own, when God shall proclaim
the year of Jubilee to the Gentiles, and bring them by the redemption of the
Messiah (which is at hand) out of the power of Hell, sin, death, and darkness;
setting wide open to them the door of life that were shut out, and Preaching
salvation of free grace to all the world according to his promise.

He has remembered his mercy and his truth toward the house of Israel: all the
ends of the earth have seen the salvation of our God.
3 The promised Messiah which was to come of the seed of Israel our Father, and
in whom is to be accomplished all those covenanted engagements, and Gospel
promises made with Abraham of grace and mercy, pardon and atonement, God in
faithfulness and fullness of time has sent him (in whom all the nations of the
earth are to be blessed) for the benefit both of Jews and Gentiles; whose
all-sufficient merit, and common salvation, shall in the fame and promulgation
of it, extend it self by a gracious and free tender to all people, in all
places of the world without exception; our God is their God, in and through
Christ, and his salvation both ours and theirs, they being through grace
adopted and ingrafted into one stock with us, the faithful seed of faithful
Abraham, every where sharers in the blessing.

Make a joyful noise unto the Lord, all the earth: make a loud noise, and
rejoice, and sing praise.
4, 5, 6 We a corner of the world, a few in comparison of the whole, O how were
we wont to resound, and echo out the Honor and praises of the Lord in that
only Temple, Sing unto the Lord with the harp: with the harp, and the voice of
a Psalm.
with all manner of musical Instruments and Voices, for our temporal and
comparatively petty deliverances from earthly enemies, With trumpets and sound
of corner* make a joyful noise before the Lord, the King.
and humane captivities and imbondagements. O with what ineffable rejoycings in
the superlativest manner we could devise, did we magnify the Lord, and set the
Crown of all glory upon his head. How much more now are his praises to exceed,
when as all the earth is his Church, Christ himself the Savior, and the terms
to and from which we are saved are heaven and hell; the subject of his
salvation, our precious souls as well as mortal bodies both redeemed, not
only into a capacity but certainty of spiritual and eternal life, and freed
from death of both sorts. What praises are enough for this? how can the
redeemed of the Lord, each whereof is a Temple, and each Temple a Quire,
sufficiently extol the Lord the King Christ Jesus, dead and risen, yea,
ascended into glory. Go not less in the praises of such a Savior for his
salvation in the universal Catholic Church, than we did for ours, in our
particular national Sinagogue, But let your faith praise him in full
assurance, your joy in heart-ravishment, your love by being such as many waters
cannot quench, your hope anchored within the vail. Let all these graces by a
joint harmony, like the voices and instruments of the Temple be sublimated to
their highest sphere of activity, in the celebration of joyful praises of his
coming from heaven to earth to redeem his Church. Yea, all that is within you
praise his holy name for so great salvation, wrought not only by the power (as
all the rest were) but also by the person of God himself, whom you ought
therefore with studied thankfulness and elaborate expressions of joy and
honor, entertain and usher into the world, worthy his greatness, and best
expressing your high esteem of such unvaluable grace.

Let the sea roar, and the fullness thereof: the world, and they that dwell
therein.
7, 8, 9 These three last verses being the same in sense and almost in letter
with the 11, 12, 13 (being also the three last) verses of the 96 Psalm, Let the
floods clap their hands: let the hills be joyful together.
see the Paraphrase upon them for the explanation of these. Saving that those
words in the eighth verse of this Psalm let the hills be joyful together,
Before the Lord, for he comes to judge the earth, with righteousness, shall he
judge the world, and the people with equity.
signify, that as all people are admitted into the same privilege with the
Jews by Christ, so all places have the same fellowship in propriety and title
to God and his worship, as has the hill of Sion once his peculiar. John 4.21.

The xcix. PSALM.
The Psalmist probably upon some deliverance magnifies the Lord in relation to
his people the Jews, and their happy condition above all people, exciting them
to praise God answerably to his mercies and righteousness, even that God, which
has ever been their God, and done great things for them by his servants of
old. Psalm xcix.


THe Lord reigns, let the people tremble: he sits between the cherubims,
let the earth be moved.
1 THe Amighty God whose throne is in the heavens, is pleased in behalf of his
Church and chosen people to make it appear, that he also has dominion upon
earth, by their powerful preservation and their enemies destruction, therefore
let the heathen people our neighbor nations that so malign us, take it into
serious consideration, and tremble to think of provoking him by injuring his
Church; Let them rather, and all the rest of the Gentiles, with a reverentiall
fear submit themselves to his regiment, and be gathered into the number of his
people, worshipping him not after their own imaginations, but in the manner and
place that he has appointed, the Temple, where only he has fixed his
presence upon the mercy-seat between the Cherubims, which condescension of the
great God of heaven, full of incomprehensible majesty and holiness, to reside
on earth, ought to make even the whole creation sensible of it, by way of
Allegiance and subjection to him, and honor of the place where, and the people
amongst whom, he is pleased to erect his throne.

2 Wonderful great has the power of God appeared in the preservation of his
people, The Lord is great in Sion, and he is high above all people.
and the defense of his holy Temple, in the behalf whereof he has mightily
approved his wisdom and power infinitely to exceed all humane policy, and
strength of the great Sages, and confederate forces of the world, which sundry
times he has dissipated and strangely defeated.

3 O therefore, Let them praise thy great and terrible name, for it is holy.
let thy people, who have been so extraordinarily blessed by thee, return
answerable thanks unto thee, and praise thee for those righteous and terrible
judgments executed upon their enemies, wherein thou have manifested such
Almighty power and gracious providence, and have thereby approved thy self a
holy God, faithful of thy word and promise.

4 And as well righteous, The Kings strength also loves judgment, thou do
establish equity, thou executest judgment and righteousness in Jacob.
as holy, not exercising a Tyrannical absolute Arbitrary power over the
creature, yea, though thou can, yet thou will not, but affectest to subject
thy proceedings to the rules of righteousnese, ordering thy power by thy
justice, and putting it forth by way of judgment, which thou both justly and
severely executest upon sinners and enemies to thee and thy people, unto whom
both by thy works and word, president and precept, thou hold forth and
recommendedst equity and righteousness for them to walk thereafter, yea, thou
art not partial to thine own people the seed of Jacob, no more than to the
heathen, but if they sin they smart for it, in righteousness thou punishest
them as well as others.

Exalt ye the Lord your God, and worship at his footstool for he is holy.
5 Magnify and praise, O ye his people this your God, the only Lord, come,
frequent his Temple the only place on earth, where he that sits in heaven is
pleased to be present, there bow down with adoration and reverence before him,
as at the footstool of the great and glorious Majesty of heaven, worshipping
him in spirit, with holiness of heart, abasing your selves, and exalting the
Lord who only is holy, and his worship holy, all other Gods throughout the
world being vain Idols, and their worship sin and superstition.

Moses and Aaron among his Priests, and Samuel among them that call upon his
name: they called upon the Lord, and he answered them.
6 That God that has made himself known to you, as by eminent Miracles, so by
eminent Messengers, such as the memory of them is famous and honorable amongst
you, how much more ought God to be so: Moses and Aaron those chosen worthies,
that in the beginning were prime Rulers and Peers of his Church, and Samuel an
honorable Prophet in the after-ages of it, what gracious answers did he
vouchsafe to their prayers. These holy men, powerful intercessours, Types of
the Messiah, the great Mediator of his Church, how ever and anon were they
heard when they prayed for the people, and what salvation was vouchsafed still
at their request?

He spoke unto them in the cloudy pillar: they kept his testimonies and the
ordinance that he gave them.
7 These Saints and servants of God had familiar communication with him, as
Moses and Aaron, all the way in the wilderness they had God present with them,
ordering and advising their course in that great charge that lay upon them,
whose command and covenant they faithfully delivered over to the people, and
observed themselves.

8 These holy men were beloved and honored by the holy Lord God, Thou
answeredst them, O Lord our God: thou wast a God that forgavest them, though
thou tookest vengeance of their inventions.
who for us his peoples sake put them into office, made them intercessours,
yea, effectual prevailing-ones (such as Christ shall be) many a time passing
by the sins of Israel for their sakes, whom thou did not, nor would not
have punished, but forgiven and forgotten too, had not iterated provocations
and backslidings from thee and thy commandments to Idolatry and will worship,
forced thee to take vengeance, and minded thee of the abuse of former
long-suffering, which then thou also reckonedst with them for, when once thine
anger did break forth.

9 See the fifth verse of this Psalm, Exalt the Lord our God, and worship at
his holy hill: for the Lord our God is holy.
only the word holy-hill here instead of footstool there means the same
thing: viz. The Temple built upon his holy hill mount Sion.

The c. PSALM.
The Psalmist excites the Church and people of God among the Gentiles as well
as Jews to praise the Lord and embrace his salvation so freely bestowed upon
them, who are so dear to him, whom therefore he would have turn proselites
apace, and lose no time, but glorify him both now and hereafter, for his grace
to his Church in all ages.

A Psalm penned to stir up the people to praise the Lord. A psalm of praise.


O give thanks and sing forth the praises of the Lord, MAke a joyful noise
unto the Lord, all ye lands.
and of his great and gracious salvation in Christ, all ye people of the earth,
not Jews only but Gentiles also, every where, where the glad tidings of it
come to entertain it joyfully, and praise him for it thankfully.

Serve the Lord with gladness: come before his presence with singing.
2 Cast off all old superstitious and vain worship of false gods, readily
embrace his truth, take the Lord for your God, and give your selves to him to
be his people, count it your happiness to be so, that you may have the honor
and privilege to be admitted to put up prayer, and to offer praises to him as
your God, that once were aliens and without God in the world; now Christ has
taken down the partition wall, and brought God and you together again, be much
with him in faithful and grateful praising of him.

Know ye that the Lord he is God, it is he that has made us, and not we our
selves; we are his people, and the sheep of his pasture.
3 Learn this lesson well, that the Lord is God, and that he only is so, you
that have been used to Idolize other gods, do so no more, own him, and honor
him for the only Jehovah that has being, and has it of himself; and that is
the sole Creator of all men, we made not our selves, and then nothing else but
he did, nay, it is he that has begotten us again, he has of and by his grace
made us new creatures, this we are sure is as much of him, and as little of our
selves as the former, those that are his people, may thank him they are so,
their souls had never been renewed nor saved by any thing they themselves could
have done or suffered, vocation, justification, and sanctification are the
gifts of God to his Elect: as are all the faithful of what nation soever, of
whom we Israelites now his peculiar are a type, and as he has done us in the
manifestation of grace, and administration of providence, such singular love
will he bear to his Church for ever.

4 Seeing we are to be all one Church, Enter into his gates with thanksgiving,
and into his courts with praise: be thankful unto him and bless his name.
begin betime, join fellowship with us in the worship of this one only true
God, do as we do now, frequent his holy Temple, worship him in the Courts and
Ordinances thereof, whilst they are, till they cease, and then in holy
Christian assemblies, worship him in spirit and truth, be thankful to him and
magnify him, for the unspeakable goodness and power manifested in so great
salvation.

5 For, For the Lord is good; his mercy is everlasting: and his truth endures
to all generations.
though we be evil, yet the Lord is good, and though our sins provoke his
judgments against us, yet his long-suffering and mercy is like himself,
everlasting, we have found it so, and so shall his Church in all ages, his
faithfulness according to the covenant of grace, shall not fail on his part,
though it be too often broke on ours, it shall be perpetuated in Christ, and
for Christ to his Church.

The ci. PSALM.
David drawing nigh toward the possession of the Kingdom so long promised and
delaid, to forward the accomplishment, preingageth himself to God, that he will
praise him for it, when he has it, and serve him faithfully in it, both as a
King and a pater-familias, in walking uprightly and avoiding sin carefully,
neither countenancing it in himself nor othors, whether in City or Country,
Church or Commonwealth, but on the contrary, the good and godly shall be they
he will prefer and employ. Psalm ci. A Psalm of David.


A Psalm made by David.

1 O Lord, I will sing of mercy and judgment unto thee, O Lord, will I sing.
when thou shall in favor to thy servant have seated me in the throne, I will
magnify thy free grace and merciful beneficence, in bringing me out of such
trouble and hazard unto such an honor and dignity, as also thy righteousness
and justice, when thou shall have executed those judgments upon mine enemies,
which thou have threatened.

I will behave my self wisely in a perfect way, O when will thou come unto me?
2 When thou have advanced me to it, I hope I shall walk worthy of it, my full
purpose is with godly wisdom to order all mine affairs, and not be as most
Kings are, wise to their own and their Kingdoms destruction, by exercising
their policy to advance their tyranny, and governing by no rule of reason or
justice, but by the arbitrary dictates of their own inordinate appetites, I
purpose to be wise with other manner of wisdom, and to tread in quite other
steps, in obedience to thy Laws and dispensation of Justice and good government
to my people, when they are mine. Lord, when shall that day be, that thou will
come in the full accomplishment of thy promises to me; I hope I shall not give
thee cause to repent thee whenever it is, for my purpose is to be both a good
King over my people, and a careful head over my Court and family, to breed my
successors, and rule my servants and officers as well as my subjects in the
fear of God, giving good example in my place to all under me both of innocence
and sincerity.

I will set no wicked thing before mine eyes: I hate the work of them that turn
aside.
3 I will watch against the temptations incident to that estate and condition
whereof it is full, and will therefore purposely avoid occasions of evil,
whereby I know beforehand I shall miscarry: if not carefully shunned, specially
then when my power is almost equal with my will, therefore in a holy fear of
sinning I will turn my back upon allurements; refuse their offers, and walk in
a steady resolved course of holiness and righteousness, without coveting an
evil covetousness, abusing my power to gratify unlawful desires, for I hate
warping and backsliding, such defection is extreme distasteful to me, by Gods
help such corrupt thoughts shall never lodge in my breast, nor such wickedness
hang at my heels to hinder my progress in piety and good government, though I
know beforehand the baits that will lie in my way, but I will not stoop to
take them up.

4 I hope then to be rid of this heart, A froward heart shall depart from me: I
will not know a wicked person.
which now by reason of my bitter afflictions is sore put to it, and often
enclines to discontent and untuneableness, but I hope then to be free from the
temptation, and consequently from the distemper, and to be never the prouder
for mine honor, which I come so hardly by, and which whenever I have it, it
must be of thy free gift, but of meek demeanor both toward thee above me, and
my fellow-brethren though subjects, under me. And as I will not allow of
wickedness in my self, so nor in any other, no wicked person, nor no person in
the practice of any wickedness, shall have my countenance to credit him.

5 I know how incident Princes are to be misled by whisperers, Who so privily
slandereth his neighbor, him will I cut off; him that has an high look, and a
proud heart will not I suffer.
and what false reports they hear by giving ear to flatterers and back-biters,
to the unjust prejudice of the innocent, but I will take a course with such
men, I will watch mine ears as well as mine eyes, and will severely punish
those that I catch doing so, nor shall any proud vainglorious fool draw me
from an humble walking with God, such shall see that I know humility and
Sovereignty are not incompatible but consistent, I will neither pride it over
my brethren, my self, nor suffer any else because of his place or office about
me to do so.

6 My countenance shall be to the good and not to the bad, Mine eyes shall be
upon the faithful of the land, that they may dwell with me: he that walks in
a perfect way, he shall serve me.
and my care shall be to find out such as are faithful and sincere-hearted
toward God, to entertain and employ such who I know will also be faithful and
incorrupt in their places, the man that is a practiser of piety and honesty,
and in the course of his life walks steadily in those ways, is he that I will
be solicitous to enquire out, and prefer both in domestic and republic
offices.

He that works deceit shall not dwell within my house; he that tells lies
shall not tarry in my sight.
7 If I may know it there shall no crafty dissembler, nor undermining oppressor
harbor under my roof, nor be imploid as any Minister of mine, he that
misinforms me thinking thereby to delude me, advantage himself, or disadvantage
another, such an one shall pack out of my doors, he shall have no favor but
all the discountenance I can give him.

I will early destroy all the wi^ked of the land: that I may cut off all wicked
doers from the city of the Lord.
8 It shall be my first and chiefest work, to weed out the notorious deboisheers
generally in the Kingdom, that have inured themselves so to sin in Saul's
licentious reign, as their is no hope of their amendment: and as it shall be my
first work, so it shall be my constant course impartially to punish evil doers
all the land over, and specially in Jerusalem the place of Gods peculiar abode
and worship, that I may as near as I can bring all my people every where to be
Gods people, holy worshippers of him by working a thorough reformation among
them; most especially will I expunge them out of the sanctuary from officiating
there, where such men are a scandal, and an eyesore to God and all good men.

The cii. PSALM.
The Author of this Psalm in the name and person of the Church then in
miserable captivity in Babylon, but near the end of it, prays for speedy
relief in their lamentable oppression, and from under Gods own indignation, and
how desperate soever their condition seems, yet he comforts himself, and in
himself the Church with Gods never failing-nature and truth, which shall give
existence to his Church, and consequently restoration, according to the
prefixed time then at hand, which will be joy to his people and honor to God,
both in present and after-ages amongst Jews and Gentiles, for it shall be an
occasion to convert some, and a figure of the great restitution that shall be
made by the coming of the M^ssiah. He magnifies Gods eternal being, and
assures the Church therefore an everlasting existence however frail in her
self. Psalm cii. A Prayer of the afflicted when he is overwhelmed, and pour^th
out his complaints before the Lord.


A Prayer made for the use and direction of the godly, when he or they are so
grievously afflicted, as they seem to be overwhelmed therewith, and his or
their burden so unsupportable, that it forces him to pour out his soul in sad
complaints before the Lord, in the dolor and anguish of his heart.

1 O Lord, HEar my prayer, O Lord and let my cry come unto thee.
hear the prayer of thy servant and servants, even of thy whole Church whom I
personate complaining to thee in great misery and bondage, to the enforcing of
them to vehement importunities, which, Lord, shut not thine ears against, but
give them audience and gracious admittance into both thine ears and heart.

2 Though our sins have caused thy frowns and disfavour, Hide not thy ^ace from
me in the day that I am in trouble, incline thine ear unto me: in the day when
I call, answer me speedily.
yet let our miseries move thy mercies, and be entreated after so long an
estrangement of so many years bondage, at last to resume thy grace, and to
shine forth in favor upon us, and to take our condition into consideration,
yea, Lord, now thou have put it into our hearts to pray hopefully, be entreated
to answer us speedily, by delivering and restoring us effectually, let it not
be long to.

3 Our whole life in this condition we are in, For my days are consumed like
smoke: and my bones are burnt as an hearth.
is spun out to an unprofitable length, our time is unusefully spent, wasted,
and consumed, without honor to thee or good to our selves; This long lingering
oppression the sorrow we sustain under it, because of the sense of thy heavy
displeasure and thy Churches desolation, has dried up our radical moisture,
and quite changed the constitution of our natures, that our bones if visible
are dried and discolored as an hearth that has long lain under a hot
scortching fire, as we have under the fire of affliction.

My heart is smitt^^, and withered like grass: so that I forget to eat my bread.
4 Thou have cut up all my earthly comforts as it were by the roots, I can think
of nothing of that nature comfortably, my heart and they are parted by thy
judgments, as the grass is from the earth by the hand of the mower, and as it
withers for want of union and communication of sap and moisture, so is my heart
shrunk and exhausted within me, by the utter absence of thy grace and favor,
finding no content the whilst in any thing, though never so necessary, insomuch
as nature forgets to sustain it self, feeds upon sorrow instead of bread,
having almost lost all appetite and digestion through anguish of heart.

By reason of the voice of my groaning, my bones cleave to my skin.
5 By reason of the expense of spirits, through my continual mourning day and
night, uttering my grief in groans and sighs for want of words, my nature is
totally impaired, and my flesh so wasted that my skin and bones are met, I am
become a very skelliton.

I am like a Pelican of the wilderness: I am like an Owl of the desert.
6 I am in a most solitary mournful condition, no representation in nature can
sufficiently depaint it, an exile, a bondslave. Chaldea and Assyria yield us as
much comfort, as if we were in a wilderness, our cohabitation with the
Babylonians is worse than the greatest solitariness upon earth, the mournful
Pelican and hated Owl, that therefore converse alone in desert places without
pity or society, so much as of one another, do best resemble us, for so are
we a banished and a scattered people in a far country, in an uncomfortable
unsociable state.

7 As my sorrow takes away my stomach, I watch, and an^ as a sparrow alone upon
the house top.
so also my sleep, and keeps me waking, so that I scarce take any rest, nor in
this disconsolation have I any to comfort me, but each of us are separated from
other, as a sparrow from his mate, lost to our country, and lost to one
another.

8 All the mischief our enemies can heap upon us by word or deed we are sure
of, Mine enemies reproach me all the day: and they that are mad against me, are
sworn against me.
they shamefully reproach us, and in us blaspheme thee, they are implacable and
outrageous against us, have sworn the destruction of us all, even of thy whole
Church sooner or later.

9 And they use us accordingly more like dogs than men, For I have eaten ashes
like bread, and mingled my drink with weeping.
exposing us to all manner of hardship through the extremity of our pressures,
and grief for them, forcing us to take no content in any thing, no not in our
ordinary repasts, our provisions being so bad and unsavorie, and our sorrows
making it worse than it is, feeding more upon sackcloth and ashes, weeping and
mourning, than either bread or drink.

10 And this, Because of thine indignation and thy wrath, for thou have lifted
me up and cast me down.
not so much for my sufferings though they be great, but for thy wrath and
indignation appearing in them and threatened by them, which is the more apparent
and the grievouser in this; that thou wast once so gracious and beneficial, the
memory whereof now aggravates our misery exceedingly, that thou should be
so changed, and enraged against a people so nearly related and dearly beloved
for whereas no nation flourished like us, we are now no more a people, but a
scattered vassalaged company of men and women, as if thou had raised us of
purpose to make our fall the greater, and made us therefore happy, that we
might become the more miserable, like a man that to break a thing in pieces,
lifts it on high with the greater violence to dash it against the ground.

My days are like a shadow that declineth: and I am withered like grass.
11 Thy poor Church, O Lord, whom I personate to thee, it is even at
sunsetting, it is but a shadow of a Church and people, no substance or Being
left, and that shadow too is extinguishing, it is expiring like the shadows
that toward sunsetting, now are, and anon are not, so soon as the sun is gone
down. Like the grass that is mown, withered with the sun and sapless, such are
thy people miserably parched with grief and sorrow, and utterly comfortless.

But thou, O Lord, shall endure for ever, and thy remembrance unto all
generations.
12 Thus it is with thy Church she is at last gasp, she has as it were received
the sentence of death in her self; But thou that art her God, her support and
strength can never die, nor she, as considered in thee, interessed in thy
faithfulness; though in outward appearance she be perishing, yet thy truth past
in promise to her, which is thy self, cannot fail, thou will certainly remember
to make it good to the uttermost period, even to the Worlds end shall it
endure, and therefore so shall thy Church, as low as it is brought at present.

Thou shall arise and have mercy upon Sion: for the time to favor her, yea,
the set time is come.
13 Therefore, Lord, though we seem to be dying, our faith begins to sprout, we
are in hope that these our greatest extremities are thine immediate
opportunities, and that as thou have lifted us up and cast us down, so now thou
casts us down to lift us up. Yea, we are very confident our sorrows are
shorter-lived than we, that we shall outlive them for all this, yea, we shall
see a speedy end of them, and that thou art even now about to show thy self for
us, and to restore thy Church, and in mercy pardon her sins which thou have
punished all this while, and suddenly ease her of her miseries which she has
so long undergone, and make Sion that was the glory of the whole earth
flourish again, for as thou art mindful of thy promise, so are we, that is
that livens our faith, and clears our heart, even the thought of the expiration
of the seventy years which is now drawing on, the time appointed, prophesied,
and promised by thee to end our captivity and restore us to mercy; which time
is now accomplished and revives our hopes.

14 For such is the love thy servants bear to thee, For thy servants take
pleasure in her stones, and favor the dust thereof.
thy worship, and the place appointed for it where thou have promised thy
presence, that it is not the devastations which before hand they know they
shall find there, that does any whit discourage them, no, they are joyed to
think that ever they shall set footing there, and see that sacred rubbish that
remains of that glorious fabric, what travel or pains so ever they undergo,
which they purpose to re-edifie.

15 When thou have thus wonderfully brought about our restoration after so
long captivity, So the heathen shall fear the name of the Lord: and all the
Kings of the earth thy glory.
and the re-edification of that thy ruinated Temple, what an amazement shall it
put the heathen into, how shall they admire thine omnipotency that thus raised
the dead, and saved us as a brand out of the fire. Yea, the Princes and
potentates of the whole earth, hearing shall be stricken with astonishment at
so glorious and Almighty a work.

When the Lord shall build Sion, he shall appear in his glory.
16 When the time comes which is now at hand, that both thy spiritual and local
Sion, O Lord, shall be restored and repaired by thee, thy worship and
worshippers in statu quo, O how glorious will thou then appear in the eyes of
Jews and Gentiles?

He shall regard the prayer of the destitute, and not despise their prayer.
17 And this be confident of, that as God at this time has extraordinarily
stirred up his people to hope, and pray to be delivered out of his destitute
condition, and made them more than ordinarily sensible of the loss of their
country and happy privileges they there enjoyed, and ardently desire to
return thither again, so will he effect it, and not let them lose their labor
and pray in vain.

This shall be written for the generation to come; and the people which shall
be created, shall praise the Lord.
18 This deliverance like that out of Egypt, shall be upon everlasting record
and renown for all posterity, and after-ages to admire, and be strengthened
thereby in the faith of Gods all-sufficiencie, truth, and grace. And those of
us that shall be gathered together again into the land of Judah in a formed
body, and an orderly way of worshipping the Lord, from out this confusion and
Chaos, where we are neither a people nor a Church, but a scattered mixture of
vagrant folk, O how shall we jointly praise the Lord, and his power that has
thus raised us from the grave, and as it were created us again out of the very
dust, nay, the nothing, whereinto we are resolved, as Christ shall his Church.

For he has looked down from the height of his sanctuary: from heaven did the
Lord behold the earth.
19 For from heaven which his sanctuary was wont to represent, has the Lord
heard and seen our moans and miseries, though he be there in unaccessable
glory and majesty, yet from that height has he vouchsafed to pity us here
below that are no better then the earth we tread on.

20 And to hear the groans we sent up to him in that sorrowful condition, To
hear the groaning of the prisoner, to loose those that are appointed to death.
and save the lives and restore the liberties of his people, a poor remainder
of them who were destined to death and destruction, as well as the rest that they
killed in hot blood, having sworn to root us all out, every mothers son, and
not leave us a name upon earth.

21 This shall the Lord do, To declare the name of the Lord in Sion: and his
praise in Jerusalem.
to the end his people so heard and so saved, may magnify the glorious power
and rich grace of God in Sion as aforetime, and praise him in Jerusalem his
royal City and place of special residence.

22 Which they shall do when they are embodied there again, When the people are
gathered together, and the Kingdoms to serve the Lord.
and reduced from that dissipation and confusion they now lie under, which
shall be a lively adumbration of the calling of the Gentiles, and the gathering
of Church and Kingdom from out the Kingdoms of the earth, every where to
believe in and and worship him, many whereof shall be won and induced to give
in their names unto him by that great deliverance, like as when that great
Jubilee and jail-delivery by Christ himself shall be, which is not far behind.

23 Long have we looked for his coming, He weakened my strength in the way; he
shortened my days.
and much has his people suffered in the profession of his truth, and for it,
in the interim, the whilst they have lived in expectation of that happiness,
even to the loss of many, yea, almost of all his whole Church here in Babylon,
(as must be the lot of the Church inhabitant in this world to suffer even death
it self in way to the end, the salvation of their souls.)

24 But I put my self before the Lord in the name of his faithful people, I
said, O my God, take me not away in the midst of my day:
and poor Church still remaining,

(...) The ciii. PSALM.
Bless the Lord, O my soul, and forget not all his benefits.
2 O thou soul of mine that art of such transcendent excellency to all
sublunarie created beings, and so adapted for to praise the Lord above them
all, do not thou bury thy talent in a napkin, nor steward it unseeming thy
trust, to whom he has committed such praise-worthie endowments, and on whom he
has bestowed such thank-worthie benefits natural and divine, which thou art
bound, no, never to forget, neither all nor any of them, but to sum them up in
thank-ful praises to his name.

Who forgiveth all thine iniquities, who heals all thy diseases.
3 Who has called thee to be faithful, and of his only good grace has freely
in the merits of his son forgiven thee all thy sins, justified thee from their
guilt, and pardoned their punishment, so that from an heir of hell thou art
translated to be an heir of heaven; And has also enabled thee by the spirit of
regeneration, to walk worthy so rich grace in mortifying thy lusts, and
raising thee to newness of life and conversation by his sanctifying quickening
graces bestowed upon thee.

Who redeemeth thy life from destruction: who crowns thee with loving
kindness and tender mercies.
4 Who to save thy life lost his own, gave it a price for thee, the virtue
whereof has influence every day and hour upon thee, (O my soul,) for every
trespass thou committest, dying virtually as often as thou sinnest, whereby thou
art kept from perishing everlastingly, as else thou had done, and would do
continually, and though the body wherein thou do officiate do die a
temporal death, and lie down in the grave as all men must, yet at that instant
shall thou be translated to live with him in Heaven, that died for thee on
earth, instead of being sent to Hell according to thy demerits; and at the
resurrection shall have a happy reunion with a glorified incorruptible body,
having honored and enriched thee here with the first fruits of glory,
pardoning, protecting, regenerating, justifying graces more than I can
enumerate, because of his love and mercy to thee, and for no cause else.

5 Who feasts thee with Spiritual and Heavenly dainties suting thy taste and
appetite, Who satisfies thy mouth with good things: so that thy youth is
renewed as the Eagles.
answers all thy prayers touching requisite graces and comforts, so that
whenever thy stock of either seems to be spent, thy graces enfeebled and thy
comforts exhausted, then at thy request comes God with sweet and seasonable
supplies, and makes them, and so thee that wast a dying, to live again,
vigorous and active like an eagle, that by casting her beak and feathers and
new-ones coming in their stead, resumes her former agilitie and strength till
then disabled; so is thy regenerate part, and sanctified habits by fresh
auxiliaries, and immediate breathings revived, when at a loss.

6 And not only in spiritual soul-desertions, The Lord executes righteousness
and judgment for all that are oppressed.
but also in external bodily afflictions does the Lord appear seasonably, for
when I was oppressed and opened my case to God, pleading mine innocence and
mine enemies injury, how did he judge my cause against them and upon them? and
so will he do for all his faithful upright innocent people in their wrongful
pressures, in a season most comfortable and profitable he will deliver them,
and judge their oppressors.

7 Witness his wonderful works of old in the deliverance of Israel out of
Egypt, He made known his ways unto Moses, his acts unto the children of Israel.
he did foretell to Moses what powerful and terrible judgments he would bring
upon the Egyptians, and how wonderfully in truth and righteousness he would
enfranchise his people, and what he said he did, all he told to Moses by
promise, he made it good by experience, in the sight of all the twelve tribes
Isreal's posterity, he faild not in a tittle, nor shall his Covenant of grace
made with our redeemer Christ touching his redeemed.

The Lord is merciful and gracious, slow to anger and plenteous in mercy.
8 And as the Lord betwixt man and man is pitiful to the oppressed, especially
to his Church, and terrible to their enemies. So is he also betwixt himself and
them a very graciously disposed God, in respect of the sins, and deserved
punishments of his people, as Israel well experimented all along the
wilderness, exceeding ready to show mercy, and to pardon sin and punishment
when it is petitioned for, not easily provoked, nor apt to anger, as they
found, and extreme ready to grant forgiveness of one sin after another; if the
sinner pray it uprightly God will grant it willingly, even the pardon of all
our sins, though both many and great, as theirs were.

He will not always chide: neither will he keep his anger for ever.
9 And when he does visit our sins upon us, for he will not always bear with
us, so nor then will he be always wroth against us, punish us he may, destroy
us he never will, no nor yet be always angry at us or frown upon us, his face
shall clear up, and his favor shine forth after a while, faithful prayer will
scatter those clouds.

He has not dealt with us after our sins, nor rewarded us according to our
iniquities.
10 We of all the World have cause to acknowledge him such an one, he has not
done by us as we have deserved, our experiences from time to time have made
good all his gracious properties, of grace, long-suffering, and plenteous
mercy, having ever been a God exceedingly bearing with us, and forbearing of
us though a provoking ungreatful people toward him.

11 For the immensity of his mercy is superlative to any natural comparison,
For as the heaven is high above the earth: so great is his mercy toward them
that fear him.
no dimensions can proportion it, the height of heaven above the earth does not
resemble it to us, such, and beyond it is his mercy in preterition and pardon
to his people that unfeinedly repent them of their sins, and with full purpose
of heart Covenant to fear and serve him.

12 Consider the heavens, either for height or wideness, As far as the East is
from the West, so far has he removes our transgressions from us.
and which you think is the greater for the help of your faith, conclude that
so great and greater is the mercy of God toward such as turn to him, and walk
with him sincerely. The East and West shall as soon come together as the sins
of such shall be laid to their charge how grievous so ever they have been, for
at a greater distance and disproportion has God sundred a penitent sinner, and
his sins even as far as infinite is from finite, Christ himself who is God
having taken them off of him, upon himself.

13 You that are earthly parents, Like as a father pitieth his children: so the
Lord pitieth them that fear him.
know what are the bowels of a father to a child, when with tears and prayers
it begs pardon for its offenses, such (for such comparisons we are fain to use
for the help of our natural apprehensions) and far greater are the earnings of
God, and his compassions toward those that in the faith of his mercy repent
of their transgressions, beg pardon of their punishments, and promise and
perform upright obedience.

14 For the Lord knows of what brickle matter we are made, For he knows our
frame, he remembers that we are dust.
he remembers how transitory our natures are, so that should he deal with us
after our sins, and would punish us according to our provocations, he would
have no people left on earth to serve him, or to carry on the existence, and
being of a Church, so that our frailty moved him to mercy, and not to do as
sin would have him, cut our short lives shorter.

As for man his days are as grass, as a flower of the field, so he flourishes.
15 Man being no better than grass, both sprung out of the earth, has a little
time of Being allotted him here, wherein he takes some contentment during part
of that little in his youthful season; as a flower that has its month to
spring, flourish, and decay in, so at best is man's condition by course of
nature, but besides that naturally he is so frail and momentany, he is subject
to be cut off by infinite accidents that his sins expose him to if God did not
guard him, as a field-flower that lies open to men and beasts, wind and
weather.

For the wind passes over it, and it is gone; and the place thereof shall know
it no more.
16 Subject to be despoiled of its beauty, and laid along by every blast that
blows, and as gay as it is, now appears, straightway it disappears, and is not,
and such is man.

But the mercy of the Lord is from everlasting to everlasting upon them that
fear him: and his righteousness unto childrens children.
17 But for all this that man is of himself thus subjected by sin to return to
dust and nothingness every moment, yet is the mercy of God long-lived, his
Church and faithful people, who shall never fail upon the face of the earth,
shall find that it shall never fail them, but they and theirs throughout all
generations that believe in him and filially fear him, shall have the benefit
of it, grace and protection.

To such as keep his Covenant: and to those that remember his commandments to
do them.
18 Even all in all ages that enter Covenant with God, and are careful and
conscionable in the keeping of it, by steadfast believing in him and exact
walking with him, in universal obedience to all his commandments, seasonably
and respectively calling to mind his will and their duty as occasion requires,
to do accordingly in all occurrences.

19 The glory of the Lord is most perspicuous in heaven where his throne of
dominion and rule is principally placed, The Lord has prepared his throne in
the heavens: and his Kingdom rules over all.
and he in his excellencies far more conspicuous there than the creature here,
does or can represent or demonstrate him, (being seen of us thereby as but
through a glass darkly) from whence yet he extends his Sovereigntie hither,
ordering and governing as well all things here as there, especially his Church,
and that for ever.

20 As the Lord appears most glorious in heaven, Bless the Lord, ye his angels
that excel in strength, that do his commandments, hearkening unto the voice of
his word.
so you his glorified angels that excel all other creatures in all manner of
excellencies, whose strength though derivative and created, yet exceeds all
humane power, yea, all humane imagination, who are as fellow creatures so
fellow servants with us, yielding obedience to his commandments as well as we,
and do his will revealed and commanded from his mouth, as we from his word, do
you I say with us and for us, bless the Lord, and praise him both in his
greatness and goodness.

21 You that are so many millions, Bless ye the Lord all ye his hosts, ye
ministers of his that do his pleasure.
waiting upon him and ministering at his pleasure what he commands, do you, even
that whole heavenly army of glorious and mighty angels, again and again bless
and praise him, that is as much above you in power and place as you are above
us.

22 And as his dominion is as well over the earth and all things there, Bless
the Lord all his works in all places of his dominion: bless the Lord, O my soul.
and in the firmament above the earth, as in heaven, so ought his praises to be
extended. Even every creature that he has made (for so far extends his
governance,) in all places, throughout all ages, ow him all the honor that in
their kinds, and after their created abilities they can do unto him. But
chiefly, O thou my soul, that art not only beholden to God for a created
being, but for redemption and salvation, which of free grace he has vouchsafed
thee, a mercy far exceeding all mere created bounty, do thou therefore above
all in heaven and earth, praise the Lord, and bless his holy name answerable to
thine engagements so far beyond theirs.

The civ. PSALM.
This Psalm as it is subsequent to the last, so it is coherent with it, made
doubtless by the same Author, the beginning and end of both being alike, and
the argument not unlike. The one treating of God as a gracious redeemer of his
Church and people, and the benefits that redownd thereby, the other as a
powerful Creator of all things, heavens, earth, seas and all things in them,
together with their orderly conservation and provident preservation. All which
things strikes the Psalmist into admiration, and puts him upon engagement to
constant meditation and praise, wishing none might live, Psalm civ.
that live not to the Lord in like sort.

BLess the Lord, O my soul, O Lord my God, thou art very great, thou art
clothed with honor and Majesty.
1 O Thou my soul, my best and principal part, praise thou the Lord, the Lord
Almighty which is the only true God whom I worship and serve, Thou, Lord, art
wonderfully great in power and dominion, the whole frame and order of nature in
the great work of creation show thee to be such, specially the heavens, (whose
situation is above as thou art,) which as in a mirror show forth thine
incomparable honor and Majesty in those glorious lights, which is the
visiblest representation of thee to our capacities, thy throne being there.

Who coverest thy self with light, as with a garment: who stretchest out the
heavens like a curtain.
2 Thou have spread the light over our heads throughout the aerie element, so
that it is filled therewith, and the Heavens where thou art, seem to be covered
thereby from our sight, who can only see on this side those supernal
luminaries. And as the light, so that vast expanse of heaven, thy Princely
pavilion is drawn between thine unaccessible Majesty and us, like the curtains
of a royal Tent.

3 Who, Who lays the beams of his chambers in the waters, who makes the
clouds his chariot, who walks upon the wings of the wind.
as he has laid the foundation of the earth, which is his footstool in the
depths of the sea, so has he laid the floor of his upper loft, the heavens
(where principally he resides as great men do above stairs) amongst the clouds
that spread like a sea far and wide over our heads, on which he seems to ride
as great men do in Chariots, directing the uncertain motions thereof hither and
thither, and so also disposes of the winds in their swift transition, and
sudden mutation, to go and do as pleases him.

4 Who therefore has made the glorious angels, Who makes his angels spirits,
his ministers a flaming ^ire.
those heavenly messengers of his, not of such natures as we sublunaries are,
but spirits, agil and active to come and go of his errands, and do his pleasure
here below instantly and effectually as far distant as it seems, making those
celestial ministers of his to execute his fiery indignation, either visibly
appearing as flames of fire as sometimes they have done, so the Israelites were
consumed in the wilderness, or invisibly destroying his enemies, but suddenly
and terribly like as fire devoures combustible matter.

5 Who also has by his transcendent supernatural wisdom so established the
earth upon its center, Who laid the foundations of the earth: that it should
not be removed for ever.
as a house upon a firm foundation, so that though it be pendent as a ball in
the air, and therefore seems nothing more moveable, yet indeed there is nothing
more immovable, all the winds and storms that overthrow other things that have
foundations, cannot stir this that has none, but from the first creation to
the uttermost dissolution of all things it shall continue firm.

Thou coveredst it with the deep as with a garment: the waters stood above the
mountains.
6 In the first creation thou did overflow all the earth, and encompassed it
with those waters that are now the sea, they then spread themselves over the
earth as a garment over a man's body so that no dry land appeared, the
mountains as well as the valleys were then under water.

At thy rebuke they fled: at the voice of thy thunder they hasted away.
7 Until thou wast pleased to command the contrary, and then when thou
preparedst that great Abyss to receive them that now contains them, and biddest
them contrary to their nature that would still be overflowing all, and
drowning the whole earth, to retire into it as into their mansion and place of
abode, they in reverence and obedience to thee, their Creator made have to
their confinement at thy appointment; Thy word of command pronounced with such
power and Majesty as if the heavens had thundered upon them, so awed them, that
it made them yield ready obedience, and give place to the surface of the earth
to appear above them, that ere while were so far above it.

They go up by the mountains: they go down by the valleys unto the place which
thou have founded for them.
8 But when as thy pleasure was otherwise made known, they in post have, break
through thick and thin, nothing could stay them, mountains could not dam them,
nor level and flat valleys hold them, from speeding their course to the place
thou had appointed for them, so effectual was thy command, that ascending and
descending, up-hill and down-hill was then alike easy to them, they could rest
no where till they were imbodied in the Abyss that thou createdst for them to
be their elemental place and station.

9 And as by the force and efficacy of thy command they were thus withdrawn
from overflowing the earth, Thou have set a bound that they may may not pass
over: that they turn not again to cover the earth.
into the depths prepared for them, and made to yield a ready obedience to it,
so by the same Almighty power, are they now kept in that station by no more
visibler bounds than the bare sands, that they cannot return to that universal
inundation, though by their mountainous waves and raging violence, they show
their propensitie and inclination, and that a supernatural power only
restrains them.

10 Which water he returns again amongst the hills and valleys, He sends the
springs into the valleys, which run among the hills.
not as it would by a deluge, but as he wills by an orderly and useful way of
springs and rivers, which though issuing from the salt sea, yet are so strained
through the veins of the earth, and thereby refined that they are made fresh,
and are refreshing to all creatures both in mountains and valleys, where they
spring up and run down.

11 To the satisfying of all sorts of beasts, They give drink to every beast of
the field: the wild asses quench their thirst.
where ever bred and fed by natures instinct, whether on hills or in dales,
those that are out of man's reach to provide for, and of themselves have no
forecast as other creatures have, yet does the Lord, out of his all-sufficient
storehouse, so dispose it, that they have no lack, but as he has ordained the
fields to give them meat even in the most desert places of the earth, where the
foot of man never trod, there also has he ordered nature to give them drink,
by springs and rivers rising and running here and there for the quenching of
their thirst, and maintaining the life that God has given them.

12 The fowls of the air resort thither also as well By them shall the fowls of
the heaven have their habitation, which sing among the branches.
as the beasts of the field, selecting by special instinct such places as are
well watered to be conversant in; building their nests, and chirping out their
notes in those trees that grow in and about them, being thereby maintained
fresh and green fittest for them.

He waters the hills from his chambers: the earth is satisfied with the fruit
of his works.
13, 14 And as thus he provides for one part of natures sustenance, the
quenching of thirst, so also for the satisfying of hunger, he as a faithful
and bountiful Creator and benefactour, He causes the grass to grow for the
cattle, and herb for the service of man: that he may bring forth food out of
the earth.
supplies the creature in both, and therefore waters the earth it self by
seasonable and plentiful showers, even the high hills and barren mountains have
the influences, and dew falls off the clouds from heaven upon them, to the
satisfying and quenching of their thirst too, so that thereby the earth is
every where made fruitful by the Lords thus husbanding of it, and caring for
it, and brings forth every creature in its kind, and according to the nature
thereof both grass and herbs for food for man and beast, as it was at first
appointed to do, which otherwise would be barren and fruitless.

And wine that makes glad the heart of man, and oil to make his face to shine:
and bread which strengthens man's heart.
15 Nor does the Lord cause the earth of it self only by his own husbandry to
bring forth mere necessaries to sustain nature, but also by his blessing upon
man's art and industry, makes it bring forth far better things than herbs,
which as they are of near affinity with grass, and appointed for the food of
man, to humble him into the apprehension of some kind of equality with the very
beasts, so to show his supremacy above them, he also has bountifully enriched
the earth for his sake with store of creatures of a higher kind, and of better
nutriment, and that not only to sustain, but delight nature in a lawful and
moderate sort, as wine to cheer the heart within, and strengthen the stomach;
oil and sweet ointments to fresh his countenance without, and refresh his
senses, and corn whereof bread is made, that staff of man's life, wherewith
above all it is supported.

16 What is there that has life, The trees of the Lord are full of sap: the
Cedars of Lebanon which he has planted.
that God does not provide for, or that can live without him of what kind
soever, whether they be creatures rational, as man, sensitive as beasts, or
vegetive, as herbs that grow upon the surface of the earth, or trees that lift
up their tops on high, they also wheresoever they are, take root by his
appointment, and grow up and increase to their height, breadth, and bigness by
the thriving moisture he affords them, watering the earth with showers which as
well gives sap sufficient for them, as for the meanest shrub or herb that
grows thereon. Those famous trees of Lebanon which exceed all others in the
world for height and growth, were such by his special blessing, being intended
and put to a special use, the building of the temple.

17 Them has he ordained to be a place of harbor and delight to the fowls of
the air, Where the birds make their nests: as for the stork, the fir-trees are
her house.
where they secretly make their nests out of harms way, each according to their
natural instinct, as the stork in the fir-trees, because the highest of all the
rest.

18 All things, The high hills are a refuge for the wild Goats: and the rocks
for the conies.
and all places have their use and property, and each creature its several
disposition, way, and means of life and preservation, as the high trees harbor
birds, so the high hills the wild goats, the unaccessible rocks they are not
uninhabited neither, the coneys climb them though other creatures cannot, and
so secure themselves, and there propagate their kind, by a natural instinct
given them of God, of self-preservation.

He appoints the moon for seasons: the sun knows his going down.
19 Nor are the earth and the things thereof only ordered by him, but the
heavens also and those glorious luminaries that so orderly succeed one another,
and measure out time into days, nights, months, years, yea, the several
seasons in each year, as summer, winter, spring, Autumn, all these are
regularly squared out of God, by the sun and moons vicissitudes, declensions*
altitudes, and augmentations.

Thou make darkness and it is night: wherein all the beasts of the forest do
creep forth.
20 And as thou have made the day and the light thereof, useful for some
creatures that converse more orderly and civilly than others, so again have
thou ordained the night and the darkness thereof, to be the time when beasts of
prey and rapine, take their turns, and come out of their dens and caves, by a
wise and gracious providence, awing their natures by the day light, that then
other creatures, as men and cattle, may with more security go about their
business and sustain their natures without hazard of their lives.
