pours contempt upon Princes, and causes them to wander in the wilderness,
where there is no way.
but Kings and Princes also are judged by him; If they forget their duties unto
him, he makes their people do the like to them, and casts their honor in the
dust at home and abroad, rendering them scornful and contemptible, and
intricates them into such Labyrinths of troubles, that all their policy and
King-craft cannot extricate them, or show them a way out.

Yet sets he the poor on high, and makes him families like a ^lock.
41 And as he pulls down unjust and wicked Princes from the top of honor and
voluptuousness into penury and disgrace, so on the other hand is he as mindful
to protect and deliver the poor oppressed people from under the inhumanity of
such tyrants when they cry to him, and makes them able to overtop their
oppressions and oppressors, by advancing them and abasing these, blessing them
with a numerous offspring, and making them able in a state of liberty and
freedom to spread forth their branches that ere-while were stocked by tyranny
and oppression, witness our condition under, and from under Pharaoh.

The righteous shall see it, and rejoice; and all iniquity shall stop her
mouth.
42 Those that have eyes in their heads, the godly-wise shall take notice of
such dispensations of justice and providence, respectively to good and bad, and
shall rejoice in confidence and hope of Gods goodness to them, and in the
goodness of their conscience and conversation toward him, when they see that
God takes notice of men and their manners, and that sooner or later he will
make it appear so, and as the good rejoice to see the reins of government in
Gods hand, so the wicked are sorry for it, and down in the mouth to see they
are under judicature, and not lawless as they hoped they had been.

Who so is wise, and will observe those things, even they shall understand the
loving kindness of the Lord.
43 Those whom God has endowed with grace and spiritual understanding (the
only true wisdom,) and will set themselves faithfully and heedfully to
consider and observe his judgments upon wicked oppressors, and his strange
providence in the behalf of the innocent and humble suppliant, to deliver,
bless, and prosper him, as he has done us: They shall experimentally perceive
the love and tender affection the Lord bears his people that sincerely serve
him, trust in him, and call upon him, and how safe and comfortable it is to do
so.

The cviii. PSALM.
A Psalm made by David, Psalm cviii. A Song, or Psalm of David.
to be sung and played by voices and instruments.

THis 108 Psalm is made up, O God my heart is fixed: I will sing and give
praise, even with my glory.
or composed of the two latter parts of two foregoing Psalms. Awake Psalterie
and harp, I my self will awake early.
viz. the 57. and 60. which being joined together upon the same, or like
occasion of success and victory do here make one entire Psalm. I will praise
thee O Lord: among the People: and I will sing praises unto thee among the
nations.


Therefore, For thy mercy is great above the heavens: and thy truth reaches
unto the clouds.
for these five first verses of this Psalm, Be thou exalted O God above the
heavens: and thy glory above all the earth.
see the Paraphrase upon the five last verses. viz. the 7, 8, 9, 10, 11. of the
57. Psalm, they being the same.

And for these eight That thy beloved may be delivered: save with thy right
hand and answer me.
last verses of this Psalm, God has spoken in his holiness: I will rejoice, I
will divide Sechem, and meet out the valley of Succoth.
see the Paraphrase upon Gilead is mine, Manasseh is mine: Ephraim also is the
strength of mine head, Judah is my lawgiver.
the eight last verses. Moab is my wash-pot, over Edom will I cast my shoe:
over Philistia will I triumph.
viz. the 5, Who will bring me into the strong city? who will lead me into
Edom.
6, 7, 8, 9, 10, Wilt not thou, O God, who have cast us off? and wilt not thou,
O God, go fo^th with our hosts?
11, 12. of the 60. Psalm, Give us help from trouble: for vain is the help of
man.
they also being the same. Through God we shall do valiantly: for he it is that
shall tread down our enemies.


The cix. PSALM.
David does promiscuously and prophetically in this Psalm treat of Christ and
himself. And though Saul, Doeg and Judas be eminently to be understood, one, or
all of them by the third person singular, in diverse verses; yet for most part
he intends thereby his enemies in the general, as they were united in
conspiracy against him, together with the nation of the Jews, embodied (as it
were) in one ^oint combination against Christ, as appears by the third person
plural, used in other verses, chiefly in the 20th, which is a summinarie, and
explanatorie conclusion to his foregoing maledictions, showing the persons he
meant them to, and for what. And so passes from his adversaries to himself,
where Christ is still here and there to be taken in. Praying as their
confusion, so his preservation, argued from Gods mercy, his own misery, and
the glory that God will get, and praises that he will give thereupon.

Psalm cix. To the chief musician A Psalm of David.
To him that is the first and principal of all the Quire, do I David, that made
this Psalm, recommend it for his care and ordering it to be sung.

HOld not thy thy peace, O God, of my praise.
1 O Lord, as I know thou art not regardless of my unjust calumniations, so I
pray thee make it appear upon my calumniators; let them find thou take notice
of the wrong they do me, O God, who has all my life long given me cause to
praise thee for thy goodness, and with whom I am well accepted, though of men
rejected, as the Messiah shall be.

For the mouth of the wicked and the mouth of the deceiptful are opened against
me: they have spoken against me with a lying tongue.
2 For such as make no conscience of what they say, and that studiously abuse
the ears of Saul whom they know hates me; they spare not to let fly aginst me
all manner of lies and slanders, to gain them his favor, and me his dis-favour.

They compassed me about also with words of hatred: and fought against me
without a cause.
3 They do me all the wrong they can, in word, or deed, reproching and
threatening me on all hands, as if they would eat me up alive, and causelessly
with open violence attempt to take away my life.

For my love, they are mine adv^rsaries: but I give my self unto prayer.
4, 5 Nay, I did not only walk inoffenssively toward them, but did them many
actual good offices, And they have rewarded me evil for good: and hatred for my
love.
and ever expressed my self a friend to them as occasion served, and the more I
have endeavored to express my love and loyalty, the more I am requited with
hatred and malignity, seeking my life that have saved theirs, as the Jews do
Christ's; but as he, so I, desire, nor seek not revenge, or like for like, as to
my self, but refer me and my cause to be judged by God, upon whose faith and
protection I cast my self, praying only deliverance from them, and that they
may be of better minds.

6 But in zeal to thee, Set thou a wicked man over him: and let Satan stand at
his right hand.
as they are enemies to thy Church and people, and forerunners of those that
shall betray, and murder the Messiah, and as a Prophet and public person, so
I wish that their deserts may over-take them; let them reap oppression as they
sow it; let those that hate and persecute me for thy sake, because I am thy
select and anointed servant, be as the Jews and Judas shall for betraying and
crucifying the Lord of life, how shall the one be captivated to the heathenish
Roman Empire, and the other exposed to Satan, that enemy of mankind to prevail
against him, and destroy him, even with his own very hands, by making away
himself?

7 Let them find such favor as shall Judas at the hands of the Chief-priests
and Elders upon his repentance, When he shall be judged, let him be condemned:
and let his prayer become sin.
even to be judged and condemned from his own confession out of his own mouth;
yea, both by God and man be unpitied and unpardoned.

8 Let them not live to the end of their lives, Let his days be few: and let
another take his office.
as they may be prolonged by nature, but cut short their days by some violent
and unnatural death, such as Judas shall die, and possess another more worthy
of their place and office, as Judas his Apostleship shall be transferred upon
Matthias, and the Jewish privileges translated to the Gentiles for crucifying
Christ.

Let his children be fatherless: and his wife a widow.
9 As the sin of my persecutour, and Christ's crucifiers, is communicative, and
tends to the destruction not of me only, but of Christ his Church and Spouse
also, so let their punishment be derivative, let their wives and children
become widows and fatherless by their untimely ends, pitied and relieved of
none, for that they oppress, and are merciless to the innocent and afflicted.

Let his children be continual vagabonds, and beg: let them seek their bread
also out of their desolate places.
10 Let my persecutours prosperity be hateful, as shall the Jews amongst all
nations; let them that have made me an exile out of my own Country, among the
heathen Idolaters, be themselves, and their children after them, no better, but
be like the wandering Jews, that when they have crucified the Lord of glory,
shall not be restored into Canaan as aforetime, (out of their captivities) but
be continual vagabonds, a dispersed people in all countries, glad to beg an
abiding place any where, being hateful every where, and driven so from place
to place, that very necessity shall enforce them to take up, and seek relief
in the most abject desolate places of the world, such as will scarce yield them
to keep life and soul, and glad they may.

Let the extortioner catch all that he has: and let the stranger spoil his
labor.
11, 12 Let them become a prey to all manner of men; let the griping usurious
extortioner, so entangle their estates in bonds and bills, and use upon use,
that they may never be able to come out of debt, Let there be none to extend
mercy unto him: neither let there be any to favor his fatherless children.
till the creditor seize on all they have, and turn them out of doors a
begging; let them find no manner of mercy, but be esteemed as enemies of
mankind; every where, where they are, let them be made a prey, counted for
intruders, and exposed to the spoil and rapine of the inhabitants, and natives
of all countries where they come, as a people not fit to be entertained any
where into scocietie and protection; both they and their children, though never
so fatherless, and destitute, let them be relict and deserted of all, according
to the curse of guiltless blood, which they brought upon them and theirs; so
let it be with them, and upon them.

13 Let my persecutours by the sword of thy justice, Let his posterity be cut
off, and in the generation following let their name be blotted out.
weilded in the hands of their enemies, be quite cut off; let them be destroyed
root and branch, so that after a while, no succession, or name of them may
remain, (though in, yet) not over Israel, but the rule thereof be utterly and
for ever trans-ferred from them to another, as shall befall the rebellious
Jews, Christ's persecutours, by the Romans, no name, nor place of any such
nation, (once so famous) shall remain, but be quite blotted out, a Lo-ammi or
vagabond people they shall be at best, and Christian, written in the room of it
in the next age of thy Church, which shall be among the Gentiles, to whom thou will trans-fer thy grace and favor for ever.

14 Let the persisting in the same sin of abrenunciation, Let the iniquity of
his fathers be remembered of the Lord: and let not the sin of his mother be
blotted out.
and blaspheming Christ by their scattered progeny, bring to remembrance the
guilt of all their stiff-necked predecessors transgressions, and rebellions
ever since they were a Church, espoused to thee their Lord and husband, the
punishment whereof was then sparingly inflicted by thee, but now upon divorce,
and putting away, let justice and judgment run down like a torrent upon them
without any mixture and stop of mercy.

Let them be before the Lord continually: that he may cut off the memory of
them, from the earth.
15 As the blood of Christ shall always appear before God, so let the sins of
them do that murtherously shed it, that as they would have destroyed the
Messiah, whom yet God raised again, so his vengeance may root out them, either
to have no being, or to be hateful and odious where ever they are.

Because that he remembered not to show mercy: but persecuted the poor and
needy man, that he might even slay the broken in heart.
16 Let such things befall mine enemies, whose mercilesness to me does in a
figure pourtray out the usage of Christ himself; for as they show me no more
mercy in misery, but are the more cruel and pitiless, by how much I am the
more miserable, and the more they see me implunged into distress, and
insupportable grief of body and mind, by so much the more eagerly lust they
after my life to take it away, thus shall it be with him, and so as aforesaid,
let it be with them.

As he loved cursing, so let it come unto him: as he delighted not in blessing
so let it be far from him.
17 Let the cursed calumnies and balsphemies, of mine and his enemies, wherein
they are so conversant, bring like evil upon their own heads, as they intend to
others; let their curses light upon themselves that refuse salvation and
blessing, and put it far from them when God graciously visites them with it,
renouncing me for their King, and Christ when he comes for their Savior.

As he clothed himself with cursing, like as with a garment: so let it come
into his bowels like water, and like oil into his bones.
18 Let such as take the curse, and bring the guilt of mine and Christ's
guiltless blood upon themselves, have enough for it, as they are ambitious to
be known to be his crucifiers, and my persecutours, and voluntarily involve
themselves into so great a sin, and the deadly consequences that attend it, by
acting the one, and laboring the other, so let it be unto them, let hardness
of heart, blindness of mind, and seared consciences, be the cursed product of
such wicked bloud-suckers.

19 Let the guilt and curse they so sinfully bring upn themselves, Let it be
unto him as the garment which covers him; and for a girdle wherewith he is
girded continually.
never depart from them, but stick by them, and accompany them in all places
and throughout all ages.

20 Let these foresaid maledictions be the judgment and reward of mine, Let
this be the reward of mine adversaries from the Lord, and of them that speak
evil against my soul.
and my Lord Christ's adversaries, who can right himself and me, though all men
join together to wrong us, and devise to take away both good name and life it
self, as mine enemies and his do endeavor, and shall in great measure effect;
but woe be to them by whom such offenses do come.

21 But Lord, But do thou for me, O God the Lord, for thy names sake: because
thy mercy is good, deliver thou me.
as much as others are against me, and mine Antitype, the Lord Christ; so thou
that art his God and father, and in him mine, be thou as much for me and him,
for thy covenant and righteousness sake, wherein and whereby thy grace and
faithfulness is engaged to approve thy self a merciful good God, protector of
the innocent, and deliverer of the oppressed, be thou so to me, let my
preservation and deliverance from mine enemies by thine Almighty power,
adumbrate Christ's powerful resurrection out of the grave, whence thou shall
raise him, and the Churches final deliverance out of all her terrestial
miseries by thy mercy, both whom I personate.

22 Let both thy mercy, For I am poor and needy: and mine heart is wounded
within me.
and my misery move thee, who am low brought by reason of outward afflictions,
and inward fears and terrors which affect me deeply, and distress me sore, as
Christ himself shall be with complicate evils, within and without, in soul and
body-sufferings.

I am gone like the shadow, when it declineth: I am tossed up and down as the
locust.
23 My life seems to me by reason of mine imminent dangers that threaten death
every moment, to be but as a shadow when the sun is setting, ready to
extinguish, and whilst I do live, I have no setlement, but am harrowed hither
and thither, from place to place, by the incessant persecutions and various
contrivances of mine enemies to take away my life, even as the grasshopper, that
never rests in a place, but by every blast of wind is driven to and fro.

My knees are weak through fasting: and my flesh fails of fatness.
24 My sorrows are so great, perils so many, and mind so restless, that through
voluntary abstinence, and involuntarie faintness, and decay of nature, I am
become stomackless and strengthless, my joints enfeebled, and my flesh
macerated.

I became also a reproach unto them: when they looked upon me, they shaked
their heads.
25 And this my misery was so far from moving mercy, or pity in my
persecutours, that they rejoiced to see it, and mocked at me, yea, and at thee
too for it, reviling me with taunting terms, saying in derision, Is this the
man that must be King of Israel? and in disdainful diffidence of any such
matter, wagging their heads at me, by that reproachful gesture, scornfully
concluding the contrary, like as they shall demean themselves to Christ
hanging upon the Cross, pass by him, look upon him, and in that dolorous
posture afford him no other pity then scornful nods, and bitter mocks.

Help me, O Lord my God: O save me according to thy mercy.
26 I am in a condition so desperate, hopeless, and friendless, that none but
thy self can or will stand me in any stead. But though it be so with me, yea,
if it were worse, if worse could be, I would not doubt either thy power, or
mercy, nor shall the badness of my condition overthrow my faith of relation,
but I still believe thee to be as my God, in Christ, so as able and gracious to
deliver me, as powerful and faithful to raise him, which I pray thee to do
for thy mercies sake in him.

27 That my wicked and ungodly enemies may by experience of thy just judgments
upon themselves, That they may know, that this is thy hand; that thou Lord have
done it.
and evident signs of favor unto me, know thou have done it for me, because
none but an Almighty power and goodness, could have effected it, as shall
appear to be in Christ his resurrection, and Jews dispersion.

28 Their cursed wishes, Let them curse, but bless thou: when they arise let
them be asham^d: but let thy servant rejoice.
false slanders, and wicked devices, Lord, frustrate them, nay, let them bring
forth quite contrary effects, the more ill they intend me, let the greater good
befall me, and let the evil befall themselves, let them do nothing that they
may have cause to brag of in the issue, when they are most confident, let them
be least successful in what they unjustly attempt, but let me have cause to
make my boasts of thee, and rejoice, when as they hang their heads for sorrow
and shame,

29 Let mine adversaries have no cause of insulting over me, Let mine
adversa^ies be clothed with shame: and let them cover themselves with their own
confusion, as with a mantle.
but be ashamed of all they have done, when they see that it is not against me,
but thee they did it, by the event; let them see what a fair thread they have
spun, that ends in nothing but shame and confusion, that that is the web they
have taken so much pains to weave for themselves all this while.

I will greatly praise the Lord with my mouth: yea, I will praise him among the
multitude.
30 When thou shall have so done, whereof I am most sure and certain, then will
I publish thy praises, and magnify thy mercies in the sight and hearing of all
thy people, by Sacrifices and Psalms.

For he shall stand at the right hand of the poor: to save him from those that
condemn his soul.
31 For all my sad condition, and the grievous plight I am in, yet it shall
appear God is not so far from me as they think for, but that he is at hand to
help, when his mine, and their time is come, spite of what they can do to
hinder; and notwithstanding their confidence because of their power, and my
poverty, yet he can, and will save me from those that in their own thoughts
have adjudged, and concluded me to death.

The cx. PSALM.
David that Kingly Prophet, and sweet singer, in this Psalm shows the glorious
exaltation of Christ in our nature at Gods right hand, there to rule as sole
sovereign, whence it shall come to pass, that by his divine spiritual
omnipotency, his Gospel shall be effectual to the creating this King, a
Kingdom of loving loyal subjects maugre all his and their enemies and opposers;
specially upon his first inthronization and royal nuptials; his Church shall
get ground spite of the devil, and all those earthly Potentates he s^ts on
work to hinder it. Such power has he by virtue of his Kingly office to protect
his people against men and devils, and of such ^fficacie is his Priesthood with
God, able to save his Church to the uttermost, ever living to make
propitiatory intercession for them in the heavens. And he concludes with
rendering the reason of all this his high esteem, and powerful prevailancie
with God, and power over angels and men, even because for the effecting of this
his Mediatourship and man's redemption, he shall drink of a full cup, the bitter
waters of affliction shall be poured out upon him, and wrung out to him with an
Almighty hand.

Psalm cx. A Psalm of David.
A Psalm which David made in the spirit of Prophecy.

THe Lord said unto my Lord, fit thou on my right hand until I make thine
enemies thy footstool.
1 GOd the Father in his eternal council and covenant, said to his son, who is
God and man, my Lord and Savior, (whose resurrection, ascension, and sitting
at Gods right hand in dominion and power, I shadow out in mine advancement from
my low and troublelous state, to the throne and scepter of Israel) for that
thou who art my fellow in the Godhead, have undertaken to do my whole will in
the Redemption of man, and condescended to take his nature the better to effect
it, and therein has effectually wrought it, by dying for sin, but being
without sin, has conquered death which could not hold thee, and art risen and
ascended into heaven. I give thee therefore, there all power and authority in
that very nature, to rule and exercise sovereign and supreme Jurisdiction over
the Church, which thou have purchased by thy blood, together with the empire,
and absolute dominion of all things else, for the Churches sake, whose King and
sole Mediator thou art; and this thy government, I give thee to execute in a
throne of majesty, equal with my self in the highest heavens, thence in thy
humane nature with divine power to dispense and transact all things belonging
to this thy Kingdom, whilst there is any Church, or that I have any people on
earth to be governed, officiated for by thee, even until I who am as solicitous
of thine honor as thou art of mine, by my power dispensed by thy self, shall
have subdued unto that thy humane nature (once so contemptible) all thine
enemies whether devils, men, or things, Jews or Gentiles, that shall oppose or
not submit to thy regiment; yea, death it self, or whatsoever shall impede the
completing of that glorious Kingdom of thy Mediatourship, in, for, and over
the Church, bone of thy bone, and flesh of thy flesh, until thou have fulfilled
her number, and safely brought the last man and member of that thy mystical
body to heaven, there in body and soul to be glorified with thee; till then I
say, shall this royal office of thine continue, whereof having then given me a
just account according to thy undertaking, and my covenant thou shall deliver
up the regal state and Kingdom of that thy Mediatour-ship in the humane nature,
into my hands as God alone, for ever after of my self in the divine nature,
only to govern that glorified Church, which by a mighty, and outstretched
arm thou have bought, and brought thither, there to remain in perfect happiness
with thee, and under me for ever.

The Lord ^shall send the rod of thy strength out of Sion: rule thou in the
midst of thine enemies.
2 The Lord Almighty, who is able to bring to pass great things by weak means,
shall raise up glorious lights in Jerusalem and Jurie, where thou first
manifests thy self, as Aopstles, Evangelist, etc. that shall give light to them
that sit in darkness, the glad tidings of the Gospel, which is the mighty
power of God to salvation, that rod of Moses to save Israel, shall by these his
emissareis be held forth and preached to the Gentiles, people of all nations
and languages, whereby they that now are foreigners shall be brought within
the pale, and shall take laws from thee, and be subjected to thee, O blessed
Savior, that art advanced in the humane nature (wherein thou sufferedst) in
such power and glory at the right hand of the most high God, there by his
appointment to sway the Scepter of thy Mediatorian Kingdom, by the power
whereof, the preaching of the Gospel, through the eternal spirit accompanying
it, shall maugre all opposition of Gentilism, who now are thy professed
enemies, and then shall strongly oppose thy Kingdom, prevail to set up thy
throne in the hearts of thy chosen all the world over, who shall every where
make glorious profession of thy name, and own thee for their Lord and King,
spite of all earthly opposing powers, and contemners of a crucified Savior,
who shall be no more able to hinder thy Church from flourishing, than thee from
rising out of the grave.

3 Those that are given to thee of God the Father, Thy people shall be willing
in the day of thy power, in the beauties of holiness from the womb of the
morning: thou have the dew of thy youth.
and redeemed by thee out of the world, when thou shall have offered thy self a
propitiatory, and taken possession of thy Kingdom at his right hand; through
thy mission of the spirit thence, and his mighty working by the word upon the
hearts of those thy people, they shall thick and threefold be converted,
neither the pravitie of their natures, nor their long accustomed Idolatries
shall obstruct their ready and cheerful compliance with the Gospel, but shall
willingly embrace the tender of grace, and come under thy governance in the
Church; which shall then so multiply as to assemble and conveen in all places
for the exercise of Christian religion, as thy people the Jews do at the
beautiful and holy Temple, (that type of Christ) in which Christian
Synagogues, especially in the first breaking forth of the light of the Gospel,
as the morning sun upon the face of the earth, shall be born unto thee out of
the then pregnant productive womb thereof, begotten by the holy Ghost in those
thy first loves and nuptial embraces of the Church, thy Spouse, immediately
upon thine ascension and investiture into glory, an offspring spread far and
wide upon the whole earth, as innumerable as the dew drops which insensibly
fall from the heavens, as the spirit shall then invisibly upon their hearts at
the preaching of the word.

The Lord has sworn, and will not repent: thou art a Priest for ever, after
the order of Melchisedeck.
4 For the great God of heaven by his everlasting decree, and immutable oath,
revealed for the consolation of his people, and corroboration of their faith,
has, never to revoke it, conferred upon thee their Mediator and Savior, the
honor and office of that everlasting Priesthood (not temporary, as the
Levitical, but) without change or succession, pourtraied in Melchisedeck. Yea,
to be a King and Priest in one person as he was, and none else; to typifie that
glorious privilege to belong to thee and none other; who therefore at thy
Fathers right hand for thy Church and people, transacts a royal Priesthood of
righteousness and peace according to the office, person, and name of
Melchisedeck, King of Salem.

The Lord at thy right hand shall strike through Kings in the day of his wrath.
5 The Lord, the God and Father, who only has the preheminencie of thee, as
thou have under him of of all things else, shall employ his power for the
advancement of thine honor, and revenge of thy dishonor, wrathfully
destroying Kings, Kingdoms that shall oppose themselves, and hinder the coming
of thy Kingdom in thy Churches growth and felicity, in the time when he thinks
fit to judge them for it.

He shall judge among the heathen, he shall fill the places with the dead
bodies: he shall wound the heads over many countries.
6 Thou who art paramount, the only He, or the promised Messiah, for the
Churhes comfort shall rule the world, the Gentiles shall be under his
Judicature, he will preserve his people that are converted to him, and profess
his name every where among the heathen, taking vengeance on their enemies, whom
he shall remarkably destroy, as he was wont to do the enemies of Israel. The
earthly Potentates of the world, shall find him to be above them; if they
bruise his heel, afflict his people, (as they will in all places) he will
bruise their heads, their greatness shall not privilege them at all.

7 If you will know the reason of this high preferment of Christ in our nature
at Gods right hand, He shall drink of the brook in the way: therefore shall he
lift up the head.
and of the power and head-ship he has there, it is because he shall drink
deep of the wrath of the Almighty, streamed down upon him in the way thereunto,
and for the obtaining thereof, by suffering a cursed death upon the Cross, with
bodily torments, and unutterable soul-agonies, the unavoidable means of
effecting his Mediatour-ship, and man's redemption; therefore shall he upon that
full and faithful discharge of his office here upon earth, ascend unto, and
sit for ever at the right hand of his Father which is in heaven, to act there
the glorified part thereof, in full power^, and absolute dominion over all
there and here, Angels and men, Jews and Gentiles, friends and foes.

The cxi. PSALM.
The Psalmist first gives the word, and then the example for praising the Lord,
which he tells us Gods works gives us cause enough to do, if we consider them
well; especially to his Church, supplying them in their need, possessing them
of the promised land, fulfilling his promises of grace to them, and for their
sakes his judgments (threatened) upon their enemies, for which he looks his
commandments should be respected, which are as binding to us, as his covenant
to him; and through grace his covenant is as binding to him, as they are to us.
Therefore he shows a man is never wise, (pretend what he will) till he have
gotten God upon this lock, to be his, by being Gods in faith and obedience. And
concludes as he begun, with invitation to praise him. Psalm cxi.


PRraise ye the Lord, I will praise the Lord with my whole heart: in the
assembly of the upright, and in the congregation.
1 LEt all of us be diligent and cordial in praising the Lord. I will not be
wanting on my part, and in mine own example herein, for he shall have the
heartiest thanks that I can give him, both in lesser meetings of entire
Israelites, that voluntarily, and frequently assemble themselves to perform
such holy exercises, as also in those more solemn, rare, and mixed
congregations that at times appointed assemble themselves at thy Sanctuary.

The works of the Lord are great: sought out of all them that have pleasure
therein.
2 Greatly does the Lord appear in his wondrous works of Creation, Providence,
and Redemption; his manifold attributes are made manifest therein, yet not to
all, but only to those that in love to God, love to busy their minds in the
practical contemplation of him, in them, that they may affect their hearts
toward him with suitable frame of thankfulness and praise, for the greatness
and goodness they are sensible of thereby.

His work is honorable and glorious: and his righteousness endures for ever.
3 All that he has done declares him to be for honor and power,
incomprehensible, nor shall one word fail of all that he has spoken concerning
what he will do, his Prophesies and promises; yea, and his threatenings too,
are as sure to be fulfilled as those which are already.

He has made his wonderful works to be remembered: the Lord is gracious and
full of compassion.
4 The Lord has done such memorable and admirable things for his Church in all
ages, as are never to be forgotten, but with praise and thanksgiving to be had
in everlasting remembrance, his grace in choosing, and compassion in relieving
and pardoning his people, is worthy our best observation and memory.

5 He has provided for his Church all along the Series of their successions,
He has given meat unto them that fear him: he will ever be mindful of his
covenant.
and in all their peregrinations, so that when in humble and faithful
addresses, they that feared him at any time sought unto him, they had supply of
needful mercies, both for themselves and others, that though they were of the
visible Church, yet did not so well deserve at his hands, their sins and
murmurings being enough to have made God unchurch them, but that he was
mindful of his covenant made with our forefathers, Patriarchs, and Prophets,
Types of Christ* not to do it; of which, as then he was, so still he is and
ever will be mindful, to be as good as his word in sparing and pardoning his
people, and blessing and preserving them, when in fear of him, and in the faith
of his covenant, they in humble-wise seek his favor toward them.

6 He made manifest enough his exceeding great power in those miraculous
victories he gave his people Israel over the Cananites, He has showed his
people the power of his works, that he may give them the heritage of the
heathen.
when they entered the promised land, which had been long possessed and
inhabited by those heathenish Idolaters, whom the Lord rooted out, to establish
them in it.

7 The things he has wrought have not only been Acts of power, The works of
his hands are verity and judgment; all his commandments are sure.
but also of Truth and Justice, his promises as well as his power have been
written in legible Caracters in those his wonderful dispensations to and for
his Church, as also his righteous judgments long before threatened to such
wicked wretches, and as his works have approved the faithfulness and
infallibility of his promises and comminations, so that other part of his word,
the Law of Commandments, a safe rule to walk by, is likewise as firm, God looks
they shall be obeyed by his people as certainly, and undispensably, as he gives
them leave to expect his promises and threats to be fullfilled by him for them.

They stand fast for ever and ever, and are done in truth and uprig^tness.
8 Both the one and the other, his word and works, commands and providence as
to his Churches preserving and governing, are built upon a firm foundation, the
good pleasure and free grace of God according to his word and covenant, and as
inseparable companions go together, God is good, and does good to those that
are good and keep his commandments, and ever will be so, his truth and
faithfulness binds him to be so, and to do so to such as in truth and
uprightness serve him.

He sent redemption unto his people, he has commanded his covenant for ever:
holy and reverend is his name.
9 The Lord from time to time when his people were in jeopardy or the thraldom
for their sins, if they cried unto him, and humbled themselves before him, he
delivered them, he has established his covenant of free grace as firm as any
Law, and has bound himself by the one as firmly, as us by the other, so that
his people shall ever find him to be the same unchangeable God for their good,
always provided they walk worthy of him, and becomingly toward him, in
reverence of his Majesty and obedience to his holiness.

10 A man that has never so much worldly wisdom, The fear of the Lord is the
beginning of wisdom, a good understanding have all they that do his
commandments; his praise endures for ever.
and lives in sin, is for all that, all that while but a fool, till in the
faithful application of Gods saving goodness, he be an altered man, and
fearing to offend him, is careful in all things to please him, then and never
till then he begins to be wise, with that which is true wisdom, for only they
have a right understanding both of the chiefest good, and their chiefest end
(what is best for themselves, and why they were made) that fulfill the will of
God their Creator, living thereafter, for therein is great reward. As his
mercy and faithfulness is and ever shall be firm to his faithful and obedient
people and Church in her preservation, and her enemies confusion, so ought to
be his praises as long and large as his benefits, which shall have no end.

The cxii. PSALM.
The Psalmist stirrs up the people of the Lord in works to praise him, the
benefit whereof will be theirs, their persons and posterities will be blessed
by it, in woe as well as in weal will God graciously visit such. He shows, a
charitable minded man is much set by of God, and by faith and a good conscience
in the worst of times, enjoys himself happily spite of those that malign him,
his liberal giving to the poor shall enrich him, when as the covetous wretch
for all his carking and caring shall suffer want, and envy his abundance. Psalm
cxii.


1 LEt the Lord have his due praises, PRaise ye the Lord. Blessed is the man
that fears the Lord, that delights greatly in his commandments.
for his great deservings and admirable excellencies that appear to be in him,
by what we see done by him, and that not only vocal but real, for he
principally praises him, and is certainly blessed of him, that with a filial
fear dares not offend him, and with a faith working by love is careful in all
things to please and obey him, whose happiness is holiness, and sin his
greatest affliction.

His seed shall be mighty upon earth: the generation of the upright shall be
blessed.
2 Nor will God determine his blessings upon himself, but extend them further
even to his posterity walking in his ways, witness our forefather Abraham, how
did the Lord multiply his seed according as he promised, and like blessings
has he in store for faithful Abraham's faithful offspring, who walking as he
did with an upright heart before God in perfect obedience, shall be as he was,
blessed in their own persons and posterities.

Wealth and riches shall be in his house: and his righteousness endures
forever.
3 God will both increase his family, and provide well for it, whereof our
times, and the times of our forefathers and Scripture-records have given good
testimony. He and his shall reap the benefit of his and their righteousness by
a Series of blessings, successively transferred by virtue of the covenant made
to him and them for many generations.

Unto the upright there arises light in the darkness: he is gracious, and full
of compassion, and righteous.
4 And though God does not always bless him that is of an upright heart, and
righteous conversation with external affluence; for his dispensations, though
agreeable to wisdom and justice, are various; yet this, such an one may be sure
of, that he shall find God most trusty in his greatest trialls, and no such
cloud of tribulation shall ever over-shadow him, but the sun of righteousness
shall shine through it upon his soul, with healing consolations in his wings;
for God whatsoever he may seem to be by his outward dispensations, is in his
native disposition very gracious and tenderly affected toward such, and just
to fulfill his goodness promised them, in one kind or other, but especially in
spirit.

5 The worldly minded man thinks he is happy and rich in laying up, A good man
shows favor and lends; he will guide his affairs with discretion.
but the good and godly differ from him, for they think themselves happy and
enriched by laying out, knowing, that as God favors them with blessings of
this life, so they ought to show favor unto others that want them, as
stewards, not owners of that they have; And therefore he that out of the love
he bears to God, loves his brother also, will not stick upon occasion to show
his love by his lending, yea, his care shall be so to walk as to credit his
profession, more than to benefit himself, to get and spend neither sinfully nor
profusely, but with a good conscience, and in an orderly sort, so that thereby
what he has may be blessed, and he made able to lend and not to borrow, and to
his power to supply others that by providence are enforced to borrow, and
cannot lend like himself.

6 Surely how ever the world think their liberality and charity is the next way
to beggary, Surely he shall not be moved for ever: the righteous shall be in
everlasting remembrance.
because Mammon is their God, yet it shall be otherwise with him, that in the
faith of God with godly wisdom expends what he has in pious uses, he shall
never be ashamed for so doing, though the world count it folly, he shall find
it both wisdom and providence so to do, he and his estate shall be upheld, when
many of those miserly diffidents, shall fall and come to lack, for God will
never forget to reward and be favorable to those, that in conscience and love
to him have laid out their store upon his that wanted.

7 Such an one shall have such provision laid up in God, He shall not be afraid
of evil tidings: his heart is fixed, trusting in the Lord.
and be so secure in him, as that he shall not fear the changes of times, nor
hazards and losses approaching, as they shall, that have much wealth and are
little conversant in faith and charity, who are ready to make away themselves
upon the very report of such things, having an evil conscience.

His heart is established, he shall not be afraid, until he see his desire
upon his enemies.
8 Though because he is good, therefore he may have many enemies as commonly it
falls out, yet shall he not care nor fear the worst they can do unto him,
having God and a good conscience to take his part and side with him, he shall
be as well satisfied and firmly persuaded of mercy to him, and judgments upon
them, as if he saw them already executed.

He has dispersed, he has given to the poor; his righteousness endures for
ever; his horn shall be exhalted with honor.
9 He has not hoarded up his pelf, but has scattered it here and there, by
lending and giving it amongst the poor as he saw them to want, like as seed is
cast into the ground, of which he shall reap the blessing. The righteous man
shall gather the fruit of his charity and beneficence, it shall follow him into
heaven, to be rewarded there, yea, and here also, God shall manifest his good
acceptance of his pious liberality, by blessing and prospering him both in his
estate and estimation.

The wicked shall see it and be grieved, he shall gnash with his teeth, and
melt away: the desire of the wicked shall perish.
10 So that the wicked covetous wretch shall to his grief behold himself
out-stript, his wisdom befooled by that which he counted foolishness, and the
highway to beggary, he shall be ready to eat his own flesh for envy at the
prosperity and increase of the righteous, the whilst his substance melts away,
and wastes insensibly like snow before the sun, notwithstanding his pains and
care to get and keep, his hopes and desires shall fail him, he shall attain
neither riches nor honor.

The cxiii. PSALM.
The Psalmist invites to the praises of God, specially his servants, and that
in all ages and places, both for his transcendent greatness, and for his no
less goodness, which his dispensations make to appear very remarkably, for
which again he excites them unto praises. Psalm cxiii.


1 LEt not the manifestations of God his power and goodness, PRaise ye the
Lord, praise O ye servants of the Lord, praise the name of the Lord.
in his works of creation and salvation be buried in ignorance and silence, but
take faithful notice of them, and give him grateful praises for them; it may
be the blind world neither will nor can, but you his sanctified and redeemed
ones, that profess to serve him, and not to be of the world, though in it,
specially ye Levites chosen by himself to that office, do you make it your
employment. Let him in his greatness and goodness be magnified by all that
serve him either by office or calling, whether Levites in letter or spirit,
praise ye the Lord.

2, 3 As largely as the power, Blessed be the name of the Lord, from this time
forth and for evermor^
wisdom, and goodness of God is declared for time and place, so let the
praisefull acknowledgements of him and them be extended in like sort, From the
(...) the sun unto the (...) down of the (...) the Lords name is (...) be
praised.
let none in no ages nor regions of the world, that have eyes in their heads
and tongues in their mouths be silent, but bless and praise him always in all
places as he well deserves.

4 The Empire of the whole world is the Lords, The Lord is high above all
nations, and his glory above the heavens.
he is King of Kings and Lord of Lords, his dominion is over all the earth, but
his throne in the glorious splendor of it is more, especially in the heaven of
heavens, where in brightness he exceeds the sun, which as it is under him
(though above us) so it is short of him, who from the highest top of Majesty and
Honor commands and orders all things, the heavens and the earth, which are as
far beneath him in glory, as in situation.

Who is like unto the Lord our God, who dwells on high?
5, 6 Who is like unto the Lord for greatness, that has his throne higher than
not only we can see, Who humbles himself to behold the things that are in
heaven, and in the earth?
but conceive* heaven that is so far above us, is under him, and the great men
of the earth, who in comparison of the vulgar are called Gods, are as far below
him as above them; Yet this God of greatness out of no less goodness, daineth
himself to be ours, and his Churches God, though but a parcel of people
compared to the world; whom yet he owns for his subjects and favorites, even
he to whom it is an abasing, considering the superlativeness of glory, that he
the Creator has above all creatures whatsoever, to condescend by way of rule
and governance to take notice of the things that are, and are done on earth,
nay, and in heaven also, so far are all below him that are made by him, and so
absolute and perfect is he in and of himself, from whom all things are, and to
whom nothing adds, neither Angels nor men.

He raises up the poor out of the dust, and lifts the needy out of the
dunghill:
7, 8 Yet does he agitate affairs here below, and dispose of his creatures as
best pleases him, and is most for his glory, That he may set him with Princes,
even with the Princes of his people.
many times raising men from an abject low estate and great poverty to honor
and opulency, yea, from the very lowest stair to the highest step of fortune,
as David from the sheepfolds to be King over his people Israel instead of Saul.

9 And in like sort by his Almighty power and good will he opens the womb that
was shut, He makes the barren woman to keep house, and to be a joyful mother
of children: praise ye the Lord.
and causes her that was in despair of having children by being long without,
to conceive, turns the grief of her barrenness into a joyful fruitfulness,
making her dry breasts give suck, and she to be mother and nurse of many
children. Take ye notice of these his greatness, goodness, and wonderful
dispensations to praise him for them, and the excellencies that shine forth in
them.

The cxiv. PSALM.
The Psalmist records a narrative of the rev^rend apprehension which the
senseless elements of earth and water had, at the Majesty and presence of the
Lord, when he went along with his people Israel from Egypt to Canaan, to
instruct them much more to do so, and wishes the earth it self would still
convince them of their duty when they neglect it, and are mindless of his
fore-past wondrous providence. Psalm cxiv.


1 WHen by the wonderful working of God the children of Israel went out of
Egypt, WHen Israel went out of Egypt, the house of Jacob, from a people of a
strange language.
entirely the whole twelve Tribes according to the families of Jacobs sonns,
when they I say were so marvellously rescued out of their long and grievous
captivity under the Egyptians, a people that ruled over them, as men rule over
beasts, rather by blows than words, being of strange language and estranged
affections, pitiless toward them;

2 The posterity of Israel were then the people of all the world he made choice
of, Judah was his sanctuary and Israel his dominion.
declaratively by signs and wonders to be their God and King, and that his
presence was as really and eminently amongst them, as ever after it was in the
most glorious times of the Church, when his sanctuary (the token of his
residence) was situate in Jerusalem Judahs lot, and the thrones of David and
Solomon were there erected.

The sea saw it, and fled; Jordan was d^iven back.
3 The red sea above its nature was made sensible of the power and presence of
the Lord with his people, insomuch as it reverently and submittingly withdrew
it self out of its place to make way for him and them to pass through, so
likewise did Jordan at their entrance into Canaan stop his course, and divide
his waves for the Ark (the pledge of God) and his people to pass through his
Channel.

The mountains skipped like ram^, and the little hills like lambs.
4 The famous mountain Sinai in the wilderness, when God to give his Law to his
people descended down upon it, the whole mount as great and ponderous as it
was, quaked greatly, and all those contiguous hills bordering upon it did the
like, so that by their motion they seemed rather to be sensible and living
creatures, than clods of earth.

What ailed thee, O thou sea, that thou fleddest? thou Jordan, that thou wast
driven back?
5, 6 O ye elements of earth and water, that by nature are without sense and
motion, saving to your center, what therefore was the cause that at those times
the sea and Jordan of themselves against nature, Ye mountains, that ye skipped
like rams, and ye little hills like lambs?
and no Art of man concurring did so withdraw. And that mount Sinai with the
adjacent hills so strangely moved and stirred like living creatures, was it
natural or supernatural? Why, the God of nature appeared and inspired them
above their natures, to teach his people the reverence and fear they should
conceive, when they draw nigh to him as he then did to them.

7 O the Majesty and terror of the Lord our God whose sanctuary and presence
is among us, Tremble thou earth at the presence of the Lord: at the presence of
the God of Jacob.
how ought it to affect us, that thus affected the senceless elements? still O
earth do thou instruct us, show us that holy fear and reverence, we that are
Isreal's offspring ought to perform to Jacobs God, when we forget it, by
trembling now as then at the representation and manifestation of himself.

8 Mind us of those miracles he wrought for our forefathers in the wilderness,
Which turned the rock into a standing water, the flint into a fountain of
waters.
the faith and usefulness whereof ought not to be let slip, with what Almighty
power he provided for them in their need, causing the dry and hard rocks
miraculously to supply so many hundred thousand men and cattle with plenty of
water.

The cxv. PSALM.
In some extremity or captivity by or under the heathen, as that of Babylon or
Antiochus, etc. This Psalm was made; wherein the Psalmist by an argument of
concession, taking their deliverance for granted, first makes his onset upon
God, and then by interrogation enforced from the heathen blasphemy, and his
peoples fidelity in him, and scorn of all Gods besides him, and God-makers:
Then comes to exhort Israel though low brought, to trust firmly in God for
better, which be enforces by an argument of Gods unchangeableness to his
Church; and the absolute necessity thereof, for if his Church perish, his
praise perishes, and then all things come to nothing. Psalm cxv.


NOt unto us, O Lord, not unto us, but unto thy name give glory, for thy mercy,
and for thy truths sake.
1 O Lord, when thou shall (as we know thou will) have delivered us out of this
miserable condition, we promise before hand, we will not rob thee of thy glory,
it shall be no merit nor motive out of thy self that shall cause it, thy power
and goodness, thy mercy and faithfulness must be it must do it, and when it is
done they alone shall wear it, we will acknowledge and ascribe it to nothing
else but thee, our great and gracious redeemer.

Wherefore should the heathen say, where (...) now their God?
2 What ever our demerits are, yet be more mindful of thine own honor than (by
our destruction and captivation, that declaratively are thy people above all
the world, and so taken notice of by the heathen) to expose thy self to their
scorn and obloquy, and to give them thereby occasion to insult blasphemously
over thy power and faithfulness, our trust and confidence, as if our profession
and thy promises were mere delusions; and that thou can not help us, or have
quite rejected us.

But our God is in the heavens, he has done whatsoever he pleased.
3 This, Lord, as to them will be the issue, though neither their Blasphemy nor
our misery shall abate of our faith and acknowledgement of thee, both to be our
God in covenant and adoption, and the sole God that in heaven art glorious, and
from thence rulest all things, and orderest all dispensations here on earth, so
that nothing befalls us thy people by any humane power that thou could not
have hindered if thou would, it is thou that have set them on work thus to
do by us in justice for our sins, else a hair of our heads could not have
perished by them.

4 It is not their Gods, Their Idols are silver and gold, the work of men's
hands.
but our own God that is able to do us harm, for they are but Idols at the
best, made of Gold and Silver, nor are they so much as their own makers, but
have their being from men, that have their being from thee, they make them that
made not themselves, and therefore must they needs be goodly Gods:

5 That are utterly liveless, They have mouths but they speak not: eyes have
they but they see not.
bare Statues and resemblances, for man's workmanship can go no further, he
cannot give life, and consequently neither sense nor motion, and therefore
though they have the fashion of a mouth, yet are they speechless, having
neither Soul nor Organs to animate and enable them, and so they have the
fashion of eyes as well as man can imitate, but are as blind as Beetles.

6 Likewise they have the similitude of ears, They have ears but they hear not:
noses have they but they smell not.
but are as deaf as doore-nails, and of noses, but smell neither sweet nor
sour.

7 They have very artificial hands, They have hands but they handle not: feet
have they but they walk not, neither speak they through their throat.
but can do nothing with them, and fashionable feet, but can neither go nor
stand, but as they are otherwise upheld, and their neck serves merely to hold
their heads on their shoulders, but is of no Organicall use at all for speech,
etc.

8 And they that make them are as void of true understanding, They that make
them are like unto them: so is every one: that trusts in them.
as they of sense, that can so against the light of reason think such things
fit to be worshipped which they make, and which made not them, and that when
they are made are but inanimate statues, short of all living creatures even the
meanest, and what must they then be that put confidence of good or evil in
such, but irrational senceless people, and as little able to do good or hurt as
they, saving thou the only living God orders and appoints them.

O Israel, trust thou in the Lord: he is thy help and thy shield.
9 O ye sonns of Israel your fathers, with whom and his seed God made an
everlasting covenant, whatever befall you, let not an evil heart of unbelief to
depart from the living God, to dumb and deaf Idols, possess you, as he has
peculiarly chosen and adopted you for his people from out all the world, so do
you him for your God, from all other Gods, trust in him, rely upon him for
your sole helper and defendour against these Idols and Idol worshippers, which
can do you just so much hurt as he for your sins permits them, and no more.

O house of Aaron, trust in the Lord, he is their help and their shield.
10 O ye Priests and Levites that are the successors and assistants of
faithful Aaron in that high office of Preist-hood, and more immediate
worshippers of the high God within his holy Temple, do you exemplarily declare
your faith of and in the Lord alone that has so highly honored you above your
brethren, that he is of power all-sufficient, and faithful of his word and
promise to protect and restore his people, and you, to their places and your
employments.

Ye that fear the Lord, trust in the Lord: he is their help and their shield.
11 But chiefly you that are nearer and dearer to God than any external
adoption or office can make men, you that are Israelites indeed, spiritual
Priests and Levites, the adopted and called of the Lord, that have the spirit
of reverence and godly fear in you, do you, as I hope you will not fail to do,
trust assuredly in God, for he is your help and shield against worse enemies
than these that can but destroy the body, and that do but serve to typifie the
power that our ghostly enemies have over us by sin, as these for sin, and
Gods greater power to deliver us from them, as from these, which he will
certainly do.

12 No doubt is to be made of it, The Lord has been mindful of us, he will
bless us, he will bless the house of Israel, he will bless the house of Aaron.
but that as God has done, so he will do, exercise mercy in deliverance, as
well as justice in afflicting us, if we seek to him, and that he see us
mindful of him, he will be so of us, as ever heretofore in like case, to ours
now he was wont to be, Israel and the Priesthood is still dear to him for old
love to our forefathers and the covenant he made with them, and for Aaron his
servants sake that Preistly type of our powerful Mediator, and therefore will
he certainly bless us with joyful deliverance and restoration.

13 Yea, He will bless them that fear the Lord, both small and great.
for his covenant sake he will bless Israel and Aaron according to the letter,
but thank them for it that amongst you are so in the spirit, with whom properly
and principally that covenant is made, these, of what outward condition soever,
high or low are dear to God, whom he will certainly bless and the rest for
their sakes.

14 You are the men that have the promise of this life and of a better, The
Lord shall increase you more and more, you and your children.
as you are the blessed seed of blessed Abraham, in whom his name is upheld,
because his faith is inherited by you, so shall the Lord raise you up faithful
successors, a more numerous offspring than ever yet his Church produced, from
generation to generation shall the faithful, your heirs and successors,
flourish and multiply.

You are blessed of the Lord, which made heaven and earth.
15 As you are the promised seed, so are you heirs of the blessed promise. He
that by his Almighty power made the heavens and the earth, is your God, and for
your sakes made he them, and with both heavenly and earthly blessings will he
bless you.

The heaven, even the heavens are the Lords: but the earth has he given to the
children of men.
16 The Lord made both and governs both, but so that heaven, the heaven of
heavens which is superlative to all the rest, is the more immediate place of
his glorious residence and inhabitancy, and the earth of man's, which he has
bountifully furnished with all needful things for his sustentation and
existence there.

The dead praise not the Lord, neither any that go down into silence.
17 And why has the Lord done so, lent me life and livelihood here below, but
that they should employ their time and improve those blessings to the praises
of him in the highest, for its true, that God made the earth and all things in
it for man, but he made man for himself for his praise and glory, who yet
praise him not, but serve other Gods, all the world but we, so that if we
should perish that are his only Church on earth, the praises of the Lord would
cease upon it, which must not be; whilst it is to have a being, he is to have
a people that shall glorify him.

But we will bless the Lord, from this time forth and for evermore; Praise the
Lord.
18 Therefore O Israel, O house of Aaron, and especially ye that fear the Lord,
trust in the Lord that he will be your help and shield, for the Lord will not
unchurch himself, no nor us neither, we are the people (though unworthy) that
his name is and shall be named upon, chosen out of all the earth, so that how
ever we are at the graves mouth, yet deliverance will come, and we shall be
restored, else nature must be dissolved, which cannot be, considering what
promises are yet to be fulfilled. Therefore be confident in hope, and in the
faith hereof engage our selves for future, when God shall so bless us, that we
will answerably bless and praise him, yea, in full assurance let us begin at
present, and be doing in that duty now as well as hereafter, that the Lord may
see the useful existence of a Church for ever on earth, for that they always,
and they only praise him. What ever your condition be then, though it were
worse than it is, which at present is bad enough, be sure to praise the Lord,
for which you live, and have your Beings, and in you all the world, which else
should cease.

The cxvi. PSALM.
David being possessed of the Kingdom according to promise, looks behind him to
see the difficulties God carried him through, to mind himself to his mercies,
and his own engagements for them. And in the first place offers the Lord his
affections, promises him his faith for future, because of what is past, and
therefore excites his soul to comfortable confidence and peaceable
acquiescence, together with a gratuitous walking with God, recalling his offs
and ons, he is in an ecstasy, how to return to God that brought him out of
them, and resolves to celebrate his praises in the most public and solemn
manner according to the prescript of the Law. Assuring all Gods people from his
example, that in their greatest danger, God has the greatest care. Magnifies
the Lord that has made him his servant and freeman, for which he will
publicly praise him.

1 I Cannot express how much the Lord is endeared to me for the grace he has
vouchsafed me, I Love the Lord, because he has heard my voice, and my
supplications.
my heart is glued to him in affection, such love has he showed to me, and
such care over me in all mine extremities, whenever I minded him of me and
craved his help, that I am bound to love him as long as I live, and from my
very heart I do so.

Because he has inclined his ear unto me, therefore will I call upon him as
long as I live.
2 The Lord has got my custom, I have had such faithful and good dealing from
him, as if my condition were never so bad, I would seek no where else, for
always when necessity wrung me I cried, and when ever I cried the Lord heard
and helped; and this course I am resolved still to take, whenever I have
occasion, and doubt not of the same success.

The sorrows of death compassed me, and the pains of hellgate hold upon me, I
found trouble and sorrow.
3 I cannot but recount my bygone difficulties, how that many a time I gave my
self unavoidably for a dead man, so near have I been to mine end in mine own
apprehension, that I made full account of my grave, the very pangs of death
have seized on my soul, and it was seldom other with me.

Then called I upon the name of the Lord; O Lord, I beseech thee, deliver my
Soul.
4 Yet though my danger and fear was never so great, so that in all humane
probability and visibilitie of means I was as good as gone, yet my faith would
still have a saying to God, pray I must, and did, and I no sooner gave the word
but God took the Alarm, if I but named my Soul, it was enough, and oft-times my
surprises were so sudden, and danger so emergent, that I had scarce time to do
that, which though they made my prayer short, yet sharp, they helped to put an
edge upon mine affections, and when I prayed for my soul, it was with my soul,
which in an ejaculation was quickly in heaven, and had as quick dispatch there.

5 For there had I the attributes of God presently to speak for me, Gracious is
the Lord, and righteous^ yea, our God is merciful.
his grace, justice, and mercy, and had an answer accordingly: Let others be
encouraged by mine example to trust in the Lord, and seek to him, for they
shall find as I did, that God is freely good, and free of his goodness,
faithful of his promise, yea, though objections lie in the way, thy sins and
his judgments flash in thy face, yet be not daunted if thou be one of us,
belongest to God; for he is merciful to pardon and pity thee, and in an
instant will break through all to do the good.

6 Those that suffer being innocent, The Lord preserves the simple: I was
brought low and he helped me.
although they be shiftless and have not worldly wisdom to do withal like
other men, yet if with honest hearts they bequeath themselves to God, and
unfainedly trust in him, he will find ways to befool their enemies, and make
good their confidence, I am sure none can be in greater danger, nor have less
hope of help (but from him) than I a poor innocent man, and more than once or
twice, and he alone served my turn, I never miscarried, but was ever delivered
though many times strangely, yea, miraculously from time to time, till he
brought me to this I am come to.

7 Be thou therefore at peace within thy self, Return unto thy rest, O my soul,
for the Lord has dealt bountifully with thee.
and recumbent upon God, O my soul, that has by his means gone through so many
difficulties, and through him thy benefactour art arrived at so great
happiness, out of all the storm that have blown over thee.

8 For the Lord has as it were raised me out of the grave, For thou have
delivered my soul from death, mine eyes from tears, and my feet from falling.
so near death was I many a time when thou delivered me, and has now made me a
livesman again, in the full accomplishment of thy promise, whereby I am
comforted beyond all my fore-past sorrows, which are as it were forgotten, and
set me free from all those deadly traps and gins that were laid for me, by my
mortal enemies.

I will walk before the Lord in the land of the living.
9 Now that God by his power and mercy has raised me to this estate, and
brought me through those many perplexities to possess his promise, I doubt not
of his further favor and protection, but in confidence thereof, I will
comfortably and conscionably labor to discharge my place and high office, as
in the presence, and to the well-pleasing of the Lord that has set me over his
people, compared to whom, all the world is in darkness and shadow of death.

I believed, therefore have I spoken: I was greatly afflicted.
10, 11 O the several frames of heart and tempers of soul that I have passed
through in my trials, sometimes chearing up my self with the faith of Gods
promises, I said in my have, All men are liars.
that they should certainly be fulfilled, and then could I hopefully address my
self to God, and comfortably bespeak and encourage my soul to wait upon the
Lord, at another time I have been as much dejected and cast down, and upon a
surprise when my fear has been great, because my danger was imminent, I have
not stuck in that perplexity of mind to think and say within my self, all that
the Prophets had foretold concerning my succession to the Kingdom was a mere
delusion, and that I must needs perish before that day could come, that they
and their predictions would certainly deceive me and come to naught, and that
they speak not of God, but of themselves.

What shall I render unto the Lord for all his benefits toward me?
12 Now when I look back and consider what a world of dangers, nay, deaths I
have past, what dismal apprehensions and perplexities of mind I have waded
through, what admirable deliverances the Lord has wrought, and how often and how
strangely I have been preserved, and now what an absolute complement he has
given to all those promises which I thought never to have seen fulfilled, and
conclusion to my miseries, which many time I thought would have made an end of
me, before I should thus have seen an end of them. I am at a stand, and in an
ecstasy, how, and what to return to this good God, I am now in perplexity by a
plenitude of happiness, for the Lord has so laden me with benefits that I
know not what to say, nor do, to, or for him in any proportion to them.

13, I will take the cup of salvation, and call upon the name of the Lord.
14 I may fancy many ways, and things to my self to gratify God with all,
and when I have done I am never the near, I will pay my vows unto the Lord, now
in the presence of all his people.
for imaginary retributions and will worship he will not accept. Therefore I
will content my self to do what he has bid me, (for when I have all done I
must live and die his debtor,) I will therefore make a feast to all Israel, (
which he did at the bringing up of the Ark,) and then and there offer my
peace offerings, and in the sight and hearing of all the Lords people, with the
cup of blessing and gratulation in mine hand, will joyfully and thankfully
publish the praises of my God, and make open acknowledgement of the manifold
benefits and deliverances from first to last that I have been partaker of; The
mercies I gained by prayers and vows in mine extremity, I will wear them by
praise and sacrifice now in my prosperity, all Israel shall be witness.

15 I have found it by experience, Precious in the sight of the Lord is the
death of his saints.
and speak it knowingly for the comfortable support of other of Gods people in
affliction, that however they may unadvisedly misjudge themselves, as exposed
of God in a regardless manner to the malice and fury of their enemies, when
their lives are endangered, yet its far otherwise. The Lord makes more account
of the lives of his holy ones, which he will suffer no man nor men on earth to
have the command and dispose of, but only himself, they are too precious to be
set so light by, and therefore be confident such cannot miscarrie by any
policy, power, or malice of men whatsoever, but by special commission from
God, for special purposes, and when they do miscarrie by his ordination, they
still remain dear to him as well dead as alive.

Oh Lord, truly I am thy servant, I am thy servant, and the son of thy
handmaid: thou have loosed my bonds.
16 Blessed Lord, I now well perceive those words true which sometime I thought
to be false, how that thou have indeed ordained me to the honor to be thy
servant, and that in an eminent manner, which truly is my highest title, and
preferment to be thy servant, and the son of thy spouse and handmaid the
Church, visible and invisible; and thus to be delivered by thee from a state of
thraldom and misery, to a condition free to serve thee, is infinite goodness.

I will offer to thee the sacrifice of thanksgiving, and will call upon the
name of the Lord.
17 For which I will magnify thee, and with public praises and peace offerings
will make my thankful acknowledgements of thy power and goodness to me-ward.

I will pay my vows unto the Lord, now in the presence of all his people.
18 And what I vowed in my misery, when I prayed for mercy, I will accordingly
perform it, now that thou have set me free to do it, all Israel being witness.

In the courts of the Lords house, in the midst of thee, O Jerusalem, praise
y^ the Lord.
19 Openly, in the public convention of all thy people at thy sanctuary in
Jerusalem, the place appointed for thy solemn sacrifice-worship, there upon
thine Altar will I offer my sacrifice of thanksgiving in the view of all
Israel, and in their hearing, praise thee; with me praise ye the Lord all his
people.

The cxvii. PSALM.
The Psalmist in Prophecy of the calling of the Gentiles, and uniting all in
one Church through the head Christ, exhorts all to praise the Lord for so great
goodness, and rich mercy so freely extended. Psalm cxvii.


1 O All ye nations and people throughout the world, O Praise the Lord, all ye
nations: praise him, all ye people.
Gentiles as well as Jews, praise the Lord, praise him every where without
exception.

2 For his saving grace and mercy by the redemption of Christ is extended unto
both, For his merciful kindness is great toward us: and the truth of the Lord
endures for ever: praise ye the Lord.
in him we are made one Church that were a divided people, and an undeserving,
the one as well as the other, his grace alike free and his goodness great to
both of us: For, for his promise sake once delivered, and never to be reversed,
has he done this for us, and as well all other promises as this will he
perform to the end, for and concerning his Church, his faithfulness cannot
fail, though our sins deserves it should. Therefore in the faith of his
faithfulness and love of his goodness that has made all partake of Christ, let
all men praise the Lord.

The cxviii. PSALM.
David seated in the throne quickens up the people and Priests of the Lord unto
thanksgiving for his endless mercies to his Church, as himself in the behalf
thereof, which he personated had experimented, whereby his faith was raised to
an holy insultation over his enemies for the future. Further shows the
happiness that God has brought to his Church by the change of him for Saul,
and the glory he has got to himself, which for his part he ingageth himself
to celebrate solemnly in his sanctuary, which upon this occasion both he and
the rest of the righteous will, now they may, frequent. There he will praise
him for making him as in humiliation so in exal^ation the type of Christ.
Prays for the Churches happiness upon this wonderful change, pronounces
certainty of blessing to himself and Christ, in the office and errand God sets
them in, and sends them about. Concludes with the manifold hearby praises of
God both from himself and the people, whom he exhorts always to be praise-ful
as God is gra^iously faithful. Psalm cxviii.


O Give thanks unto the Lord, for he is good: because his mercy endures for
ever.
1 LEt us be mindful of the goodness of God to be thankful for it, whose mercy
to his Church and faithful people never failed, nor never shall.

Let Israel now say, that his mercy endures for ever.
2 Let his adopted people, now in this their flourishing condition, give him the
glory of those many mercies which ever since they were known by, the name of
Israel they have successively in all ages partaked of.

Let the house of Aaron now say, that his mercy endures for ever.
3 Let the Priests, and Levites their adjutants, that occupy Aarons place and
office in the sanctuary, now that they are reduced into such a form and model
as never before of worshipping the Lord, acknowledge his mercy, and the
succession of it to them according to promise from their first progenitors.

Let them now that fear the Lord say, that his mercy endures for ever.
4 Yea, let those that are Gods Priests and people indeed, that believe and obey
him, say now if God be not as good as his word in showing mercy to his Church;
those I mean that fear his name.

5 I have had my share of sufferings in which I personate the Church, I called
upon the Lord in distress: the Lord answered me, and set me in a large place.
and yet I can say, and do, that his mercy endures for ever, and so shall she
in all ages, for when ever the Lord put me to it, and that I was distressed, I
put him to it, in humble wise I minded him of his promise, and this way my
constant custom, and so it was his, ever when I did so to deliver me all along,
till now that he has set me quite at liberty from my troubles, and enlarged
my happiness as you see.

6 I have had such experience of the Lords being for me against mine enemies,
The Lord is on my side, I will not f^ar: what can man do unto me?
that however I look never to be without, yet that shall not trouble me,
neither their power nor their plots, for he that could deliver me then, can and
will much more protect and prosper me, now that he has brought me to this
estate.

7 I have ever found it, The Lord takes my part with them that help me:
therefore shall I see my desire upon them that hate me.
and doubt not but I ever shall, that God blesses me and those that side with
me, many or few, with good success, which makes me confident that as I have
had, so I shall ever have the better of mine enemies, what, or how many soever
they be, and in stead of ruining me, I shall ruin them.

8, It is better to trust in the Lord, than to put confidence in man.
9 I have found it better, and so shall who ever tries it, to put confidence in
God than men, of what number or degree soever, It is better to trust in the
Lord, than to put confidence in Prince^.
and mine enemies have found the contrary, for by that means I a despicable
lone man am preserved and exalted, and they for all their honor, and power
above me are destroyed by his Allmighty hand so much above them.

10, All nations compassed me about: but in the name of the Lord will I destroy
them.
11, 12 I have been as the Church always shall be, the mark that all men have
shot at, I had all the world against me, and none for me but God, his power
was, They compassed me about, yea, they compassed me about: but in the name of
the Lord I will destroy them.
is, and ever shall be my sole trust and confidence, O with what deadly hatred
from time to time have I been hunted, and how many times has my life been
endangered that I could see no way to escape, They compassed me about like
bees, they are quenched as the fire of thorns: for in the name of the Lord I
will destroy them.
and yet I have escaped, God has always preserved me, and in stead of mine
enemies destroying me, he has destroyed them, and I am confident I must, and
shall ever do so, God inabling me as he has done, I have been as hard beset as
a man that has a swarm of bees about his ears, not knowing 'ith world how to
avoid them, ready to fall upon me on every hand with deadly devouring hatred,
which though it was very terrible for the time, yet the Lord put an end to it,
made their malice to me the destruction of themselves like thorns consumed in
their own flame, and so shall he ever enable me against all mine enemies I am
confident, and that they shall never have better success.

Thou have thrust sore at me, that I might fall; but the Lord helped me.
13 Mine utter ruin, as an obstruction to this preferment has been strongly
endeavored by him that had no small power in his hands, nor small malice
toward me, but God has both preserved me, and advanced me, maugre all that
Saul could do and all his accomplices.

The Lord is my strength and song: and is become my saltion.
14 The Lord alone was my defense, and the ruiner of mine enemies, who else had
ruined me a thousand times over, the glory and praise belongs to him, and he
shall have it, who has perfected his promise, given me final deliverance from
all those troubles, and seated me above the reach of those mine enemies.

The voice of rejoicing and salvation is in the Tabernacles of the righteous:
the right hand of the Lord does valiantly.
