15 What cause of rejoicing has God given to the families in Israel that fear
the Lord? how glad are they to see this day, and such a change of things? I and
they so preserved and delivered from the malice of those, that hated and sought
the ruin of goodness and good-men, and now to see them conquered and quite
subdued, and that by so apparent providence and Almighty power, must needs
rejoice them greatly.

16 It is he that deserves, The right hand of the Lord is exalted: the right
hand of the Lord does valiantly.
and I hope shall accordingly have the honor of it, who by his sole power and
victorious providence has mightily effected it.

17 As near as I have been to destruction many and many a time, I shall not die
but live, and declare the works of the Lord.
and as hopeful as mine enemies were of it, so that both they and I my self
have given me for a gone man, yet God has purposed otherwise, die I must not,
and therefore die I did not, but am alive at this day, and in a good condition,
preserved purposely of God, by example and acknowledgement to manifest and
magnify what he has done for me, and what he can and will do for his Church,
whose person I bare, and represented in all my troubles and enfranchisements.

18 The Lord gave mine enemies much power over me, The Lord has chastened me
sore: but he has not given me over unto death.
so that I under-went sore trials, and sad chastisements to teach me to know my
self and sin, but though he gave them liberty to afflict me, yet not to destroy
me, as they hoped to have done, but maugre their malice has preserved my life,
though often endangered.

19 O ye that are the porters and door-keepers of the Lords holy sanctuary,
Open to me the gates of righteousness: I will go in to them; and I will praise
the Lord.
a place of late years disfrequented and sequestered from good and righteous
men, that properly have only right and title to it, Now by Gods good
providence the case is well altered, I and other such as I am, that with
upright hearts desire to serve the Lord, have liberty and opportunity to do it,
therefore set the doors of the courts of the Tabernacle wide open for us, that
I and they may comfortably come and worship the righteous Lord, there specially
present, and give him the due praises of all his faithful performances, of
those his gracious promises touching me, and his Church in my time.

This gate of the Lord, into which the righteous shall enter.
20 I mean I say the gate of the Lords own Tabernacle, where he is so peculiarly
resident, and will therefore there be especially worshipped, set that open for
me and all my fellow-saints and servants of God, who as of right they ought, so
now I have power they shall have free access unto it, having been too long
secluded.

I will praise thee, for thou have heard me, and art become my salvation.
21 Lord my heart is full, and there I am purposed to empty it upon thee in most
affectionate thanks and praises, for thine often audiences, gracious and
effectual answers, and principally for this complement of all thy promises, in
saving me from mine enemies, and advancing me to the Kingdom so far above their
power to hurt me.

The stone which the builders refused, is become the head stone of the corner.
22 Insomuch as now I, who heretofore was, by Saul and his Grandees, those great
Artificers of State, hatefully persecuted and disdainfully rejected, as
unworthy and unfit for this preferment, like a refuse stone that is broken and
cast out of the way by master-workmen, as altogether useless and unserviceable
for building, and as the Messiah (whom I prefigure) shall be by Cajaphas with
his confederates the chief Priests and Scribes, those ringleaders of the Jews
who shall despightfully use him and cruelly crucify him. I say, I, that was
thus refused am advanced from this my despicable condition, to fit in the
throne and wield the Scepter of Israel, upon whom under God, the Government and
welfare of Church and Commonwealth principally depends, even as it shall be
with Christ, (whom both in weal and woe I typifie) he shall rise again from the
dead, and be gloriously advanced even in his humane nature, so much contemned
and hardly used, to be Savior, Mediator, and King of and over the Church,
consisting then of Jews and Gentiles united in him, and supported by him,
maugre her enemies, as the sides and weight of a building are by a principal
binding corner stone, against all blasts.

23 This strange transversion of a persecuted abject to become a King, This is
the Lords doing, and it is mavelous in our eyes.
and a contemned, condemned, crucified man to be the sole Savior and Monarch
of the world, is by the holy and wise ordination and effectual operation of God
brought to pass, both which are worth our wonder and admiration, to see
persecution produce dignity, and death life and glory.

24 This day of mine inthronization resembling that of Christ's resurrection,
This is the day which the Lord has made, we will rejoice and be glad in it.
and glorious exaltation at his fathers right hand, is the time and means
whereby God has and will make good all his promises of grace and happiness to
his Church, who lives therefore that has the faith and acknowledge of these
things, and joys not that he has lived to so happy an hour, as to see them
thus fulfilled?

25 O Lord, Save now, I beseech thee, O Lord: O Lord, I beseech thee send now
prosperity.
its a day indeed, that thy Church has cause to be glad of, and so she is, and
prays thee to add to her joys, and that now from henceforth all those blessed
promises of happiness to thy King and people may be effectual, and they
prosperous.

26 As Christ himself who is the Messiah, Blessed be he that comes in the name
of the Lord: we have blessed you out of the house of the Lord.
and sent of God for the good and salvation of his people is blessed, and
diffuseth blessings to his people, whom they again that are his Priests, and
the living Temples of the living God do gratify with the return of blessings
in behalf of his Kingdom, praying the increase and consummation of it, and
offering the sacrifice of praise to him, that by Gods gracious emission came to
offer himself in sacrifice for them. So let David the anointed of the Lord, for
the good and welfare of his Church, and to be a type of Christ, be blessed in
his own person, and a means of much blessing unto Israel, and blessed of them
again with a prayer and praise to God for him and his Government. Yea, let the
Priests of the Lord that wait upon the Altar, whose office by the Lords special
appointment it is to bless his people, discharge their sacred function in
performance of that holy action, from out that sacred place (where they
immediately attend the Lords service) upon David and his people the figure of
Christ and his Church, and let him and them be blessed accordingly, both of
Priests and people that worship within or without, in the Courts of the
sanctuary of the Lord.

God is the Lord, which has showed us light, bind the sacrifice with cords,
even* unto the horns of the Altar.
27 God has approved himself to be the Lord omnipotent, for that he has
brought us out of a miserable estate, void of temporal, but especially
spiritual felicity, having of late nothing but confusion amongst us in Church
and Kingdom, and reduced us to a comfortable condition in both, principally in
the enjoyment of the Doctrine and ordinances of his saving truth and holy
worship, which by David and Christ that blessed type and Antytipe are made to
shine forth upon the Church and people of God, after the dark times of Saul's
reign and Gentilism, like as the sun comforts and lightens all creatures, when
the darkness is past, for which unspeakable and unvaluable mercy, let us
therefore bring those offerings and sacrifices the Law appoints, accompanied
with sincere and hearty praise and thanks-givings before him, and tie them with
cords ready for their oblation, and that in abundance, answerable to his
benefits, and for the larger expression of our praises, in proportion to those
Holocausts of Hallelujahs that shall be offered under Christ's regiment. Let the
people by their frank and liberal offerings find the Priests store of work in
their sacrificing employment at the Altar.

28 For my part I am resolved to lead the way by mine example, Thou art my God
and I will praise thee: thou art my God, I will exalt thee.
unto thy praising and magnifying, and I confess cause I have to do so, if I
consider how much thou have done for me, and how thou have made choice of me to
this place, and office of honor and service.

29 As I begun, O give thanks unto the Lord, for he is good: for his mercy
endures for ever.
so I conclude with hearty advice and instigation, to be mindful of, and
thankful for the goodness of God, whose mercy to his Church and faithful
people never failed, nor never shall.

The cxix. PSALM.
This Psalm by the Author of it (which some say, and by many circumstances
probably was David, in his flight and exile) is divided into 22 parts,
according to the number and order of letters in the Hebrew Alphabet, each part
containing eight verses, and the first word of every verse in each part
beginning with the same letter that is prefixet to the part it self, as it is
in order and succession in the Hebrew A. B. C. which its conceived was done for
help of memory. The Psalm is without title, and for the matter of it, drives
on no one particular subject, but partly by the Psalmists own example, and
partly by rule is represented what is requisite to enter a man into, and carry
him through a holy life, specially in an afflicted state; which are
promiscuously scattered throughout the Psalm, promises, precepts, documents,
prayers being variously intermingled, and to be taken notice of accordingly by
the Reader as they happen in his way, as also the Authors exalting Gods grace
and decrying self in his own person, a president for all, and a confutation of
all self-opinionists or justiciaries, whether Papists, Armenians, in judgment,
or practice, m^n morally righteous, or carnally confident, Israelitish
Christians which worship God, but not in the spirit, and rejoice but not in
Christ Jesus, having confidence in the flesh, contrary to Paul Phil. 3.3. and
David throughout this Psalm.

Aleph.
Aleph. Is the first letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, and is therefore here
according to order prefixed to the first part of this Psalm, to signify that
it is so, and so do all the rest of the Letters in their rank and order, as
they are prefixed to each part, signify alike numerarie orderly succession of
the rest of the parts of this Psalm, for instance, The second letter Beth
signifies that to be the second part, and the third letter the third part, and
so of the rest.
BLessed are the undefiled in the way, who walk in the Law of the Lord.
1 ALl men would be blessed, but certainly happy, and only happy is, here,
and shall be hereafter, that man, that seeks not after a sensual sinful
felicity as most do, but on the contrary throughout the whole course and
trade of his life, approves himself as one that walks toward heaven in heavens
way, in conscience to God, avoiding the spots and stains of every sin in heart
and life, that may render him unpleasing or unsightly with God, and strives to
walk exactly in holy obedience to all his commandments to his well-pleasing,

Blessed are they that keep his testimonies, and that seek him with the whole
heart.
2 Yea, they only do and shall partake of true happiness (peace of conscience
and favor with God) which deviate not into by-ways of their own fancying, but
keep constant to an obediential walking with him, according to the rules he in
his word has prescribed and commanded, and that set so high a rate upon his
grace and favor, as to overvalue it to all other happiness, and therefore
pray for it as their chiefest good, and strive to walk worthy of it in all
well-pleasing, with sincere and entire obedience.

3 Nor dare they transgress or willingly contract the least guilt of any known
sin upon themselves, They also do no iniquity: they walk in his ways.
out of a filial fear of displeasing God, and forfeiting his favor, but
carefully tread his paths, which only lead to life and true happiness, and
bring with them sweet peace of conscience and seals of sincerity.

4 And if it be asked what is the cause of the blessed man's exact walking, Thou
have commanded us to keep thy precepts diligently.
and not taking the liberty that others do to sin, it is because he prefers
Gods will before his own, because the holy God strictly commands holiness,
therefore is he strict in observance to do thereafter, to keep all, and break
none of his commandments.

5 Lord, O that my waye^ were directed to keep thy statutes.
let other men take other courses, my prayer is and ever shall be, that I may
be so happy as to be enabled by thee to walk in well-pleasing to thee all my
days, and in all my ways, according to the rule of righteousness.

6 Others think shame of holiness, Then shall I not be ashamed, when I have
respect to all thy commandments.
but I count it my glory, yea, the more holiness the less shame, to come short
of duty and sincerity is only shame-worthy; make me therefore in sincerity of
heart, and integrity of life, to do thy whole will with my whole heart, and
then (and never but then) am I as I would be, because then and only then I am
as I ought to be, able to look God and man in the face, free from an evil
conscience.

7 Truly, I will praise thee with uprightness of heart, when I shall have
learned thy righteous judgments.
Lord, if I know mine own heart, and I take it to be upright toward thee,
there is nothing that thou can give me or do for me, shall better please me,
and more oblige me to praise and thank thee with an honest gratuitous heart and
conversation, than thy teaching of me by thy word and spirit, to know and do
thy commandments, the only righteous rule of faith and manners.

I will keep thy statutes; O forsake me not utterly.
8 O Lord, my purpose of heart is to keep thy commandments, and to walk exactly,
in faith, love, and obedience, as thou enjoynest, but alas, I know mine own
imbecility, and the necessity of thy continual inablement hereunto by thy
spirit and grace, which if withdrawn, I am at a loss, therefore, Lord, in pity
of my weakness, and in prosecution of the good work begun in me, that desire to
fear thy name, leave me not to my self, nor lead me not into temptation, to
buckle with it in mine own strength; let no sin cause separation, though
correction, but remember mercy, and renew in me a right spirit when I do go
wrong, as who does not.

Beth.
Beth. The second letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the second part.
Wherewithal shall a young man cleanse his way? by taking heed thereto
according to thy word
9 Young men are aptest to go astray, and therefore had need to be inquisitive
and circumspect of themselves, and their ways, how to avoid the pollutions of
mind and manners, whereunto their age prompts them, with a more than ordinary
aptitude, and doubtless, (I speak it knowingly) the only remedy for such
distemperature, is, for them to be conversant in thy word, and thence to
observe with a childlike disposition, what pleases and displeases thee, their
heavenly father, and in conscience thereunto, carefully to regulate their
inward and outward man accordingly, by believing and obeying.

10 O Lord, With my whole heart have I sought thee: O let me not wander from
thy commandments.
thou know my heart to be perfect with thee, (for thou have made it so) how
that I have neither been partial nor unsincere in mine obedience, but entirely
endeavored always in all things to please thee, as desirous above all things
of thy grace and favor, fearing to forfeit it, which, good Lord, grant I may
never do by going astray from thy precepts, therefore I beseech thee watch over
me, that no temptation mislead me on the right or left hand out of the way of
thy commandments, in which I desire to walk from one end of my life to the
other without deviating.

11 I have, Thy word have I hid in my heart, that I might not sin against
thee.
Lord, stored up thy word in mind and memory, especially such, and so much of
it as I knew was of present and practical concernment to me in my condition,
with full purpose of heart to keep close thereunto, and not sinfully to suffer
my self to be seduced therefrom, what ever happened.

12 Thou, Blessed art thou, O Lord: teach me thy statutes.
Lord, art only blessed, in, and of thy self, from whom as from a fountain
flows forth all derived blessedness unto thy creature, which thou art wont to
confer most upon them that please thee best, as a gracious remuneration of
their love and service, Lord, therefore teach me to know, and enable me to do
thy will revealed in thy word, that I may partake thy blessedness, be sharer in
thy holiness and happiness, here and hereafter.

13 As I have found thy law useful to me, With my lips have I declared all the
judgments of thy mouth.
by my knowledge of it, and framing my course of life according to it, so have
I endeavored to make it to be to others, and therefore have I according to my
measure of light, and the duty of my place and office, taught it publicly and
privately, not concealing any truth I knew might make for thy glory and their
edifying: when I had opportunity of time and occasion.

I have rejoiced in the way of thy testimonies, as much as in all riches.
14 My delight and care (I bless thee for giving me such an heart) has been
more to hear, understand, and practice those things which in thy word are
testified to be thy will, and more sweet peace and consolation have I had, when
I have been so happy, as to attain the knowing and doing of them, than they
that set their hearts to heap up riches, when they have their desire of
opulency and affluence.

I will meditate in thy precepts, and have respect unto thy ways.
15 Therefore, whereas worldlings cast in their minds, and occupy their thoughts
how to enhance their earthly store, because their delight is there, my
meditations shall be otherwise employed, my care and thoughts shall be how to
know more and practice better thy will revealed, for therein is my delight, and
thereto will I bend my mind, studying how best to please thee.

I will delight my self in thy statutes I will not forget thy word.
16 To know and do what pleases thee, shall be a pleasure unto me, yea, nothing
shall more delight me, and therefore am I fully purposed to make thy word the
subject of my meditation day and night, and the rule of mine obedience in weal
and woe.

Gimel.
Gimel. The third letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the third part.
Deal bountifully with thy servant, that I may live and keep thy word.
17 Lord, thy promises to thy people are comprehensive of all good things; as
thou have made them, so fulfill them; Let me thy servant reap the blessed
fruits of thy grace and bounty according to them, touching life temporal and
spiritual, grant me both, and what conduces unto both, as a faithful creator
and gracious redeemer, that by grace I may live both the life of grace and
nature.

18 Lord, Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of thy
law.
thou know what great impediments there are that hinder our knowledge and
acquaintance with thee, even in those things thou have revealed, of which yet
we are ignorant, and seeing, we see not, there being a twofold vail that
interposeth betwixt a right understanding and them, the one over our hearts,
blindly mistaking the mind and meaning of the spirit, and stumbling at the
stumbling stone the letter. The other over thy law and covenant it self,
expressed in dark and typical umbrages and dispensations, full of wondrous
divine excellency in their signification and antitypicall meaning, but
impossible to be understood, but by thy more than litterall revelation.
Therefore dispense thy spirit, who only knows the mind of God, and can only
make it known unto thy servant, draw aside thy curtains of my blindness, and
thy laws darkness, that in thy light I may see light, and be made able to
behold the mystical and spiritual tenderness of thy whole law and covenant,
both in the moral and typical dispensation of it, which unfolded to a
spiritual eye, are admirable and ravishing, portraying as in a table the
divine history and mystery of man's redemption and salvation, with all that
heavenly wisdom, free grace, and Almighty power that shines therein.

19 I am thine, I am a stranger in the earth, hide not thy commandments from me.
and properly belong to another world, only here I must for a time lead a
transient life, because it is thy will more than mine, who though I am in the
world, yet not of the world, but in mind and heart estranged from it, therefore
seeing it is thy pleasure that I must live mine appointed time to serve thee on
earth, take it into consideration, what divine light and guidance is requisite
so to do, and vouchsafe me it proportionably, least I wander out of thy way,
the world and flesh with which I here converse being strangers, and estranged
thereunto, and apt to mislead me, if thy word and spirit be not always a light
and guide unto me.

My soul breaks for the longing it has to thy judgment at all times.
20 Lord, my soul is as the broken and chawned earth in time of drought,
laboring always in unsatiable desire after the soul-nourishing and refreshing
knowledge of the divine excellencies, comprehended in thy righteous precepts
and covenant-dispensations, as it does incessantly after rain, that so I may
always live the life of faith, and fear, love, and obedience.

Thou have rebuked the proud that are cursed, which do err from thy
commandments.
21 That's my desire to understand the fear of the Lord, that I may walk humbly
with my God, for the proud disobedient gainsayers of his will, that have taken
cursed and displeasing curses, the Lord has sooner or later met with them, as
they are hateful to him, so he has made it appear upon them by heavy
judgments.

Remove from me reproach and contempt, ^or I have kept thy testimonies.
22 Which I am confident shall still be their portion, even the portion of my
proud disdainful enemies, who think scorn of me, and basely asperse me,
because of my faith in, and obedience unto God, but, Lord, I hope that both I,
and they are accepted at thine hands, and that thou take notice of mine
Ismaelitish persecution by mine arrogant foes, and wilt find a time to quit me
of them, who thou know has not been ashamed of thee, nor deserted either my
faith or fear of thee, for fear of men.

23 I have been the byword of high and low, Princes also did sit and speak
against me: but thy servant did meditate in thy statutes.
those that should have been by their places men of more integrity and good
example, yet did not they stick to abuse their authority, and me, by casting
scorn upon me in the audience of others, but I patiently bear it, and my
thoughts the while were upon thy word and my duty, in such cases, that so I
might approve my self to thee, not caring to be judged by man's day.

24 And though I had cause enough of sorrow and trouble, Thy ^e^timonies also
are my delight, and my counselors.
yet my comfort is they made me not break covenant, nor falsify my faith, but
still I kept a good conscience, and followed my rule, and had the comfort of it
in mine own spirit, not consulting with flesh and blood, what to do at such
times when temptations were sore upon me, but with thy word, which I knew was
the will and wisdom of God, the mighty Counselor and Prince of Princes.

Daleth. Daleth.
The fourth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the fourth part.
25 I am exceeding low brought by thine afflicting hand, My soul cleavet^^ unto
the dust: quicken thou me, according to thy word.
my discomfitures make my life a very death, oh, do thou raise me, restore
comfort, and thereby life unto me, according as thou have graciously promised.

26 For I have not hid mine offenses, I have declared my ways, and thou
heardest me: teach me thy statutes.
but confessed and declared them to thee, as I have done every thing else in
the whole course of my life. I have always acquainted thee how it was with me,
in my temptations and troubles, and I have ever found thee gracious, and so
doubt not still to do; speak peace and holiness therefore now to my soul, that
I may sin no more, but learn to love and serve thee.

Make me to un^derstand the way of thy precepts: so shall I talk of thy
wondrous works.
27 Lord, instruct me, and overpower my natural pravity and corrupt
disposition, to walk holily and steadily in the fear of thy name, and obedience
of thy commandments, by thy renewing of my joys, and strengthening of my
graces, so shall I magnify thy power in my weakness, and animate the faith of
others.

My soul melts for heaviness: strengthen thou me according unto thy word.
28 The sense of my sin and thy displeasure for it, lies so heavy upon my
spirit, that I sensibly decay and wast under it, speak reconciliation and
absolution to me, that may revive and restore me, according to thy promise of
grace and mercy to poor penitents and suppliants, such as I am.

Remove from me the way of lying: and grant me thy law graciously.
29 The sin that has brought me into this distemper is my want of faith to
carry me through, and my making now and then in extremity of temptation lies my
refuge, which repents me that ever I did so, the Lord forgive it, and remove
that spirit of fear and diffidence that caused it, that I may no more tread in
such bypath; of thine own free goodness, grant me the mercy and grace
promised in thy word, and exhibited in the typical ordinances of thy law.

I have chosen the way of truth; thy judgem^nts have I laid before me.
30 Lord, how ever I have slipped through frailty, yet thou know the bent and
bias of my heart is to love truth and not falsehood, it is the way I have chosen
to walk in, and have used the means that might aw me to it, and direct me in
it, by serious pondering thy righteous commandments, penally inhibiting such
sinful aversations, though, my grace being weak, my endeavors through
temptation have sometimes been ineffectuall.

I have stuck unto thy testimonies: O Lord, put me not to shame.
31 I have not ordinarily, no nor willingly at any time given the reins to my
corruption, though otherwhiles they have been too strong for me, but have
carefully and conscionably in the main and course of my life, though troublous
and temptatious, walked exactly, and kept me closely to thy will, testified in
thy word, O Lord, therefore compassionate me in this my sin, and trouble for
it, and so order my ways, that I sin no more, to provoke thee against me, to
the loss of thy favor, and the forfeiting my self to mine enemies.

32 I have been faithful though with some failings, I will run the ways of
thy commandments when thou shall enlarge my heart.
which if thou will but please to pass by, and renew thy favor to me, and
grace in me, whereby my heart may again be comforted, and consequently
enlarged, and enabled, (for thy joy is my strength) then do I promise for my
self, being confident in the power of thy grace, to yield universal and
cheerful obedience to thy commandments, maugre impediments.

He. He.
The fifth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the fifth part.
33 I know my whole life throughout is to be expended in thy service, Teach me,
O Lord, the way of thy statutes, and I shall keep it unto the end.
but how to persevere with unwearied and unvaried constancy I see not, but by
thy special and spiritual guidance, who can either order mine affairs to
be free from temptation, or teach and enable me to wade through them, without
warping from the rule and way of thy commandments: pity therefore my weakness
and humane frailty, and by thy spirit supply and prompt me continually, so
shall I do what else I cannot, avoid sin, and persevere in holiness all my
life, in all the various alterations of it.

Give me understanding and I shall keep thy law; yea, I shall observe it with
my whole heart.
34 How many are befooled with worldly wisdom and carnal reason, Lord, thou
know, and truly so shall I amongst the rest, if thou be not more
merciful unto me, to teach me better, yea, contrary to such things as those
principles dictate; even the wholesome rudiments of thy law and covenant
dispensation, which if thou will of thy good grace vouchsafe to do, I shall
gladlier serve thee than sin; yea, if thou will effectually lead me, I will
gladly and cordially follow and obey thee in whatsoever thou command, for to
will is present with me, but how else to perform I see not.

Make me to go in the path of thy commandments: for therein do I delight.
35 Both the will and the deed is thine and of thee, now therefore as thou have
enabled me in the one, for through thy grace my heart is biased to obedience,
so that my desire is to it, and my delight is in it, so do thou no less
graciously and powerfully enable me in the other, let me through thine
assistance be as able as willing to do thy will, always, in all things.

Incline my heart unto thy testimonies, and not to covetousness.
36 I know, O Lord, naturally I have the same corrupt and inordinate affections
in me as others have, as ready upon temptation to warp world-ward as another
man, but I know thou have my heart in thy hands, and though I cannot rule it,
thou can, so that I pray thee have an eye to it, and keep an hand over it, to
dispose and bend it the way of thy will, and from the worlds allurements of
pleasure or profit, let grace supersead me from corruption, specially of
covetousness the root of all evil.

Turn away mine eyes from beholding vanity: and quicken thou me in thy way.
37 Let not my outward senses be caught, and sinfully transported with the baits
of the flesh, or of the world, but give me a sanctified understanding to
believe truly, and not seemingly of sublunary things, and to know them to be as
in their own natures they are, vain and transitory, that can convey no
permanent nor substantial good or content to a man, but delude him with the
shows thereof by a false medium, carnal concupiscence, and that serves to
steal the heart from God, but, Lord, avert both eyes and heart from them, give
me such active graces, and lively affections, that may have continual
influence into all the parts of body and soul, and so dispose them in love to
thee, and desire of heavenly things, that as dead to the world, they may
comparatively be indisposed to all things else.

38 Lord, Stablish thy word unto thy servant: who is devoted to thy fear.
fulfill those promises of grace and goodness, wherein thou stand engaged
unto thy servant. Thou that art Jehovah in thy Being, be so in thy word by
giving it a being in all those gracious promises it comprehends and exhibits,
and wherein thou have caused me to trust, in confidence whereof I have wholly
cast my self upon thy grace and providence, minding always to serve thee, more
than how to provide and shift for my self, as men of the world do.

39 Let not thy servant sin against thee, Turn away my reproach which I fear:
for thy judgments are good.
thereby to provoke thee against him to the loss of thy favor, the forfeiting
of thy protection, and the exposing me to mine enemies scorn and insultation,
which I exceedingly fear, as well for thy sake who art so deeply concerned in
me, as for mine own. If at any time I do fall, Lord, let not that be my
punishment, be thou and not they my Judge, for that thy judgments are like thy
self, righteous and good, but theirs are like themselves, merciless and wicked.

Behold I have longed after thy precepts^ quicken me in thy righteousness.
40 Thou know my heart is perfect toward thee, take notice of it, O Lord,
how my desires and affections are upright and sincere to the knowing and doing
of thy will according to thy word, give me a spirit of power and enablement, as
well as of will and desire, according to thy righteous, as well as gracious
engagements, for thou art as just to fulfill promises, as to inflict
punishments.

Vau.
Vau. The sixth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the sixth part.
Let thy mercies come also unto me, O Lord: even thy salva^tion a^cording to
thy word.
41 And as I desire that thou will enable me with a spirit of holiness to walk
uprightly in the way, so also that in mercy thou will remember me concerning
the promised end, that it may effect that for me, even my preservation in, and
my deliverance out of my sad condition and many dangers, as thou have engaged
thy self to do.

So shall I have wherewith to answer him that reproacheth me; for I trust in
thy word.
42 By this means I that now only live by promises, unpossessed of the thing
promised, and therefore cannot at present effectually convince men of carnal
understandings and void of faith; shall then be able demonstratively to stop
their mouths, that now flout me for mine improbable hopes and foreign
expectations, and because I bear my self upon thy word which they think will
never be fulfilled, but I am otherwise persuaded; therefore, O Lord, let not my
trust be deceived and they in their presumptuous impiety confirmed.

43 And let me never so sin against thee, And take not the word of truth
utterly out of my mouth, for I have hoped in thy judgments.
as thereby to have mine own mouth stopped, and despoil my self of what thou
have promised me, whereof, in faith of thy truth and goodness, I have openly
declared my confidence according to thy word, which, Lord, let me never have
cause to retract, nor to speak less in praise of thy faithfulness, but more, by
thy turning promises into performances, according to the hope I have had in thy
just fullfilling what thou have promised me, and threatened mine enemies.

44 So shall thou oblige me, So shall I keep thy law continually: for ever and
ever.
when I am delivered out of these heavy pressures which lie upon me, as so many
clogs and hindrances, (which I shall never forget) without making bawks in
mine obedience, (which through temptation I have been forced to do, and fear I
shall still do without thy powerful prevention) in love and thankfulness to
serve and please thee, the utmost hour of my life, if set at liberty.

45 Yea, And I will walk at liberty: for I seek thy precepts.
when thou have enfranchized me out of these encumbrances of fear and care, and
made me a man of liberty and authority in Israel, I will as thy freeman and
servant carry and demean my self, in all manner well-pleasing, walking in the
way of thy service, and keeping all thy commandments, which never shall be a
burden or bondage to me, for to be at liberty, and to have ability, and
opportunity to learn and do thy will according to thy word, is that I beg above
any thing, and which I should esteem as my greatest felicity.

46 When thou have advanced me, I will speak of thy testimonies also before
Kings: and will not be ashamed.
I also will advance thee, and execute the office of a Prophet, as well as of a
King, and think it no shame to do so, by declaring to others as occasion is
offered, what thy will and word is, even to Kings and mighty men of the earth,
with whom I shall then be of equal level, and so have opportunity in that
condition to converse more with them, than now I have, and I promise to improve
it when I have it.

And I will delight my self in thy commandments, which I have loved.
47 And then will I as a man set at liberty from restraint, run the ways of thy
commandments, by daily and frequent doing them, my delight shall be to be
conversant in thine ordinances, which I have longed for, and heartily loved,
and desired to be an actour in, but hitherto have been an exile from them,
which has set a vehement edge upon mine appetite, which then I will satiate.

My hands also will I lift up unto thy commandments, which I have loved, and I
will meditate in thy statutes.
48 For then both heart and hand shall act for thee, my whole man, with my whole
might, shall be set on work to know and do thy whole will in thy law revealed,
which I have dearly loved and longed to do, and will perform them in spirit as
well as in letter, for when my mind is free from these distractions, it shall
move in a higher sphere, and be active in and about the Gospel-sence of thy
laws and ordinances.

Zain.
Zain. The seventh letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the seventh part.
Remember the word unto thy servant, upon which thou have caused me to hope.
49 Be mindful of thy word of promise, and voluntary engagements made to me thy
chosen, though unworthy servant, touching grace, preservation, and deliverance,
upon which as thou have commanded me, so also have thou effectually
overpowered, and enabled me by thy spirit, to rest in assured hope of thy
faithfulness, and my happiness thereby.

50 Throughout all my long and tedious trial where with thou afflictedst me,
This is my comfort in my affliction: for thy word has quickened me.
I have nothing to bear up upon but this, and I bless thee for it, this serves
the turn to do it, thy promise through faith does comfort and cordialize my
heart, and has done many a time, when to sense and reason I have been a dead
man.

51 My faith, The proud have had me greatly in derision: yet have I not
declined from thy law.
and I for my faiths sake, have been exceedingly slighted and scorned by mine
enemies, men of proud and carnal minds, yet have I neither been afraid nor
ashamed of my cause or confidence, but have stuck to thy promises in faith and
obedience, waiting the fulfilling of them.

52 I was ever confident that as mine enemies had their time, I remembered thy
judgments of old, O Lord, and have comforted my self.
so thou would have thine, and that I should see thee as just in reward and
punishment as heretofore, when by miracle thou savedst thy people, and
destroyedst thine and their adversaries, the consideration hereof, knowing thee
to be the same unchangeable God in omnipotency and faithfulness, has always
born up my heart comfortably in hope of no worse success.

53 And were it not for thy word of promise, Horror has taken hold upon me:
because of the wicked that forsake thy law.
and works of power and providence, that the faith of these are a stay to me, I
were of all men most miserable, for the horrid insolences, and unjust
violences of my wicked and graceless enemies, that have no fear of God before
their eyes, but reject both thee and thy precepts, it makes me tremble to think
of it, and the heavy judgments that will befall them for it, so, at present I
feel the evil effects thereof, being driven to extreme straits and perplexities
both of body and mind, by these impious lawless wretches.

Thy statutes have been my songs in the house of my pilgrim age.
54 For my life is no better to me by their persecution and prosecution of me
from place to place, than a perpetual pilgrimage, so that my dwelling is no
dwelling, for I am in a continual peregrination, restlesly changing my
station, sometimes in caves, sometimes in deserts, and sometimes in exile and
banishment, yet every where and at all times the memory and meditation of thine
engagements and promises concerning me, which bind thee by grace, as laws do us
by duty, and are thy statutes, as well as are thy commandments, have cheared up
my heart, and were, as my songs, and instruments of music heretofore were wont
to be unto me, at leasurable times in mine own house.

I have remembered thy name, O Lord, in the night, and have kept thy law.
55 I have made it my employment, and set my seriousest thoughts on work upon
the minding and meditating thy faithfulness, power, and justice, when others
have been refreshing their bodies with rest in the night season, then have I
been refreshing my weary and careful mind, with pondering thee in thine
excellencies, O Lord: and have been so settled in mind thereby, as I have taken
up a resolution by carnal and sinful shifts, never to prevaricate what ever
come of me, but to persist in faith and holiness to the end.

This I had: because I kept thy precepts.
56 These soul supportations, renewed graces, and heart comfortings, the Lord
vouchsafed me in the meditations of him, his promises, and properties, because
I was conscionable and careful to walk always in all things to his
well-pleasing, therefore did he reward and sustain me with these divine
cordialls, and comforts, in the time of my comfortless peregrination.

Cheth. Cheth.
The eighth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the eighth part.
57 The comforts and confidences of worldly men, Thou art my portion, O Lord, I
have said, that I would keep thy words.
are in worldly things, there portion is here below in things (I bless my God)
too low for me, who have no happiness, contentment, or confidence short of God,
who is all in all to me, and as, Lord, thou art mine, so I have fully purposed
to be thine, and to yield thee faithful and fruitful obedience in dependencie
on thy promises, and conformity to thy precepts.

58 Lord, I entreated thy favor with my whole heart: be merciful unto me
according to thy word.
thou know what value I have always set on thy favor, how above all
blessings I have lain at thee for that, as more to me than all besides, so that
before and above all, have I preferred and sought it as my choicest and
chiefest happiness, and therefore beg of thee that I may ever be blessed with
thy grace, mercy, and truth, vouchsafed and fulfilled according to promise.

59 Fearful was I to offend, I thought on my ways, and turned my feet into thy
testimonies.
and forfeit that thy favor I set so much by, and therefore was always
solicitous and thought-ful of the steps I took, whether they tended to thy
pleasing or displeasing, and if at any time by temptation or frailty I began to
be misbiassed, or that actually I deviated before I was awar, I quickly
(through thy grace) recollected my self, and faced about.

60 When I found mine error I soon quit it, I made have, and delayed not to
keep thy commandments.
no reasonings of flesh and blood prevailed to make me persist, but by the
power of thy grace, I broke through all impediments to serve and please thee.

61 Wicked men by wicked ways have prospered and thriven, The bands of the
wicked have robbed me: but I have not forgot thy Law.
and by combination have turned me out of all, and enriched themselves with my
spoils, but for all that I have stuck to my tackling, held close to faith and a
good conscience in believing, and doing as I was appointed, and left their
punishment and my vindication unto thee.

At midnight I will rise to give thanks unto thee: because of thy righteous
judgments.
62 And it no whit repents me, but exceedingly rejoices me of that thy gracious
supportation of my faith, yea, such peace of conscience it brings with it, and
such a seal of special favor it is unto me, according to thy righteous
engagements to be thus enabled to walk holily, as that the thoughts thereof are
more sweet and refreshing to my mind, than sleep to my nature, and make me
suspend the one, even in the season thereof, to feed upon the other, and make
thankful repayment of my debts and endearments contracted thereby.

I am a companion of all them that fear thee: and of them that keep thy
precepts.
63 Thy ways, and they that walk in them, are my delight, I fear thee my self,
so I love all those that do so, I have no pleasure, as not in wickedness, so
nor in wicked men, but the outcasts of the world, such as I my self am, that
fear to offend thee, and desire to please and serve thee, these have my heart,
and with such will I stand and fall, live and die.

The earth, O Lord; is full of thy mercy: teach me thy statutes.
64 As a faithful Creator thou have plentifully provided for man and beast,
nature is well stored with varieties of created conveniences for all kinds of
Beings upon earth, which also are mercifully continued, though long since
forfeited by the fall. But, O Lord, there is one thing necessary, and a mercy
more worth than all these, and that is to be able to see and seek a happiness
that is above nature, and that grows in no earthly soil, to have a frameable
and teachable heart, Lord, grant me that, write thy Law in it, and let both thy
precepts and promises be believed, and obeyed by me, That is my desire.

Teth. Teth.
The ninth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the ninth part.
65 I have not found thy grace or truth to fail me, Thou have dealt well with
thy servant, O Lord, according unto thy word.
but as I have endeavored to approve my self a good servant, so, O Lord, have
I found thee a good master, true of thy promise, and as good as thy word.

66 Lord, Teach me good judgment, and knowledge: for I have believed thy
commandments.
give me a right understanding of things that differ, let me not mistake
falsehood for truth, nor evil for good, but teach me to know the thing that good
is, and dispose mine heart and affections practically thereunto, for so far as
I have been taught by thy spirit, I have gladly embraced and conscionably
obeyed, and not refused either belief or subjection to any thy commandments.

67 My very afflictions through thy grace and faithfulness, Before I was
afflicted, I went astray: but now have I kept thy word.
are become wholesome physic and good documents to me, for I was apt to wander
out of thy way, until I smarted for my folly, but now I have learned another
lesson, and have ever since run another course, kept close to thy will revealed
in thy word without hearkening to the dictates of corrupt reason, tending to
self-pleasing or self-saving, which before were too prevailing.

68 Goodness of all kinds, Thou art good, and do good, teach me thy statutes.
O Lord, is natural to thee, so it is not to us in any kind, for there is none
good but God, and flows plentifully from thee, as all creatures but man
especially can witness, of whose bounty they have their beings, and those
beings their subsistencies all the world over, but Lord it is thy saving
goodness that I pray to partake of, my soul is more to me than my body, and
grace than nature, therefore do I beg special and supernatural grace and wisdom
to know and do thy will, which I prefer before common and natural benefits, the
pleasing of thee before either profit or pleasure to my self, of thy goodness
grant me this, which is part of the divine nature, and only makes man like to
God in being and doing good, which I would both be and do.

The proud have forged a lie against me: but I will keep thy precepts with my
whole heart.
69 My proud disdainful enemies that fear not God, nor care not what wickedness
they commit in word or deed to discredit me, have falsely aspersed me for a
traitorous conspiratour, and that it is my ambition, not thy determination that
puts me upon expectancie of the Kingdom, but I am resolved, this slander shall
not stagger me, but in confidence of thy truth and mine own integrity, I will
persist to serve thee in sincerity of heart, who I know wilt vindicate mine
innocence, and make appear their forgerie.

Their heart is as fat as grease, but I delight in thy Law.
70 Their worldly pomp and plenty has made their hearts so gross and carnal,
as that their consciences are benumbed and senseless, and their minds puffed up
with pride and arrogance, they sin without restraint, and scoff at piety as
pusillanimitie, but thy Law is my delight, though not theirs, I am troubled
when I break it, and glad at heart when I do and can keep it through thy
gracious enablement.

It is good for me that I have been afflicted: that I might learn thy statutes.
71 Yea, such is my love to holiness, that I never think it a dear purchase
whatsoever it cost me, and therefore value mine afflictions, which in mercy
thou sentest to beget in me a teachable and tractable heart to thy
commandments, above their prosperity that hardens their hearts in ignorance
and carnallitie.

The Law of thy mouth is better unto me, than thousands of gold and silver.
72 Thy word and Law written in my heart, effectually taught and wrought there
by thy spirit, however it is counter to my corruptions, yet because as it is
thine, (so pliable have thou made my will to thy will) even therefore do I
praise it, and apprehend my self more enriched with my knowledge of it and love
to it, than if I had the wealth the world so dotes on in never so great
abundance.

Iod. Iod.
The tenth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the tenth part.
73 Thou, Thy hands have made me, and fashioned me; give me understanding, that
I may learn thy commandments.
Lord, that made me was pleased to difference me from other creatures, by
endowing me with natural capacities above them, so that though I have lost my
created perfections of righteousness and holiness, yet not my created and
passive capacities of thy renewing them again in me, my soul has the same
faculties, and my body the same parts and Organs thou gave me at the first,
in, and upon which thou art able to re-imprint thine image; vouchsafe me I pray
thee thy renewing grace more and more, powerfully enlighten my dark
understanding, incline my whole man, O Lord, to the loving and obeying of thy
whole will, I am still thy creature, renew thy likeness.

74 If Lord thou will strengthen thy graces in me, They that fear thee will be
glad when they see me: because I have hoped in thy word.
and enable me to hold out steadfast in faith and holy obedience to the end, and
then reward thine own graces in me with a happy issue and close of things, how
will it rejoice the hearts of thy servants that fear thee, and hope in thee?
when they shall see me have overcome all my miseries, and be possessed of my
hopes and thy promises, because of thy gracious enabling me to hold out in
affiance of thy word, it will affect them greatly.

75 I know, I know, O Lord, that thy judgments are right: and that thou in
faithfulness have afflicted me.
O Lord, that thou art righteous in what thou say, and do, thy word and
thy works are consentaneous, thy faithfulness is fulfilled in my very
afflictions though seemingly otherwise thy judgments and mercies, and shall
conduce to bring about thy promises made to me.

Let, I pray thee, thy merciful kindness be for my comfort; according to thy
word unto thy servant.
76 Let, I pray thee thy mercy of favor and grace long since promised me, be
in the faith of it a continual comfort to me, yea, Lord, comfort me thy servant
chosen and called, with the accomplishment of it, according to thy word.

Let thy tender mercies come unto me, that I may live: for thy Law is my
delight.
77 Make me inwardly sensible of those tender affections which thou bear me,
that they may help to revive me in this comfortless condition whilst it lasts,
and express them also in outward manifestations, let me see thy pity and
compassion in a comfortable deliverance and conclusion, that I may live free
from these troubles which makes my life a very death, for how ever by frailty
I have and cannot but offend thee, yet thou know thou have mine heart and
good will in all things to serve and obey thee, that is my desire, and in that
I delight.

Let the proud be ashamed, for they dealt perversely with me without a cause:
but I will meditate in thy precepts.
78 Let not me therefore miscarrie by the hands of proud men and evil doers,
that are lawless and scorn subjection, Lord, let them miscarrie in their
designs and evil purposes, for thou know how contrary to their consciences
they have persecuted me as nocent, when as they know me to be an innocent
person, but their dealing shall not make me forget my duty, I will keep mine
eye still fixed upon that, and walk steadfastly in the way of thy precepts, in
confidence of my reward and their punishment.

79 Give me such remarkable deliverance and so change the scene, Let those that
fear thee, turn unto me, and those that have known thy testimonies.
that those of thy people that truly fear thee, and have been savingly
enlightened by thee, whom my afflictions have staggered, or that have been
misled by delusions and false reports, may see convincing signs of thy special
favor to me, and purposes concerning me, and thereby be encouraged and invited
in the faith of thy promises, and my innocent cause to take part and join with
me, against mine enemies.

80 Let me be enabled by thy gracious assistance to keep faith and a good
conscience steadfast to the end, Let my heart be sound in thy statutes; that I
be not ashamed.
that I lose not the prize by falling short of the goal, fainting either in
faith or duty, and so render my self and cause a laughing stock to mine
enemies, which is it they would have.

Caph. Caph.
The eleventh letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the eleventh part.
81 Lord, My soul faints for thy salvation: but I hope in thy word.
I have waded through many and grievous troubles, and with much long-suffering
have a long time eagerly longed and looked for thy promised deliverance, almost
to the exhausting of my soul and spirit in sighs and groans after it, but yet
it comes not, nevertheless I am still sustained in faith, and am resolved to
live and die in expectation of thy promise, no length of time, nor trouble,
shall null my hopes, nor, I am confident the thing I hope for.

82 I have waited long and dreely looked for the accomplishment of thy promise,
Mine eyes fail for thy word, saying, when will thou comfort me?
even to the weakening of my sight and impairing my senses, every foot thinking
within my self, as my mind gave me and occasion was offered, that sure this is
the time, and that the opportunity, that I shall be delivered, but still I am
prolonged and put off, sighing out my hopes, with, If not now Lord, when then
will the time be, and what the means that must fulfill thy word, and my desire?

For I am become like a bottle in the smoke: yet do I not forget thy statutes.
83 The scorching sun of adversity has almost quite exhausted my radical
moisture, my spirits which should animate my members, and extrinsical parts are
spent with continual grief by reason of afflictions, and disappointments of my
longing expectations, which lingringly consume and wast me into leanness and
deformity, like a bladder or a skin-bottel hung up in a chimney, that in tract
of time will parch and crack and shrink up into wrinckles not like it self, and
so am I become, yet though nature thus decays, grace does not, by thy goodness
to me I am, for all that, upheld in care and conscience to do thy will, and
believe thy word.

How many are the days of thy servant; when will thou execute judgment on
them that persecute me?
84 Lord, how long too, is the end of my miseries? consider how much of my life
is already spent and wasted in them, even of mine, who am appointed and
designed by thee for great and special services in thy Church, therefore
consider me who would fain be employed, to shorten these days; when shall they
that unjustly would cut me off, be themselves justly so served? and I set free
to serve thee.

The proud have dug pits for me, which are not after thy Law.
85 Mine enemies that scorn thy commands, and me thy servant, have not only
persecuted me with open violence, but with cunning craft and dissimulation
sought my life, for their will is their Law, and not thy word, to which they
yield no manner of obedience, nor bear no regard, but practice what them list
though never so wicked and unjust, so it serves their turns.

86 But, All thy commandments are faithful, they persecute me wrongfully, help
thou me.
Lord, I have another estimate of thy commandments, I set not so light by them,
for I am sure they come from a faithful God, who may suffer the wicked for a
time to sin against them, but the punishment due to those that break them,
shall befall them, and so shall the reward promised to them that keep them; in
the faith whereof I do and will innocently persevere, and pray thee to make it
good, in my help and deliverance from, and upon, these treacherous and unjust
persecutours.

87 Mine enemies, They had almost consumed me upon earth: but I forsook not thy
precepts.
men of the world, that take all ways and advantages upon earth against me,
had what one way and other by their continual vexations and my griefs almost
brought me down to the grave, and got the better of me, had not thou been
above them, and heaven more my friend than earth, where I had no help, but when
I was at lowest, hopeless and helpless, as to outward appearance, I still kept
faith and a good conscience, hoping in thee.

88 Lord, Quicken me after thy loving kindness, so shall I keep the testimony
of thy mouth.
give me to enjoy that happy condition which of thy free grace and loving
beneficence thou have promised me, which will be as a resurrection to life from
death, after so many sorrows as I have undergone, so shall thou both engage and
enable me, when I am set free from these hindrances to do thy whole will and
walk in thy Law, which bears the stamp of Divine and royal authority upon it,
and therefore is worthy of reverend and solemn observance and obedience, which
then I will be sure to pay to it, but now I cannot.

Lamed.
Lamed. The twelfth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the twelfth part.
For ever, O Lord, thy word is settled in heaven.
89 Thy word and decree, O Lord, is as firm as thy self, no chances nor changes
here below can make void what thou above have determined shall be, nor can time
it self wear out, what thou that art eternal before all time have appointed.

Thy faithfulness is unto all generations: thou have established the earth, and
it abides.
90 Our faith may bear it self boldly upon thy faithfulness, which according to
thy word of truth and promise is always the same, how ever matters frame or
seem to be out of frame, therefore it is that the world is not long since
dissolved, because thou have decreed and promised the continuance of it,
therefore, and for no natural cause does the earth thus long subsist in nature
and order.

They continue this day according to thine ordinances: for all are thy servants.
91 All created Beings according to their several natures, stations, and
operations, are as at the beginning, thou in wisdom determinedst them, which
else of themselves would run into confusion and destruction, what Laws thou
gave them they keep, and thereby are themselves kept and preserved, for all
the elements and elemental creatures as they are made by thee, so they are made
for thee, to be at thy ordering and dispose, and so they are, and not at their
own, and it is well for us and them, they are so.

Unless thy Law had been my delights: I should then have perished in mine
affliction.
92 And surely, Lord, I hold by the self-same tenure the creation does, as it
had been long since dissolved and annihilated, but for the Law of orderly
existence thou laidst upon it, whereby ever since it retains a beautiful being,
notwithstanding the contradictions that are in those primarie principles the
elements, as also the strange concussions and alterations that time and sin
has brought forth; So unless I also had thy righteous word to stay my heart
upon, and to cheer up my soul with, which I knew would not fail me in those
various providence and strange agitations which I have undergone, I could
never have lasted thus long, but had long ere this been in my grave, by the
outward pressures and inward griefs I underwent.

93 I have cause all the days of my life thankfully to remember and bear in
mind, I will never forget thy precepts: for with them thou have quickened me.
and I hope I shall, thy faithfulness, according to what thou have ordained in
thy word for me to trust in, and yield obedience to, many a time in mine
extremity when my spirit was ready to sink and die within me, thou have
therewith comfortably revived and cheered me, and set me upon my feet.

94 Let me to the end have experience of thee to be the self-same God in truth
and goodness, I am thine, save me: for I have sought thy precepts.
preserve me in, and deliver me out of this my sad condition, let nothing fail
me that thou have spoken, who am related in a nearer propriety to thee than
that of creation, I am thy son and servant, not passively but actively, by a
gratuitous intrinsical principle, as thou have chosen me, so I have chosen thee
for my Lord and Master, and thy Laws for the rule of my faith and manners, and
always consult them to that purpose.

95 I have been in a many a sore temptation and imminent peril of my life by
sinister plots and practices of my ungodly adversaries, The wicked have waited
for me to destroy me: but I will consider thy testimonies.
and still am, yet will I not deviate by sinful shifts, but study to keep
faith and a good conscience, for so art thou engaged to my security by thy
word the testimony of thy truth.

I have seen an end of all perfection: but thy commandment is exceeding broad.
96 There is but a finite and transitory good in the very best things that are,
their natures are too narrow to give either full content to a man's mind, or
stay to a man's heart, being subject to alter or end, as I have found by
experience, and know by reason, but thy word is all-sufficient, nothing
pertaining to holiness or happiness, stay or contentment, is wanting in thy Law
or Divine dispensation, nor shall be to him that believes and obeyes it, for
the dimensions of it are as large as thy self, in truth and goodness infinite,
and permanent, superabundantly soul-satisfying.

Mem.
Mem. The thirteenth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the thirteenth
part.
O how love I thy Law? it is my meditation all the day.
97 I for my part see so much goodness, and find so much settlement in and by
thy word, that the love of it far transcends the love of all things else, I
cannot express the affections I bear it, they are so ardent toward it that
they set my mind on work continually upon it, my thoughts and meditations are
day and night taken up with the consideration and application of the blessed
soul-affecting Divine truths and benefits, contained and exhibited in that Law
and word of thine.

Thou through thy commandments have made me wiser than mine enemies: for they
are ever with me.
98 By thine instructing and enabling me to walk according to the rule of faith
and righteousness commanded in thy word, thou have thereby prospered me above
mine enemies, and made this mine holy simplicity to be too hard for their
subtilitie and craft, which has never yet taken effect against me, but come to
naught and ever will, whilst by thy grace I abandon the wisdom of the flesh,
and walk in the wisdom of thy spirit and word, which I am careful to do
always in all things, and prosper by it.

99 I have had the benefit of education, I have more understanding than all my
teachers: for thy testimonies are my mediation.
and humane helps, as to the affairs and literature of the world, and conversed
with men of understanding, and seen the ways that they have gone in the
managing of their transactions, and when I sum up all the wisdom that ever I
have learned and known, I both count it and find it to be but foolishness
compared, with the study and practice of those holy and righteous rudiments
thy word dictates, wherein I bless thee, I have through thy grace, being taught
of God, out-stript all humane teaching and teachers, by delightning to know,
and do thy will revealed for my direction and supportation.

100 Yea, I understand more [than the ancients: because I keep thy testimonies.
I find by experience though young, that godliness is greater wisdom and better
succeeds a man's affairs, by the blessing of God according to his promises
thereupon, than the advice and counsel of the grave senators and sages of the
world, who pretend and justly to great wisdom by advantage of years and
experience, yet with reverence to those hoary heads, I like my wisdom which is
thine, better than theirs, and find sincerity the best policy, and that the
best wisdom is to do thy will, which accordingly I endeavor.

101 I have I bless thee, I have refrained my feet from every evil way: that I
may keep thy word.
ever since thou taughtest it me been of that mind, and my practice has been
answerable, for my care was still at no rate to sin, but in every thing to
tread the steps thy word has chalked me out, and leave the rest to thee.

102 I have not suffered my self to be misled, I have not departed from thy
judgments: for thou have taught me.
and seduced by mine own or other men's counsels from keeping thy commandments,
which I am sure must judge me and all men else, for I bless thee thou have
taught me better by thy word, and overpowered me by thy spirit to yield to
those thy teachings, which therefore have been to strong for my temptations,
which else had been too strong for me.

How sweet are thy words unto my taste! yea, sweeter than honey to my mouth.
103 I cannot express for any to understand, but my self that feel it, what
pleasure and contentment thy covenant of grace and adoption with its
concomitant promises, and precepts of holiness and happiness believed and
applied, brings to my soul and conscience, beyond all earthly comparisons, honey
to my palate is not comparable.

Through thy precepts I get understanding: therefore I hate every false way.
104 I make thy precepts my study and meditation, whereby I get, by thine
assisting grace, good understanding and enablement to avoid by-ways of sin and
errou^, tending to thy displeasing, whereunto I am tempted, but make constant
resistance, and from my heart detest deviation, as knowing holiness only leads
to happiness, and has the promises both of this life, and of that to come.

Nun.
Nun. The fourteenth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the fourteen
part.
Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.
105 Lord, throughout this untrodden path of mine where there are so many ways
to miscarrie, and the right way so hard to hit, the world and Satan without,
flesh and corruption within, counselling this and that to make me stumble and
fall: my manner is to silence them all, and consult thy word the Divine light
whereof of guids me out of, and dispels those mists and fogs that carnal
reason, taking advantage of my present temptation, casts before mine eyes, and
sets me into and leads me on in the path of thy well-pleasing, which I choose
to walk.

106 As Lord thou have been pleased to enter covenant with me, I have sworn,
and I will perform it, that I will keep thy righteous judgments.
of pardon, acceptance, and grace, so also have I stipulated with thy Majesty,
and bound my self by solemn vow for ever to be thine obedient and faithful
servant and subject, and by thy gracious assistance I am accordingly purposed
to walk in conformity to thy Law, the righteous rule of thee my righteous
Judge.

107 My affliction and grief is very great, I am afflicted very much: quicken
me, O Lord, according unto thy word.
remember Lord it is for thy sake, and by thy providence befallen me, therefore
grant me what thou have promised me, comfort in, and deliverance out of my
calamities.

108 Thou know, Accept, I beseech thee, the freewill-offerings of my mouth,
O Lord, and teach me thy judgments.
O Lord, I am debarred from sacrificing to thee, as else I would, but that
which is the substance of those ceremonies, the free-will-offerings of praise
and thanksgiving, those I can and do offer, which I pray thee accept, and
shall give me cause so to do by teaching me to know, and do thy righteous
precepts in all my difficult cases, and great temptations.

109 I am in perpetual peril of my life, My soul is continually in my hand: yet
do I not forget thy Law.
imminent danger and destruction is ever at hand, yet through faith in thee
they do not distract or afright me from my duty to thee, and thy commandments,
but I call them to counsel, and have them in mind at every turn.

110 I have been attempted upon and my life laid for by wicked dissemblers that
rather than their lives would have had mine, The wicked have laid a snare for
me, yet I erred not from thy precepts.
and cared not how nor which way, yet I have not revenged my self, nor taken
indirect ways against them, as they do against me, but have committed my cause
to thee and kept thy commandments.

Thy testimonies have I taken as an heritage for ever; for they are the
rejoicing of my heart.
111 I have abandoned all confidence and contentment in every thing, saving thy
precious promises, and covenant-ingagements, the testimonies of thy love,
wherewith alone I am sufficiently enriched, and as well by voluntary election,
as outward necessity have chosen thy free grace testified in thy word, as my
chief and only portion to be happy by for ever; for my heart can take felitie
in nothing else, comparatively to them, they rejoice me above my sorrows.

I have inclined mine heart to perform thy statutes always, even unto the end.
112 And as I have chosen thy free grace for ever to be happy by, so in like
sort have I given my self a free-will-offering unto thee again, for ever to be
thine, in love, and thankful obedience to thy commandments.

Samech.
Samech. The fifteenth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the fifteenth
part.
I hate vain thoughts: but thy Law do I love.
113 Temptations have wrought upon my corruptions and suggested this thing and
that to me, tending to misbelieving and misdoing, but though I could not hinder
my mind from entertaining the thoughts of them, yet I always set my will on
work to dismiss and oppose them, they had no room in my heart, though they
intruded into my head, for there thy Law kept them out, which has anticipated
mine affections, and sequestered them to it self from all Heterodox suggestions
to the contrary.

Thou art my hiding place and my shield: I hope in thy word.
114 I abhor all sinful shifts and carnal securities, thou only art my
security and defense what ever my danger be. Thy word of truth and goodness do
I fly to, and confide in, and in no earthly refuge whatsoever.

Depart from my ye evil duers; for I will keep the commandments of my God.
115 This is the full and final purpose of mine heart, therefore all that are
not thus minded, I renounce them as no friends nor counselors of mine, they
that do evil and would have me do so, avaunt, for I am resolved what ever others
think, say, or do, to stick to my principles and to my God, to be saved in the
way of faith and Godliness, or to perish.

116 This is my purpose, Uphold me according unto thy word, that I may live:
and let me not be ashamed of my hope.
but, Lord, the power of performance is from thee, and truly therefore do I
purpose it, because thou have promised it, thou have said I shall, and
therefore is it that I say I will, fail me not then I beseech thee neither of
grace nor protection, but grant me both, that neither by my sin, nor thy
desertion I perish, but may live holily and hopefully to thy glory and my
comfort, and never have cause by my miscarriage either in sin or success, to be
ashamed of my confidence, or frustrated of my expectation.

117 Do thou, Hold thou me up and I shall be safe: and I will have respect unto
thy statutes continually.
Lord, support and preserve me, and then I am sure not to fall (as on the other
hand if thou do not uphold me, I am sure not to stand,) whereby I shall be
confirmed in well-doing, for thy grace can only establish me, and thy gracious
performances will strengthen and engage me more and more in faith and obedience
to the end.

118 Thou have made examples good store in several ages of the world of thy
dislike of wicked workers, Thou have trodden down all them that err from thy
statutes: for their deceit is falsehood.
worldly wise, and carnal confident men, by executing vengeance, and bringing
fierce destruction upon them, and made it appear plain enough, how vain and
deceiveable such ways and confidences are, which thy word does not warrant,
and that truth and safety are only there to be had.

119 I well know of what value and esteem wicked men, Thou put away all the
wicked of the earth like dross: therefore I love thy testimonies.
how ever the world thinks of them, are of with thee, and what ends they make
compared to the godly, they are to thee as refuse dross to refined silver, and
so shall be differenced and distinguished by thee, in thy wrath they shall be
consumed with all their earthly confidences, and go out like a snuff, whilst
those that serve thee, and were as dross in the worlds eye, are notwithstanding
highly esteemed of thee, and safely preserved by thee, both living and dead
they are precious to thee, therefore do I stick to what thy word warrants and
testifies to be thy will, that I obey, love, and delight in, spite of the
wicked of the world, their hatred and contempt of me and it.

My flesh trembles for fear of thee, and I am afraid of thy judgments.
120 I see such effects of sin and so well know the doom of sinners, that I fear
more to offend thee and incur thy displeasure, than any evil that can else
befall me, from which I chiefly pray to be delivered.

Ain.
Ain. The sixteenth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the sixteenth
part.
I have done judgment and justice: leave me not to mine oppressors.
121 Thou, Lord, know mine innocence and the uprightness of mine heart and
conversation to my very enemies in this very cause, wherein I am so wrongfully
and injuriously prosecuted and persecuted, neither thinking nor doing them
evil, no not evil for evil, therefore in thy righteousness take part with the
righteous, and leave me not to the mercy, or rather expose me not to the
cruelty of mine oppressors that seek my life.

Be surety for thy servant for good: let not the proud oppress me.
122 Do thou in grace and faithfulness own thy servant and his innocent cause
for thine, to protect him and it, from the violence of his clamorous
bloodthirsty adversaries, let them not by their potencie, which makes them
proud, wrongfully ruin me as they desire to do.

I have waited long and dreely looked even to the weakening of my sight, Mine
eyes fail for thy salvation, and for the word of thy righteousness.
and impairing of my senses, for thee to deliver me, and fulfill the word of
grace, thy promise of salvation, which thou the righteous God have made unto
me, and will undoubtedly fulfill in righteousness.

124 Lord, Deal with thy servant according unto thy mercy, and teach me thy
statutes.
thou know the hardship I undergo, the temptations wherewith my faith and
holiness is assaulted and endangered. Good Lord, have compassion upon me, that
am and desire to be thy faithful and obedient servant, and in tender mercy
deal gently with me, lead me not into temptation, but deliver me from evil, I
know my frailty, therefore in self-diffidence I pray thee, at every turn stand
by me to instruct and enable me what to do, that I err not.

125 Thou have honored me to be thy servant both by effectual calling, I am
thy servant, give me understanding: that I may know thy testimonies.
and special designment to extraordinary employment in thy Church, therefore
furnish me with such a measure of illumination and sanctification, that I may
walk worthy my high calling, and evermore to the end approve my self that which
I am by a proportionable measure of grace, enabling and assisting me to know,
and do thy will constantly.

126 It is high time, It is time for thee, Lord, to work: for they have made
void thy Law.
O Lord, for thee to show thy self in some remarkable manner against my proud
enemies, and to execute judgment upon them, nor so much for my sake as thine
own, for such is their presumption that they care as little for thee as me,
slighting thy Law and scorning obedience to it, as if it were a thing of
naught, to no purpose and of no authority.

Therefore I love thy commandments above gold, yea, above fine gold.
127 And surely, Lord, so ill do I like their manners, that I love thy
commandments the better for it, because they are so contrary to them, the less
they set by them, and the more they value the wealth of the world, the more I
value them, and the less I set by it, for swine know not the worth of pearls,
no treasure under heaven is so precious and profitable in mine eye, nor indeed
in it self, or to the possessour, as thy Law and Commandments are to the
sincere professor and practiser of them, the holy dictates of a holy God
making both holy and happy them that know and do them which I desire, and
good, Lord, grant me to do, above all things, as alone sufficient, to make me
both rich and happy to my hearts content.

Therefore I esteem all thy precepts concerning all things to be right: and I
hate every false way.
128 As black sets forth white, and a crooked line a straight one, so does mine
enemies ways thy commandments in their purity and rectitude, their deformed
and crooked courses of impiety and iniquity makes the line of thy precepts
much more straight and right in mine eyes, yea, those that carnal sense and
corrupt reason can worst approve of, to me through thy grace they are most
precious and desirable, as tending to nearest perfection and likeness with thy
self, and on the contrary, as I love thy Law which they hate and make void, so
do I hate what they love, sinful deviations and prevarications.

Pe.
Pe. The seventeenth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the seventeenth
part.
Thy testimonies are wonderful, therefore does my soul keep them.
129 Man's reason and understanding is both contrary to, and infinitely short of
comprehending the holy and high mysteries of salvation and Godliness revealed
in thy word, which nature could never have known nor taught us, had they not
been supernaturally revealed, being the hidden uncreated wisdom of God, taught
and wrought in the souls of thy servants by extraordinary illumination, and of
special grace and favor, therefore for their Divine nature and worths sake,
which in mercy thou have opened mine eyes to see, though others do not, do I
love and delight in them, meditate and obey them, even lay out my whole
strength upon them.

130 In whomsoever, The entrance of thy words gives light: it gives
understanding unto the simple.
and at what time soever, thy word by the efficatious working of thy spirit
first takes saving and sanctifying impression, there, and then, and never till
then, the sun of righteousness rises with light and healing, to the expulsion
and dispersion of that deadly darkness that naturally benighteth every soul;
man though otherwise never so worldly wise, is but a very fool, vain, and
ignorant both of truth and goodness, till thou write thy Law in his heart, that
and only that is true wisdom, and they and only they have true understanding
though otherwise never so foolish.

131 I for my part never longed more after meat and drink in my greatest
extremity of hunger and thirst, I opened my mouth, and panted: for I longed
for thy commandments.
nor any creature living, than I did for the incomming of thy word with power
into my soul, when it was under the guilt and dominion of sin, O the sighs and
groans that I incessantly breathed forth, after my transforming, and thine
inabling grace to believe and obey.

132 Thou, Look thou upon me, and be merciful unto me, as thou usest to do unto
those that love thy name.
Lord, know how I longed and still do to serve thee out of a sincere and
hearty love to thee; Let therefore thine eye of grace and compassion be upon
me, mercifully to keep me from falling into sin, or by sin into thy
displeasure, as thou have promised, and in thy goodness art accustomed to do to
such as thou know I am a lover of, and hoper in thy grace, truth, and mercy.

Order my steps in thy word, and let not any iniquity have dominion over me.
