133 Let my whole conversation and course of life by thy spirit, according to
thy word, the rule of holiness and righteousness, be powerfully overruled and
ordered in all things, and let not my innate pravity by force or subtility of
temptation in no case overmaster thy grace, and make me sin against thee, whom
I desire to serve.

Deliver me from the oppression of man: so will I keep thy precepts.
134 My greatest temptation and fear is the unjust violence and cruel
persecution of mine enemies, thou that art the Almighty and gracious Lord God,
set me free and deliver me from the injuries of proud malicious minded men, so
shall I be engaged and enabled when set at liberty, thankfully and cheerfully
to serve and please thee.

Make thy face to shine upon thy servant: and teach me thy statutes.
135 Bring me out of this comfortless darksom condition threatening thy
displeasure, whereby I have nothing but troubles without, and sorrows within,
let me by deliverance see the sky clear up upon me, let thy favorable aspect
break forth from under this cloud, and Lord, it is as well the light of grace
as comfort, of sanctification as deliverance, that I beg of thee, the one
without the other will but little profit nor please me.

Rivers of waters run down mine eyes: because they keep not thy Law.
136 So deeply am I affected with the opprobries and contempt that thou
undergoest by the wicked of the world, specially mine enemies who turn grace
into wantonness, and make thy impunity their immunity to sin, that it is a
greater trouble and grief of heart to me than any I undergo in mine own behalf,
and costs me as many sighs and tears the injuring of thee in thine honor, as
my self in my peace and innocence, which I should be as glad were vindicated,
and they punished as I delivered.

Tsaddi. Tsaddi.
The eighteenth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the eighteenth part.
137 Let other men that love to live in sin think as contemptuously as they
will of thee and thy Laws, Righteous art thou, O Lord, and upright are thy
judgments.
yet art thou, and they righteous, and so they shall find when according to
those Laws thou passest a just and righteous sentence upon them for their
wicked disobedience.

138 What thou have testified to be thy will in thy word, Thy testimonies that
thou have commanded, are righteous, and very faithful.
by commanding it to be done, is just and righteous in it self, and tends to
make men so if rightly performed, yea, happy also, thy commands having their
rewards, which to the faithful shall be faithfully performed.

139 I sustain no small grief by my persecutours in mine own person, My zeal
has consumed me: because mine enemies have forgotten thy words.
but if I know mine own heart, it is far short of what I undergo for thy sake,
the contemptuous neglect and slight esteem, which my proud enemies have of thy
commandments, making a trade of sinning, has so affected me, to see thee thus
dishonored, and thy Law unregarded, that mine ardent apprehension of it, in
fervor and affection to thee, and holy impatience against them, has meagred
and impaired me much.

140 That for which others dislike and refuse thy word is, Thy word is very
pure: therefore thy servant loves it.
because it is in its own nature pure, and tends to the refining their natures
and corrupt manners, which wicked worldlings cannot abide. And for this very
reason sake do I love it, and delight in it, because it is such, and has that
gracious operation with it, for that I am thy servant and do long more and more
to be so in all manner of holiness and righteousness, whereof it is the perfect
rule and pattern.

I am small and despised; yet do I not forget thy precepts.
141 I have temptations of poverty, persecution, scorn, and what not, that put
me to it, yet I swerve not, nor cast not off thy yoke, though in the condition
I am in, I draw hardly in it through very rough and un-even ways; I am not
mercenary, earthly felicity is not it that moves me to, nor shall infelicitie
remove me from my duty, and allegiance to thy precepts.

Thy righteousness is an everlasting righteousness, and thy Law is the truth.
142 No Lord, it is the perfection of thy righteous will in thy word that draws
me to it, so that nothing can separate me from it, because it is, ever was, and
shall be, the only unchangeable certain standard for holiness and happiness,
life and salvation, and of that absolute truth and infallibility is thy Law and
the rudiments thereof, that all else are living destructive vanities, that
differ from it, and conform not to it.

Trouble and anguish have taken hold on me; yet thy commandments are my
delights.
143 I am under arrest, never at liberty, but a perpetual prisoner to outward
trouble, and inward grief, and yet faith and a good conscience comfort me, for
I am sure if I be faithful to thee in obedience, thou will be so to me in
gracious recompense, thy word is my warrant

The righteousness of thy testimonies is everlasting: give me understanding,
and I shall live.
144 The righteousness which thou prescribest in thy Law to be observed and
obeyed, is the only absolutely unchangeable infallible rule to be holy and
happy by, teach me and guide me in the knowledge and practice of it, and I
doubt not the consequence, because of thy faithfulness, preservation temporal
and salvation eternal, how deadly and desperate soever my condition seem, will
certainly be the issue.

Koph. Koph.
The ninetenth letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the nineteenth part.
145 Thou, I cried with my whole heart, hear me, O Lord; I will keep thy
statutes.
Lord, know the faithful and affectionate addresses I have made to thee in
this my distress, not as men naturally do by instinct of fear and grief, but of
faith and hope, Lord, therefore hear me praying in spirit, and grant my groans,
and what thou have or shall command me I will gratuitously observe, and by thy
grace make good my word.

146 It was thou alone that I put my confidence and hope in, I cried unto thee,
save me: and I shall keep thy testimonies.
in this my need, do not therefore deceive thy servant, nor frustrate my
expectations, but according to thy promise and my dependence, preserve, and
deliver me into a free and comfortable condition, wherein I may be able as well
as willing to do those things which are held forth in thy word to be thy will
and pleasure.

147 Night nor day have I ceased to solicit thee, I prevented the dawning of
the morning, and cried: I hoped in thy word.
my first thoughts are upon thee, I no sooner wake but my heart falls to work,
and before I can see I am bespeaking thee in prayer, for delay does not abate
but sharpen the edge of my hope in thy promise and faithfulness.

148 Yea, Mine eyes prevent the night watches, that I might meditate in thy
word.
early and late do I give my self to meditation and faithful consideration of
thy word, for to strengthen and direct me, consulting it at all times about all
things to be ruled by it.

149 Let me prevail, Hear my voice according unto thy loving kindness: O Lord,
quicken me according to thy judgment.
not, Lord, for my merits, but for thy grace sake, which I have ever in mine
eye, both as thy word specifies it, and thy works have always manifested it
to the faithful. Let my soul be evermore upheld in lively hope and expectation,
by the faith of thy respective righteousness of justice and mercy to me and
mine enemies, and let me effectually be delivered by it.

They draw nigh that follow after mischief: they are far from thy Law.
150 I am sharply assaulted and sorely pursued by mischievous minded men, void
of all conscience, to mine exceeding great hazard, such as greedily covet to do
evil, but are far from the thoughts or care of well-doing, diametrically
opposite in their ways to thy word, have no fear of God before their eyes.

Thou art near O Lord: and all thy commandments are truth.
151 Blessed be thy name, though they persecute me, and seemingly endanger me,
yet art thou as near to help, as they to hurt, and thou would not have
commanded me and thy faithful people so often in thy word to believe in thee,
wait for thee, and not to turn aside from thee to false refuges, and
unjustifiable courses, but that in faithfulness thou will protect and preserve
them that do so, and not let them be disappointed by so doing.

Concerning thy testimonies I have known of old, that thou have founded them
for ever.
152 For thine injunctions of that nature, they are as true and stable, and many
as firmly be believed in, as thou thy self, and have been in all ages
experimentally approved so to thy Church, and are so to be to thy people for
ever; grace and salvation shall always be their portion.

Resh.
Resh. The 20 letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the 20 part.
Consider mine affliction, and deliver me; for I do not forget thy Law.
153 Lord, consider mine affliction according to the nature and pressure of it,
which thou know is grievous, and let it move thee in compassion and mercy
to deliver me out of it, as thou have promised: For, for all my distemperature
I carefully and conscionably bear in mind both for my supportation and
direction, what thy word the rule of my life and foundation of my faith
exhibites, to walk thereafter, not fearing God the less for fear of men.

154 Thou know the goodness of my cause, Plead my cause, and deliver me:
quicken me according to thy word.
mine innocence, and the solitary helplesness of my condition, how all is
against me, and none for me, doing me all manner of wrong in word and deed, so
that I have none to fly but thee, and accordingly do I make mine humble
address to thy justice and mercy, to undertake and engage for me against mine
enemies, maintain, defend, and deliver me, and it from my wrong doers, cheer up
my heart in thy promises concerning it, and set me free from this impendent
death and destruction, as thou have promised.

155 I know thee too righteous to patronize mine enemies, Salvation is far from
the wicked: for they seek not thy statutes.
and their cause against me or mine; thou will not let me perish and them
prosper, but contrarily I know and am confident such wicked wretches are so far
from being saved and preserved by thee as that they shall be destroyed, for
they are under no promise, judgment belongs to them who neither care to know
nor do what thou have commanded.

156 Though mine afflictions be great and sorrows manifold, Great are thy
tender mercies, O Lord: quicken me according to thy judgments.
yet thy mercies are so too, wherewith thou tenderly compassionates thy people
under wrongful sufferance, O Lord, therefore cheer up my heart in the hopeful
expectation of thy righteous power and goodness, and faithfully fulfill it in my
actual deliverance.

157 I have had as much provocation to sin, Many are my persecutors, and mine
enemies: yet do I not decline from thy testimonies.
and temptation to diffidence, as can well be imagined, considering my manifold
dangers by open and secret enemies, and my wrongful injurious usages by word
and deed of my many slanderous bloudy-minded persecutours; Yet do I keep faith
and a good conscience, obey thy word, and will for all that.

I beheld the transgressors, and was gr^eved: because they kept not thy word.
158 Mine enemies and wrong-doers did not only trouble me, as to my self, but
it sadded me exceedingly for thee, to see thee so contemned, and thy word which
should be a Law to them, so despised by them, walking quite contrary.

Consider how I love thy precepts; quicken me, O Lord, according to thy loving
kindness.
159 Hereby thou may perceive the dear affection I bear to thy word and will
revealed in it, I beseech thee take notice of it in way of gracious
remuneration, and Lord, encourage me to hope, and do thou fulfill all that in
thy loving kindness and grace, thou have promised to those that do so.

Thy word is true from the beginning, and every one of thy righteous judgments
endures for ever.
160 Thy promises have lost nothing of their virtue and vigor by their long
standing, but are, as thou thy self art in goodness and faithfulness to thy
people, the same that ever they were, and so shall all thy righteous
engagements be to the end, no one word shall fall to the ground that thou have
spoken in way of promise to be believed in, or of reward to be hoped for, but
shall certainly be fulfilled to thy people and Church in one age as well as
another, hereafter as heretofore, and now as well as either.

Schin.
Schin. The 21 letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the 21 part.
Princes have persecuted me without a cause: but mine heart stands in aw of
thy word.
161 Mine enemies, as they have not been few, so nor mean, for the chief have
been chiefly against me, men of might and greatness that should yield
protection and right to the innocent and oppressed, contrarily they have turned
their power upon me to oppress and wrong me, to whom I never gave cause of
offense, but I am, I bles thee for it, not so transported with the fear of man,
as to forget God, thy word, the duty and reverence I ow to it, has taken such
rooting in my heart, that no earthly powers can extirpate it.

162 Whenever I have been hard beset by temptation, I rejoice at thy word, as
one that finds great spoil.
and thy word through grace has seasonably minded me of my faith and duty, it
has joyed mine heart beyond expression, no victor has joyed more in the
unexpected spoils of a conquered enemy.

163 All false ways and refuges are an abomination to me, I hate and abhor
lying: but thy Law do I love.
my mind and affections can entertain no treaty nor agreement with them, they
are utterly against the hair with me, but thy Law is as consentaneous and
connatural, as they are contrary and heterogenial, I love it at my heart.

164 Continually does my heart ejaculate thy praises, Seven times a day do I
praise thee: because of thy righteous judgments.
every foot am I lifting up my soul in way of thankful acknowledgement of thy
grace vouchsafed me, in seasonable and effectual revealing thy righteous truths
unto me, for my support and guidance, daily as I have need, which draws forth
praises proportionably.

165 What outward troubles soever happen unto thy people, Great peace have they
which love thy Law: and nothing shall offend them.
yet in the sincere filial affection they bear to thy word and will, to live up
and walk according to it, herein do they enjoy transcendent peace and happiness
surmounting all misery, for so they know they please thee, and are accepted of
thee, and having God and a good conscience on their side, what can trouble them?

And for my part what thy Law requires, Lord, I have hoped for thy salvation,
and done thy commandments.
that have I constantly and diligently endeavored to perform, both by firm
believing and exact walking. Thou Lord, know my hope of salvation has been
in thee and thee only in all my troubles; and my ways and works have been
ordered by thy precepts, not by mine own corrupt suggestions.

My soul has kept thy testimonies: and I love them exceedingly.
167 Nor have I served thee either formally or hypocritically, with outward
shows, or for base ends in the ways and works of obedience, but with an honest
sincere heart have I done thy commandments in love to thy righteous will
testified in thy word, which has my heart above all things.

I have kept thy precepts and thy testimonies: for all my ways are before thee.
168 Thy whole covenant and dispensation of thy will as well in one thing as
another, have I in faith and obedience carefully observed, without wilful
swerving. Thou know what I say to be true, who from heaven have beheld me
every step I have gone in this my troublesome pilgrimage of persecution, and as
thine eye has been upon me, so has mine eye been upon thee all the while, as
upon an all-seeing righteous judge and gracious rewarder, to aw and encourage
me.

Tau.
Tau. The 22 letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, signifying the 22 part.
Let my cry come near before thee: O Lord, give me understanding according to
thy word.
169 Lord, let me find favor in thine eyes, and my earnest prayer have audience
at thy throne of grace, in a thing so reasonable and consonant to thy mind, as
is this my request, to wit, that thou would give me a good and perfect
understanding of thy will effectually to be taught me by thy spirit at all
times, and in all things as occasion requires and thy word dictates, and which
is no more than thy word promises.

Let my supplication come before thee: deliver me according to thy word.
170 And as I pray to be heard concerning a good understanding to guide me in the
way, so also that I may have a gracious audience, and comfortable answer
concerning the end and determination of these my troubles, Lord, deliver me
from them, as well as order me in them, for so also is thy promise.

171 If thou will be the guide of my life, My lips shall utter praise; when thou
have taught me thy statutes.
and powerfully instruct me how to walk well-pleasingly all along this hour of
temptation, and time of trial in the end thereof, when thou shall have done so,
I will pour forth praise to thee in solemn wise at thy sanctuary.

172 Then will I magnify the faithfulness and righteousness of thy word, My
tongue shall speak of thy word: for all thy commandments are righteousness.
and teach others to trust in it and walk by it, for that they shall be sure to
find in the end, as I have done, that all it says is yea, and Amen, certain
and infallible, materially righteous it is in it self, and effectually so to
all that keep and observe it.

173 Lord, Let thine hand help me: for I have chosen thy precepts.
take my part who have taken thine, strengthen me against and deliver me from
mine enemies, and out of this my perilous state, fight for me, for I fight for
thee against the world and the flesh, and have chosen to embrace thy precepts
before their allurements, and preferred thy will in all things before their
suggestions to the contrary.

174 I have not sinfully shifted as I have been tempted to do, I have longed
for thy salvation, O Lord: and thy Law is my delight.
but have persevered in a faithful expectation and hopeful longing still for
thy promised salvation and deliverance, for, O Lord, thou know mine heart is
fixed upon nothing with contentment and confidence, but thy
covenant-dispensation for my welfare and happiness.

175 Do thou therefore tender me accordingly, Let my soul live, and it shall
praise thee: and let thy judgments help me.
let it not be in the power of mine enemies to deprive me of my soul, by taking
away my life, but preserve it, (as thou have redeemed it) from destruction,
that I may live by thy mercy and not perish by their cruelty that seek my
death, so shall I lay out and spend the life thou give me, in faithful
affectionate praises of thee all my days. Lord, let thy righteousness be
employed for me in my defense and preservation against mine enemies, their
cruelty and oppression, according as thy word holds forth for me to trust in
and rely on.

I have gone astray like a lost sheep, seek thy servant: for I do not forget
thy commandments.
176 In this wilderness of troubles that I am in, driven up and down from thy
presence and people like a sheep wandered from the flock, and out of the
Shepherds ken, I have, I humbly confess lost my way, and stepped aside out of
the direct and straight path I should have trod, by infirmity and frailty. O
thou that art my Lord, and God, the shepherd of my soul, whose I am, and whom
I desire to serve, bring me back again into the un-erring path of thy precepts,
and enjoyment of sweet communion with thee and thy people, by freedom from
these my troubles and temptations, for I have not cast off thy Law, though
through strength of temptation I have warped, but recollect my self and
remember thy commandments, approving and justifying, as holy and desirable, to
conform thereunto.

The cxx. PSALM.
David grounding his hopes upon former experience of mercy, prays to be
delivered from that sad disaster which Doegs slanderous misre-presentation of
him to Saul had brought him into. Prophetically he delivers his doom for it,
and sadly laments his own banishment by it, whereof he shows the necessity,
and pleads his own integrity.

A song of degrees.
Why these Psalms are called songs of degrees is unresolved amongst expositors,
nor is the thing much material to be known, but it is concluded most probably
for one of those two reasons. Either from the ascending of the voice by a
gradual rising in the tune, or else, because the Levites or Priests did sing
them in the ascent of the stairs to the Temple, or else standing upon the tops
of the stairs, or on some high place above the people, where either they sung
them alone, or begun them to the people, the better to be seen and heard. Psalm
cxx.


1 I Have had experience of Gods good grace to me, IN my distress I cried unto
the Lord, and he heard me.
for heretofore when I have been in jeopardie, I put up my earnest prayer to
him, and truly I was heard in what I prayed for, had deliverance and
preservation out of my danger.

2 And this incourageth me still to apply my self to him when ever I have need,
Deliver my Soul, O Lord, from lying lips, and from a deceitful tongue.
or that any thing aileth me; Good Lord, look upon my wronged innocence, the
cause of my cruel persecution, and deliver me from the mischievous false
reports suggested against me by Doeg to Saul, that fawning sycophant and lying
informer, for which I run hazard to lose my life if God preserve it not.

3 Thou art in hope to get favor and preferment for this thy wicked
officiousness, What shall be given unto thee? or what shall be done unto thee
thou false tongue?
whereas thy reward shall be of a far other nature, I doubt not but God will
requite thee, he will give thee thy desert, and pay thee thy wages for such
service done against his chosen, thy false and slanderous tongue shall have its
recompense.

4 Even the mischief that by falsehood it brings upon me, Sharp arrows of the
mighty, with coals of juniper.
exasperating the displeasure and implacably inkindling the anger of Saul
against me to destroy me, shall justly by a mightier hand be retorted upon thy
self, for God shall one day let thy conscience loose upon thee, which shall be
as so many pointed arrows in thy bosom shot from an Almighty arm, yea, the
unutterable torments, and unquenchable fire of hell it self shall be thy
portion.

Woe is me, that I sojourn in Mesech, that I dwell in the tents of Kedar.
5 Woe is me that by thy pernicious lies I am persecuted and driven into exile
from the enjoyment of Gods ordinances, and Communion of his people in the land
of the living, to wander in strange places, and cohabit amongst Gentiles void
of the knowledge and fear of God, and common humanity, as bad to me as if I
were in the barbarous and savage country and confines of Arabia, being forced
out of the pale of the Church to shift for my life.

My soul has long dwelt with him that hates peace.
6 My life has been in a great deal of danger along time, and sundry ways in
the land of Canaan where I inhabited as long as possibly I could, being loath to
leave it till I must needs, laboring by all means possible to be in peace with
Saul, that I might be quiet, but nothing would do to gain his good opinion, or
persuade with him, such deadly hatred does he and his party bear me, and so
irreconcilable are they to me.

I am for peace: but when I speak, they are for war.
7 Lord, thou know how I have labored for atonement, and how much I desire
peace contrary to what is falsely suggested against me, as if by rebellion I
sought to get the Kingdom, nor can I be heard speak for my self to acquit mine
innocence, but am condemned and proscribed, nothing will serve them but my
blood, that they are resolved to have, and with hostile rage proclaim it.

The cxxi. PSALM.
The Psalmist abasing all false and earthly subtersuges, advances God only in
his valuation, and recommends him for sole protector to the whole Church and
every member of it, to trust in and rely upon, promising to such in his name
safety against all annoyances and direction and success in their affairs and
enterprises.

See the title of the 120 Psalm. Psalm cxxi. A song of degrees.


1 MAny men have many refuges and different confidences, I Will lift up mine
eyes unto the hills from whence comes my help.
whereunto in time of danger they fly, and wherein they trust, but for my part
I put more confidence in faithful prayer addressed toward the sanctuary of
God, that pledge of his presence situate upon those hills Moriah and Sion in
Jerusalem, than in the highest mountain or strongest Fort on earth, thence is
my help and hope, and from thence will I seek and expect it in greatest danger
(like as the faithful shall from heaven, where shall be their confidence, and
whither the Churches prayers shall be addressed in all emergencies.)

2 Because the Lord God is there as in heaven, My help comes from the Lord,
which made heaven and earth.
especially resident for mine aid and assistance, no Idol God do I mean, such
as the heathen worship and expect aid from, but the only true God, that by his
Allmighty power made heaven and earth, from him and only him, who both can and
will bestead me and all the faithful, it is that I hope for help, and so shall
they.

3 Be thou confident of it for thy self, He will not suffer thy foot to be
moved, he that keeps thee will not slamber.
and let others for themselves be so too that are his, and trust faithfully in
him, that he will protect and have a care of such, that they shall not miscarry
by any power or malice on earth, no accident or emergencie can befall thee, that
he is not privy to, whose eye is never off his church and every member of it,
yea, upon every member of that member, from head to foot

Behold, he that keeps Israel shall neither slumber nor sleep.
4 Take it for a truth infallible, That God, that by his covenant of grace has
taken upon him the guidance and guardianship of his faithful Church and people
will never break his word, his protection is not as man's is, subject to
miscarriage, and who himself had need be protected, but he is omniscient as
well as omnipotent, he sees and knows all things always, so that nothing at
no time acts without him, nor can act against him to the prejudice of his
people.

The Lord is thy keeper, the Lord is thy shade upon thy right hand.
5 And what he is to all his whole Church, that he is to every one, each member
may apply the covenant and promises to it self that are made to the body,
touching grace and protection, that God is particularly his undoubted helper
and preserver, yea, that always at all times in all perils he is at hand to
shelter and shield him.

The sun shall not smite thee by day; nor the moon by night.
6 Night and day will God protect thee from whatsoever would annoy thee, no
created Being whatsoever of it self has or shall have power to offend thee:
The creatures above thee in the heavens, sun, moon and stars, whose influences
and operations thou of thy self can not avoid by any humane wisdom or power,
are yet subject to God and under him, and shall have no more power to hurt thee
through his gracious providence and protection over thee, than a worm under thy
feet.

The Lord shall reserve thee from all evil: he shall preserve thy soul.
7 Fear neither less nor more, great nor small, for God shall certainly protect
thee as well from one evil as another, especially thy soul, whether respecting
life temporal or eternal, shall have a special guard, fear that least, because
as it is most of wroth in it self, so also in Gods esteem and valuation.

8 God is every where in all places at all times; The Lord shall preserve thy
going out, and thy coming in, from this time forth and even for evermore.
thou need not put cases of fear and doubt to thy self of this though not
that may befall me, and then though not now, for whatsoever thou do, and
whither ever thou go, God is with thee and it, and will ever be so to keep
thee from evil, and bless thee with good, and to prosper thee in all thy ways
of well-doing, believe it steadfastly, and live comfortably in the faith thereof.

The cxxii. PSALM.
David overjoyed to see the universal concord and conformity in his people for
the bringing the Ark to Jerusalem, and worshipping the Lord there, as God had
appointed; the more to sharpen them to it, and ingratiate it to them, highly
commends the prerogative of that place and that people by reason of it: and
therefore exhorts them not to degenerate, but in love and zeal still to labor
and pray for the happiness of it, promising happiness to those that do so, and
so does he himself, and shows the reasons why.

See the title of the 120 Psalm, Psalm cxxii. A song of degrees of David.
the Authors name superadded here.

1 HOw infinitely did it rejoice me to hear and see such an universal unanimity
in my people Israel to submit to, I Was glad when they said unto me, let us go
into the house of the Lord.
and approve of the transportation and fixing the Ark and sanctuary in
Jerusalem where God had appointed it, with desire and forwardness to worship
God there, without the least scruple or question.

2 Saying, Our feet shall stand within thy gates, O Jerusalem.
amongst themselves with rejoicing, now is the time, and Jerusalem is the place
that God will fulfill his promise by giving his Ark a settled condition, which
hitherto has moved and removed from place to place, and together with his Ark
his Church and people Israel, who have been both for worship and Government in
an unsettled and various state, but now shall there be an happy establishment,
as both Christ and the Church by Christ shall have at his glorifying.

Jerusalem is builded as a City, that is compact together.
3 And indeed a blessed and desirable place Jerusalem is exceeding lovely, for
uniformitie of structure, order in Government and harmony of hearts and
affections in the inhabitants toward the true worship of the only true God,
stately and strong both in men, and materials, sweetly composed and well
compact, a City specially blessed of God to represent the happy condition of
his Church both under Christ on earth, united by faith in him their head, and
with Christ in heaven.

Whither the tribes go up, the tribes of the Lord, unto the testimony of
Israel, to give thanks unto the name of the Lord.
4 It is the most beautiful place of the world, and enriched with the most
singular and Divine privileges of any on earth, being a resemblance of heaven
it self and the Church both there and here, for as thither the twelve tribes of
Israel, a chosen generation out of the whole world do congregate and ascend to
the mount of God, solemnly to worship him before the Ark the testimony of his
covenant and presence with his people, so shall his elect the Church of the
first born all the world over be gathered to Jesus, and ascend into the
heavenly Jerusalem, evermore to praise him in that general assembly the
celestial Quire of innumerable Angels, and spirits of just men made perfect,
Yea, by spirit and faith they shall meet in one body mystical on earth, and
with raised affections worship one God in Christ, that blessed Emmanuel the
mediator of the new testament upon mount Sion in spiritual Jerusalem, the
Church, that City of the living God.

5 And as Christ's Priestly office is established and clearly held forth in the
sanctuarie-worship in Jerusalem, For there are set thrones of judgment: the
thrones of the house of David.
so also is his Kingly in those thrones of honor and justice civil and
ecclesiastical, erected and perpetuated there in the royal line of David and
his posterity, Kings of Judah, the figure and progenitors of Christ according
to the flesh as is his tribunal in heaven, where he has dominion over his
Church and the whole world, and from whence he shall come to judge all flesh at
the latter day.

6 Many are the enemies of this flourishing City Jerusalem, Pray for the peace
of Jerusalem, they shall prosper that love thee.
as shall be to the Church, yea, all the world is against it, and the worship
and Government that is in it, but yet we need not fear, for God is for it, able
to preserve it in peace and prosperity maugre all its adversaries, if our sins
and carnal presumption do not indispose him to it. Therefore all ye Israelites,
specially ye that with a spiritual understanding are enlightened to know the
worth and excellency of the place, which is in the world as the sun is in the
firmament, mystically comprehending all that Divine light and life, that the
sun of righteousness the Messiah shall illuminate the world withal when he
comes to save his Church as Gods High Priest, and take possession of his
Kingdom, as King of Kings and Lord of Lords; do you serve the Lord and seek to
him for the continuation of his grace and favor to it, and his blessing upon
it, that it may be evermore happy with his love and presence, and as a
consequent thereof, have rest and quiet from its enemies. And of this be
confident, that they that thus for Christ and religion sake, under that notion
and relation, sincerely love, pray for and endeavor the happiness of it;
shall, how ever it may suffer by other men's sins, and formal hypocrisies,
within the pale, or without by external violence of Gentile enemies, be
themselves happy and blessedly rewarded of God, with grace, peace, and
protection in their own particulars.

Peace be within thy walls, and prosperi^ie within thy palaces.
7 It is and shall be my hearty prayer, that the Lord will preserve thee as
from outward foreign enemies, so also from intestine civil broils and
disunions, in peace, unanimity and concord within thy self, as the Church shall
be in heaven, and ought to be on earth; as one, so at one, under their one and
only head the Lord Christ. And that the throne of David, his royal seed, and
successors over his people Israel here in Jerusalem may successively flourish
in peace and prosperity and by the blessing and favor of God be established
in judgment and righteousness there administered in honorable equipage, as
shall the Prince of peace, Christ Jesus the righteous his throne and dominion
over his Church be for ever in heaven.

For my brethren and companions sake, I will now say, Peace be with thee.
8 Nor am I a self-seeker in my well-wishes to this place, no, the Lord can
witness for me that I desire the good and happiness of all the faithful, yea,
of all Israel, as mine own, who to me are as dear as my nearest kindred and
acquaintance, by that relation natural and civil that God has given me to
them, knowing right well that in the peace and prosperity of it, the
Government and worship in it, consists the happiness and tranquillity of all
Israel, chiefly the Israel of God, whose heaven upon earth Jerusalem is, where
they worship and serve the God of Israel, seek his face and enjoy his presence,
therefore pray I for her prosperity and welfare, that they may be blessed
with her and by her, who are interessed and concerned equally in her felicity
with my self, I as the head, and they as the body.

9 It is the zeal I have to the Church and glory of God that makes me pray
thus, Because of the house of the Lord our God, I will seek thy good.
and for which I will spend and be spent, therefore will I lay out mine
uttermost endeavors to compass the good and welfare of Jerusalem, that that
singular happiness and privilege of the sanctuary, and sanctuarie-worship of
the Lord God of Israel, who there is present with us his people, and from
thence hears our prayers, and to which appertains so many excellent promises,
and by it to us redounds so many precious privileges and benefits; and where
is performed the only true honor and service to the only true God in all the
world. Therefore for these reasons do I, will I, evermore pray, and faithfully
endeavor the good of this place, and so let all others do that are good,
together with me, as members of the Church and body mystical, typified in this
resemblance.

The cxxiii. PSALM.
The Church and people of Israel being at present either under Babylons
captivity or Antiochus his cruelty, some Prophet or holy man of God bespake
the Lord in this pathetical short psalm in her behalf, uttering much of the
spirit in few words; for afflictions commonly swell the heart too big for the
mouth, which makes him here to pray rather by signs than words, with his eyes
rather than his tongue, yea, with both he presses hard upon God for free grace
to show them mercy in their unspeakable misery, professing their patient
waiting till then.

See the title of the 120 Psalm. Psalm cxxiii. A song of degree^


1 WHat the present distress and calamities of thy poor Church and people
Israel are, UNto thee lift I up mine eye^, O thou that dwell in the heavens.
thou Lord know right well, utterly helpless and hopeless, forlorn and
disconsolate, none on earth favoring us, showing any mercy or compassion to
us, but exercise all manner of cruelty and scorn toward us; yet, Lord, in thy
Churches and mine own behalf I am an humble suitor to thee in the agony of my
heart, who, I dare not, can not, believe, have quite forgotten to be gracious,
though thou seem so as things frame here below, but, O thou that inhabitest
the heavens, and have thy reserves of good will and pleasure there known to thy
self, unknown to us, but hoped in by us, and power to bring them to pass,
though to us impossible, as much above all sublunarie powers as heaven is above
earth, to thee there, with groans and sighs lift we up our eyes, speechless
with grief, for thee graciously to look down upon us here in this our calamity.

Beho^d, as the eyes of servants look unto the hand of their maiters, and as
the eyes of a maiden unto the hand of her mistress: so our eyes wait upon the
Lord our God, until that he have mercy upon us.
2 Look how bondmen and bond-women, who by their condition are (as we) exposed
to hard and uncourteous usage, depend upon the free grace and beneficence of
their masters and mistesses, can challenge nothing, no wages, nor reward, but
wait with patience till pity and compassion move them to extend their hand of
favor and good will to them; so do we under this just deserved punishment of
long and grievous thraldom by cruel taskmasters, humbly and patiently wait
till thine own mercy move thee toward us a sinful undeserving people, yet thy
people, and thou our God by grace and election, which hold us in hope.

Have mercy upon us, O Lord, have mercy upon us; for we are exceedingly
filled with contempt.
3 Good Lord, take our case into consideration and commiseration, to pity us at
last, and to show mercy to us, a people that are made the very scum and scorn
of our proud imperious enemies, who for thy sake, whose name we bear and whose
we are, do Lord it over us with disdain, which imbitters our sorrows and breaks
our hearts.

4 Yea, Our soul is exceedingly filled with the scorning of those that are at
ease, and with the contempt of the proud.
Lord, it is not to be spoken how afflictive the reprochful vilifications of
our insolent enemies are to us, who judging by events, because of our
calamities scoff and scorn us as a vain besotted people, that believe in we
know not what, and worship we know not whom, and boast themselves unmeasurably
over us, our God, and religion, to our unutterable grief, because of their
superiority and present felicity, which puffs them up with pride and
contempt, even to blasphemy.

The cxxiv. PSALM.
David minds Israel in their prosperity of their adversity, to make them
mindful of God, praiseful to God, and evermore dependent on God, as his Church
and people ought ever to be, in their transmutations of estates and fortunes.
Psalm cxxiv.


See the title of the 120 Psalm, A song of degrees of David.
the Authors name superadded here.

1, 2, 3 NOw that the Lord has been pleased to bring us to the happy
condition we are in, IF it had not been the Lord who was on our side; now may
Israel say:
we should do well to look back, we the Israel and and Church of God, If it had
not been the Lord who was on our side, when men rose up against us:
and consider from the beginning to this day, ever since we were a people
chosen of the Lord out of the world to name his name upon, Then they had
swallowed us up quick, when their wrath was kindled against us.
what a world of enemies we have had, and perils we have waded through before
and since we came into this land, where we have been a continual eyesore not
only to the natives remaining in it, but to all the mighty nations and
Gentile people bordering round about it, who severally and jointly by
combination of great men and Potentates, have sundry times and ways subtly
projected, and violently attempted our utter abolition, which to speak humanely
was inavoidable, had not the Lord our good God miraculously from time to time
delivered us from their fury, and preserved us a people to this day, maugre
all they could do (as he shall his Church spite of the wicked world its power
and malice) who else long ere this had been no people nor nation, but destroyed
again and again, by those many mighty barbarous enemies of ours that on all
hands from all quarters have assailed us, with most mortal and bloody purposes
greedy to prey upon us; and with that odds of strength, that they were able to
have devoured us, and as it were swallowed us alive, as easily as the great
fish does the little ones, or the savage and ravenous beast tears his prey in
pieces, if God had not overpowered them, and been for us against them when we
were altogether unable to make resistance, which now we should do well to weigh
seriously, and in all humility to acknowledge thankfully to his praise and
glory.

Then the waters had overwhelmed us, the stream had gone over our soul.
4, 5 Yea, to consider that when all mankind was as it were against us, and we
were like sheep in the midst of Wolves and Bears, that with mighty power and
rage have broken in upon us like an unresistable torrent, Then the proud waters
had gone over our soul.
able to overrun the whole land and destroy man, woman, and child, as easily
as the sea, or some mighty river drowns the country when it breaks the
banks, and with pride and confident disdain made sure to do it, and no doubt
had done it long ere this, but that God would not let them, but still preserved
and wonderfully delivered us from being swept away with a total destruction as
was intended, and easy else to have been effected by them.

6 O let us lay it seriously to heart, Blessed be the Lord: who has not given
us, as a prey to their teeth.
and heartily bless and praise the Lord our God, for so long preserving, and so
many sundry times delivering us by no less than miraculous power from the
cruelty, and outrage of such barbarous bloody enemies, and that has not been
provoked by our sinful ingratitude, himself to give us for a prey to their
destructive malice, as in justice he might.

7 But has brought us notwithstanding all their power, Our soul is escaped as
a bird out of the snare of the fowlers; the snare is broken, and we are escaped.
malice, and treachery, wherewith we have been long ensnared and endangered on
all hands into a state of liberty and freedom, not only given us our lives
for a prey, but a liberty from them, yea, a superiority above them, insomuch
as now we are as much too strong for them, as they were wont to be too strong
for us, and have them as much at an under as they had us, their strength is
become weakness, and by his goodness our weakness is become strength, too
strong for them.

8 Let the power and goodness of God have the praise and glory of what is done
and wrought for us, Our help is in the name of the Lord, who made heaven and
earth.
both as to our preservation and exaltation, and as in time past we have found
him, so for time to come let us believe in him, as ought the Church and people
of God to do in all ages of the world: Let us and they magnify his power and
goodness in all estates and times, not despairing in adversity, nor presuming
in prosperity, but in the one hopefully, and in the other humbly believe in
him as our all-sufficient and only deliverer and preserver, not fearing, nor
Idolizing an arm of flesh or second causes, but rely on, and seek to the only
true God that made all things, and disposes all things, and is able to help
above all power to hurt, if we believe; and to hurt above all power to help, if
we presume.

The cxxv. PSALM.
For the encouragement of the faithful and sincere hearted, the Psalmist tells
them, as what they must meet with, so what they may trust in, firm protection
in their sorest affliction. And adds prayer to promise. But bids the
hypocrites, hands off, tells them their doom, that are in, but not of the
Church, to whom only blessedness belongs. Psalm cxxv.


See the title of the 120 Psalm. A song of degrees.


THey that trust in the Lord shall be as mount Sion, which cannot be removed,
but abides for ever.
1 BElieve firmly in the Lord, and you shall be established, every such an one
is as dear to God as mount Sion it self, where is his Temple, Ark, and all his
sanctuarie-worship, every faithful servant of God, being spiritually all these,
a living Temple, Priest, and sacrifice, a very heaven on earth, in whom God is
really, more than typically present, and to whom belongs all the promises made
to the Church in general, so that though he may be externally assaulted, and
seemingly endangered with ghostly enemies, and manifold temptations and trials,
as Jerusalem by the Gentile nations round about, yet shall the same invincible
guard and protection be upon him, and them that so believe, as upon it, so that
the gates of hell shall never prevail against them to un-establish or
disinterest them, as to the rock whereon they, and the whole Church of God are
built unmoveably by faith, Christ Jesus.

As the mountains are round about Jerusalem, so the Lord is round about his
people from henceforth even for ever.
2 See you the hills that compass this City Jerusalem, hence let your faith,
helped by setting your imagination on work, raise a suitable Idea of Gods
encompassing his faithful Church and people, yea every such one, by his
Almighty power and guard of Angels for their sure defense, and preservation
against all assaults of the world and devil, who also surround them, and this
is as everlasting as those mountains; an infallible truth for all and every
faithful servant of the Lord in all ages, and places of the world now and ever
to trust unto.

3 Not that the godly are in this world exempt from oppression and temptation,
For the rod of the wicked shall not rest upon the lot of the righteous: lest
the righteous put forth their hands unto iniquity.
no, for they are the great eyesore of Satan the Prince of the world, and all
his malignant instruments, and natural Subjects, the men of the world, which
with their utmost malice and power shall labor to afflict the faithful, as the
Gentile nations do Israel, and, partly for their sins, partly for their trial
and exercise of their graces, which God sets much by, they may be permitted to
sit sore upon their skirts, and put them to it, but this be sure of, that the
siedge shall be raised before the Town be taken, no afflictions, nor afflictors
by what ever wicked practices, shall any longer be permitted to oppress the
righteous than they have grace to sustain them under it; God always gages one
by the other, afflictions to the faithful are often less, never more; tempted
they may be and sint, hey may by their frailty and strength of temptation, but
fall away by sinning they never shall, for God is faithful, who will not
suffer them to be tempted above that they are able, but will with the
temptation make a way to escape, that they may be able to bear it.

4 This is thy promise which as in faithfulness it is Do good, O Lord, unto
those that be good, and to them that are upright in their hearts.
made, so as faithfully shall it be performed to those that are faithful and
holy, but thou will be sought unto by them and for them, for thy promise and
its performance is of grace not of debt, even to the righteous themselves; O
Lord, therefore be entreated in the name and for the sake of all thy people, to
be ever mindful of it to do according to it in time of need; Let mercy and
protection be extended seasonably and effectually to those that themselves are
good, and suffer in a cause that is good by those that are evil. Yea, bless
with all manner of blessings those that in sincerity of heart believe in thee,
and are careful to please thee with integrity of soul, and universalitie of
obedience active and passive.

As for such as turn aside unto their crooked ways, the Lord shall lead them
forth with the workers of iniquity: but peace shall be upon Israel.
5 But as for those linsy-woolfy professors, Israelites after the flesh, that
have a room in the Church, but no firm rooting in religion, that serve the Lord
in show, and not in substance, neither know him perfectly, believe in him
firmly, nor serve him sincerely, either with a right heart, or by a right rule,
but are divided in their faith and affections, trusting and obeying by halves,
deviating into by-ways and carnal confidences of their own to their own
self-pleasing; such hypocrites. counterfeits in piety, how ever commixed with
the Godly, partakers of their outward privileges and formal worshippers of the
same God in the self-same ordinances, yet the all-seeing and heart-searching
eye of God knows them, notes them, and esteems them, as bad as the very
Gentiles who worship Idols, these making an Idol of the true God when they
worship him, and their reward and portion shall be alike, judgment shall be
pronounced against them both, and they cast out, the vile from the precious,
which here are undistinguished, into the place of execution and torment
together. But blessed are they that are Israelites indeed, that worship God in
spirit and in truth, who only are the Israel and Church of God, grace and
peace from God their Father, through Christ their Savior, shall be their
portion, interessed in their consciences, to their unspeakable consolation
here, with assurance of glory hereafter.

The cxxvi. PSALM.
This Psalm shows the excess of joy the Jews, specially the Godly, had at Gods
wonderful infranchising them after their long captivity in Babylon, which the
heathen themselves admired God for, but much more his people, who pray for
accomplishment of those happy beginnings, and promise out of their own
experience and ^aith, that all Gods people that undergo afflictions patiently,
shall have them end happily.

See the title of the cxx. Psalm. Psalm cxxvi. A song of degrees.


1 AFter we had endured a long and grievous captivity in Babylon, WHen the
Lord turned again the captivity of Sion; we were like them that dream.
(the figure of Satan and Antichrist) exiled out of our own country, and from
the privileges we there enjoyed of worshipping God in Jerusalem, at last when
the set time was come, prefixed long before by Jeremiah's prophecy, and that
according thereunto, the Lord so miraculously moved the heart of Cyrus, a
heathen Potentate, to proclaim our liberty with so much unexpected favor and
accommodation for our journey, and entertainment at our journeys end when we
came into Canaan, with leave there to dwell, and to rebuild Jerusalem and the
Temple, and there to worship God as formerly. It was so great a mercy after so
long a misery, so unexpected and improbable, considering the disproportion of
our abject condition, and Cyrus his greatness, not worth his taking notice of,
and so strange to come of himself, an Infidel and Pagan, together with the
suddenness of it, and the over-joy we conceived at it, that we know not whether
we apprehended it sleeping or waking; we could scarce believe our own ears,
what we heard of it, or our own hearts what we thought of it to be real,
fearing the certainty, and yet hoping the truth.

Then was our mouth filled with laughter, and our tongue with singing: then
said they among the heathen* the Lord has done great things for them.
2 But when we had overcome our amazement, and were come to our selves, and had
digested the certainty and wonderfulness of the thing; O the unexpressable joy
that we were in, like men besides our selves, not knowing how to vent our
passions, sometimes congratulating it amongst our selves, with inarticulate
laughter, and hands lifted up to heaven in stupefied admiration,
other-sometimes, more soberly resolving our joy into articulate expressions of
thanks and praises, expressed in Psalms and Hymns. And as God overpowered the
King to grant it, so he convinced the very heathens in their kind to magnify
him for it; those with whom we were captive, could not but see and admire the
finger of God in this their own very act of our deliverance, so much against
their nature and interest, and to acknowledge both the transcendencie of the
King, and of the power that wrought it to the glory of our God, whom they were
forced to magnify in our behalfs, that formerly had contemned both him and us.

The Lord has done great things for us: whereof we are glad.
3 Surely we can say no less of it, than they; that the Lord has wrought
wonders for us; yea, let us at least go one step beyond them, as we have cause:
If they that are blind Idolaters, and bare spectatours, are yet so far
enlightened by it, as to have the sight of God in it, and to magnify (though
not gratify) him for it; let us do more, every way indear it, that are the
immediate subjects of so rich mercy, not only see his power and greatness,
(as they do) but admire his love and goodness, thank him for it as a benefit
inestimable, as well as praise him for it as a miracle, and with a holy avarice
take the praises out of their mouths that are no sharers in it, and
appropriate both him and it wholly to our selves, by a joyful welcome of God
again amongst us in his declarative goodness, and thankful acknowledgement of
his favor.

4 O Lord, Turn again our captivity, O Lord, as the streams in the south.
go on to show thine omnipotency, as in begetting and beginning, so in the
progression, and perfecting this great work of our return from captivity, and
re-establishment in Canaan, that as the sun in its season, makes streams like
rivers to run in the droughtie deserts of southern countries, where naturally
there are none to the refreshing of the thirsty traveller, by dissolving snow
and ice from high hills, and remote parts; so, O Lord, let thy favor, now it is
returned upon us, go on to move and melt the heathenish hearts of Cyrus, his
Princes and people on our behalfs, and to our infinite rejoicing, to forward us
homeward to Judah out of this our Babylonish captivity under them, which with
so much hardship we have long endured, as also the frozen and carnal hearts of
thine own very Israel, to accept this opportunity, and offer themselves
willingly (as thy people shall do in the day of thy power, and Gospel-jubilee,)
in one joint complete body, universally, and unanimously to return (as rivers
by instinct run toward the sea from whence they came) to repossess and
replenish our desolate country, that as a wilderness is uninhabited, except by
barbarous and savage people, without form or beauty of Church or
Commonwealth, and neither for fear or sloth, in respect of difficulties, or
dangers in the journey or at the journeys end, faithlesly draw back, choose to
stay and refuse to go, as carnal Christians will the tender of grace, embracing
rather this present world.

They that sow in tears, shall reap in joy.
5 The Lord will never quite forsake his people, we are a perfect emblem of his
faithfulness to the faithful, that submit to him and wait upon him; O the sad
hearts that we left our country withal at the command of God, by his prophet
Jeremiah, to put our necks into this long Babylonish yoke, but our sins and
Gods decree had so destined it, either so or worse, therefore though with great
renitencie, as the needy husbandman in time of dearth, casts his corn which
should stustain him, for seed into the ground, in hope of future gain by
present loss, so we with a willing willingness, for obedience sake, put our
selves into thraldom, loath to displease, and as loath to leave our liberty and
country, in hope and expectation of a joyful return and deliverance as the
Church and people of God shall ever have out of their sufferings) from out this
bondage, as now it is made good unto us, our joy surpassing our sorrow a
hundred fold.

He that goes forth and weepeth, hearing precious seed, shall doubtless ^ome
again wi^h rejoicing, bringing his sheaves with him.
6 We are set for the encouragement of the Church in whole, and in every part,
for what is true in the general, is applicable to each particular, the members
singly sharing the promise among them that is made to the body jointly,
therefore may all and every one that is godly, be confident that what precious
faith and patience in obedience to God they sow in affliction, they shall at
last reap it again in reward and consolation: God will wipe all tears from
their eyes, let them not fear it how improbable soever, as he has done from
us; Jeremiahs good sighs that went out of Canaan submittingly, carrying along
with us the faithful hope and expectation of Gods engagement, though loath to
depart from that good land which God had given us to worship him in, but yet
did put our selves upon adventure, and have outlived our sorrows, and at last
enjoy those promises in their accomplishment, though after so many years, in
all which time God has preserved us, and his promise sustained us in hope, and
now at the appointed period, delivered us by an Almighty hand, and strange
providence, to our admiration, and joy unspeakable, and should encourage us to
take the opportunity God has now put into our hands, not consulting with flesh
and blood to break through all difficulties, and discommodities, either in the
journey, or at the journeys end, which fear and faithlesness may represent to
deter us, in confidence, that as they that obedientially came; do live to go,
so they that in this imperfect condition adventures upon God, obey his call,
and rely upon his grace, shall in like sort be enabled to undergo, and survive
all imaginable evils, and have their faith and patience abundantly rewarded
with grace and peace, and themselves at last established again in quiet in the
holy Land and City.

The cxxvii. PSALM.
This Psalm is conceived to be penned rather by Solomon himself, than by David
^or him, and to be a compendium of his Ecclesiastes: the style and matter owns
him, the subject it treats being politics, government civil, and domestic,
the part appointed him by God more especially to act both in scripture, and in
practice, which he handles not as a mere moralist or Philosopher, but as a
divine, instructing in all civil and natural affairs, to eye God by faith, and
to make him the efficient and final cause in all public transanctions, and
private business or blessing, else we take course to set God against us, and so
to loose all our labor in all we do, and in all we hope and desire. And
shows what is the best, and most desirable blessing under heaven, that brings
most happiness to a man's self, and makes him most useful to the public; to
wit, a numerous and godly offspring.

Psalm cxxvii. A Song of degrees for (or as in the margin, of) Solomon.
See the Title of the 120. Psalm, the Authors name super-added here.

EXcept the Lord build the house, they labor in vain that build it: except the
Lord keep the city, the watchman waketh but in vain.
1 MOst men act upon their own principles, in their own affairs and callings,
without any eye to God, or faith in God for direction, or success, apprehending
issues naturally to ensue upon use of means, as they project and design;
whereas it is far otherways, for the Lord is all in all, nothing can prosper
without him; it is not enough toward the building of an house, (whether
materially, or civilly considered,) to have the persons and things that conduce
thereunto; the art of Artificers, and the wisdom of a Pater-familias will not
serve to erect, or order and well govern it, or raise and enrich posterity
without the blessing of God; he can, and does therefore often times blast their
endeavors, and befool their skill, because he is not made the first cause, and
the last end; not sought to for a blessing, nor intended to be blessed for the
success, when second causes are set up above him, and a man is his own Idol,
and kisseth his own hands. And as in government domestic, so in that which is
civil and popular, there is the same error committed: men of place,
Statesmen, and politicians stand on their heads (like children) and shake
their heels at heaven; but let such learn from me that know it, and by the
blessing of God have as much wisdom, if not more, than other men, that it is
neither wise for sight and advice, nor vigilancie and diligence, nor power and
strength; it is indeed nothing either in a military, or civil way that can
order, or secure any country, place, or people, from foreign, or intestine
evils, but the gracious, provident, and watchful eye, and ruling hand of God;
none can prevent accidents, overruled hearts, frustrate designs, bless
endeavors, but the Lord alone, infinite unexpected occurrences will, nay,
shall purposely fall out, to endanger and deceive them that are carnally
confident in an arm of fleshly wisdom, strength, or diligence, if not to ruin
them. Therefore use the means, but subserviently, trust in the Lord only, seek
him, and seek to him faithfully and self-denyingly, else look not to succeed or
prosper, or not to be blessed but cursed in prospering, either in the one or
other.

2 How do men moil and toil in the world, It is vain for you to rise up early,
to sit up late, to eat the bread of sorrow: for so he gives his beloved sleep.
some to compass riches, others, other designs, their heads and hands in
continual action, scarce allowing themselves time to cherish, and sustain
nature by sleep or food, which very repasts are also imbittered by inordinate
carefulness through diffidence and vnacquaintance with God, not considering
that all they do is fruitless and labor lost, if God pronounce not a Fiat, and
say not Amen, to what they design and solicit, though never so eagerly, which
yet is certainly true, if they did believe it, and knew to live by faith, how
would it moderate and quiet their thoughts, make their lives much more
comfortable, and enjoy themselves, and the blessings God gives them with
contentment; for so do all they that inwardly feed upon the sweet sense and
assurance of Gods love, and are happier in that, than the cares of the world
can make them; and whose hearts by believing are stayed on the Lord for this,
he recompenceth it into their bosoms with recumbancy of spirit, so that they
enjoy him, themselves, and the blessings less or more he bestows upon them,
free from perplexities, with abundant soul-satisfaction, and continual quiet,
which carking wordly-minded men loose, and their labor besides.

Lo, children are an heritage of the Lord: and the fruit of the womb is his
reward.
3 And as some men's ambition and contentment, is in honor and riches, and such
like earthly felicities, whereto they bend themselves with might and main, and
think to compass them by wit and industry, but are deceived: so others desire
to be rich in children, and a good desire it is, if moderated by submission,
and mixed with faith, but in this also do men and women miscarrie, having their
expectation more upon natural causes, in natural production, than upon Gods
supernatural agencie. Whereas, it is nor strength nor pregnancie of nature in
either sex that can assure posterity; but the power and free-gift of God, that
can only make parents happy with a happy issue, which he dispenses of grace
to whom he pleases.

As arrows are in the hands of a mighty man: so are children of the youth.
4 A numerous and virtuous offspring is an unspeakable blessing of God, he that
has them is fitted by them for all assaies, as a strong and valiant man
skilful in martial affairs, and plentifully provided of ammunition, darts, and
arrows, can with honor and advantage to himself, and them that employ him, for
offense, and defense discharge them hither and thither; so a father blessed
with an hopeful and plentiful issue in the flower of his age, is himself
blessed by it, and of God made to be a blessing to the commonwealth where he
lives, being thereby more than ordinarily useful, fitted to do God and it
service in any kind, sacred, civil, and military, as God disposes and adapts,
so he has them to dispose of, for public weal in Church or State.

5 There are diversity of imaginary happiness, Happy is the man that has his
quiver full of them: they shall not be ashamed, but they shall speak with the
enemies in the gate.
but certainly of all earthly ones, this is really the best, and that man the
happiest that has his house and family well filled with such living riches,
that no money can purchase, for they are (if good, and got by prayers, and
faith) the immediate gift, and extraordinary favor of God to him that has
them, who thereby is strengthened against the wrongs and oppressions that men
in a solitary condition are subject unto, and able to stand the commonwealth
in stead in opposing open enemies, or suppressing civil injuries.

The cxxviii. PSALM.
The Psalmist to undeceive the world, sh^ws who, and who only is a blessed
man, he that fears and obeys God, and sh^ws every such an one the favors he is
in with God, both as to his own particular, his family and post^ritie, the
Church, whereof he is a member, and the commonwealth, whereof he is a part,
all these shall fare the better for him, whom God will bless both in his
person, and in all his relations.

See the Title of the 120. Psalm. Psalm cxxviii. A Song of degrees.


1 ALl men would be blessed men, BLessed is every one that fears the Lord,
that walks in his ways.
but few take a right course for it, nor indeed do they either judge that to be
blessedness which is so, or that to be the way to it, which only is so; for as
to the favor of God they see no such matter in it, as that it should make them
happy or blessed, conceiving of spiritual things with carnal apprehensions,
knowing no felicity but what is earthly and sensual, and for the fear of God
that leads to his favor, and obedience to his commandments, which he rewards
with blessedness: these they skill not, it is against the hair, and loath they
are to purchase God, by being good. But let deluded worldlings think how they
please: The God of truth tells thee, who ever thou art, that if thou will be
blessed of him, (and otherways thou can not) thou must with a reverential
filial fear in the faith of him thy God and Father, do his will, and not thine
own, please him, not thy self, and so doing, thou and every such one shall be
as surely blessed, as God is faithful.

(...) thou shall eat the labor of thine hands: happy shall thou be, and it
shall be well with thee.
2 For God whose thou art, will also be thine, not only in the grace of
salvation, but also in the grace of providence and protection, if in his fear
and faith thou usest the means soberly, he will bless them successfully to thy
contentment, so that though he give not to surfeit thee, yet to suffice thee he
will, thy labor shall not be in vain in the Lord, nor cursed of the Lord, as
others are, but though thou work for thy living, yet thou shall be able to live
by thy work, which shall maintain thee and thine, and that happily and
contentedly (which many that have much, do not;) for thou shall have the favor
of God to thee, and the blessing of God upon thee, in what thou do and have,

Thy wife shall be as a fruitful vine, by the sides of thine house: thy
children like olive plants, round about thy table.
3 Within doors and without shall God bless thee, with what ever blessings he
knows convenient for thee; if thou be in a married condition, whilst others
that are so, either have no children, or have them taken from them when they
have them, or are cursed to them, if not taken from them. Thou that fear God
he will provide better for thee, thy wife and thou shall with conjugal comfort
behold the blessing of the Lord upon your marriage bed, in her fruitful womb,
and thy hopeful issue; children wherein thou may have comfort, and not a
few, nor short-lived, which shall delight thee to look on them, and see God in
them enriching thee by his gift, with what rich men cannot purchase by their
wealth, and with them will give thee sustenance for them; if he send thee
mouths, he will also send the meat.

4 O that men would effectually believe this, Behold, that thus shall the man
be blessed, that fears the Lord.
and take out this lesson, that they that in conscience to God fear to sin, and
do good, are the blessed of the Lord in their own persons, and shall be blessed
of the Lord in what is theirs, and find all true that I have said.

5 The God of Israel shall upon thy prayers made at, The Lord shall bless thee
out of Sion, and thou shall see the good of Jerusalem, all the days of thy life.
or toward the place of his presence and pledge of his Covenant, the Ark and
Mercie-Seat in his Sanctuary upon Sion (the type of Christ in heaven,) hear
thee and bless thee, as he has promised to do, and thou shall be a means not
only to procure blessing to thy self, but to the whole Israel and Church of
God, typified in Jerusalem, which shall fare the better for thy sake and such
as thou art, and thou and they for its sake reciprocally as parts, and whole,
as shall the Church and members mutually in all ages.

6 Yea, Yea, thou shall see thy childrens children and pea^e upon Israel.
thy piety shall preserve thee in grace and favor with God, and make thee
both blessed in thy self, and a blessing to many others, yea, to the whole
Israel of God; thou shall thy self be blessed with long life, and happy days,
and in thy family and relations, with children, and with childrens children,
which shall be a rejoicing to thee to behold, and walking in thy ways (who
walks in Gods) shall to many generations fare the better for thee, and inherit
the grace and faithfulness of God promised to the righteous and their seed,
yea, the Church and commonwealth, whereof thou art a member, and wherein thou
live, shall prosper for thy sake, and such as thou art, grace and peace from
God and with men, shall thy prayers and godly walking procure them.

The cxxix. PSALM.
The Psalmist lays forth the common state of the Church, for her present
comfort under her present affliction, the Jews (as is conceived at this time
being under those pressures that besel them after their return out of their
grievous Babylonish captivity, by their wicked envious pick-thank neighbors,
the Samaritans, endeavoring their subversion by accusing them to the Persian
Kings, encourageing the ^aithfull by late experience in Gods faithfulness, for
the Churches preservation, and her enemies disappointment and destruction,
which with a prophetical prayer, equivalent to a promise he foretells and
desires.

Psalm cxxix.
See the Title of the 120. Psalm.

Many a time have they afflicted me from my youth, may Israel now say.
1, 2 WHen was the Church and people of God, which for the paucitie of them in
the world is as it were but one man amongst a many, Many a time have they
afflicted me from my youth: yet they have not prevailed against me.
ever without afflictions and enemies at any time, in any place, among any
people on earth? from the very beginning in Abel, and so along through all the
Patriarks quite down to us from Egypt till very now, whose fortune therefore is
not singular in that at present we undergo, but common with all the faithful
in all ages, this you know to be true, and yet this world of wicked enemies
which the poor Church has evermore had, and which many and many a time has
crushed them sore, yet could never through the overruling hand of our
Almighty and good God, prevail to supplant and eradicate it as was their aim
and desire to have done, no, nor never shall, no more now than heretofore, fear
it not.

3, 4 The poor Church and people of God, The plowers plowed upon my back: they
made long their furrows.
have undergone great hardship by the ungodly men of this world, to whom it
has been meat and drink to afflict us, The Lord is righteous: he has cut
asunder the cords of the wicked.
(witness our late Babylonish taskmasters) and as much pains have they taken
to do it by plots and practices, as the plowman does to tear the ground in
pieces, and as cruelly they have handled us, so far as ever God gave them
leave, (and so they shall Christ himself) whose husbandmen they are, and ever
have been, and the Church his field, wherein thereby he has always sown his
seed and reaped his harvest; that has been the use he put the Churches
afflictions and persecutions to, always notwithstanding them, approving himself
righteous and faithful to his word and promise of grace, and so is still, and
ever will be, to remember mercy, though the wicked world know none, to abate
of what it intends against them both for length of time, and measure of
affliction, as we have experience in our late deliverance, and to disappoint
their purposes and machinations as he has always done, to his churches
preservation and their destruction, in his own time, and by his almighty power
maugre their malice.

5 And as, Let them all be confounded and turned back that hate Sion.
Lord, thou have ruined Babylon for our sakes, so vouchsafe still to appear for
thy Church against her enemies, bringing them all to confusion that would do so
by Sion the place of thy worship, and type of thy Church for ever, let not
their malicious combinations, and wicked projects take effect against the type
or antitype, but utterly and shamefully defeat and frustrate them, for it is
for thy sake that they bear evil will to thy place and people.

Let them be as the grass upon the house tops: which withers before it
springs up.
6, 7, 8 Lord, let such haters of God and godliness, however they seem to
flourish, and overtop thy poor Church, Wherewith the mow: silieth not his
hand: nor he that binds sheaves his bosom.
come to naught, both they, and all their wicked designs: as the light corn
that makes a fair show on the ridge of an house, for want of rooting withers in
a moment before it ripen, Neither do they which go by, say, the blessing of the
Lord be upon you: we bless you in the name of the Lord.
and comes to any perfection by the heat of the sun, and is of no use nor
regard; so let always the Churches enemies, that are under a curse, and not a
blessing; and at present our persecuting neighbors be blasted, and in thy
wrathful displeasure destroyed both their persons and purposes; let neither
the one, nor the other ever come to good, like those empty ears; let them be
found, by those they curryfavour with, a dissembling, lying generation, great
promisers, and no performers, and find favor accordingly. Let not those that
are spectatours of us and them, whose pendulous judgments the event will
preponderate (the common error of the world, to judge and side according to
success;) let them not have cause by their prospering against us, to bless
them, and curse us, and to misuse thy name against thine own people, in behalf
of thine, and our enemies, by blessing those whom thou cursest, and cursing
those whom thou blessest.

The cxxx. PSALM.
The Psalmist sore afflicted under the sense of sin and misery, cries to the
Lord for mercy, making mercy his only plea for himself, and encouragement to
persist in the obedience of faith, and patient waiting, and eager longing for
appearance of grace; And draws his practice into precept to all the faithful
people of God, willing them to hold out, hoping in mercy for deliverance
through Christ, whatever be their pressure, sin, or suffering.

See the Title of the 120. Psalm. Psalm CXXX. A song of degrees.


1 IN the extreme agony of my spirit, OUt of the depths have I cried uno thee,
O Lord.
now that I am to mine own sense, and in all appearance quite overwhelmed with
outward distress and inward terror, death on the one hand ready to devour me,
my sins, and thy wrath on the other hand, grievously afflicting and affrighting
me; yet, as from the bottom of this gulf, and sea of miseries, have I sent
forth mine ardent prayer in the faith of thy power, and hopes of thy goodness,
O Almighty, and merciful Lord.

2 In such a case as this, Lord hear my vioce; let thy ears be attentive to the
voice of my supplication.
Lord, let me not speak to a deaf ear, but graciously grant me audience, yea,
watch for my prayers at such a time, for they shall never fail thee, neither do
thou fail them, especially in such straits.

3 If thou, If thou, Lord, should mark iniquities: O Lord, who shall stand.
O Lord, who art the righteous and terrible Judge of all the world, a jealous
God, and a consuming fire, does take strict notice of our sins, to take us to
task, and punish us for them, according to our deservings by the law of
righteousness, and rule of justice; alas, in such a case, what man can stand
before thee in his own justification, either to acquit himself, as sinless, or
to make satisfaction, being sinful, or in case he be able to do neither, as no
man can, how shall he be able to bear and undergo thy judgment, and heavy
displeasure for sin, without sinking under it? no flesh can do it.

4 But the case is otherways with thee toward poor humble hearted sinners,
But there is forgiveness with thee: that thou may befeared.
and suitours, to such thou stand not upon such terms of strictness, for
thou have proclaimed pardon to all such, which by faith they may take out and
plead for themselves, as also a gracious acceptance of their weak but filial
services, whereby they may be and are encouraged, knowing thy loving kindness
and mercy, to worship and serve thee, both by believing in thy promises though
with much mixture of unbelief, and doing thy commandments though in frailty and
weakness, short of perfection which none can reach, yet in sincerity.

I wait for the Lord, my soul does wait, and in his word do I hope.
5 Though my sins be heavy and mine affliction burdensome upon me, and have
been so along time, yet I despair not, but in the faith of his forgiveness and
compassion, I wait for the sun to break out from under this cloud, my soul is
in continual expectation of it, and so long as I have his word for it, I will
hope and look for deliverance and mercy, what ever be my fears and dangers.

My soul waits for the Lord, more than they that watch for the morning: I
say, more than they that watch for the morning.
6 My soul longs for, and looks out after, the comfortable appearance of the
grace of God, to set me free from these my tedious insupportable miseries of
his disfavour and the sad effects thereof, with as eager a desire, yea, far
more earnestly and affectionately do I, and will I, hold on to expect it, than
ever the poor weary Watchman or Centry that has been kept waking all Night,
prays for Daybreak that he may be discharged, and have his liberty to take
his rest.

Let Israel hope in the Lord, for with the Lord there is mercy; and with him is
plenteous redemption.
7 What ever be the afflictions of faithful Israel the people of God, let them
for all that by no means relinquish their hope in the Lord his power and
goodness, but hold out, in the assured confidence that God both is merciful in
himself however he seem, and will be so to them sooner or later in compassing
