their deliverance, which he that so wonderfully redeemed their souls, can
easily, and will certainly, do, by ways and means they never dreamed of, be
their case never so desperate.

8 Yea, And he shall redeem Israel from all his iniquities.
let not sin it self dismay Gods people, though they may fall into them, and by
them into sad afflictions, yet despair not, but believe, pray, and wait, and
then where sin has abounded, grace shall at last much more abound, so that
neither the number or greatness of their sins should make them hopeless or
desperate, but live by faith upon the promise both for pardon of sin and
punishment, for God is as able to deliver us (by his mercy) from his own
justice as man's malice, and will do it to his faithful Israel, by and for the
sake of his son Christ, God and man, our propitiatory sacrifice, and merciful
mediator or High Priest, who to effect and perfect our redemption is certainly
to come into the world, and after he has suffered, shall ascend into glory,
which shall be fulfilled and his Church thereby saved.

The cxxxi. PSALM.
David acquits himself of ambition to the Kingdom, or in it, now he has it,
being merely passive in the first, and no self-seeker in the last, but one that
accounts himself appointed by God for the good of his people, as Christ for his
Church, which is their exceeding great happiness, and should be their
encouragement.

See the title of the 120 Psalm, Psalm cxxxi. A song of degrees of David.
the Authors name superadded here.

1 THou Lord know however I have been misjudged by some through weakness,
LOrd, my heart is not haughty, nor mine eyes lofty, neither do I exercise my
self in great matters or in things too high for me.
by others through perverseness, to be an ambitious self-seeker, as touching the
Kingdom of Israel, and those high dignities spiritual and temporal that are
concomitant to it, how that herein I am wronged, for that I never had any such
aspiring thoughts, but as comparatively I was a mean man, so I always had a
lowly heart, and as were mine inward affections, such was and is mine outward
comportment, I overlook not my brethren with an imperious countenance as most
Kings do their subjects, counting them their vassals. Nor do I of mine own
accord for ambition sake, as most Princes are wont, put forth my self beyond my
self and calling to enlarge my dominions, how ever I may be censured
considering the great things I am called unto, but walk by the dictate of Gods
word and spirit in all mine undertakings both in matters of Church and State
for the good of both, that is my rule, and this is mine end and aim.

Surely I have behaved and quieted my self as a child that is weaned of his
mother: my soul is even as a weaned child.
2 My behavior neither heretofore nor now, either was or is such as should
deserve to be so thought of, I think I have gone through mine afflictions with
another spirit than ambitious worldlings show, in the exercise of much
patience, as seeing God in all, waiting and submitting to his will and
providence with a childlike temper and carriage, not seeking my self, or mine
own either untimely or ambitious advancement, had I, then I would have steared
a far other course, as others do that do so, made a noise and a bussle in the
world, taken all advantages, not been merely passive, as I was both in regard
of God, and mine adversaries, but active against mine enemies, as they were
against me, yet I did no such thing, but stayed the Lords leisure, and in all
things submitted to his pleasure, without repining or precipitancie, living all
the while by faith without using either unlawful means, or lawful means
unlawfully, to compass the Kingdom from Saul, and I bless God now I have it, I
am not altered, I am no more proud of it now, than I ambitiously coveted it
heretofore, but am every whit as much at Gods dispose, who as he gave it, so I
know to what use and end, for his honor and service sake, and not for mine,
and hereunto stands my heart only affected, to advance him, and to be ordered
by him, as Christ's shall be whom I prefigure, who yet shall be censured as I am.

3 This I would have Israel know, Let Israel hope in the Lord, from henceforth,
and for ever.
That the Kingdom was not my seeking, but the mere gift of God for their good,
and advancement of their happiness, (as the Church is Christ's) which I would
have them know for their comfort and encouragement, to believe and hope in the
Lord accordingly for time to come, as I have done in time past, if so, they
shall find him faithful of his word, as he has been to me, in making them a
happy people under my regiment, and those that come of me, as the Church and
spiritual Israel shall be in all ages, whilst the world endures, under the
governance of Christ the Messiah that Prince of peace and Lamb of God that
takes away the sins of all those who are Israelites indeed, that believe and
hope in his name.

The cxxxii. PSALM.
Solomon (as is most probable) at the complete finishing and furnishing of the
Temple, made this Psalm, much of it being the same with the prayer he made at
the dedication, wherein he prayer-wise minds God first of David's faith and
zeal, as also of the peoples in his time for the promotion of the glory and
worship of God at Jerusalem, which now being brought to perfection in the
perfecting of the Temple, he prays, that God would turn his promises to David
into performances by vouchsafing himself to be present there, and his blessings
both to the Priestly and Kingly office, that they may flourish to the rejoicing
of the godly, especially in his own time and person, according to those
especial promises and prophesies concerning him, who also is an extraordinary
type of Christ, and his glorious Kingdom.

Psalm cxxxii. A song of degrees.
See the title of the 120 Psalm.

LOrd, remember David, and all his afflictions.
1 LOrd, remember thy servant David, that type of Christ thy son, what sad
sufferings by thy ordination he underwent for the good of thy Church and
people, what miseries he sustained in his faithful dependence on thee and thy
gracious promises made to him, and for his sake to his posterity, yea, to the
whole Kingdom of Israel, which are still of force to thy people, whom, by and
for him thou have blessed accordingly (as through Christ thou will the Church)
and we pray thee still go on to do so, to bless both him and them, let his name
and sufferings be still precious with thee, and efficacious to us as Christ's
shall be after his death and departure, carrying in mind thine engagements of
grace and mercy to his people and posterity for his sake.

How he swear unto the Lord, and vowed unto the mighty God of Jacob.
2 Call to mind the wonderful zeal he had for thee and thy worship, which made
him infinitely solicitous in it, solemnly swearing, affectionately and freely
vowing to, and before thee the Almighty God of Jacob, that holy Patriark and
progenitour of him and all Israel, (whom thou did bless and powerfully
preserve, and promisedst to bless his seed after him) as follows.

Surely I will not come into the Tabernacle of my house: nor go up into my bed.
3 Surely I will not rest my self contentented with the advancement of my royal
throne, and erecting of mine own house and palace in the City of David, it is
not the flourishing of my Crown and Kingly office that my heart is so much
fixed on, as thereby to forget the Priestly office and worship which is to go
hand in hand, and by which and for which it must be, that both I and my Kingdom
must be preserved, therefore though I have built me an house fit for me, yet
will I take no pleasure to dwell in it, nor enjoy the benefits and conveniences
of it.

4 Nay, I will not give sleep to mine eyes: or slumber to my eyelids.
I will not sleep in quiet, nor take any comfortable rest with content of mind.

5 But with a longing desire will watch at what time, Until I find out a place
for the Lord: an habitation for the mighty God of Jacob.
and by what way and means (the season being now at hand) God will reveal to me
the place long ago forespoken of that he would choose to set his name, pitch
his Ark, and build his temple there, where he has promised his constant abode,
his presence and residence for ever, and from whence he will eminently yield
protection and assistance to his people the seed of Jacob, calling on him as he
did, whom he assisted mightily against his enemies, and so will them from
thence against theirs.

6 Lo, Lo, we heard of it at Ephratah, we found it in the fields of the wood.
we have heard of the several transplantations and removes thine Ark has made,
one while residing at Shiloh within the tribe of Ephraim, another while, after
thou had miraculously rescued it from the Philistines, in the house of
Abinadab at Kiriath-jearim, a place of plains and woods, whereby the iniquity
of the times, and obscurity of the place it was disfrequented, and scarce
taken notice of to be there, where yet David found it out, and whence he with
the approbation and applause of all Israel removed it to Jerusalem,
preordained, and by thee revealed to him, to be its place of residence, where
accordingly it now is to be frequented, and thou to be worshipped in that
solemn manner befitting the present State of thy Church.

We will go into thy Tabernacles: we will worship at thy footstool.
7 Whither we thy people generally and unanimously will resort with cheerful
obedience to thy holy sanctuary and temple, where thou that art in heaven art
pleased by typical umbrages to vouchsafe thy real presence and residence, and
there we will worship thee as thou have ordained, and only there henceforward,
as the Church shall for ever worship God in Christ, only accessible in his
humane nature, where is the fullness of the Godhead bodily.

Arise, O Lord, into thy rest: thou and the Ark of thy strength.
8 And that prayer, which has been so often made by Moses in the itinerarie
removes of thine Ark, now do I prefer, and do thou, Lord, fulfill, as it were
once for all, now possess thy self of this holy mountain, and take thou up thy
rest and residence there, where thou have promised to dwell amongst thy people
in a state triumphant, (such as both Christ and his Church shall have after
their afflictions) even on mount Sion in the Temple, where thine Ark is at last
situate, the sign as of thy presence, so of thy powerful goodness in thy
peoples preservation, and their enemies confusion, to remove no more, neither
thou nor it, but there to abide, a blessed God amongst a blessed people.

Let thy Priests be clothed with righteousn^s: and let thy saints shout for joy.
9 Now, Lord, let thy Church flourish, that has been long under the wheel, let
it at last bear the character of thee, the Almighty and merciful God, in
holiness and happiness, both Priests and people, let those in thine abundant
faithfulness, not only ritually but really, by the sanctifying graces of thy
spirit be holy to the Lord, as their office holds forth salvation, so let them
in life and conversation so walk before thee, as that thou may bless and
preserve them, and thy worship and people by their means. Let the time to come
bury the memory of thy Churches former infelicitie by a glorious resurrection
of all things, to the highest pitch of heavenly and spiritual luster, in
temporal and typical resemblances, to the ravishment of thy faithful servants,
and sanctified ones that have long looked for this triumphant condition of
Christ in his Churches felicity and the Temples glory.

10 Yea, For thy servan David's sake, turn not away the face of thine anointed.
grant I pray thee my request put up in behalf, as, of thy service, and
servants, the Temple, and Kingdom in general; so, more particularly in mine own
behalf, in whom they are so eminently concerned, and that for the sake, and in
the name of that typical mediator and faithful servant of thine (the blessed
type of thy blessed son the Messiah) David my father, with whom thou plightest
thy faith by promise and Covenant to be his God, and the God of his seed after
him, to bless them, and make them blessings to thy people, Lord, make me so
happy, whom thou have by especial appointment ordained to be his immediate
successor in this high dignity and office of being King over Israel, before
whom I pray thee honor me with a gracious acceptance of my service in building
thee an house, by some extraordinary token of favor, and by effectual
answering my prayer, put up in their and mine own behalf at that thy Temple,
that they may see thou favourest me, and for that cause may have me and my
Government in honor, and estimation as they had my fathers, and be blessed as
by him and his Government, so by me and mine.

11 Thy faithfulness is my confidence and comfort, The Lord has sworn in truth
unto David, he will not turn from it, of the fruit of thy body will I set upon
thy throne.
thou have of thine own free grace engaged thy word of truth, that is as
infallible thy self, by a firm and lasting promise to David (that lived and
died in thy favor, a lively type of the Mediator Christ) that thou will not
do by him as by Saul, let him be King for term of life only, but out of his
own loins should proceed his successor whom thou will choose, as thou did
David himself from among all his brethren to govern his people after him, as is
verified this day in me thine anointed.

If thy children will keep my covenant and my testimony that I shall teach
them, their children also shall fit on thy throne for evermore.
12 Nor has thy favor to him determined in his immediate seed, but is extended
by thy gracious promise to a successive establishment of the throne of Israel
in his seeds seed, in case they walk worthy so rich mercy, treading in the
steps of their father David by keeping the Commandments of the Lord in faith
and godliness, without deviating or stepping aside to carnal confidence or
will worship, even so long as it is to endure, to Christ's coming, and in him to
eternity.

For the Lord has chosen Sion: he has desired it for his habitation.
13, 14 For the Lord has foretold the prosperous condition of his Church in the
days of David and his seed, This is my rest for ever: here will I dwell, for I
have desired it.
how his Ark should then have rest, his temple be built where he would reside
among his people by special presence of goodness and faithfulness, in Sion long
defore designed for this honor but not revealed till David, and to him it was
made known, that that was the very place where he would establish the Kingly
and Priestly office of his beloved son, the Messiah, in their lively
prefigurations whence he will by his anointed Kings and Priests rule and bless
his people if they forfeit not so great blessedness, as from heaven he shall
his Church, in and by Christ's mediation, the only High Priest and Potentate
ascended and sitten down for ever at the right hand of his Father in the
heavenly Jerusalem, whose blessed exaltation unto the execution of those
offices there, is the desire and delight of his soul, as being only well
pleased in him, and reconciled by him, therefore so is Sion here, which is the
representation of him and them.

15 I will multiply blessings (for so thou have said) upon the whole land for
Sions sake, I will abundantly bless her provision: I will satisfy her poor
with bread.
that she may be provided with all manner of store for holy services. Let not
the poor Israelite fear to bring his offerings, and disfurnish himself to
worship me as I have appointed, for if the service of my sanctuary lessen his
store, if there he seek me faithfully, he shall carry such a blessing home
with him, as he shall have no cause to repent him, for I will both bless him
with livelihood (let him not fear it) and bless it to him.

16 The Priests that there officiate in consecrated garments, I will also
clothe her Priests with salvation: and her saints shall shout aloud for joy.
shall be in like manner clothed upon with the saving and sanctifying
righteousness of the Messiah, which in their zeal and faithful discharge of
their places they shall hold forth to the example and edification of their
brethren, who in the sincerity of their hearts shall bless the Lord for such
happy times, wherein so much of God his grace and favor appears in blessing
them with a holy Priesthood and Divine worship, and powerfully protecting both
it and them.

17 I will bless Sion, There will I make the horn of David to bud: I have
ordained a lamp for mine anointed.
and there shall David my servant be blessed, not only in himself during the
time of his regencie, but after him his successor and Gods anointed King
Solomon shall far exceed him in power and glory, whose wisdom, which I shall
give him to govern by, shall shine with that brightness, as shall wonderfully
increase his fame and dignity the world over, who shall be a lively pattern of
the anointed Messiah that also shall spring out of the stock of David, that
spiritual Solomon, the Prince of peace and mighty counselor.

His enemies will I clothe with shame: but upon himself shall his Crown
flourish.
18 And his enemies that would not he should rule over them, but oppose his
advancement, or disturb his Government, I will shamefully cut off both them and
their enterprises, but him will I bless with a flourishing reign of glory and
affluence, at home and abroad, resembling Christ both in his own happiness, and
his enemies confusion.

The cxxxiii. PSALM.
David being received of all Israel for their King by common and joint consent,
after much disagreement and war among the tribes, some being for and some
against him; He shows the happy condition they were now in upon the change,
how amiable and acceptable unity had rendered them to God, what a flourishing
Church and Commonwealth they had and should have by it, and that nothing can
be a greater blessing to them, nor shall be to the Church and people of God in
all ages, than for them to honor their father and head in heaven, by living in
brotherhood here on earth.

A song of degrees of David. Psalm cxxxiii.
See the title of the 120 Psalm, the Authors name superadded here.

BEhold, how good and how pleasant it is, for brethren to dwell together in
unity.
1 COnsider well the singular mercy of God in uniting all the tribes, sons of
the same father both by nature and adoption, that were so far asunder, at
deadly feud, and open war among themselves to the hazard of the whole, had not
God graciously overruled them to peace and unity under one head and to be all
of one heart. And as the mercy so the good and benefit of this union is
worthy your consideration, to move you to cherish and nourish it all you can,
for besides that Harmony of hearts is it self an unestimable Jewel and
beautiful ornament in the Church, and among the people of God, a very
resemblance of that concord and consort which shall be in heaven, the
commodities also that issue thence to the public, and every man's particular
weal is very considerable and impulsive, how thereby all things go well and
happily forward in Church and Commonwealth, the worship and service of God
that flourishes, the re-publick that does the like, things are now orderly
constituted, magistracy maintained, people protected, justice administered, and
whereas before we weakened our selves by civil wars, now we are strong to
defend our selves, and offend our enemies round about us. In breef, it renders
us acceptable to God, comfortable to our selves and an astonishment to our
adversaries; both profit and pleasure, yea, all manner of good that can be
named is complicate in, and productive from this one comprehensive mercy of
concord; we for our parts find the sweet of it, and so shall the Church of God
always, especially after such sour dissentious as we have waded through.

2 If I would compare this brotherly union of us, It is like the precious
ointment upon the head, that ran down upon the beard, even Aarons beard that
went down to the skirts of his garment.
and so of the people of God in all ages, in the pleasurable and delectable
part of it to any thing, it must be to a nonsuch, for such it is, and I cannot
liken it to any thing that in all points better resembles it, than that rich
sacred odoriferous ointment made by the special appointment of God himself (for
so is peace and unity in his Church) for the consecration of Aaron and his
sons to their holy office and service, which being plentifully poured upon the
Highpriests head, did diffuse it self down to his beard, and so from thence to
the holy vestments from top to toe; such, in perfect analogy, is this general
amity wrought by God among us, in the sweet savor and blessed effects of it;
God by me your King and head, (consecrated as it were to mine office by this
your unanimous consent and election, as with an holy unction, as well as by
Gods immediate designation) conveighing the benefit and sweetness thereof,
through the blessing and mediation of the Priestly office and service, as by
Aarons beard, down to you again, and so you made happy in the sweet and
comfortable benefits and blessings of both, by means of amity and unity with
them and among your selves; like as the Church mystical united to her head
Christ at Gods right hand in glory, and at brotherly love and amity in it
self, shall be unspeakably blessed with those Divine influences of grace and
spirit, derived from her King and Priest Christ Jesus, by the mediation and
ministration of his Evangelists and Gospel Ministers, down to all the members
of his body, partakers of the sweet fruits and benefits of all his offices,
and thereby consecrated a sweet savor, even Kings and Priests to God with the
selfsame spirit or holy unction, to their infinite honor and consolation.

As the dew of Hermon, and as the dew that descended upon the mountains of
Sion, for there the Lord commanded the blessing, even life for evermore.
3 And as brotherly love and concord is a pleasant and amiable thing in it self,
and sweet and acceptable with God, so also it is exceeding; profitable, and
brings with it abundance of blessings, peace, God is wont to bless with
plenty, whereas wars and discord are accompanied with curses and scarcity.
Look how the fruitful dew that falls upon, and from mount Hermon that fertile
hill down into the fields of Bashan, and so abundantly enricheth them to the
owners benefit, or look (which is indeed a properer comparison, for brotherly
love is a celestial benefit) how the spiritual dew is dispensed from God in
heaven on those holy consecrated mountains, Sion and Moriah, where he
vouchsafes his presence unto his people, who resort thither to worship him, and
where they meet with soul-enriching graces and consolations, othergets
blessings than the dew of Hermon, which makes them abound in faith and
godliness to their own eternal as well as temporal felicity; such like is
peace and love among the Israel and people of God, it self is a special
blessing from heaven and brings with it all manner of blessings from thence,
both temporal and spiritual, if ever we mean to be rich and happy, this is the
way, to live and love as sons of one father, and mother, God and the Church,
members of one body under one head the Messiah, as all Israel shall be through
love and obedience to David and his successors ruling in Sion, as types of
Christ.

The cxxxiv. PSALM.
David being a man of fervor and affection in the service of God, gives a
watchword to the watchmen of the Temple, the Priests and Levites, and in them
to Gospel Ministers, not regardlesly to pass over their duties, but to be
employed for the whilst, as Christ himself is for ever, in praying for the
people and Church of God, and blessing both God and them, and that in a
proportionable zeal here, to Christ and his saints in heaven, in their
respective employments there.

See the title of the 120 Psalm. Psalm cxxxiv. A song of degrees.


1 YOu that are by the special appointment and ordination BEhold, bless ye the
Lord, all ye servants of the Lord, which by night stand in the house of the
Lord.
of God chosen (as Christ himself) from among all your brethren, and preferred
to the honor of sanctuarie-administration continually in his presence,
consider the place you hold, whom and what you personate, even Jesus Christ in
his Priestly office at the right hand of God, who ever lives to make
intercession and offer thanks-givings for his Church to his father, have that
always in your eye, and be active suitably, stand not idle in your offices,
nor keep not sleepie centry in the sanctuary, but as your turns come to watch,
do service there as well night as day, rouse up your spirits, call to mind the
moral meaning of your employments, which is to improve your nearer interest in
God (by virtue of your offices) for the good of his Church and people, as
Christ does in heaven, continually through Christ presenting to God in the
Churches behalf the spiritual sacrifices of praise and thanksgiving for his
mercies vouchsafed, together with prayers and supplications for the
continuation and constant gracious dispensation of them still as there is need.

Lift up your hands in the sanctuary: and bless the Lord.
2 I say again busy and lay out your selves in those sacred and religious
employments of praise and prayer, neither idle nor nifle out your time and Turn
in the sanctuary, nor yet with formalitie or hypocrisy do you do your service
to him, as bare pretenders, but as holy and real performers, clap your wings in
your night-watches, let your hearts be in heaven, and your hands in token of
the fervor of your spirits lifted up thitherwards, and so bless the Lord not
betwixt sleeping and waking, but with the whole soul and body too, considering
he whom you worship is a spirit, and his proper place of residence is above in
the heavens, whose service there for condiscention sake you personate in the
sanctuary here in types and shadows, wherein you must not stick, but by them
mount up higher, even to him where he is in spirit and faith externally
manifested by suitable comportment of bodily action and expression, such as are
significant and adorative, commensurable to Gods glory and greatness, your own
hearts purity, faith and fervor, and the Divine condition of the
Church-Triumphant in heaven.

3 Your office is double faced upward and downward, The Lord that made heaven
and earth bless thee out of Sion.
you are in Christ's stead like Jacobs ladder, on which and by which blessings
are to ascend and descend, for as you are the mouth of the Church and people of
God, to offer him their thanks and praises, blessing him continually in their
behalfs, (as Christ does the father for the elect;) so likewise are you to be
the mouth of God down to his people to bless them from him, which doubtless is
as an honorable, so a full employment, if you set your selves to do it as it
ought to be done with that zeal and reverence the Church owes to her head, and
with that delight and love, the head has in and to his body and
fellow members. Pray therefore for, and as presenting the person of Jesus
Christ that effectual mediator, in his name also faithfully bless ye the
Israel of God that do worship him in Sion, his place of residence, with the
blessings of his special protection and salvation who is the only true God,
and Allmighty master of heaven and earth.

The cxxxv. PSALM.
The Psalmist quickens up the people of Israel in general, the Priests and
Levites more particularly, but most especially the faithful of both sorts to
magnify and praise the Lord, and this he does by way of argument taken from
the congruitie, delectabilitie, and duty of it from such a people to such a
God, who as he is greatly to be preferred for his self-sake, and the excellent
power that is in him, so for the effects of it toward them, the grateful
memory whereof should ever be upheld for his glory and his peoples faith
sake. All other Gods being but puppits, he only is God, and only to be
blessed as such, especially of them that are his only people and Priests, his
Church, preferred by him of all the world, to that honor, who therefore ought
to honor him how and where he will be worshipped. Psalm cxxxv.


PRaise ye the Lord, praise ye the name of the Lord, praise him, O ye servants
of the Lord.
1 O That all sorts of people would consider their duty of praising God,
conscionably to discharge it in spirit and power, to magnify him for his
greatness as Lord of and over all, yea for his excellent attributes and
properties not only absolute, but relative of grace and goodness, and for his
alonenes, for as there is no God like him, so there is no God but him; O ye
servants of the Lord chosen by him and set apart for that purpose, what ever
others do, forget not you your duties, not only of your persons but of your
places, to praise the Lord worthily with hearts enlarged with the apprehensions
of him and his manifold excellencies.

Ye that stand in the house of the Lord, in the courts of the house of our God.
2 I mean ye Priests and Levites principally, be you especially conversant in
this service of praising the Lord in his holy Temple, where you are privileged
to administer like to the glorified saints in heaven that stand in his presence
for ever more praising the Lord. Yea, and all others also that are admitted to
the participation of grace, and that worship him in his ordinances though at
greater distance, whether Levites or people, whose persons and praises
faithfully tendered in spirit are yet really accepted and graciously regarded
by the God of Israel, whose presence is as well in the courts which also are
sanctified, as in the Temple it self (with his Church on earth, as well as in
heaven.) Praise ye therefore the Lord, ye that worship him without as well as
within the holy sanctuary of our God, both Priests and people.

3 Be not so much awed by fear to praise the Lord, Praise ye the Lord, for the
Lord is good; sing praises unto his name, for it is pleasant.
as induced by love, for those lovely excellencies of grace and goodness that
are in him, and shine forth from him to his people, let the faith and
experience the Church has had thereof in all ages, tune your voice and
instruments to the exaltation of his name, in praiseworthy commemoration of
all the good he has either promised or performed, which to do is delightful
to God, and every good heart.

4 Surely, For the Lord has chosen Jacob unto himself, and Israel for his
peculiar treasure.
we far above all the world are debtors to God; ow more in way of praise than
ever we can pay him, for this unestimable mercy and privilege of adoption to
be his peculiar, to name his name upon, and marked out of all the great fold of
the world for his people, and the sheep of his pasture, even we, a poor
hand-full, that came out of the loins of one man, our Father Jacob, that he
should choose him and his out of all mankind to set his love upon, and thus to
honor, as to esteem none else worth reckoning of, but us, and us as his
treasure and Jewels of value, whom he only sets by, as he shall by his Church
and people in all the world, and only by them.

5 Under what notion soever we apprehend God, For I know that the Lord is
great, and that our Lord is above all Gods.
he is worthy our uttermost praises, whether as good to us, or as great in
himself, who indeed is of that immensitie, as that his positive admits of no
comparative degree, he is abstractly great, even greatness it self, in power
and majesty beyond humane apprehension and capacity, in the faith whereof yet
we ought to praise him, for so his people best know him, and that not only as
absolutely and essentially so, but also relatively and derivatively so to us,
this great God being greatly our God; his greatness as it is superlative to all
greatnesses, whether humane powers or imaginary deities, so his grace shall
extend it accordingly unto our protection and preservation against them, and to
the confusion of men and Idols that are set against him or us his Church and
people.

Whatsoever the Lord pleased that did ^e in heaven and in earth.
6 I mean the great and mighty God, the sole Sovereign and Monarch of all the
world both heaven and earth, who of his mere will and by his only word made
all things to be that they are, from the highest to the lowest, whether in the
heavens above or in the earth beneath, or in the waters under the earth, and
the invisible depths of both down to the very center, and as he commanded them
to be, so he rules and commands them now they are, to be, and do what he would
have them, and not otherwise, to his praise and his peoples security.

He causes the vapors to ascend from the ends of the earth, he makes
lightn^ngs for the rain: he brings the wind out of his treasuries.
7 He creates ruin by appointing and impowering the sun from all parts of the
world, sea and land, to exhale the vapors which we see ascend on high into the
middle region of the air, where they engender clouds, and those clouds rain,
which by his providence is dispersed and dispensed all the world over, what the
earth sends up in exhalations from all parts, it receives down again every
where for its use in showers and dews. Yea, what a piece of Artifice do our
eyes behold, when by the force of thunder, he sends lightning and rain, fire
and water, out of one and the same cloud, so that when we see the one break
forth, we conclude the other not far behind, as if naturally fire produced
water, which are so contrary, but yet are made to cohabit till, and be
subservient, when he pleases to dispose of them in storms and tempests. The
wind also blows when, where, and how he lists, and not otherwise, how unruly
and boisterous so ever it seem, it breaks not prison of it self, but is let out
of its restraint by him, without whose will and pleasure it cannot so much as
breath, who is the God of nature, ordeining and ordering her in all causes, and
all their effects, how rare soever, beyond our knowledge, and above our reach
transacted in the heavens, whereof these are few instances.

8 Yea, Who smote the firstborn of Egypt, both of man and beast.
and on earth too, where not a few things praise-worthie have been wrought by
the same Almighty power for his people Israel, whereof we will enumerate some,
a few of many, as, the high and mighty slaughter he made of the firstborn
both of man and beast in Egypt, with a strong hand bringing his people thence,
spite of Pharaohs power and oppugnation.

9 He wrought miracles, Who sent tokens and wonders into the midst of thee, O
Egypt, upon Pharaoh, and upon all his servants.
and made strange demonstration of his heavy displeasure by manifold
judgments, destructive signs and prodigies, in the midst of thee, O Egypt, for
their sakes, when his people the Israelites had no harm there, forcing thereby
hard-hearted Pharaoh, thy King, and his courtiers, to acknowledge his power,
and at last submit to his will.

10 Nor in Egypt only did he do wonders and execute judgments upon his
Churches enemies, Who smote great nations, and slew mighty Kings.
but when by a mighty hand and the destruction of the Egyptians, he had
brought them thence, by the same outstretched arm did he lead them through the
wilderness, destroying all that made opposition to them, both Princes and
people, though far greater and every way better provided then they, wayfaring
men were.

Sihon King of the Amorites, and Og King of Bashan, and all the Kingdoms of
Canaan.
11 As for instance. Sihon the King of the Amorites, and Og that mighty man the
King of Bashan, who opposed their passage, these Kings and their people they
destroyed on the other side Jordan, and on this side even all the Kings and
Kingdoms of Canaan, thirty one in number; those under Moses, these under Josua,
were subdued by the Lord, who fought for Israel against all their enemies.

And gave their land for an heritage unto Israel his people.
12 And he that is Lord of all the earth, as before he had promised to Abraham,
so now he fulfilled his word by an effectual possession and implantation of his
people Israel in the lands and possessions of all the foresaid Kings and
Kingdoms, gave them to them and their heirs for ever, which he has ever since
preserved to and for them, and their posterity, with as Almighty a hand, as at
first he gained and gave them.

Thy name, O Lord, endures for ever, and thy memorial, O Lord, through all
generations.
13 The glorious manifestations thou have always made of thy powerful goodness,
and gracious faithfulness in the behalf of thy people against their enemies,
ought to be renowned for ever hereafter in all ages, which also shall produce
experiments answerable to those thy properties, which are ever the same in thy
Churches behalf, who shall transmit the grateful memory of thy former mercies
and miracles down from age to age, and from one generation successively to
another, to thine everlasting glory and their corroboration and comfort, in
the faith of thy faithfulness to thy covenant and promises, (the grand charter
of the Catholic Church) theirs as well as ours, made to them as to us.

For the Lord will judge his people, and he will rep^nt himself concerning his
servants.
14 For the Lord is his peoples according to covenant, so that though he do,
yea, must both in justice and mercy chastize them for their aberrations,
thereby to humble and reduce them: For impunitie would argue him no father, nor
they no children; as sure I say as he is both just and gracious to lay the rod
upon them for sin, so he is as merciful and faithful to take it off again, when
of sinners they become penitents, and renew their covenant to be his, he will
soon be theirs, and repent as well as they, and then woe be to their enemies, we
have and shall ever find it so.

15 That he has ever approved himself the only God of power to deliver us
when the time has come, The Idols of the heathen are silver and gold, the work
of men's hands.
maugre all the Powers on earth that have been against us, and their gods to
boot, which cannot preserve them that worship them, against the power of the
Almighty whom we only serve of all the world besides, which is heathen, and
their gods mere Idols, at best made of gold and silver, nor are they so much as
their own makers, but have their Beings from men, they make them that made not
themselves, therefore must they needs be goodly Gods.

16 They are mere liveless statues, They have mouths, but they speak not; eyes
have they, but they see not.
without sense or motion, able neither to speak nor see, having no better
mouths, nor eyes than man can make them.

17 Their ears are like their eyes, They have ea^s, but they he^r not, neither
is there any breath in their mouths.
the one blind, the other deaf, and their mouths as breathless as speechless,
for such an inversion of nature, as men to make Gods, can produce no better
effects.

18 And they that make them are as void of understanding, They that make them
are like unto them: so is every one that trusts in them.
as they of life and sense, that against reason can think such things fit to be
worshipped for Gods, which are their creatures, not they theirs, and so is
every one (that seeing what they are, and knowing whence they come) puts
confidence of good or evil in them, both their Gods and they are alike
blockish, and as void of power as understanding, as plainly appears, when our
God appears for us against them.

Bless the Lord, O hou^e of Israel, bless the Lord, O house of Aaron.
19 Let therefore your faith and zeal be laid out upon no such imaginary
deities, nor your fear upon any earthly powers, do you that are the posterity
of Jacob, from whom you have the name of Israel given of God himself, walk
worthy such a father and servant of the Lord, by honoring and praising him,
and him alone, all of you own him and honor him for your Lord and God,
specially you that are his in principal place and office by special
designation, you Priests the sons of Aaron, let your zeal exceed as much, as do
your engagements.

Bless the Lord, O house of Levi; ye that fear the Lord, bless the Lord.
20 And you that are of an inferior rank in the Priesthood, ye Levites,
remember also your engagements to honor, and praise the Lord, who has called
you to so sacred an office about his Temple, do your duties worthy your
places; but because no doubt too many are, as formal people, so formal Priests
that serve the Lord, if at all, more in show than sincerity, therefore my
exhortation is chiefly to you both Priests and people that are regenerate,
Israelites indeed, Priests of the Lord as well as of the Temple, endowed with
the true fear of God, and sanctifying graces of his spirit, you are they that I
hope and exhort, and that God looks should honor and serve him with praise and
thanks in faith and spirit, worthy your selves and him your God, as a chosen
generation, a royal Priesthood, a holy nation, a peculiar people, that ye
should show forth the praises of him, who has called you out of darkness into
his mavelous light.

21 Let all Israel, Blessed be the Lord out of Sion, which dwells at
Jerusalem. Praise ye the Lord.
whether in power or profession, his visible or invisible people, of what rank
or quality soever, Prince, Priest, people, resort unto the place appointed for
his solemn worship, mount Sion, where his sanctuary is seated, and there join
their forces and affections to bless and serve him, who is especially present
there, of all Israel having preferred Jerusalem to be the place of his
residence, and of all his glorious dispensations where he will be blessed of
his people; and whence he will bless them again that honor and serve him.
Therefore fail not on your part, praise him, and pray to him, that is and will
be your God if you do so.

The cxxxvi. PSALM.
This Psalm for the magnifying of mercy, it is thought was sung daily in the
Tabernacle and Temple. 1 Chronicles. 16.41. Jer. 33.11. and this clause for his
mercy endures for ever, so often repeated was sung by turns of the Levites, and
often used for the burden of the song at solemn celebrations of remarkable
mercies. 2 Chronicles. 7.3. and 6. and 20.21. The drift of the Psalmist is to
advance covenant-mercie, that Church privilege in the eyes of the faithful, as
the great and almost only thank-worthie benefit, by which God himself, and
all that is Gods, is his Churches, the fountain of all good, general, special,
of creation, and providence, to the world, to the Church, which therefore we
should behold in every thing, and thank God for in all things. Psalm cxxxvi.


1 GOds greatness is better known and more taken notice of than his goodness, O
Give thanks unto the Lord, for he is good: for his mercy endures for ever.
but this ought principally to be his peoples study, to see all he does as
well the acts of his grace, and that a stable covenant-grace, as of his power;
Therefore ye that are so, be sure to do so, be thankful to him, and faithful in
him for his goodness sake, that is so transcendent even to the sins of all
mankind in general, who live, move, and have their beings, in and from, him
notwithstanding them, and to his Church in particular, as appears by his many
gracious promises and great performances temporal and spiritual in goodness
made, and in mercy made good; sin cannot finally hinder the current of his
grace, which is as himself everlasting, as in being, so in acting, an ever
overflowing fountain, whose mercies therefore are renewed every morning.

O give thanks unto the God of Gods: for his mercy endures for ever.
2, 3 Exalt him in his greatness, yea, in the full dimensions of it,
superlatively prefer him to all things in heaven and earth, O give thanks to
the Lord of Lords: for his mercy endures for ever.
principalities, powers, or imaginary deities. Praise him as such, but withal
be thankful to him that is such, so great, and yet of such condiscention in
continual dispensation of mercies; for the consideration of his goodness
sets forth his greatness with greater beauty and sweetness, which by reason
thereof becomes a useful property and encouragement to his Church and people
to draw nigh to him, and trust in him for ever.

To him who alone does great wonders: for his mercy endures for ever.
4 And as for his mercy sake he is to be honored in what he is essentially,
being thereby that to us, and for us which he is in himself, so also in what he
does, for his mercy and free grace, it is the cause of the manifestation of so
great power in all those glorious works of wonder, wrought so apparently by the
immediate hand and finger of God, (who only is Almighty, for, and in his
peoples behalfs) in all their dangers notwithstanding all their sins, as we can
witness in an everlasting Series of them.

5 Free grace and mercy is and ought to be the salt that seasons all things,
To him that by wisdom made the heavens, for his mercy endures for ever.
as what you offer to God is seasoned with the salt of the covenant, so let all
the considerations you have of God his acts or attributes, works, or wisdom, be
salted and seasoned in like sort, with the thankful memorial of covenant-grace,
without which all God is, and all God does is as nothing; for grace only gives
verdure to and propriety in all, (yea, and in himself that is more than all)
not only his works of wonder to his Church in particular, but even his
wonderful works in common of creation, are to be considered, not as acts of
power and wisdom only, but his mercy in both is chiefly to be considered, ^s
that which makes the very heavens to be heavens to us; as at first they were,
so still to be, glorious and excellent in their beauty and use, be thankful
therefore to the God of everlasting grace, ever when you behold the heavens,
and admire his wisdom in those works of nature.

6 Yea, To him that stretched out the earth above the waters, for his mercy
endures for ever.
whethersoever ye look upward or downward, and whatsoever ye see in heaven or
earth, that shows you God under any notion, see mercy in it, and so be
thankful for it, as the dry land and habitable earth which wonderfully
declares his power, being so great a superficies by his appointment above the
waters that were above it, and would be so again, but that his decree stands
firm, our sins have not let them loose from their restraint, because his
never-failing grace and mercy overrules them now as did his word of command
at first, therefore whenever you see him in the one, do not over-see him in
the other, for what power created, powerful mercy has continued.

To him that made great lights, for his mercy endures for ever.
7 How many are enlightened by those two glorious luminaries that shine in the
firmament, that either see not God by them, or if they do, but with a natural
notion of temporal benefit, and common goodness, and are not thereby raised in
their thoughts to see him a God in covenant, and that therefore as at first, in
goodness he made them, so in mercy he continues them for the use of man.

The son to rule by day, ^or his mercy endures for ever.
8, 9 The sun to give light by day wherein man is to labor, and therefore has
need of greater light, and the moon that other great, The moon and stars to
rule by night: for his mercy endures for ever.
but lesser light, together with the additionals of infinite stars, all which
giving less light, seasonably shine in the night, the time appointed properly
for rest, and improperly employed in business, which yet more or less cannot
well be avoided, and therefore has his goodness afforded, and his wisdom
ordered these gradual lights to shine so opportunely and successively, as man
has more and less need of them, and so also his mercy does and has continued
them for these many thousand years, notwithstanding so many millions of sins;
never therefore see these lights or by them, but see Gods grace and mercy
shine through them, and be thankful for it and them.

To him that smote Egypt in their firstborn: for his mercy endures for-ever.
10 If mercy be the motive of common natural benefits, why God gives them and
we enjoy them, and be to be seen in them as thank-worthie, how much more in
those special and supernatural benefits and miracles wrought for his Church in
peculiar, surely we are not to forget them, nor his mercy in them, but as to
magnify it in his acts of creation, which are common, so much more in those of
providence and preservation to his people in special, as that of his killing
all the firstborn of Egypt both of Prince and people, man and beast, when they
would not let Israel go, which is for ever to be memorized and recorded by his
firstborn the Church, as a special fruit and effect of that covenant-mercie,
by which she is, and shall ever be preserved, thereby to be corroborated.

11, 12 Whereby he rescued his embondaged people Israel, And brought out Israel
from among them: for his mercy endures for ever.
even all of them, by a mighty hand of power, With a strong hand, and a
stretchedout arm: for his mercy endures for ever.
which his mercy set on work, from their cruel Taskmasters, whose power
through mercy wrought that their deliverance, maugre the Egyptians powerful
opposition; remember it, see mercy in it, and thank him for it, yea, let your
thoughts run descant upon it, double and treble your sense of it, and thanks
for such a mercy, the great seal, and firstborn mercy of his everlasting
covenant to his Church national.

Yea, To him which divided the red sea into parts: for his mercy endures for
ever.
go from circumstance to circumstance, see a succession of miraculous mercies,
and all of them springing out of that everliving root and mother-mercie,
covenant-grace, as before in Egypt, so out of Egypt at the red sea, which by
almighty mercy (being one) was divided into two (as it were) walls of water,
on each hand them, and a great distance of dry land betwixt.

14 Through which he made all Israel to pass with safety, And made Israel to
pass through the midst of it: for his mercy endures for ever.
the divided sea never offering to unite, the whilst they and their cattle
journeyed through it.

15 But on the contrary when hard-hearted Pharaoh that pursued Israel after he
had let them go, But overthrew Pharaoh and his host in the red sea: for his
mercy endures for ever.
ventured after them, God the second time made dreadful slaughter of the
Egyptians, even of Pharaoh and all his host, causing the sea to return and
destroy all them, who else had destroyed all Israel, a mercy indeed as well as
a miracle, and so to be taken notice of; admire therefore the one, and thank
him for the other, (by an eye of faith see mercy all along, yea,
covenant-mercie, such as makes God himself to be yours, as well as his
benefits, and that by a tie of grace, which through grace is never to be
dissolved, else your digestion of benefits themselves is crude and not
nourishing,) as therefore this was typical, so let your apprehension of it be
spiritual, see a blessing as well as a benefit in it to Israel, which is the
much more sweet and beneficial consideration, and bless ye the Lord for
blessing his people, with so gracious as well as great deliverance.

To him which led his people through the wilderness: for his mercy endures
for ever.
16 And as in your minds you revolve and carry on the story of Isreal's march
from Egypt through the sea, and so from the sea, where they took an everlasting
fare-wel of Pharaoh, through the dry and desert wilderness, where God lead
them all along as a shepherd his sheep, providing for them, meat, drink, and
clothes, shade, and protection miraculously, but no less mercifully, their
provocations and his admirable patience showed it, and proved it too to be such
a mercy, whose motive is in God, and therefore everlasting like himself, a
mercy that dures for ever, else had it and the Church for ever there received
an end, for which then as such, we are to thank and praise him, and to mind
that mercy in a parallel line quite along, through all our consideration of the
story.

17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22 And as before he overthrew Pharaoh for their sakes in
their entrance into the wilderness, To him which smote great Kings: for his
mercy endures for ever.
so now at their going out of it and entering into Canaan, And slew famous
Kings: for his mercy endures for ever.
by virtue of that his everlasting mercy, Sihon King of the Amorites: for his
mercy endures for ever.
patience, And Og the King of Bashan: for his mercy endures for ever.
and long-suffering exercised for so long together upon a people of so great
provocations, And gave their land for an heritage: for his mercy endures for
ever.
did he destroy potent Princes and Kings that were famous warriors, Even an
heritage unto Israel his servant: for his mercy endures for ever.
by them a wayfaring people, as Sihon King of the Amorites, and Og the Giant
King of Bashan, who opposed them, and so utterly subdued them, as that in stead
of leave to pass, he gave livery and seisin of all they had to his people
Israel, whose sword and service he made use of against them, and well rewarded
their labor and travel, making them conquerours and heirs of the conquered,
both beyond and on this side Jordan in Canaan, whose lands they have to this
day, and where they are to serve and worship him, mercy gave it and mercy
has continued it, our sins could neither hinder the getting nor the keeping
it, because though sin breaks on our part, yet grace keeps covenant on Gods
part, thank and admire the God of so rich, infinite, and everlasting mercy in
all and every passage from first to last, of his dispensations and Isreal's
provocations.

23 Indeed we cannot say that ever his mercy failed us, Who remembered us in
our low estate: for his mercy endures: for ever.
he remembered us many and many a time, when we forgot our selves toward him,
giving us the inheritance of that mercy he long since passed over by Indenture
and covenant to our forefathers, insomuch as our extremity was but his
opportunity, always when our miseries and dangers were greatest, mercy and
deliverance was nearest.

24 Yea, And has redeemed us from our enemies: for his mercy endures for
ever.
he has redeemed us from our enemies with the blood and slaughter of them,
when but for mercy we had been slaughtered by them, or been perpetual bondmen
to them; and that many a time with successive deliverances by never-failing
mercies.

Who gives food to all flesh: ^ for his mercy endures for ever.
25 Nor do his people only thus fare the better for his mercy, but for their
sakes all creatures living do so too, his covenant of grace made everlastingly
with his Church in special has influence upon the creation in general, the
world subsists by it, and for it, and all flesh living is plentifully provided
for, with suitable and seasonable food by reason of it, temporal benefits are
bestowed on the Churches enemies for the Churches sake, and on those out of
covenant, because of the covenant, and them it pertains to, according as he
promised to Abraham, saying, In thy seed shall all the nations of the earth be
blessed.

O give thanks unto the God of heaven: for his mercy endures for ever.
26 You therefore that have such privileges to be the Lords adopted, heirs of
the covenant and covenant-mercies, do not you degenerate, own this God for your
God, that has thus owned us by his special mercies for his peculiar people,
even the only true God whose throne is in the heavens, no vain earthly Idol;
give, as, is due, praise and thanks to him for his mercy, and especially for
that it is made over to you, and all the faithful Israel by a covenant of
grace, as unchangeable and everlasting as God himself.

The cxxxvii. PSALM.
The Psalmist in the name of the whole Church led captive into the empire of
Babylon, and Judah and Jerusalem miserably destroyed, shows their behavior
there, how uncomfortable their condition was, that could joy in nothing,
derided in captivity with the very worship of God, (their glory) which
notwithstanding they resolve to glory in, and in nothing comparably; He prays
and prophecies against Edom and Babylon that they may be rewarded, as they have
done, and deserve. Psalm cxxxvii.


1 WHen the Lord brought that great judgment upon Judah, BY the rivers of
Babylon, there we sat down, yea, we wept, when we remembered Sion.
the ruin of all at once by the Babylonian, who destroyed many and carried the
rest captive, when in that condition we were far advanced into that Kingdom;
and from our own country, the solitary consideration of it seized sadly upon
us, no earthly nor pleasurable improvements here could give allay to our
sorrows, but with restless repose we sat down, as the rest did, by those
pleasant rivers, where notwithstanding we were capable of no content or
refreshing, except it were by venting of our grief in tears, which whilst they
rejoiced, we shed abundantly at our rememberance of so unvaluable a loss as is
Sion, to be driven from the enjoyment of God and his worship there, and to
leave it in that desolate estate, which no earthly felicities could recompense.

2 Whereupon though the Priests and Levites in the midst of that general
plunder and devastation, We hanged our harps upon the willows, in the midst
thereof.
in their zeal to the memory of Gods worship in the Temple preserved their
instruments, and carried them as fellow-mourners into captivity with
themselves, thinking to mitigate and mix their sorrows with some musical
refreshings, yet when at leasurable times and delectable places by clear
streams under cool shades they were invited to it, their hearts misgave, their
fingers failed them, sorrow so overwhelmed their spirits, that it put all out
of tune, them and their instruments, which in the condition and place they were
in, they as useless hung by, untuned and unstrung, upon the willows, their
grief increasing by their sight, in stead of lessening by their use, when they
apprehended them and themselves jointly and totally captived in the midst of
their mortal enemies far from Jerusalem, which too was left as desolate, as
themselves were disconsolate.

For there they that carried us away captive, required of us a song, and they
that wasted us, required of us mirth, saying, sing us one of the songs of Sion.
3 And the rather, for that the Babylonians insultingly called to us to sing and
be merry, laughing at the misery they had brought us into, being now their
prisoners far from home in their own country, having laid ours quite wast, and
with deriding insolence commanded us to profane the worship of God, which we
were wont solemnly to celebrate in his Temple upon Sion, by making them merry
with one of those sacred songs.

How shall we sing the Lords song in a strange land?
4 But we took courage, and disdained to do it at their command, though in that
condition, resolving to expose our selves, rather than Gods sacred service to
heathenish der^sion, and therefore made answer. Though we are your prisoners,
yet we are servants to the Lord our God, and must obey him before you, who has
commanded those songs (you require) to be sung in a sacred manner to him only,
and in the place appointed by him, his Temple in Jerusalem, and not to be
profaned to any other use in any other place; nor, were it lawful, are we in a
condition to sing, that are as you see such sad spectacles of misery and
misfortune in a strange place, and captives to a strange people that understand
not our language, much less our musical ditties.

5 If any worldly contentment whatsoever bury in me (who personate, If I
forget thee, O Jerusalem, let my right hand forget her cunning.
in that I speak, Gods faithful servants, Priests and Levites, uttering their
thoughts) the sad rememberance of the Churches desolations, that my grief for
thee, O Jerusalem (that was wont to afford such sacred solace in Gods worship,
now under scorn and derision) be not ever in my thoughts, above pleasing my
self or others, let me forfeit the privilege of that gift and honor God has
given me of celebrating his divine praise and worship; let mine hand fail to do
its duty, when I fail of mine to thee, and all my skill forsake me, If I abuse,
or use it to any other purpose than God has appointed it for his worship in
his Temple, do mine enemies what they can.

6 Nay, If I do not remember thee, let my tongue cleave to the roof of my
mouth: if I prefer not Jerusalem above my chief joy.
if I let out my hopes or joys toward any thing comparable to thy restitution;
if any thing (though in this estate) take up my mind and heart more than that,
so that I make it not the continual subject of my desire and prayer, let me be
dumb, and my tongue cease to speak, especially to sing and celebrate thy
praise; if above all desires I desire not, and above all joys rejoice not in
the happy recoverie, and flourishing estate of Jerusalem, and Gods worship
there, as my sole and only solace, how ever both it and we are here in
derision.

7 O Lord, Remember, O Lord, the children of Edom, in the day of Jerusalem: who
said, Raze it, raze it, even to the foundation thereof.
as thy people forget not Jerusalem now in her, and their captivity, so, nor do
thou forget her enemies hereafter, in the day of her prosperity; let the cruel
despite the Edomites, (those sons of Esau, old enemies, though near of kin to
Jacob and his posterity) together with the other bordering nations, be upon
record against them, that with greater hatred than the very Babylonians
themselves, (whom they stirred up against us) helped to demollish that sacred
city, encouraging them and one another to do it to the full, not to leave one
stone upon another, desiring the utter abolition of it and its memory for ever,
so insatiable was their malice. Lay therefore thy vengeance upon Edom, by the
hand of thy people (when thou shall restore them,) and let them do in Edom
according to thine anger and fury, as by thy Prophet thou have foretold they
shall.

O daughter of Babylon, who art to be destroyed: happy shall he be that
rewards thee, as thou have served us.
8 O thou great and mighty Empire, now in thy prime, that take thy
denomination from famous Babylon, the mother-citie, who for all thy pride and
potencie wherewith thou now insultest over others, and us especially; as thou
art the rod in Gods hand for our punishment at present, so the time shall come,
and that assuredly, that thou shall be cast into the fire, lamentable
destruction is preparing for thee, and shall in the time appointed befall thee
unavoidably by the Medes and Persians, the Princes and people whereof shall do
by thee, as thou have done by us, utterly ruin and captivate the whole Empire
with reciprocal cruelty to that we have found at thine hands; for all thy might
at present, this is true of thee, and so thou shall find it; neither thy great
city Babylon, nor its Empire, shall escape one jot better than our poor
Jerusalem and Judah, but confusion and desolation shall be thy portion, for
they shall prevail against thee, and be victorious.

Happy shall he be that takes and dasheth thy little ones against the stones.
9 Remember how thou tyrannizedst in thy victory over us, deflowring, ravishing,
butchering, even poor innocent infants, taking pleasure in barbarism and
cruelty, such measure shall be met to thee in those days. Cyrus and Darius
shall revenge our quarrel, and right our wrongs, and with like success, and no
less delight in blood shall they recompense thee with utter subversion, even to
the slaughtering men, women, and children, without sparing sex or age; none
pitying your condition, but rejoicing at your misery, no more than you pitied
us, but rejoiced at ours, and thought it your felicity, so shall yours be
theirs.

The cxxxviii. PSALM.
David having got through the worst of his troubles under Saul, whom God had
dispatched, and being earnested of the whole Kingdom by possession of a
considerable part, st^^ds as it were, and admires what is past, and the
wonderful progress already made by God in the fulfilling of his promise,
promising himself cause of praising God for the rest that is behind; and
promising God the actual performance of it, who has never failed him in his
need, but upheld his faith, which upheld him. Which wonderful grace of his
exaltation, shall shine as the sun in the firmament, to give light and
conviction to all the Princes round about that hear of it, to their admiration,
and Gods glorification. And lastly he recommends by experience, an humble
suffering State, before a proud presumptuous one, not doubting of Gods
perseverance in mercy toward him unto preservation, and in judgment toward
his enemies unto their utter confusion.

A Psalm of thanksgiving, Psalm cxxxviii. A Psalm of David.
of David's making.

1 LOrd, I will praise thee with my whole heart: before the Gods will I sing
(...) unto thee.
I am neither unmindfull of, nor unthankful for the great things thou have
done, and wilt do for me; but will (not with hypocrytical semblance, as too
many do that worship thee,) but with an honest and sincere heart give the glory
of them wholly to thee, and those opportunities that may most advance thy
praise, will I take more especially to celebrate it, even then when the
greatest concourse of heaven and earth is present, when the Princes of thy
people Israel, and thy people with their Heads and Elders, are solemnly
congregated at thy sanctuary, and thine Angels (those blessed spectatours) who
are there figured by the Cherubims, attendants upon the Ark, that sacred
representation of thine own presence, be present also, even in the sight and
hearing of these created powers and principallities, celestial and terrene,
will I with cordial affection, and musical adoration, celebrate thy praises
that art God of Gods, and Lord of Lords.

I will worship toward thy holy Temple, and praise thy name for thy loving
kindness, and for thy truth: for thou have magnified thy word above all thy
name.
2 Yea, both in thy Sancturay, and out of it, will I memorize thy praiseworthy
goodness to me, wheresoever I am, the face of my soul shall turn like the
needle of a dial by sacred instinct toward thee in that holy repesentation of
thee, the Ark of thy presence, when fixed upon Sion where it is to have its
residence for ever; in the Temple which shall be built thereon, thither-ward
will I worship thee that art there, wheresoever I am, (even as thy Church from
all places on the earth, shall Christ their head in heaven) and magnify thy
power and goodness so clearly demonstrated on my behalf in those acts of grace
and favor, and of no less truth and faithfulness vouchsafed me in my manifold
protections, wonderful deliverances, and happy establishment in the Kingdom,
according as long since thou promised, and foretold by thy Prophets, which
considering the greatness of the thing, the remoteness of time, the
improbability of means, the distance of my condition, and the difficulties
intervening; these things considered, though all thine attributes of greatness
and goodness shine with a beautiful luster in thine accomplishment thus far
advanced, yet thy faithfulness in fulfilling those thy so unlikely promises and
prophesies, out-shines, and be-dims them all, for they being known to all, and
believed of few or none, because of those interposing improbabilities, now they
are fulfilled in a good measure in their view, and to their admiration: it
makes thy truth to bear the bell, comparatively nothing else is thought of, thy
power nor mercy, (saving in subservience thereunto.) It is magnified of all,
and above all.

3 In my calamitous estate when as I cried unto thee, In the day when I cried,
thou answereds^ me: and strengthenedst me with strength in my soul.
as I did often and many a time, thou still heardest and answeredst me
graciously, and gave me inward supportation, strengthening me by faith in
that thy word, to undergo my time of trouble with patience, and wait for the
promised time of my deliverance with confidence.

4 All, All the Kings of the earth shall praise thee, O Lord, when they hear
the words of thy mouth.
even the heathen Kings that have little knowledge or sense of God, round
about, when they hear and understand how this thing is brought to pass, that I
am become King of Israel, a poor persecuted abject man, how that it was
foretold by thy Prophet that it should be so, and answerably fulfilled by thy
power, it shall convince those very infidels to believe and admire thee, for
thy word of truth, and the wonderful unquestionable truth of that thy word, to
the praise thereof.

5 Yea, Yea, they shall sing in the ways of the Lord: for great is the glory
of the Lord.
they shall be ravished in their spirits at the consideration of circumstances
and providence, and shall not contain themselves, but in praisefull
expressions shall vent their apprehensions of thee, touching those strange and
circumferent ways thou have taken, and untroden paths of unlikely means and
providence which thou have made use of, to bring to pass thy purpose toward
me, so manifestly shall thou appear even to them, to be the sole author of it,
and so glorious shall thou appear in those manifestations of my preservation,
exaltation, and mine enemies confusion, notwithstanding the great disproportion
that was betwixt me and them.

6 For though the Lord be in heaven, Though the Lord be high, yet has he
respect to the lowly: but the proud he knows afar off.
swaying there the universal scepter, and that such greatness seems to be at
too infinite a distance and disparitie to one man of mankind, and he also a
mean one as I was, that he should regard him; yet is that no cause of disregard
in God; I have found it so, that this almighty glorious Lord, and heavenly
Potentate, is, notwithstanding respectfull of the poor in spirit, that suffer
wrongfully, and walk dependingly on his grace to relieve and protect them;
whereas those that walk presumptuously to God, or oppressively toward their
brethren, and think their places, or personal excellencies (as Gods on earth)
engage him, or prefer them in his favor, such shall find that humble
adversity is more regarded of God, than proud prosperity; he is near to those
that to the world seem to be far from him, and far from those that upon
mistaken grounds, think themselves near unto him, and much respected by him,
for such he knows indeed, but with no good intentions toward them, to judge
them, not to save them, I and mine enemies have found it so, and so shall
others too.

7 The experience I have had of thy power and faithfulness, Though I walk in
the midst of trouble, thou will rev^ve me, thou shall stretch forth thine hand
against the wrath of mine enemies, and thy right hand shall save me.
makes me confident for future, that however I may have troubles still, yea,
though my life be a continual war-fare, and that I may seem to be crushed by
them, yet my greatest extremity shall be but thine opportunity, even from the
grave it self as it were, will thou restore me (as thou shall Christ.) Mine
enemies rage against me, shall enrage thee against them, and instead of hurting
me, they shall undo themselves, for in judgment shall thou mightily destroy
them, and with almighty mercy preserve me from them.

8 What the Lord had purposed and promised concerning me, The Lord will perfect
that which cocerneth me, thy mercy O Lord, endures for ever* forsake not the
works of thine own hands.
though it seem impossible to be brought to pass, yet, he that has thus far
advanced it, will as certainly perfect it, as he will the Kingdom of Christ; it
shall not miscarrie by any malice or power of men; for God is not as man, to
say and unsay, do and undo; the works and calling of God are without
repentance, what thou, O Lord, in mercy purposes to, and for thy Church and
people, that thou will in mercy perfect; thy Covenant is an everlasting
Covenant, as mercy moved thee to it, so nothing shall remove thee from it, or
make the grace and faithfulness of God of none effect; in mercy therefore
persevere to finish, and lay the top-stone of grace concerning me, who am
brought thus far onwards toward it, by thine almighty goodness and
efficiencie, who has done all that has been done; and so must do still.

The cxxxix. PSALM.
David to evince God of his integrity, and freedom from close hypocrisy (a
sin too common in the world) uses several arguments of his knowledge of Gods
omnisciencie, omnipresencie, and omnipotency, as appears in his works of
creation, but specially in himself so artificially framed, for which (with
reverence and fear) he magnifieth and praises God; as also for his gracious
purposes toward him, which also are ever in his eye, as the one to deter him,
so the other to affect and dispose him better, than to dissemble with such a
God, who is severe against sinners, with whom therefore he dare hold no
correspondencie in their wicked ungodly courses, but from his heart abandons
them, and bears them as much ill will that are so minded toward God, as if
they were open enemies to himself, for all which, both on his integrity of
heart toward God, and sincere hatred of sin and sinners, he puts himself upon
Gods soul-searching inquisition, praying if he be in any thing mistaken, God
would rectify him.

Psalm cxxxix. To the chief musician, A Psalm of David.
To him that is the first, and principal of all the Quire, do I David (that
made this Psalm,) recommend it, for the care and ordering of it to be sung.

1 O Lord, O Lord, thou have searched me, and known me.
that art all-seeing and all-knowing, thou have exercised me under many trying
temptations for a long time, and what has been my behavior under them, thou
know right-well, having put me to it, thou know me by it, what mine heart
is, and how it stands affected toward thee, and thy commandments.

2 Thou know me throughout, Thou know my down ^itting, and mine uprising:
thou understandest my thoughts afar off.
in thought, word, and deed, all the actions of my life are apparent to thee
(from one to another) of what kind or nature soever they be, none excepted;
yea, my very thoughts (whence originally spring those mine actions) are also
known unto thee, yea, before my mind conceive them, thou fore-seest them, much
more before I act them, whilst I think them.

3 Wheresoever I am, Thou compassest my path, and my lying down, and art
acquainted with all my ways.
whithersoever I go, whatsoever I do, night or day, thou art with me, and
know both me and it, nothing can escape thee, no time nor place, for thou art
present with me every step I take, and every thing I do all my life long, to
judge both it and me.

4 For there is not the least word which at any time I have a purpose to speak,
For there is not a word in my tongue, but ^o, O Lord, thou know it
altogether.
but sure enough thou know it before I utter it; yea, the motives and ends
whereupon, and whereunto I do speak it, are known to thee, though oftentimes
they are concealed from man, who can judge only by the letter, but thou
know the spirit.

5 Thine omnipresencie has, Thou have bes^t me behind and before, and laid
thine hand upon me.
and does begirt me round, there is no avoiding thee, if one had a mind to it;
for as thou willest, or permittest, so it is, and must be; even as a child in a
man's hand is guided which way he will, so am I by thine all-disposing hand of
power and providence in all I do, think, or speak.

6 Lord, Such knowledge is too wonderful for me: it is high, I cannot attain
unto it.
such incomprehensible wisdom as thou have, that thus wonderfully know all
things before they are, and when they are, in their causes, motives, ends, is
too deep for me to fathom, and too high for me to climb, being a peculiar
property of thine, the only wise God. I stand at gaze and admire it, and thee
the God of it, that is the nearest that I a poor finite foolish creature can
come to so infinite a wisdom.

7 Had I a mind to shift out of thy sight or knowledge, Whither shall I go from
thy spirit? or whither shall I flee from thy presence.
as those have that walk in ways of wickedness, whither can I go to do it, or
how possibly can I avoid thy presence that art both omniscient and omnipresent

If I ascend up into heaven, thou art there: if I make my bed in hell, behold,
thou art there.
8 There is neither height nor depth that can obscure or hide me from thine
all-seeing eye, or ubiquitarie being: if I could ascend into the heavens, there
I should be sure to find thee, where thou art more especially, or if knowing
and fearing that, I run into the contrary extreme, and by death seek a burying
place out of thy sight, why, it is utterly impossible: For the earth, and under
the earth, the very grave it self is visible to thee, thy sun shines into it,
though ours do not, there thou art in power and presence, as well as in any
other place, knowing and disposing every crum of dust.

If I take the wings of the morning, and dwell in the uttermost parts of the
(...).
9 If in any instant, as the light upon sunrising disperseth it self, I could
convey my self from where I am, to the remotest parts of all the world, over
sea as well as land, thinking by so sudden shifting my place and sight, to so
great distance, to quit thy presence, and deceive thy sight, as one may man's;

Even there shall thy hand lead me, and thy right hand shall hold me.
10 But I should find I am mistaken, and that as swift as I may conceive my self
to move, thou will out-go me, and be there with me, and before me, conveying me
all the way thither, if ever I come there, and ordering me there as here; and
where instead of being at liberty and free from thee to do mine own will, I
shall find my self under thy cognizance and power, not able to stir a foot,
think nor act one jot more or less, than thou dispenses and disposes.

If I say surely the darkness shall cover me: even the night shall be light
about me.
11, 12 If according to humane apprehension, I foolishly imagine and persuade my
self, that though by transmigration of place I cannot in the day time shift thy
sight, Yea, the darkness hides not from thee, but the night shines as the
day: the darkness and the light are both alike to thee.
yet no doubt when the sun is down, and that I can see nothing, nothing (not
God himself) can then see me, but that I am then at mine own dispose to do what
I fancy without discovery, even that very darkness, midnight it self shall,
though indeed it be a cover from man that sees by created light, yet shall it
(respecting God) be none at all, who sees not by a borrowed light as we do, but
by his own, and so sees all men, and all their actions, always, night as well
as day, there is no difference to his uncreated allseeing eye that needs no
help, nor is capable of no hinderance.

13 And Lord, For thou have possessed my reins: thou have covered me in my
mothers womb.
no wonder thou should thus know and discern me, in all places and touching
all things, thoughts as well as deeds, within as without; for from my very
first initiation and beginning to be, wast thou in me and with me, yea, thy
power made me, therefore thine eye saw me, even my most inward parts were then
ordered by thee in their being, and so have they been ever since in their
acting, as my very reins are in me, so art thou in them by thy power and
efficacy, even in all those secret closeted parts of nature, which thou
causedst to be thus externally covered over with flesh and skin in my
conception, whereby (though born into the world) they are yet hid from man's
eyes, but not from thee and thine, who as thou framedst and made them in the
dark womb, where and when no man saw them, so under this skin covering are they
also open, and perspicuous to thee.

14 And though divine art and skill in framing my many inward parts, I will
