praise thee for I am fearfully and wonderfully made: mavelous are thy works,
and that my soul knows right well.
and their concurrences, be thus hid from mine eyes, yet so much knowledge have
I of it, as to know my self both within and without to be wonderfully framed by
an incomprehensible power and wisdom, that makes me astonished at the
consideration of it, and fear and reverence thee* the God of such
transcendencies, and never shall my mind reflect upon my self that am thine
Artifice, but with praise to thee, the great and wise Artificer. Yea, Lord,
which way soever we look, either with the eyes of mind, or body, we cannot but
acknowledge all created substances in the heavens, and the earth in their
several kinds, and orderly sub-ordinations, to be all and every of them
marvellously framed, and extreme wisely contrived and disposed, which has not
taken me up a little time, nor a few thoughts, but many, and many a serious
consideration have I had of them, and of thee, thy power and greatness
manifested in them, to glorify thee answerably: my soul has not been idle
touching thy works in general, and mine own fabric in particular, both body
and soul, which thou have so marvellously made and endowed, but been studious
in practical Philosophy, wherein, in a sanctified way (studying the creature,
for the Creatours sake, and mine own spiritual improvements) I have made good
proficiencie.

My substance was not hid from thee when I was made in secret: and curiously
wrought in the lowest parts of the earth.
15 All that I am, my bones, veins, and sinews, every thing of me was known to
thee, even from the very first conception of them, when nature made my several
parts, and of them an entire body in the unseen cavern of my mothers womb,
there they were most artificially framed, joynted, and contrived, and all this
by thee in heaven, seemingly at infinite distance, and in (as it were) the
darksom cells and concaves of the earth where no light comes (for such is the
shop thou made me in) where yet thou saw and orderest all the mavelous
proceeding of my conception, and formation here below.

16 Thou saw and knew me when I was in my Chaos, Thine eyes did see my
substance yet being unperfect, and in thy book all my members are written:
which in continuance were fashioned, when as yet there was none of them.
mine Embrio, even in that confused slimy congealed lump and substance of mine
original matter, before nature had concocted and digested it into any form of
parts and members, which yet in thine eternal decree and praeordination were
appointed to be, and which for that only reason, and by thine only power,
concurring with thy will, was in process of time (such, and so long) as thou
have ordained for nature to ripen, and heat and moisture to bring to maturity
in, at last formed into a comely and beautiful order, worthy the name of thy
creature, and bearing thine Image; even this did thou produce out of most
unlikely materials by thy skill, in thy time.

17, 18 Nor art thou only admirable in thy creative power and goodness, How
precious also are thy thoughts unto me, O God? how great is the sum of them?
but otherways also; thy word declares by manifold promises and prophecies,
very gracious and merciful intentions, If I should count them, they are more in
number than the sand: when I wake, I am still with thee.
and inclinations toward me in a special manner, and thy works of grace and
providence have also shown as much, which I can better admire, than number, for
they are numberless, which occupy my thoughts continually day and night,
always but when I am asleep.

19 And as my thoughts are of thy wisdom, Surely thou will slay the wicked, O
God: depart from me t^erefore ye blo^dy men.
power, and goodness, so also am I mindful of thy justice and holiness, how
that thou will be meet with wicked workers, and pay them in their kind; they
that unjustly seek to destroy others, shall themselves justly be destroyed by
thee the righteous God and judge of all the world, therefore will I keep me
free from partner-ship with them in those their evil and injurious ways of
wrong or revenge; no such guilt will I bring upon my head, and so I declare my
self; I fear thee though they do not.

For they speak against the^ wickedly, and thine en^mies take thy name in (...),
20 For they stick not presumptuously to despise and despite thee by open
blasphemies, and reproaches of thy justice, power, and faithfulness, scornfully
abusing (in the height of their pride, and malice against thee and thine,) all
those thine excellencies which thy people fear, and reverence thee for

21 Thou, Do not I hate them, O Lord, that ha^^ thee? and am I not grieved with
these that rise up against the^?
Lord, know how little good will I bear to wickedness, and wicked men, I am
far from having fellowship with them that I see bear an evil will toward thee,
thy worship, or people; my very heart rises at such with indignation, out of
zeal to thee, and it is no small trouble to me, to see wicked men to provoke
thee, and bear themselves so contemptuously toward thee so great a God, as they
do.

I hate them with perfect hatred: I count them mine enemies.
22 Yea, from my heart root do I abominate wicked men, in their wicked courses;
nor do I dissemble the matter, but profess my self no friend or favourer of
them, no more (nor so much) than if they were mine own very enemies, and hated
me; for my love to thee, makes me more sensible of the dishonor, and
indignity that is done thee, than my self, and worse can I endure it, or them
that do it.

Search me, O God, and know my heart: try me and know my thoughts.
23 And in regard many that are mine enemies, are also thine, such as perversely
sin against thee, as well as injure me, and that therefore I may play the
hypocrite, and dissemblingly make show of hatred to them for thy sake, when
covertly it is for mine own, thinking thereby to commend my self unto thee, and
gain upon thee by such a profession, therefore do I willingly lay my self open
before thee, and uncover every corner of my heart for thee to see into it,
whether it be not as I say, and that my thoughts and affections in this point
be not sincere and upright, against wicked men, purely for wickedness.

24 Yea, And see if there be any wicked way in me, and lead me in the way
everlasting.
spare not to make such discovery of me, whether (although I speciously seem to
hate their persons, if yet secretly I love not their ways, and could find in
my heart to practice wickedness as they do, rather than piety; yea, if there
be any the least root of bitterness remaining in me, or the least sin
unmortified or abetted by me, whereby I may incur thy displeasure that art an
all-discerning God, or grieve thy spirit who am judge of mine, and if there be
any such unknown to me, for I know man's heart is deceitful, convince me of it
and convert me from it, that by thy gracious and powerful manu-mission I may be
set free from thraldom to sin, that leads to perdition the reward of every such
transgression, and by thy no less gracious and powerful manu-diction be ordered
and enabled in my whole man through my whole life, to walk in a perfect way of
holiness, that only leads to everlasting life, and thy well pleasing, this
Lord is my desire.

The cxl. PSALM.
David in way of prayer makes his complaint against his wicked and violent
persecutours Saul and Doeg, and the rest of their considerates, that by a saint
combination, plot and labor to take away both his life and good name, by all
underhand contri^an^^s that may be. Therefore he applies himself to God that
has preserved him from open, now to protect him from secret violence, and
bring the evil they intend to him upon themselves, yea, remarkable judgments
upon such imp^nit^nts. And promises himself and all others that suffers in a
good cause with a good conscience as he does, happy deliverance, and their
enemies confusion.

Psalm cxl. To the chief musician, A Psalm of David.
To him that is the first and principal of all the Quire, do I David, that
made this Psalm, recommend it for the care and ordering of it to be sung.

DEve^ me, O Lord, from the evil man: preserve (...) from the violent man.
1 O Lord, that know the wrong I sustain by being thus unjustly persecuted of
Saul and his accomplices, that most wickedly and unmercifully prosecute me to the
death, that never wronged him nor them in all my life, do thou that art a
righteous Judge of oppressors, and a gracious God to right the oppressed,
undertake my cause and me, to vindicate the one and protect the other, from the
bloody intentions of my causeless cruel enemy and enemies.

Which imagine mischiefs in their heart: continually are they gathered together
for war.
2 Whose hearts are full of cursed contrivances how to mischief and undo me, and
to take away both my good name and life, laboring to increase their party, and
stir up others against me daily by false suggestions plotting all manner of
ways and means by joint advice, and endeavor to wage war upon me that would
fain be at peace.

They have sharpened their tongues like a serpent: adders poison is under their
lips. Selah.
3 They labor to wound mine innocence as deep as they can possibly, by lying
and slanderous reports of me, and vermin-like spit their venom at me behind my
back, by prejudicing the people against me with their false calumnies, which
they have ready at hand to poison all ears that will give them the hearing; It
is their continual practice.

4, Keep me* O Lord, from the hands of the wicked, preserve me from the violent
man, who have purposed to overthrow my goings.
5 The good Lord watch for me to save me, as they do against me to undo me, and
keep me from their destructive malice and power that have put in practice every
way in the world to compass my ruin; The proud have hid a snare for me, and
cords, they have spread a net by the way side: they have set grins for me.
Sela^.
with extreme and unappeasable violence does Saul seek my life, and to that end
has laid snares to catch and entrap me, that I should not escape him, as yet I
bless thee I have done, and pray still I may do by thy powerful preservation
and deliverance of me from him, and those proud presumptuous wretches his
Partisans that disdain the purpose, though of God himself as touching me to be
King over them, and therefore try all conclusions, and use their utmost
endeavors to disappoint it by subtle stratagems and wicked devices, laying as
it were traps and toils, nets and grins, all manner of engines to catch me that
craft can device, the way they think I take, as if I were some wild beast, or
monster among men, of a perilous nature, and dangerous consequence, not fit to
live; They are restless to ruin me.

6 In this my hazardous condition when I was thus waylaid on all hands, I said
(...) Lord, thou art my God: hear the voice of my supplications, O Lord.
I repaired to God as always I do, to extricate me out of it, by faithful
prayer, pleading my propriety in him and his grace, which of grace he had
vouchsafed me, minded him of it, and prayed him for it, to lend me an hearing
ear in my very great need, for deliverance and preservation.

7 Saying, O God the Lord, the strength of my salvation; thou have covered my
head in the day of battle.
O gracious God, the only Lord Almighty, the sole power I trust in and depend
upon for safety, I have found thee a deliverer and preserver in former dangers,
when my life has laien at stake, and been in hazard by open violence in the
day of battle against the enemy, as now it does by secret machinations of
inveterate deadly foes, no less endangering it.

Grant not, O Lord, the desires of the wicked, further not his wicked devi^e,
least they exalt themselves. Selah.
8 And as I pray for my self by virtue of mine interest, and near relation to
thee, so give me leave to pray against my wicked enemies, that are also thine,
that what they desire to bring to pass against me, may not take effect, blast
thou their wicked designs, which I am sure can take no place if thou do not
more or less allow them, which I pray thee do not, but the contrary, least
they vain-gloriously magnify their cause, and disparage mine, and being
fleshed with success, blasphemously set light by thee, as well as me, compared
with themselves, which else they will be sure to do.

As for the head of those that compass me about, let the mischief of their own
lips cover them.
9 As for the chief hunts-men, the principal ringleaders, and occasioners of
this my trouble and persecution, Saul and Doeg, that set the multitude on work
to betray and entrap me every where where I come, whom they have deceived and
misled by their false reports; let that they intend to bring upon me, even
destruction, fall heavily and unavoidably upon them, that they may by no means
escape it, but in thy justice, be themselves taken in the net they laid for
others.

Let bu^ning coals ^all upon them, let them be cast into the fire; into deep
pits, that they rise not up again.
10 Let such impenitent reprobate minded men come to an exemplarie end by some
severe and formidable judgment, as did Sodom and Gomorrah, consume them
utterly by thy vengeance and fiery indignation, yea, by sudden and fearful
destruction, as thou did Korah and Dathan, remove them once for all from off
the face of the earth, where they do so much mischief in opposing thee and the
coming of thy Kingdom, that they may rest in perpetual darkness of death,
which only can stitle them and hold their hands, and whence they shall never
more return to do as they have done, being thereby everlastingly disposed of.

11 Lord, Let not an evil speaker be established in the earth: evil shall hunt
the violent man to overthrow him*
let not any man (much less mine enemies) by lying and slandering and such
wicked unworthy ways prosper in his designs, against the plain and sincere
hearted, least it encourage other earthworms that know not God, nor care not
for heaven, to take the like courses, when they see them thereby brought to
ruin, and the wicked contrivers succesfull and fortunate against them. No, I am
confident and dare pronounce it in the name of the Lord, that the wicked
purposes and contrivances of the ungodly bloodthirsty man, be he higher or
lower, wherewith he hunts others to the death if he could catch them, shall
follow him at heels, and drive him into such a trap and snare at last, that he
shall never escape, even utter destruction.

12 And on the other hand I dare promise as much for God on the behalf of them,
I know that the Lord will maintain the cause of the afflicted, and the right of
the poor.
that for his sake are unjustly wronged and persecuted, be they never so poor,
and their oppressors never so potent, God will patronize both them and their
cause against the wrong-doers, stand to them, and appear for them to do them
right, and justify their innocence, of this I am confident, for his truth is
engaged for it, and his glory is concerned in it, I doubt not to find it so in
mine own particular, though it fare ill with me now.

Surely the righteous shall give thanks unto thy name, the upright shall dwell
in thy presence.
13 Sure enough the time will come that they that with a good and honest heart
manage a righteous cause, though they may and must be content to suffer for a
time, as long and as much as pleases God, yet they shall see a happy end of
their sufferings, and the miserable catastrophe of their oppressors to their
exceeding great cause of joy in, and thankfulness to God, that by his grace and
power has brought it so about beyond expectation or probability: They that are
upright and so hold out under affliction, keeping a good conscience toward God
and man, patiently waiting and enduring, shall happily survive their
afflictions and afflictours here, so that God shall lead them through, and land
them safe on the other side, (as I doubt not he will do me) where the residue
of their days they shall propitiously enjoy the Lord for their God, or if they
miscarry in them (as so he may permit) yet shall they not miscarry by them, but
shall be happier in heaven, whither they shall translate them, than earth could
have made them, in a full fruition of him there in that glorified estate,
whither no sorrow shall follow them.

The cxli. PSALM.
David and his men being in great danger by Saul's surprise, probably either in
the wilderness of Engeddi or of Ziph, and having opportunity and temptation of
revenge, prays that God would deliver him both from death and sin in that
strait. Is greatly troubled that so many innocents should so prosecute him
through misunderstanding, wishes they would take another course more agreeable
to charity, for whom yet his charity shall move him to pray, that they may not
perish with their malicious misl^aders, in hope, that when they are removed out
of the way by Gods just judg^ments, these will then be reduced and hear reason,
though now their ears are charmed. And lastly represents his, and his partisans
perilous case to God, but withal, his faith in God, praying for his own
deliverance and his enemies subversion.

A Psalm made by David. Psalm cxli. A Psalm of David.


1 LOrd, LOrd, I cry unto thee, make have unto me, give ear unto my voice when
I cry unto thee.
no danger is so great nor eminent as to stifle my faith or stop my mouth, but
be it what it will be, I make my moan unto thee, even now in this mine
extremity, wherein I am not a little concerned, nor thee, to make have to my
rescue, being sore laid to; be not therefore a stranger to me, nor deaf to hear
me, but graciously compassionate my misery, and hear me effectually now and
always, when in such straits I supplicate thy Majesty.

2 Let my prayer, Let my prayer be set forth before thee as incense, and the
lifting up of my hands, as the evening sacrifice.
which I daily put up unto thee in the virtue of Christ's mediation, ascend and
be accepted of thee, as the Type thereof that perpetual fragrant
incense-offering, burnt each morning in the sanctuary, and let my supplication
the spiritual sacrifice of a faithful heart be as pleasing, as the appointed
meat offering every evening.

3 Lord, Set a watch O Lord before my mouth, keep the door of my lips.
my temptations are great and provocations many, suffering so unjustly and
ungratefully as I do, under a tedious and trying persecution that exercises
all the faith and patience I have, and were it not for thy supporting auxiliary
grace, would be too hard for me, notwithstanding mine, which can of it self ill
grapple with such adversaries and adversities, without out-breaches of
corruptions, whereto my mind and mouth in thoughts and words are over prone,
therefore good Lord, carefully keep and restrain me, that through sinful
impatience or incogitancy, I sometime or other forget not my self, and
imprudently let fall either words or rash discontent toward thee, or of
sinful revenge toward mine adversaries, unworthy the Mediator and Lamb-like
patience of him, whom I prefigure in these my durances, but may patiently wait,
and bear what is thy pleasure to the utmost time and measure, as he shall, not
sinning so much as in word or thought.

Incline not my heart to any evil thing, to practice wicked works with men that
work iniquity: and let me not eat of their dainties.
4 I well know mine own natural inclination what it is, how prone to evil mine
heart and affections are, specially upon temptation, yea, to any or to every
evil of words or actions how vild soever, and that unavoidably, if thou decline
it not; thou must bend it the contrary way by thine over-powering efficacious
grace grace-ward, or else it will warp sin-ward, with the weight or attraction
of temptation; I have no confidence in it but only in thee, in whose hands are
all hearts, and mine more especially; dispose thou (...) therefore to good and
not to evil, to right and not to wrong-doing of no kind, less, nor more, let no
temptation, in no condition, upon no occasion, prevail with me to sin, but so
establish my heart, and strengthen my graces, that I may make constant
resistance without envying their happiness, that prosper by undue courses,
whilst I in the practice of piety find nothing but misery; keep me from being
taken with their golden baits of earthly felicity to the loss of heavenly, for
that shall be their reward that live in sin, how sweet soever it is at
present to their corrupt tastes, and so shall it to be mine, if I leave the way
I am in of serving thee to serve sin, whence, Lord, deliver me.

5 O that I might be free from the temptations of these wicked malicious
persecutours, Let the righteous smite me it shall be a kindness; and let him
reprove me, it shall be an excellent oil, which shall not break my head: for
yet my prayer also shall be in their calamities.
Saul and his chieftaines, that so impiously against their own consciences
traduce me to the people, and unworthily seek my life by all sinister courses,
tempting me to the like wicked ways of revenge and retaliation, which I find I
can hardly forbear, so injurious are my sufferings, and hazardous my condition,
it being humanely impossible to shift them by lawful and conscionable courses,
without taking all advantages as they do. And that the well-meaning innocent
people that perpetrate nothing of malice, but through credulity and misprision
are misled to do that they do against me: O that they would not so err, but
would question and blame me to my face in a fair and friendly manner, as
becomes one toward another, touching what they hear and too easily take upon
trust. I should take such dealing exceeding kindly, and interpret those
reproofs no acts of enmity and hostility, but friendly and good offices. Who
though they do not so, but suffer themselves thus to be misled to the wronging
me in this sort, yet wish I no ill to them, but pity them for their unhappy
engagement in so bad a cause, and shall be heartily sorry when any hurt befalls
them for it, as I know there will, which when it does, I will pray for them as
for my self.

6 When the time comes for God to execute vengeance on their Rulers and
Commanders, When their Judges are overthrown in stony places, they shall hear
my words, for they are sweet.
who now so bewitch the people, and that they fall by the sword in mount
Gilboa, and the Kingdom so unexpectedly be translated to me, then will the
people be brought to a right understanding of me, when I shall declare to them
that I never sought the Kingdom, as they had been made believe, but it was the
purpose and good will of God to cast it upon me for their good, and the
happiness of all Israel which shall follow thereupon, they shall then be won to
believe and hope so to their comfort, when they see it so wonderfully brought
about merely by providence, and Gods just judgment, maugre the malice and
power of mine enemies (their seducers) to the contrary.

Our bones are scatter^d the graves mouth, as when one cutteth and cleaves
wood upon the earth.
7 The danger of me and all that take part with me in regard of its eminency and
mine enemies rage, is as great as great can be; sure we are all of us to be
slain if taken, and that in a barbarous cruel manner too; hewn in pieces and
piecemeal exposed above ground, no mercy alive nor dead can such Traitors, as
we are counted to be, expect, but the uttermost rigor and exemplary severity
that can be inflicted, are we sure of.

But mine eyes are unto thee, O God the Lord: in thee is my trust, leave not my
soul destitute.
8 But, Lord, in this strait of me and mine, I am not so dejected as to let fall
my faith, nor to cease prayer, but to thee a gracious and omnipotent Lord God,
to whom belong the issues from death, do I in the vehement ardency of my spirit
make mine address for relief in this mine extremity; my confidence is more
because of thee, thy power and goodness, in which I trust, then is my fear by
reason of my dangers greatness, therefore be not wanting to save my life, which
I give for lost if thou save it not, for other help or helper I have none.

9 I know nothing is impossible to God, Keep me from the snare which they have
laid for me, and the grins of the workers of iniquity.
the snares and grins that mine enemies lay privily for me are known to thee,
though by mine ignorance I may be hazarded, yet by thy providence I hope to be
prevented. Keep me from being caught which else I shall be, and from being made
a prey to malicious bloodthirsty men, that are void both of piety and humanity.

10 Let my wicked enemies be overtaken in their own projects by thy just
judgments, Let the wicked fall into their own nets, whilst that I withal
escape.
who art able to ensnare them in, and by their own craft, and to make it appear
that simple honesty is the best policy, and wicked policy the greatest
simplicity and most self-destructive, make them manifest examples of it, by
thine out-witting and mine escaping them, but their not escaping thee.

The cxlii. PSALM.
David shut up in the cave at Engeddi by an in raged multitude, lays seidge to
God by servent and incessant prayer, who (he confesses) saved him by his
wisdom and contrivance when his own had almost undone him. He shows his heart
made some excursions toward the creature, but in vain, and quickly with-called
it self, and betook it again to God, as to all that was left him, and therefore
presses hard upon him for deliverance particular and general, that he and the
righteous may once be acquainted that now are strangers, and may jointly praise
him.

David's instruction to the faithful in time of extremity to pray as he did,
Psalm cxlii. Mas^hil of David; a p^ayer when he was in the cave.
when he was hid in the cave of Engeddi, begirt with Saul's Army.

1 AS was mine extremity, I cried unto the Lord with my voice: with my voice
unto the Lord did I make my supplication.
so was mineimportunity, I was hard beset, and I beset God as hard, incessantly
urging my condition upon him, again and again iterating it in his ears, so that
I gave him no rest whilst my danger lasted.

I poured out my complaint before him, I showed before him my trouble.
2 I made my moan unto him how injuriously my life was sought, for him to right
me, and how my danger increased to a very crisis, for him to relieve me, showed
him how nothing humanely was betwixt me and utter destruction, if he interposed
not, death was unavoidable.

When my spirit was overwhelmed within me, then thou knew my path: in the
way wherein I walked, have they privily laid a snare for me.
3 When I was at my wits end, and knew no way to escape, when I thought this
thing and that thing, but saw safety in nothing that I could imagine, then
had thou designed the way of my deliverance, how I should come out of that so
eminent peril, else I could never have been preserved, for that which I took
to be my safest course, there to hide my self in the wilderness of Engeddi,
proved of all other my greatest dangers, mine enemies were too cunning for me,
and all the shift I could make, and by their subtility and secrecy had
certainly surprised me, had not thou mightily prevented it.

I looked on my right hand, and beheld, but there was no man that would know
me, refuge failed me: no man cared for my soul.
4 I ruminated with my self, and thought (as men in such cases are apt sometimes
to hope and sometimes to fear) that sure this or the other man would intercede
to Saul for me, and stand up in the defense of mine innocence to save my life,
and that I had some friends and acquaintance yet left me, that would appear for
me in such a time of need, but there was none, all were against me, not a man
for me, all sought my ruin, none pitied my case, nor offered to speak a word in
my behalf, when my life lay at stake, so utterly destitute was I, and humanely
helpless.

I cried unto thee, O Lord, I said, thou art my refuge, and my portion in the
land of the living.
5 My last and best refuge was therefore to thee, O Lord, whom I earnestly
beseeched to be helpful to me in that so great extremity, showed thee how all
helps else failed me, that thou only and alone wast left me to fly to, and
hope in, who art the stay and strength of mine heart, my never-failing
deliverer, and how that being stripped of all interest and propriety in the
promised land, and all in it (as if I were an utter stranger and no Israelite)
nothing is left me but thy self, a naked God in promise is all my part and
portion therein.

6 Lord, Attend unto my cry for I am brought very low; deliver me from my
persecutours, for they are stronger than I.
forget not thy servant that is so mindful of thee, whose all in all thou art,
but make this mine extremity thine opportunity, hear me effectually that cry
unto thee ardently, as mine extremity enforces me to do, having as it were one
foot within the door of death, never man was nearer it and escape, be thou that
art Almighty my powerful deliverer from my potent enemies, and bloody
persecutours, that so surround me, and so far surpass me.

7 Deliver me from out this present danger and inclusion, Bring my soul out of
prison, that I may praise thy name: the righteous shall compass me about: for
thou shall deal bountifully with me.
yea, put a final end to my persecution, whereby my life is held in continual
danger, and set me at liberty from the oppressing power of mine enemy, that as
thy freeman (when freed) I may glorify thee, thy power and goodness that has
done so great things for me. And then shall the good and well-meaning people
(though now misled too many of them) flock about me with admiration and praise
of thy wonderful works in my strange, manifold, and manifest deliverances, by
the good hand of God to me, which shall clearly show it self to the conviction
of all, that I am the man which under thee must rule over them, as Christ over
his Church.

The cxliii. PSALM.
David under great persecution and trouble, prays earnestly that God would
not, as he might, proceed against him in relation to himself, but against his
enemies in relation to him, for though as to God he was a sinner, to them he
was none, who therefore injuriously sought his life to his extreme perplexity.
Yet he comforts himelf in God his former mercies, and prayers to him for
present deliverance, and perseverance in holiness, and concludes with prayer
for his own preservation and his enemies destruction.

Psalm cxliii. A Psalm of David.
A Psalm made by David.

HEar my prayer, O Lord, give ear to my supplications in thy faithfulness
answer me, and in thy righteousness.
1 MY calamities are such as put me upon vehement and often supplications to thy
Majesty for deliverance; O that thou would hear me once for all, by putting
a period to my misery, according to the faithfulness of thy promise in that
behalf, and the gracious nature that is in thee in justice to deliver the
oppressed.

And enter not into judgment with thy servant: for in thy sight shall no man
living be justified.
2 Let not mine afflictions be the punishments of my sins, as I confess they
justly may, for then shall I be hopeless and they endless, but remember me
under another notion, as one chosen and called through grace to be thy servant,
and that in eminent place in thy Church, consider me as such I pray thee, in
mercy to pardon and pass by my sinfulness, for it is not mine innocence but thy
clemency that must acquit me as to thee, though as to mine enemies I dare plead
it, but not as to thee, who art a God of pure eyes, and see sin enough in me
and every one else, seem he never so righteous in the eye of the world or his
own, utterly and for ever to sentence us to hell, much more to punish us here.

3 It is justice betwixt me and mine enemies that I sue for, For the enemy
has persecuted my soul, he has smitten my life down to the ground: he has
made me to dwell in darkness, as those that have been long dead.
to be of grace vouchsafed me, for they have unjustly hunted after my life for
a long time together, and have brought it as near to death as could be
possible, and banished me the society and communion of men, to seek sanctuary
in wildernesses and caves, solitary and desolate, disregarded, and given of all
for lost, never to recover any better fortune, no more than for a man that is
dead and buried to arise.

4 Which uncomfortable forlorn castaway condition does grievously affect me
with trouble of mind, Therefore is my spirit overwhelmed within me: my heart
within me is desolate.
and makes my heart as void of comfort within, as my life is without.

5 Yet, I remember the days of old, I meditate on all thy works: I muse on the
work of thine hands.
Lord, do not I altogether count my self, as others do, but for all I am so as
I am, my hope is still in thee, I consider how it has been both with my self
and other thy servants of old; what difficulties they have waded through, what
deliverances and preservations they have had, and from what an ebb-condition
thou have by thy mighty power and goodness raised them, and truly this holds
mine head still above water, and sustains me in faith and hope.

6 So that I cease not to pray, I stretch forth mine hands unto thee: my soul
thin steth after thee, as a th^rsty land. S^la^.
my danger stops not my mouth, nor makes me desperate, but in the hope I have
in thee (though destitute of all else) I make my fervent addresses to thee,
with an eager desire to be heard and to enjoy the fruits of thy promises, never
did the chawned earth more need and desire the rain to moisten it in time of
drought, than does this heart of mine thirst after the supplement of grace in
this my calamity. Thou Lord know it.

7 And therefore accordingly vouchsafe to expedite help unto me, Hea^ me
speedily, O Lord, my spirit saileth: hide not thy face from me, least I be like
unto them that go down into the pit.
for truly such outward miseries, inward perplexities, and forcible
heart-breathings after thee, will quickly expire me, I cannot long live under
such heavy burdens and depressions of nature, they will consume me, if thou
do not quickly afford some reviving by timely redress, and effectual
favor, which I beseech thee to do, least death and destruction seize suddenly
upon me, which (to speak humanely) I am within a very little of.

Cause me to heathy loving kindness in the morning, for in thee do I trust:
cause me to know the way wherein I shall walk, for I lift up my soul unto thee.
8 Whilst yet there is hope before life extinct, make have to help me, and as
it were to revive my dying decaying spirits with some cordial of grace and
timo^s deliverance, for my trust is still in thee for it, how low soever I am
brought; point me out by thy singer of direction and hand of providence, how I
may come safe out of this inextricable labyrinth of troubles, wherewith I am
encumbered, and know no way to escape them but by immediate and miraculous
mercy, for which I am an humble suitour to thee, with all the powers of my soul
that is left me.

Deliver me, O Lord, from mine enemies: I fly unto thee to hide me.
9 Thy effectual grace in my powerful deliverance is mine humble and earnest
suit, I put up unto thee, that mine enemies who seek and make sure of my life,
may not destroy it, which they will certainly and suddenly do, if thou prevent
not, to whom only I fly from them, for no place on earth can escape them.

Teach me to do thy will, for thou art my God: thy spirit is good, lead me in
the land of uprightness.
10 And as I beg to be preserved by thy power out of the hands of mine enemies,
so by thy grace out of the power of my corruptions, which by reason of my
temptations are very stirring and hardly suppressed, inclining me upon occasion
to deviate, but my trust is in thee, and prayer unto thee for this as well as
that, sin being as death to me, therefore for thy goodness sake which has so
freely and so fully engaged thee to be every way a gracious God unto me, and
specially in soul-concernments. Lord, teach me at every turn and in every
strait what is thy will, and how to obey it, by the powerful energie of thy
spirit, which himself is good, and can make me so, by his efficacious
impowering my spirit thereunto, maugre all temptations within or without, yea,
all my life long effectually dispose me to walk in the way of holiness and
righteousness, which only leads unto everlasting life, the new heavens and new
earth, wherein dwells righteousness; a pattern whereof shall be that
flourishing estate of thy Church in holiness, shortly to be accomplished to
thine Israel by and under me a figure of Christ, which, good Lord, teach me how
to attain to, that my sins debar me not so great a blessing.

11 For the glory of thy power, Quicken me, O Lord, for thy names sake: for thy
righteousness sake bring my soul out of trouble.
which is so highly esteemed and little feared by mine enemies, do thou
manifest it, in (as it were) my resurrection from the dead, for such am I in
effect, and in all humane appearance; and for thy faithfulness sake both in
point of grace and justice, be mindful of me thy servant wrongfully oppressed
and persecuted, to set me free from these deadly dangers I am continually in.

12 And of mere compassion to me in so great misery undertake my cause and
quarrel, And of thy mercy cut off mine enemies and destroy all them that
afflict my soul: for I am thy servant.
that without cause am thus persecuted to the death by violent and bloody
enemies who are untreatable, and from whom I must never expect other, till thou
shall disable them to destroy me, by destroying them, which I pray thee do, as
an act of mercy to my wronged innocence, let none escape, that would not have
me do so, that my soul may be free from these distractions to serve thee, for
thereunto through mercy am I designed, and by grace am I called.

The cxliv. PSALM.
David being in part possessed of the Kingdom, blesses God for that, which he
acknowledges to be of him, as also all his achievements and deliverances, and
aggravates the greatness of God goodness to him from the baseness and disparity
of him to God, whom he prays extraordinarily to stand for him against, and rid
him of his remainder of enemies, as bad as the rest, and promises upon final
deliverance to tune all his instruments to his praise, as the sole Savior,
specially of him; and again iterates his request, that the times of Isreal's
tranquillity under him and his may hasten, that they may once be happy after
so much misery, which then they shall be, with the ample possession of
temporal felicities of all kinds, and God to boot, which will make them or any
people happy that are so blessed.

Psalm cxliv. A Psalm of David.
A Psalm made by David.

BLessed be the Lord my strength, which teaches my hands to war, and my
fingers to fight.
1 MAgnified be the Lord, for his praiseworthy goodness to me, in so
marvellously inabling me beyond either natural ability or acquired skill, to
do things so much above my self in soldiery, as through his assistance I have
done to mine own and all men's admiration, and to such wonderful success as I
have had thereby.

My goodness and my fortress, my high tower and my deliverer, my shield, and he
in whom I trust: who subdueth my people under me.
2 But it was the Lord, and of him only, who has and does show me so many
favors, and is so bountiful and beneficent to me as I cannot express it, but
in the abstract of goodness it self, so freely are they acted, and so
manifoldly multiplied; to descend into particulars were infinite, but what can
be imagined by way of offense to mine enemies, or defense to my self, that the
Lord is, and has been to me, and I am confident so will be still: He it is
that has brought and will go on irresistably to bring this stubborn
stiff-necked people of Israel to submit to me as their King, who so hardly are
removed from their prejudices concerning me, and brought to believe the truth
of promises touching me.

3 Lord, Lord, what is man, that thou take knowledge of him? or the son of
man, that thou make account of him?
I cannot when I reflect upon my self and thee, the disproportion 'twixt my
nature and essence, frail mortal dust and ashes here below, and thy spiritual,
eternal, incomprehensible Being and infinite Majesty in heaven above, but
admire, That such an earthworm as man (the whole kind whereof is at best but as
the drop of thy bucket) subject to generation and corruption, should be so
regarded of thee as to expend and lay out so much of thy wisdom, care, and
providence upon him, especially considering what he is become by sin, not
worthy the name of a creature, that by nature is thine enemy, and that yet
thou should exercise so much grace and goodness toward him sundry ways.

4 Man in respect of thee, Man is like to vanity, his days are as a shadow
that passes away.
is as the most vain, and emptiest thing in the world is to him, for substance
a thing of nothing, and for duration as momentanie and uncertain is his life,
subject to time and change, as the shadow which is as transient as the sun is
moveable.

5 Yet such is thy goodness to this poor inconsiderable creature, Bow thy
heaven^, O Lord, and come down: touch the mountains and they shall smoke.
that thou art pleased to work miracles many times for the preservation of a
very few, yea, of one single person that belongs unto thee, and to descend as
it were from thine imperial throne of Divine Majesty, to help here on earth
wonderfully, when thine are in extremity, and so, Lord, vouchsafe to do now,
manifest thy presence, as when in thick and darksome clouds thou formerly
descendedst, and made the mountains seem all on fire under thee, such let be
thine outgoings against mine and thy Churches enemies, consume those
mountainous powerful adversaries that oppose themselves against thee in thy
wrathful displeasure; a little whereof will serve to do it, as high and mighty
as they are in their own vain imaginations.

Cast forth lightning, and scatter them: shoot out thine arrows and destroy
them.
6 Thy peoples extraordinary dangers have produced extraordinary, and
miraculous effects of providence for their preservation, and so let it do
still, let thy power be now as evident, as when with thunder and lightening
thou foughtest for them, destroyedst and discomfitedst their enemies heretofore.

Send thine hand from above, rid me, and deliver me out of great waters: from
the hand of strange children.
7 When earthly helps fail, from heaven do thou send succor, and set me free
from this deluge of trouble, and troublesome adversaries that break in upon me
like an unresistable torrent, let me not fall into the hands of those that
though they are visible Israelites, of the seed and family of Jacob, yet by
their wicked malicious deportment, might be as well infidels and heathens, and
as much charity and humanity may I expect from those, as these.

Whose mouth speaks vanity: and their right hand is a right hand of falsehood.
8 Who are perfect proficients in all kind of treachery and dissimulation,
practicing nothing else but how they may deceive and entrap the innocent, no
tie can hold them, whatsoever they promise they break, and their contracts,
though never so solemnly smitten, are but snares and traps, one can believe
nothing they say or do, so false are they.

I will sing a new song unto thee, O God: upon a ^saltery, and an instrument of
ten strings will I sing praises unto thee.
9 As thy mercies multiply, so shall my praises, which hitherto have gone along
foot by foot with all thy gracious dispensations, every remarkable mercy has
inspired me afresh, and brought forth a suitable Psalm of praise and
thanksgiving, and so shall they that are to succeed; when thou shall complete
mine establishment, and work out my final deliverance, I will not be behind
hand to express it to the full, in a full and open acknowledgement, answerably
magnifying thee with the uttermost of my skill, both by voice and instrument
tuned to thy praise.

10 And I will say, It is he that gives salvation unto Kings: who delivers
David his servant from the hurtful sword.
that the Lord alone is worthy to be magnified by all his vicegerents upon
earth, who disposes of Kings and Kingdoms as pleases him, none, though never
so great, standing or prevailing by their own power, but by his, either in
victory over their enemies, or peaceable government over their people, and I
least of all, who am most of all bound to acknowledge his protection and
deliverance of me out of (otherwise) unavoidable deaths, yea, many an one,
that had else swallowed me up, had not his hand of power answered his word of
promise in the preservation, and preferment of me to this place of honor, and
service to rule his people Israel.

11 Thou have made some good riddance of mine enemies, Rid me, and deliver me
from the hand of strange children, whose mouth speaks vanity, and their right
hand is a right hand of falsehood.
but more remain, do by these as by those, who are no better, Israelites at
large, only by birth-priviledge have they got the start of heathens, savouring
the things of honesty and truth no more, than they. See further the 7 and 8
verses foregoing of this Psalm.

12 Settle us in a peaceable and prosperous condition, That our sons may be as
plants grown up in their youth; that our daug^ters may be as corner stones,
polished after the similitude of a palace.
by ridding out those that stand in the way of Isreal's welfare, and
flourishing estate under me and mine, that the times may come, which are not
far off, according to the date of thine ordination and promise, when we shall
have even a heaven upon earth, thy blessings of all sorts abounding to us, and
our posterities, and the Commonwealth be peopled, (and re-edified as it were)
with handsome well educated youth, the effects of peace, both men and women,
that has been so long unpolished and in the rough, void of all order and
comeliness.

That our garners may be full, affording all manner of store, that our sheep
may bring forth thousands, and ten thousands in our streets.
13 And when the blessings of corn and cattle shall to admiration be poured out
upon us in so great abundance, as ever, either room within doors can receive,
or pasturage without (all the land over) can maintain.

That our oxen may be strong to labor, that there be no breaking in, nor going
out, that there be no complaining in our streets.
14 And when by peace and plenty our beasts of labor and burden shall be
blessed with strength thereto, and the Kingdom enriched therewith, and that
there shall be no more wasting, robbing, plundering, spoiling, killing, and
captiving as lamentably has been by invasions and inroads of cruel enemies,
nor no need of flying for our security or fighting for our defense, but that
in stead of wringing our hands, and wailing our misfortunes at home, we may
carry sorrow to our enemies doors abroad, whilst nothing but peace and
tranquillity is in the borders of Israel.

Happy is that people that is in such a case: yea, happy is that people, whose
God is the Lord.
15 O the blessedness of such a change, what a happy age will be that brings
with it such an affluence of posterity, peace, and plenty, which are the
riches of a Kingdom, and thus shall it be with us, nothing shall be wanting to
the perfecting our felicity even in these, above all the nations upon earth,
and which is more worth, and sets a Crown upon the head of all the rest, God
himself will be ours to bless us and remain with us, whose grace and favor is
our greatest felicity when our felicity is at greatest, a happiness of all
other most desirable, and an enjoyment incomparable, when, and to whom God
vouchsafes it, as in goodness and faithfulness, under the reign and government
of me and mine now at hand, he will to us his peculiar people.

The cxlv. PSALM.
It is noted of this Psalm as also of some others tending to praise, (as Psalm
111, 112) that they are written according in the Hebrew Alphabet, each verse
beginning with the letters as they lie in order of succession, some only
pretermitted. This particular Psalm it is conceived was composed when the
Kingdom of David flourished, wherein he insists much upon the supremacy and
empire of God over all in general, and his people in special, promising as high
as he is to set God above him, confessing him only to be great, that rules and
does all by an Almighty power and greatness, consounding his enemies, and
exercising all manner of grace to his Church and people, and though just, yet
beneficent, deserving praise from all, but his saints especially, who are under
the covenant and Kingdom of grace, which has been so powerfully administered in
their behalfs, and shall continue to the end of the world, as it has done from
the beginning, for the preservation of his people by him, who is pitiful to the
oppressed to right and raise them. He shows his goodness to be universal, and
that as all things have an instinct toward him, so he toward, them, to do
them good, and as he has given them ^ Being, so he maintains it, which he does
by manifold dispensations of good creatures in sit seasons. And whose
transcendencie appears chiefly in this, that nothing falls out in the
administration of his government, but what is holy and righteous. And though he
be bountiful to all, yet is he graciously propitious but to few, and yet to all
those (which yet are but few) that serve him in sincerity, salvation is there
portion, and destruction the wickeds. For all which he promises to magnify
God, and bespeaks all else to do so.

A Psalm made by David, Psalm cxlv. David's Psalm of praise.
wherein himself praises God abundantly, and incites all others to it
exceedingly, by setting forth before them his praiseworthy acts and
excellencies.

1 THou Lord have highly exalted me, I Will extol thee, my God, O King: and I
will bless thy name for ever and ever.
and so will I thee, as well thou deservest at my hands, I will magnify thy
bounty to me, and do my homage to thee the King of Kings, and more peculiarly
of me thine anointed, who hold what I have by thy donation, and am what I am in
subordination to thee, the Sovereign Lord of all the Kingdoms of the world, but
more especially of mine. Thy greatness and goodness shall for ever be
acknowledged and magnified by me whilst I live, were I to live everlastingly,
and I will leave it upon record to posterity to do so too.

Every day will I bless thee: and I will praise thy name for ever and ever.
2 The memory of thy mercies shall never depart from me, nor shall the duty of
thanksgiving be intermitted by me, time shall not cancel them, but day by day
will I recount and recall them, and afresh magnify thee for them, and bless
thee that blesses me, yea, live I never so long, they shall never die, but all
that I am, or shall ever be, I will be it of thee, and acknowledge it to thee,
thy praise and glory.

Great is the Lord, and greatly to be praised; and his greatness is
unsearchable.
3 In Majesty, power, and grace, transcendent is the Lord, the worlds sole
Sovereign, and how ought his praises to be suitably superlative, whose
greatness in glory, and every other excellency is infinite and
incomprehensible, rather to be admired than understood by men of finite and
shallow capacities, as his works declare.

One generation shall praise thy works to another, and shall declare thy
mighty acts.
4 The world shall never be without matter of praise, that shall set forth the
immensity of thee the Lord, whose praiseworthy works of power, justice, and
mercy, shall be renewed upon the face of the earth continually, every
generation shall have a succession of them, which shall accordingly by thy
people be observed, and transferred in their gratulatorie memorials from one to
another, the fathers shall tell and teach what their forefathers taught and
told them, and the additions thou have made in their time of works of wonder,
and acts of power and grace to their posterities, and they to theirs to the
worlds end.

5 I for my part will extol thee in the age that I live in, I will speak of the
glorious honor of thy Majesty; and of thy wondrous works.
and leave a copy for after-ages, to write by, and do the like in exalting thy
supreme superlative honor and glory, that is essential to thee, the Sovereign
Majesty of heaven and earth, and in magnifying thine Almighty power so
wonderfully specified in the works of creation, preservation, and destruction,
acted and evident in the world respectively to good and bad.

6 Those that give themselves to observation as I do, And men shall speak of
the might of thy terrible acts: and will declare thy greatness.
shall have cause enough whilst the world endures, to extol thy powerful
justice upon thine and thy Churches enemies, in the terrible execution of it by
formidable judgments, such as former ages have been full of, and after-ages
shall not be wanting in, and I will be sure to do my part toward it in
preaching thy Sovereign justice and power, how able thou art to confound them,
and how terribly thy displeasure shall be executed upon evil doers, wicked
despisers of God and oppressors of his people.

7 Such faithful observers shall also have abundant matter stored up in memory
of thy goodness and mercy, They shall abundantly utter the memory of thy
great goodness, and shall sing of thy righteousness.
yea, manifold and remarkable mercies to thy Church and people, which they
themselves shall bless and praise thee for, and teach them to others, even to
succeeding generations, to be remembered of them in like sort, and shall rejoice
exceedingly in their own, and the Churches constant experience of thy faithful
performances of thy gracious promises freely made, and in righteousness made
good touching thy blessings to them, and thy judgments upon their enemies.

The Lord is gracious, and full of compassion: slow to anger, and of great
mercy.
8 They shall have cause to magnify Gods manifold gracious properties by
manifold sweet experiences, and to say of him as he by Moses says of himself,
That he is as good as great, Gracious, in promising and performing,
Compassionate, over his people in their afflictions, though afflicted for their
sins, which he is slow to punish, and very forbearing to execute his just
displeasure where and when, or as often, as it is deserved, and as ready
mercifully to forgive their sin, when committed, and remove his judgments when
inflicted, upon their repentance, as they themselves can wish, be their sins
what they will, never so great, he can and will forgive them, upon conversion,
and repent of his punishing when they repent of their provoking.

The Lord is good to all: and his tender mercies are over all his works.
9 And though covenant-grace and pardoning mercy be the portion of his own
peculiar, yet to those that are not so but strangers, yea, enemies to him, he
is beneficial, even to all good and bad God is good, and declares it by large
dispensations of manifold good things creative and providential: Though sin
has brought an overflowing deluge of displeasure into the world, and shut up
the whole creation, man and all things that were made for his use, under a
curse and Divine severity, yet cannot this hinder on Gods part his being
merciful, who freely extends his liberal beneficence to every creature,
supplying their wants, maintaining and taking care for their subsistencies,
from the least to the greatest.

10 There is nothing in the whole world in that its kind and nature sets not
forth thy praise-worrhy goodness and greatness, All thy works shall praise
thee, O Lord: and the saints shall bless thee.
O thou Sovereign and sole Lord thereof; and above all thy peculiar people
chosen and called have cause, not only for common mercies, whereof together
with the rest of the world they liberally partake, to praise thee, but for
special love tokens of grace and favor, which the world knows not what belongs
to, wherewith thou peculiarly blessest them, shall they actively bless and
magnify thee in love and thankfulness.

11 Thy saints, They shall speak of the glory of thy Kingdom, and talk of thy
power.
they shall not by bare instinct, or mere necessity of nature passively praise
thee, as others do that are subjects at large of the Kingdom of thy power
only, but as those that are received into grace. shall they magnify the
glorious excellency of that thy Kingdom of grace, (as well as of power)
whereof more especially they are subjects; and knowingly, in the comfortable
experience of their own hearts, declare the happiness of that estate
transcendent to any worldly one both for dignity and security, the King of
saints being the only Lord God glorious in Majesty, and omnipotent in power,
as his acts declare.

12 From the enlargements of their hearts, To make known to the sons of men,
his mighty acts, and the glorious Majesty of his Kingdom.
in the love and admiration of thee, they shall publish to the world, that so
best understands thee, the memorable achievements which thou have in sundry
ages brought to pass thereby to spread thy fame, and gain thee the glory of
thine omnipotency, and sole Sovereigntie over the world, the pomp and power
thereof, as sundry times and ways upon sundry nations and mighty potentates
thou have made it manifest, by demonstrative evidence in thy Churches and
peoples behalf.

Thy Kingdom is an everlasting Kingdom, and thy dominion endures throughout
all generations.
13 Yea, all the excellent prerogatives and properties of thy Kingdom and empire
shall they preach and promulgate, to gain thee the precedencie of worldly
honor, which though never so great, yet is transient and momentanie, on top of
the wheel to day, and under it to morrow, whereas thy dominion and
Sovereigntie, as it excels in power and dignity, so in permanence and
perpetuity, thou can crush earthly Kingdoms, their Princes and people, but
they with all their might and malice can neither crush thee nor thine, neither
weaken thy power, lessen thy glory, nor extirpate thy Church, but as thou, so
it, maugre all the world is of an infinite date, no period can be put to
either, for both shall everlastingly endure, and every age shall make it appear
so, by the admirable works of governance, and powerful preservation of thy
Church and Kingdom, founded upon an everlasting covenant.

The Lord upholdeth all that fall: and raises up all those that be bowed down.
14 Otherwise his Church had been extirpated many a day ago, every age lifting
at it, so that it has been under sore dejections, and grievous oppressions,
yet still upheld, and in its lowest condition made to keep its feet, to have a
Being, and raised in time to a well-being in despite of its potent adversaries,
by the Lord, whose power many a time has underpropt it, and his grace restored
it, when it was low brought, and who indeed in righteousness is pitiful to all
that are wrongfully oppressed to right and relieve them, and has power to do
it, be their condition never so bad, especially if they trust in him and seek
to him, whose Kingdom over the world is chiefly exercised in administering
justice and mercy for and toward the afflicted.

15, 16 Whose goodness is as universal as his greatness, The eyes of all wait
upon thee, and and thou give them their meat in due season.
and providencially extends it self to every creature that he has made, which
also by instinct of nature it self, Thou openest thine hand and satisfiest the
desire of every living thing.
waits upon providence, seeks after, and endeavors its own means of
subsistence, every one what is proper to its nature and kind, as by and from
God his ordination and especial dispensation, thus acknowledging his
supremacy, both man and beast, even the whole creation: And he orderly in a
suitable and seasonable manner supplies unto them food of several kinds, in
several seasons of both time and opportunity, for sustaining the nature, and
satisfying the hunger of all creatures of so many several kinds as are in the
world, and of every individual of each kind, by his liberality and bounty so
universally extended over the whole earth, and providently dispensed to the
sundry particulars in it, which is only then had when he gives it, and
therefore had, because he gives it, none being able to supply their own wants,
much less worthy to share in the honor of the worlds providing for, both which
is of the Lord alone, who makes second causes instrumental to him, and useful
to man, the power and governance of all creatures being his, which therofore
brings forth and increases, because he appoints, and is satisfied, because
he dispenses.

17 Manifold dispensations there are in the world toward good and bad, The
Lord is righteous in all his ways, and holy in all his works.
that seems strange to us, but in this also is God and his government
admirable and transcendently praiseworthy, that nothing he does be it never so
discrepant, to humane reason, and rules of policy amongst men, but he is both
righteous and holy in so doing, for his will being the only rule of both, his
works can none of them disaagree from either.

The Lord is nigh unto all them that call upon him, to all that call upon him
in truth.
18 His government and dispensation, though it be to and over all, yet
principally and primarily does it belong to the faithful; as near as he seems
to others, yet is he far enough from them, and as far as he seems from these,
who have the greatest share of adverse fortune in this life, yet is he near
unto them. They that profess him publicly by adoration and worship, and withal
serve him sincerely in faith and affection, that offer to find him fervent not
fained prayer, they shall be sure to find him a propitious God to a gracious
heart accompanied with a holy life.

He (...) the (...) that fear (...) will h^ar their cry, and will save them.
19 Such as take care of him, he will take care of them, they that fear to sin
shall be satisfied with good; such God will hear and answer graciously, as hear
and obey him conscionably, and though sometimes by extraordinary trials he may
put them to it to ask, yea cry hard for ease before they have it, yet that is
but to try and exercise their graces with patient waiting and fervent
importuning, till the time, the set time be come which he has determined in
himself as most opportune for him and them to be relieved and answered in, and
then, though not till then, they shall be sure of it, when their fears are
greatest, and their hopes (humanely) least.

The Lord preserves all them that love him: but all the wicked will he destroy.
20 The Lord will keep promise with all that fear to offend him, out of love and
desire to please him, he may venture them, but he will not lose them, his eye
is over and his hand under them, for he has not many such that so love him, nor
therefore are there many that are so beloved of him, and so they shall find
that wickedly transgress against him, that as he has powerful grace in store
to preserve the one, so has he vindicative justice to destroy the other, which
shall certainly fall to their lot every mothers son of them, his Kingdom is
administered by mercy and justice, and so the good and bad shall find.

21 My mind shall meditate of these thine admirable excellencies of several
kinds exhibited to the world in general and thy people in particular, My mouth
shall speak the praise of the Lord: and let all flesh bless his holy name for
ever and ever.
, both which are wholly under thy dominion and dispensation, subject to thy
greatness, and sharers of thy goodness, respectively common and special, as
also of thy mercy and justice. My mouth shall extol them and praise thee the
God of them, that art so great in power, so gracious in providence, so rich in
mercy, and so severe in justice, and let mankind in general in all times and
places, who ought to know thee under all, and do know thee under most of these
notions, whereof they have daily and frequent experience, bless and magnify
thee in all thy holy attributes and properties, that so shine forth in thy
works of mercy, power, and righteousness, all the world over, in all the ages
of it.

The cxlvi. PSALM.
David exciteth all, especially Gods people, and most especially himself, to
praise the Lord; principally by trusting in him, and distrusting all but him.
Man both great and small being a perishable creature, and God only to be
relied on, but then that must be the true God, and that also by a true faith,
acted upon his power, goodness, and never-failing faithfulness, and that is
every condition, believing in God with a like never-failing stedfastness,
though our estate be various and miserable, for that to the good he is ever,
graciously inclined, and to the wicked quite contrary. As also for the
perpetuity and unchangeableness of his throne and dominion over his Church and
people, for their protection throughout all ages to the end of the world, does
the Psalmist again excite to praise him, concluding as he began in this, and so
do every of these 5 concluding Psalms. Psalm cxlvi.


PRaise ye the Lord: praise the Lord, O my soul.
1, 2 AS it is the duty, so I wish it were the practice of all, especially his
people to be constant and conversant in praising God, who himself is so
constant and conversant in praise-worthie dispensations of several sorts, While
I live will I praise the Lord: I will sing praise unto my God, while I have any
being.
and what I admonish others of, I do much more so to my self, that have cause
beyond all men to praise the Lord, and that with my whole heart throughout my
whole life, as well he deserves, that I should spend and lay out my utmost
strenght and best affections in praising him, which I will be sure to do
whilst my tongue can wag.

Put not your tr^st in Princes, nor in the son of men, in whom there is no help.
3, 4 But let your praises be real, give God the praise of your faith, which is
thank -worthy, when in your hearts you set up his throne above all
principalities and powers, His breath goes forth, be returns to this earth:
in that very day his thoughts perish.
trust in him solely and wholly, let not worldly appearances dazzle your eyes,
and make you disparage God by preferring others to him, though they be never so
great and powerful Kings or Princes; trust in nothing short of God, no not in
all the power of flesh, which it self is mortal and perishable, and to you or
whomsoever trusts in it, will prove deceitful, not being of power, though never
so powerful to stand us in stead, further than God wills and assists, their
preparations and projects being like themselves, die when they do, and how soon
and sudden that may be none knows; and for ought he knows what ever he is, if
he be a man, that very instant, when his undertakings and preparations are the
greatest, and his and thy hopes by reason of them are at the highest, he and
all the arm of flesh (thou trusts in) may expire, breathe his last, which, him
for ought, every breath he breaths may be, and then this goodly confidence of
thine in man, whom thou make a God of, as from the earth he came in the first
creation, so to earth he returns by dissolution, the fate of all flesh, one and
other, and so all thy hopes built upon such imaginary helps as he or they
promised and designed, fall to the ground, are in an instant annihilated, and
come to nothing, though never so wisely forecast, and humanely hopeful.

5 Happy, Happy is he that has the God of Jacob for his help, whose hope is
in the Lord his God.
and only happy is he or they, that contradistinguished to all false
Heathenish Gods or creature-confidence, has his assurance in the only true
God, the sole creator (who is the God of Israel, his servant Jacobs
posterity) for his helper and defender, the anchor of whose hope is cast in
firm ground, Divine not humane, such as will not drag after him as do all other
hopes in all other helps, Gods or men, that has his heart fixed upon the Lord
and none other, and that also by a Divine not a humane faith, the faith of
adoption, such as Jacobs was, first being regenerate by him and so believing in
him by a faith of gracious propriety unto salvation, as his God as well as
Jacobs, and then hoping on him for faithful performance of his promise of
security, and preservation as to Jacob, so to him, being the faithful seed of
that faithful Patriark to whom he is alike engaged.

6 That thus I say with a true and unfeigned faith trusts in the true God, Which
made heaven and earth, the sea, and all that therein is: which keeps trust
for ever.
in him that has his being of himself, and gives being to all things else, as
the heavens, earth, and sea, and all things in them, and that not only as an
Almighty, but also as a gracious benevolent God, neverfailingly faithful of
his word and promise of grace to all in all ages and cases that confide in him,
and therefore as well willing as able to do them good, who himself is as well
good as great.

Which executes judgment for the oppressed, which giv^th food to the hungry:
the Lord loses the prisoners.
7 That be his wrongs never so great, his necessities never so pressing, his
case never so desperate, yet holds up his hope in his God, and supports his
faith by his power and goodness, justice and mercy, waiting believingly upon
the Lord as knowing him, though free in his gracious dispensations, yet just to
dispense his righteous judgments, which shall sooner or later certainly and
most seasonably be executed upon oppressors, for vindication and relief of
those that are oppressed, and in like sort though he let the faithful suffer
want, yet to believe in him for supply by virtue both of his promise and pity,
and that principally when they are in their greatest necessity; and though
they be in actual bondage and imprisonment, yet to have their hearts at liberty
in the midst of their thraldom, in the faith of his power and faithfulness to
release and relieve them, which when the time comes for him to do, no bolts nor
bars can hinder him.

The Lord opens the eyes of the blind: the Lord raises them that are bowed
down: the Lord loves the righteous.
8 Be a man's condition what it will, and of what nature soever, faith and
affliction must always go together, and that makes him a happy man in his
greatest unhappiness, whether they be those external and bodily ones
aforementioned, or that he be implunged into inward inextricable perplexities of
mind, and difficulties of affairs, that his own or other men's councels cells
cannot wind him out off, yet must he believe in the only wise God to direct
him, whose very creative power and goodness we should allegorize, and improve
them into the faith of providence as occasion offers, arguing fom things
natural and corporal, to things supernatural or spiritual, and proportionably
believing the one as the other, that Jehovah who can and does give bodily eyes
to see with, and sight to those eyes, can and will as well enlighten the eye of
the mind in time of need; and as he cures the impotent and crazed in body, so
is he the same to comfort and relieve the distressed in spirit: yea, he or they
that are righteous, and does righteousness, it is not any thing under the sun
that befalls them within or without, in body or mind, in way of trial or
trouble, that should make them think one jot worse of themselves, as to God his
love and care of them, but first to know themselves to be faithful, and that
they suffer not for evil doing, and then to be confident in God, and of God his
love and faithfulness, but not otherwise.

9 No, it is not the solitary condition of the stranger or exile that can
render him unhappie, The Lord preserves the strangers, he relieveth the
fatherless and widow: but the way of the wicked he turns it up^side do (...).
or exposed, (as in such cases we are apt to fear it will) if he believe in the
Lord Almighty, who is abler to preserve him, than man is to oppress him, we
his people have found it so, when and where we are strangers, for that
notwithstanding, we were strangely preserved and powerfully delivered. Nor need
the widow and fatherless give all for lost, when God takes away their earthly
supports, if they marry him, and secure themselves under his wings by faith,
they shall find him to supply the want of all earthly relations and
accommodations in and from himself, by his faithfulness and mercy. But no such
thing can I promise to the sinner that loves, and lives in sinful ways and
courses, nothing but subversion and misfortune is his lot by any thing the
promises speak; for to him of due belongs only the threatenings and curses of
the word, not the blessings and mercies of the covenant; as the good by faith
and hope are finally happy in all unhappiness that can, or does befall them;
so the wicked in their seeming felicities are both finally and totally sure to
conclude in misery, and utter frustration of their confidence and forecast.

The Lord shall reign for ever, even thy God, O Sion, unto all generations.
Praise ye the Lord.
10 And as the Lord Jehovah is faithful and Almighty to do as aforesaid, so is
he also everlasting, and therefore also worthy and solely to be trusted in, and
relied on, he is not like earthly Princes, that may be, and are many times
dethroned whilst they live, or if not so, yet mortal, and sure to die, and so
not to be trusted in, but of the same power and faithfulness to all faithful
ones for ever in all ages, to do them good, protect and save them, spite of all
worldly power or malice. Such a God is thy God, O Israel, whom thou worshippest
in his sanctuary upon his holy hill, Sion of which accordingly he will bless
and preserve as the type of his Church universal, which as his, shall be upheld
by him, who himself is everlasting, whilst the world endures. Therefore praise
ye the Lord, (trust in him, and in nothing else) all ye that are now, or shall
hereafter be his people, the true worshippers of the only true God.

The cxlvii. PSALM.
David exceedingly exciteth the people of God, his Israel, to be frequent and
conversant in praising the Lord, by sweet motives and powerful arguments
proper and common, showing sometimes his tender care in special over his
Church, then again illustrating him by his native excellencies, also by his
gracious, just and different dispensations to good and bad, all having relation
to his people, whom he again stirs up to the duty of thanksgiving and praise,
by acts of powerful providence above and below, to beast and birds. He further
cautionizeth them not to be misled in judgment, so as to think the favor of
God, or success from God is attainable by humane inducem^nes or probabilities;
no, but by faith and holy fear, which being the things that indear us to God,
he again incites gods people to praise him for the privilege of such truths
revealed, and such graces exhibited, whereby they are so blessed and prospered
with peace and plenty by him, who as Lord paramount commands the whole
creation, and is obeyed by it both in heaven and earth; but he is Isreal's, and
Israel his after a more peculiar and excellent manner than any other nations,
or all the worlds besides, for which he concludes they ought to praise him
answerably. Psalm cxlvii.


1 O Ye people of the Lord be much busied in praising him, PRaise ye the Lord,
for it is good to sing praises unto our God: for it is pleasant, and praise is
co^ly.
no greater testimony of a good heart toward God, than to be praisefully
affected and disposed; nothing we can do more profitable and available to our
selves, for it keeps the heart in a holy frame and tunableness in the exercise
of faith, and love to Godward, and gains upon him exceedingly, who is much
delighted with that kind of service and sacrifice, to have the honor done him,
and homage paid him that's due unto him from the creature, specially his people
that do it with faith and understanding; it is a work well becoming these, to
magnify the Lord both for what he is in himself considered, and also to them
in grace and gracious dispensations.

2 Who indeed deserves praise but he*. The Lord does build up Jerusalem: he
gathers together the outcasts of Israel.
That is all in all, specially to his Church; it is he that lays the
foundation of it in election, and builds it progressively by faith and
sanctification, and finisheth his work of grace, and his peoples happiness in
glorification, like as out of all the world, Jerusalem is the chosen place of
his worship, and Israel a chosen people to worship him, both which he of mere
grace by an Almighty power does bless and build up unto a flourishing state
and condition, and that notwithstanding their many enemies. Yea, he brings his
people Israel out of their several misfortunes and dispersions, to be the sole
subjects of his Kingdom, and to be united under me their head, his substitute,
in a formed Church and Commonwealth, thereby to live happily, and serve him
acceptably, as in like sort he shall call his chosen all the world over into
one body, his Church, under one head Christ to serve and honor him, and
partake of his happiness. It is he that does both the one, and the other.

He heals the broken in heart, and binds up their wounds.
3 God many times is pleased to break and bruise his people with outward
afflictions, and inward depressions of mind and conscience by the weight of
sins, guilt, or his dis-favour, but it is but to find his grace and spirit
work, to show his skill, and to verify his word, who heals them again with
the balm of Gilead, the light of his countenance arises upon such a soul after
some conflict; for God is tender over his people, specially in distress, and
most specially in soul-agonies, when they pant under a troublesome spirit: he is
the true Samaritan that pours in wine and oil, and binds up the wound of his
Church and chosen, which the world without or trouble within has made.

He tells the number of the stars: he calls them all by their names.
4 He that can number the numberless stars from one end of the heavens to the
other, and knows them particularly and distinctly one by one, as many as they
are, having indeed made them all, and ordained each one its orb and office,
causing them to appear and act in their seasons orderly and successively
without confusion, notwithstanding their infinite number, as also their
variable, manifold, and inter-winding courses: he as well knows the number of
the stars on earth, as in heaven, his people, wheresoever dispersed upon the
face of the whole earth, to gather them into his body, as Israel into Canaan
from their dispersions, yea, every particular person and member of his Church
universal, knows he to bring him in, in his season, age, and generation, and
both where and how to employ him, in what station of the world, and place in
his Church for the service of him and it.

5 For as the Lord is great in knowledge, Great is our Lord, and of great
power: his understanding is infinite.
so also in power; there can no bounds be set to either, he is infinite in
understanding past our capacity, a fit object of of our faith, and subject of
our praise in all his proceedings.

6 As appears by the certain conclusions he brings out of uncertain
providence, The Lord lifts up the meek: he casts the wicked down to the
ground.
how those that meekly, and humbly undergo their time and portion of
sufferings, (the share of all his servants) wherein they seem to themselves and
others to be forlorn and helpless, he by an Almighty hand, beyond
imagination, relieves and releaseth them, makes them able with joy to overtop
their sorrows, how despicable soever they were in the eyes of the world,
whereas on the contrary, those that with worldly, pomp and affluence are
lifted up to do wickedly against him, or his Church oppressing them, or
contemning him; these, as high as they are in power and pride, and though they
